zh: 卡特里奥娜
en: Catriona

zh: 第一部分　检察总长大人
en: Part I—THE LORD ADVOCATE

zh: 第一章　一个暴发户
en: CHAPTER I—A BEGGAR ON HORSEBACK

zh: 1751年8月25日，约摸下午两点钟，我——戴维???·鲍尔弗，走出了不列颠利嫩公司，一个杂役提着一袋钱跟着我，一些店老板在他们的店门口向我鞠躬致意。两天前，甚至近在昨天早晨，我都还像路边的叫花子一样：衣衫褴褛，落魄得只剩最后几个先令；我的同伴被宣判为叛国者；我自己也因涉罪而在全国被悬赏缉拿。今天我却被当成有社会地位的继承人、一位拥有土地的领主而受到礼遇，身边有一个银行杂役帮着我搬金币，口袋里还揣着几封推荐信，（通俗的说法）就是球正好在我的脚下了。
en: The 25th day of August, 1751, about two in the afternoon, I, David Balfour, came forth of the British Linen Company, a porter attending me with a bag of money, and some of the chief of these merchants bowing me from their doors.Two days before, and even so late as yestermorning, I was like a beggar-man by the wayside, clad in rags, brought down to my last shillings, my companion a condemned traitor, a price set on my own head for a crime with the news of which the country rang.To-day I was served heir to my position in life, a landed laird, a bank porter by me carrying my gold, recommendations in my pocket, and (in the words of the saying) the ball directly at my foot.

zh: 有两件事使我在如此春风得意之时仍能保持镇定。第一就是我仍有一件非常棘手而极度危险的事情要处理；第二就是我所处的这个地方。这座高大、阴暗的城市对我来说是一个陌生的世界，这里人口众多、人员流动频繁而且喧闹嘈杂。以前我常去的地方都是一些荒坡野地、海边沙滩和寂静的乡村。那些熙熙攘攘的市民尤其让我感到不安。兰基勒的儿子身材矮小，他的衣服我几乎都穿不了。显然我还不够格在一个银行杂役面前摆架子。很明显，如果我穿了他的衣服，只会惹人嘲笑，（对我而言更为糟糕的是）会惹得他们打探询问。因此，我有必要去买几件自己的衣服，而且暂时还得和那个杂役并肩行走，把手搭在他的手臂上，就好像我们是一对朋友似的。
en: There were two circumstances that served me as ballast to so much sail.The first was the very difficult and deadly business I had still to handle; the second, the place that I was in.The tall, black city, and the numbers and movement and noise of so many folk, made a new world for me, after the moorland braes, the sea-sands and the still country-sides that I had frequented up to then.The throng of the citizens in particular abashed me.Rankeillor’s son was short and small in the girth; his clothes scarce held on me; and it was plain I was ill qualified to strut in the front of a bank-porter.It was plain, if I did so, I should but set folk laughing, and (what was worse in my case) set them asking questions.So that I behooved to come by some clothes of my own, and in the meanwhile to walk by the porter’s side, and put my hand on his arm as though we were a pair of friends.

zh: 在卢肯市场的一家店里，我把自己装扮一新：不太华丽，因为我不想显出一副暴发户的样子，而是想显得体面且值得信赖，那样仆人们就会尊敬我。接着我去了一家军械店，在那里弄了一把普通的剑，好和我的社会地位相称。有了武器，我感到安全多了，尽管（对一个丝毫不懂防卫的人来说）它有可能会是个额外的危险。那个杂役当然有些经验，他评论说我的衣服挑得不错。
en: At a merchant’s in the Luckenbooths I had myself fitted out: none too fine, for I had no idea to appear like a beggar on horseback; but comely and responsible, so that servants should respect me.Thence to an armourer’s, where I got a plain sword, to suit with my degree in life.I felt safer with the weapon, though (for one so ignorant of defence) it might be called an added danger.The porter, who was naturally a man of some experience, judged my accoutrement to be well chosen.

zh: “一点儿也不打眼，”他说，“这一身朴素又体面。说到这柄长剑，配你的身份绝对没的说。不过我要是你的话，我就会去找一个更好的地方花钱买剑。”随后他提议我到牛门后街的一位主妇那里买冬袜，那是他的一个表亲，她织的袜子“耐穿得很”。
en: “Naething kenspeckle,” (1) said he; “plain, dacent claes.As for the rapier, nae doubt it sits wi’ your degree; but an I had been you, I would has waired my siller better-gates than that.”And he proposed I should buy winter-hosen from a wife in the Cowgate-back, that was a cousin of his own, and made them “extraordinar endurable.”

zh: 但是我手头还有其他更紧急的事情要做。我置身于这个破旧、阴暗的城市之中，相对于整个世界来说，这座城市就像一个养兔场，不仅居民数量多，而且走廊和门洞错综复杂。事实上，这是一个任何陌生人都不可能找到朋友的地方，还会让朋友成为另一个陌生人。就算他碰巧找到了附近，由于人们密密麻麻地住在这些高大的楼房里，他也极有可能得找上一天才碰对要找的门。通常的做法是雇一个他们称为杂工的伙计，就像是向导或者带路人，带领你去要去的地方，（在你的差事办完以后）再把你带回落脚地。但由于这些杂工总是被雇来提供同类服务，就有必要让他们了解这个城市的家家户户，于是他们逐渐形成了一种密探之间的兄弟情谊。我从坎贝尔先生讲的故事里了解到他们彼此如何交换信息，他们对雇主的事务所怀的好奇心有多强烈，以及他们如何充当警察的耳目。就我目前的情况而言，我要是真去雇佣这么一个尾随我的探子，恐怕不太明智。我要去拜访三个很紧要的人：我的同宗皮尔里格的鲍尔弗先生，阿平的代理人斯图尔特大律师，还有苏格兰的检察总长大人——普雷斯顿格兰奇的威廉·格兰特先生。拜访鲍尔弗先生之事并不难办，况且（皮尔里格在乡下）凭着自己的双腿和一口苏格兰语，我就敢自己找路去那里。但是其余的情况就不一样了。阿平凶杀案正在风头上，此时拜访阿平的代理人不仅危险，也和其他要办的事情很不协调。我希望有足够的时间和检察总长格兰特大人在一起，这是最好的办法。但是一出阿平的代理人之门便直奔那里，好像对我自己的事情不太有利，而且还有可能给朋友艾伦带来灭顶之灾。此外，整件事在我看来就像是：既要和兔子一起奔跑又要和猎人一起狩猎，这简直让我无法想象。因此，我决定立刻去办其中与斯图尔特先生和整个詹姆斯二世党人有关的事情。为了达到这个目的，我只能靠身边的这个杂役来做向导。但是就在我刚要给他地址的时候，突然淅淅沥沥地下起了一场雨——其他倒没有什么不好，只是可惜了我的新衣服——我们只好在一条巷子或是胡同的屋檐下躲雨。
en: But I had other matters on my hand more pressing.Here I was in this old, black city, which was for all the world like a rabbit-warren, not only by the number of its indwellers, but the complication of its passages and holes.It was, indeed, a place where no stranger had a chance to find a friend, let be another stranger.Suppose him even to hit on the right close, people dwelt so thronged in these tall houses, he might very well seek a day before he chanced on the right door.The ordinary course was to hire a lad they called a caddie, who was like a guide or pilot, led you where you had occasion, and (your errands being done) brought you again where you were lodging.But these caddies, being always employed in the same sort of services, and having it for obligation to be well informed of every house and person in the city, had grown to form a brotherhood of spies; and I knew from tales of Mr. Campbell’s how they communicated one with another, what a rage of curiosity they conceived as to their employer’s business, and how they were like eyes and fingers to the police.It would be a piece of little wisdom, the way I was now placed, to take such a ferret to my tails.I had three visits to make, all immediately needful: to my kinsman Mr. Balfour of Pilrig, to Stewart the Writer that was Appin’s agent, and to William Grant Esquire of Prestongrange, Lord Advocate of Scotland.Mr. Balfour’s was a non-committal visit; and besides (Pilrig being in the country) I made bold to find the way to it myself, with the help of my two legs and a Scots tongue.But the rest were in a different case.Not only was the visit to Appin’s agent, in the midst of the cry about the Appin murder, dangerous in itself, but it was highly inconsistent with the other.I was like to have a bad enough time of it with my Lord Advocate Grant, the best of ways; but to go to him hot-foot from Appin’s agent, was little likely to mend my own affairs, and might prove the mere ruin of friend Alan’s.The whole thing, besides, gave me a look of running with the hare and hunting with the hounds that was little to my fancy.I determined, therefore, to be done at once with Mr. Stewart and the whole Jacobitical side of my business, and to profit for that purpose by the guidance of the porter at my side.But it chanced I had scarce given him the address, when there came a sprinkle of rain—nothing to hurt, only for my new clothes—and we took shelter under a pend at the head of a close or alley.

zh: 因为没来过这地方，我又朝里面走近了一些。那条窄道突然急转直下。两边冒出一些巍峨的高楼，而且凸显出来，一层高过一层。头顶上只现出窄窄的一线天空。根据我从窗户所偷窥到的情形和那些出出进进的体面人物来看，我就知道这些房子里满满都是人。这个地方的整个景象就如故事一般引起了我的兴趣。
en: Being strange to what I saw, I stepped a little farther in.The narrow paved way descended swiftly.Prodigious tall houses sprang upon each side and bulged out, one storey beyond another, as they rose.At the top only a ribbon of sky showed in.By what I could spy in the windows, and by the respectable persons that passed out and in, I saw the houses to be very well occupied; and the whole appearance of the place interested me like a tale.

zh: 我还在盯着看，这时从我的身后突然传来一阵急促的踏步声和金属的撞击声。我迅即转身，发现一队武装士兵，在他们中间有一个穿着厚大衣的高个男子。他躬身行走着，一副谦逊有礼甚至卑躬屈膝的样子：他行走时似乎在挥动着双手，他的脸英俊中透着阴险。我觉得他看见了我，只是我没有迎面相视。这队人从我身边经过，走向巷子里的一扇门，一个穿着精致制服的男仆打开了门，两个年轻士兵夹着囚犯进去了，其余的人则抱着明火枪守在门边。
en: I was still gazing, when there came a sudden brisk tramp of feet in time and clash of steel behind me.Turning quickly, I was aware of a party of armed soldiers, and, in their midst, a tall man in a great coat.He walked with a stoop that was like a piece of courtesy, genteel and insinuating: he waved his hands plausibly as he went, and his face was sly and handsome.I thought his eye took me in, but could not meet it.This procession went by to a door in the close, which a serving-man in a fine livery set open; and two of the soldier-lads carried the prisoner within, the rest lingering with their firelocks by the door.

zh: 在城市的街道上，无论发生什么事情，都会有一些无所事事的人和孩子跟着看热闹。现在也是如此。但是大部分人很快散去，最后只剩下了三个人。有一位是姑娘，她的穿着像位淑女，而且她的头上戴着德拉蒙德风格的纱罩。但是她的同伴或者（我应该说）随从却是衣衫褴褛，就和我的高地之行途中所见的很多人一样。他们一起用盖尔语热烈地交谈着，由于艾伦的缘故，这种声音在我听来很悦耳。虽然雨又停了，我的杂役拉着我要离开，我却朝他们凑近了些，想听他们说什么。那位女士厉声斥责着，其余的人则一个劲地在道歉，在她面前显得畏畏缩缩的，因此我敢肯定她出身于大户人家。他们三个人一直在口袋里找寻着，由此说明他们一行人非常拮据，为钱所困。看到所有的高地人都一样谦恭顺从且毛皮袋中空空如也，我不禁轻轻地笑了。
en: There can nothing pass in the streets of a city without some following of idle folk and children.It was so now; but the more part melted away incontinent until but three were left.One was a girl; she was dressed like a lady, and had a screen of the Drummond colours on her head; but her comrades or (I should say) followers were ragged gillies, such as I had seen the matches of by the dozen in my Highland journey.They all spoke together earnestly in Gaelic, the sound of which was pleasant in my ears for the sake of Alan; and, though the rain was by again, and my porter plucked at me to be going, I even drew nearer where they were, to listen.The lady scolded sharply, the others making apologies and cringeing before her, so that I made sure she was come of a chief’s house.All the while the three of them sought in their pockets, and by what I could make out, they had the matter of half a farthing among the party; which made me smile a little to see all Highland folk alike for fine obeisances and empty sporrans.

zh: 碰巧那位女孩突然转身，所以我第一次看到了她的脸庞。一位年轻女子的面容就这样印入了一个男人的脑海，并驻留在那个男人的脑海中，没有比这更神奇的事了。他根本说不出个所以然，只是好像这正是他想要的东西。她有着一双像星星一样美丽而明亮的眼睛。我认为很可能眼睛是原因之一，但是我记得最清楚的还是她转身时嘴唇微微张开的样子。可是，不论出于什么原因，我就像个傻瓜一样站在那里盯着她看。而她那边，因为并不知道会有人靠得这么近，所以她看了我好一会儿，也许是出于惊讶，而并非全然出于礼貌。
en: It chanced the girl turned suddenly about, so that I saw her face for the first time.There is no greater wonder than the way the face of a young woman fits in a man’s mind, and stays there, and he could never tell you why; it just seems it was the thing he wanted.She had wonderful bright eyes like stars, and I daresay the eyes had a part in it; but what I remember the most clearly was the way her lips were a trifle open as she turned.And, whatever was the cause, I stood there staring like a fool.On her side, as she had not known there was anyone so near, she looked at me a little longer, and perhaps with more surprise, than was entirely civil.

zh: 我这个乡下人的头脑中突然想到她也许是对我的新衣服感到奇怪，这么一想，我的脸就红到了耳根。看见我脸红了，她可能得出了自己的结论，因为她带着侍从走向巷子的更深处，然后他们又开始争论起来，而我再也听不见了。
en: It went through my country head she might be wondering at my new clothes; with that, I blushed to my hair, and at the sight of my colouring it is to be supposed she drew her own conclusions, for she moved her gillies farther down the close, and they fell again to this dispute, where I could hear no more of it.

zh: 在那以前我也时常仰慕少女，但几乎没有这么突然而强烈的感觉。按照我的本性，我是宁愿往后退也不会朝前走的，因为我很害怕受到女人的嘲笑。你们会认为我现在更有理由故伎重演，因为我在大街上遇到的这位年轻女士似乎在跟随一个囚犯，而且还带着两个衣衫破旧、样子粗蛮的高地人。可是现在情形有点儿不同，显然这位姑娘认为我一直在探听她的秘密。但我穿着新衣服，带着佩剑，而且我还新得到了一笔财富，她这样看我就让我无法忍受了。暴发户是不能忍受被人如此看低的，或者，至少不能被这么一位年轻女士给看低了。
en: I had often admired a lassie before then, if scarce so sudden and strong; and it was rather my disposition to withdraw than to come forward, for I was much in fear of mockery from the womenkind.You would have thought I had now all the more reason to pursue my common practice, since I had met this young lady in the city street, seemingly following a prisoner, and accompanied with two very ragged indecent-like Highlandmen.But there was here a different ingredient; it was plain the girl thought I had been prying in her secrets; and with my new clothes and sword, and at the top of my new fortunes, this was more than I could swallow.The beggar on horseback could not bear to be thrust down so low, or, at least of it, not by this young lady.

zh: 于是我跟着她，尽可能优雅地脱下我的新帽子向她致意。
en: I followed, accordingly, and took off my new hat to her the best that I was able.

zh: “女士，”我说，“我觉得只有让您知道我丝毫不懂盖尔语，这样对我本人才公平。确实，我是在听，因为我有朋友在高地线另一边，所以那种语言听起来很亲切。可是至于说你们的私事，如果你们说的是希腊语，我也许猜到的还多一些。”
en: “Madam,” said I, “I think it only fair to myself to let you understand I have no Gaelic.It is true I was listening, for I have friends of my own across the Highland line, and the sound of that tongue comes friendly; but for your private affairs, if you had spoken Greek, I might have had more guess at them.”

zh: 她冷淡地向我微微行了一个屈膝礼。“无妨，”她说，带着悦耳的口音，极像英格兰口音（但更加优美），“猫还可以看国王呢。”
en: She made me a little, distant curtsey.“There is no harm done,” said she, with a pretty accent, most like the English (but more agreeable).“A cat may look at a king.”

zh: “我没有冒犯您的意思。”我说，“我不懂城里的礼节，在此之前，我还从来没有踏进过爱丁堡的城门。就把我当成一个乡下人吧——我就是这么个人，与其让您发现这一点，还不如我自己告诉您。”
en: “I do not mean to offend,” said I.“I have no skill of city manners; I never before this day set foot inside the doors of Edinburgh.Take me for a country lad—it’s what I am; and I would rather I told you than you found it out.”

zh: “的确，陌生人在路上互相交谈是一件很不寻常的事，”她回答说，“不过如果你是在乡下长大的，那又另当别论了。我跟你一样来自乡下。正如你所看到的，我是高地人，我觉得自己比你离家乡更远。”
en: “Indeed, it will be a very unusual thing for strangers to be speaking to each other on the causeway,” she replied.“But if you are landward (2) bred it will be different.I am as landward as yourself; I am Highland, as you see, and think myself the farther from my home.”

zh: “我穿过高地线还不到一个星期，”我说，“不到一个星期以前，我还在巴尔惠德的山坡上呢。”
en: “It is not yet a week since I passed the line,” said I.“Less than a week ago I was on the braes of Balwhidder.”

zh: “巴尔惠德？”她叫道，“你居然来自巴尔惠德！这个地名让我太高兴了。你在那里没有呆很久吧，该不会认识我的朋友或家人吧？”
en: “Balwhither?” she cries.“Come ye from Balwhither!The name of it makes all there is of me rejoice.You will not have been long there, and not known some of our friends or family?”

zh: “我曾和一个非常诚实、善良、名叫邓肯·杜·麦克拉伦的人一起住过。”我回答。
en: “I lived with a very honest, kind man called Duncan Dhu Maclaren,” I replied.

zh: “嘿，我认识邓肯，你说对他的名字了！”她说，“如果他是一个诚实的人，那他的妻子才真叫诚实呢。”
en: “Well, I know Duncan, and you give him the true name!” she said; “and if he is an honest man, his wife is honest indeed.”

zh: “是啊，”我说，“他们都是好人，而且那个地方很美。”
en: “Ay,” said I, “they are fine people, and the place is a bonny place.”

zh: “偌大的世界，哪里还会有这么好的地方呀！”她喊道，“我热爱那里的气息，以及生长在那里的一切。”
en: “Where in the great world is such another!” she cries; “I am loving the smell of that place and the roots that grow there.”

zh: 我完全被这少女的热情所感染了。“我真希望给您带来了一束石楠花。”我说，“虽然我刚开始和您说话时不太友善，但是现在看来我们有共同的朋友，我恳请您不要忘记我。人们都管我叫戴维·鲍尔弗。今天是我的幸运日，我刚继承了一处地产，而且才脱离生命危险没有多久。我希望您会为了巴尔惠德记住我的名字，”我说，“为了我的幸运日，我也会记住您的名字的。”
en: I was infinitely taken with the spirit of the maid.“I could be wishing I had brought you a spray of that heather,” says I.“And, though I did ill to speak with you at the first, now it seems we have common acquaintance, I make it my petition you will not forget me.David Balfour is the name I am known by.This is my lucky day, when I have just come into a landed estate, and am not very long out of a deadly peril.I wish you would keep my name in mind for the sake of Balwhidder,” said I, “and I will yours for the sake of my lucky day.”

zh: “我的姓名说不得。”她回答道，满面骄傲之色，“一百多年来它从没有被人们说起过，哪怕是一刹那都没有。我是无名氏，就像精灵一样。卡特里奥娜·德拉蒙德是我现在用的名字。”
en: “My name is not spoken,” she replied, with a great deal of haughtiness.“More than a hundred years it has not gone upon men’s tongues, save for a blink.I am nameless, like the Folk of Peace.(3)Catriona Drummond is the one I use.”

zh: 此刻我真正明白我面对的是谁了。在整个辽阔的苏格兰，只有一个姓氏被禁止，那就是麦格雷戈家的姓氏。然而我不但没有逃避这不愉快的相识，反而陷得更深了。
en: Now indeed I knew where I was standing.In all broad Scotland there was but the one name proscribed, and that was the name of the Macgregors.Yet so far from fleeing this undesirable acquaintancy, I plunged the deeper in.

zh: “我和一位与您处境相同的人相处过，”我说，“而且我认为你们会成为朋友的。人们叫他罗宾·奥伊格。”
en: “I have been sitting with one who was in the same case with yourself,” said I, “and I think he will be one of your friends.They called him Robin Oig.”

zh: “真的？”她叫道，“你遇到过罗布？”
en: “Did ye so?” cries she.“Ye met Rob?”

zh: “我曾跟他一起度过一个夜晚。”我说。
en: “I passed the night with him,” said I.

zh: “他是夜间的一只鸟。”她说。
en: “He is a fowl of the night,” said she.

zh: “他那里有一套风笛，”我继续说道，“您可以据此看出他是怎么打发时间的。”
en: “There was a set of pipes there,” I went on, “so you may judge if the time passed.”

zh: “无论如何，你应该不会是敌人。”她说，“刚才那个人就是他哥哥，被红衣士兵包围的那个人。此人正是家父。”
en: “You should be no enemy, at all events,” said she.“That was his brother there a moment since, with the red soldiers round him.It is him that I call father.”

zh: “是这样吗？”我叫道，“您是詹姆斯·莫尔的一个女儿吗？”
en: “Is it so?” cried I.“Are you a daughter of James More’s?”

zh: “是他唯一的女儿，”她说，“是一个囚犯的女儿。我应该忘记这一点的，哪怕只忘记一个小时，好和陌生人一起谈谈话！”
en: “All the daughter that he has,” says she: “the daughter of a prisoner; that I should forget it so, even for one hour, to talk with strangers!”

zh: 这时她的一个侍从用所会的英语向她报告，想知道“她”（意思是他自己）该拿“鼻烟”怎么办。我稍一打量，发现他个子矮小、罗圈腿、红头发、大脑袋，我可在这种人身上吃过不少亏。
en: Here one of the gillies addressed her in what he had of English, to know what “she” (meaning by that himself) was to do about “ta sneeshin.”I took some note of him for a short, bandy-legged, red-haired, big-headed man, that I was to know more of to my cost.

zh: “今天不可能有了，尼尔，”她回答，“没有钱，你怎么可能弄到‘鼻烟’呢！这又一次教训你以后要更加小心。我想詹姆斯·莫尔也会对汤姆家的尼尔不大满意了。”
en: “There can be none the day, Neil,” she replied.“How will you get ‘sneeshin,’ wanting siller!It will teach you another time to be more careful; and I think James More will not be very well pleased with Neil of the Tom.”

zh: “德拉蒙德小姐，”我说，“我跟您说过今天是我的幸运日。我在这里，还有个银行杂役跟着我。要记住我曾在您的家乡巴尔惠德受到过热情款待。”
en: “Miss Drummond,” I said, “I told you I was in my lucky day.Here I am, and a bank-porter at my tail.And remember I have had the hospitality of your own country of Balwhidder.”

zh: “那不是我的家人所给予的。”她说。
en: “It was not one of my people gave it,” said she.

zh: “啊，好，”我说，“但是至少我欠你叔叔几首风笛曲的情。此外，我已经把自己看作是您的朋友了，而您很健忘，并没有适时拒绝我。”
en: “Ah, well,” said I, “but I am owing your uncle at least for some springs upon the pipes.Besides which, I have offered myself to be your friend, and you have been so forgetful that you did not refuse me in the proper time.”

zh: “如果是需要一大笔钱，也许要请你帮忙，”她说，“不过我要告诉你这是怎么回事。詹姆斯·莫尔戴着镣铐被关在监狱里，但是这段时间，他们每天都会带他来这里，到检察总长家……”
en: “If it had been a great sum, it might have done you honour,” said she; “but I will tell you what this is.James More lies shackled in prison; but this time past they will be bringing him down here daily to the Advocate’s...”

zh: “检察总长家！”我喊道，“那就是……？”
en: “The Advocate’s!”I cried.“Is that...?”

zh: “这就是普雷斯顿格兰奇的格兰特检查总长大人的府邸。”她说，“他们不时地带我父亲来审问，我还不太清楚目的何在，但是好像还是给他留了一些希望。一直以来他们都不准我见他，也不准他写信。我们就在国王大街上等着想碰到他，有时我们在他经过时给他送点儿鼻烟，有时会送别的东西。但现在这个惹乱子的小子——尼尔，邓肯的儿子，把我用来买鼻烟的四个便士给弄丢了。这样詹姆斯·莫尔肯定没鼻烟了，他会以为他女儿把他给忘记了。”
en: “It is the house of the Lord Advocate Grant of Prestongrange,” said she.“There they bring my father one time and another, for what purpose I have no thought in my mind; but it seems there is some hope dawned for him.All this same time they will not let me be seeing him, nor yet him write; and we wait upon the King’s street to catch him; and now we give him his snuff as he goes by, and now something else.And here is this son of trouble, Neil, son of Duncan, has lost my four-penny piece that was to buy that snuff, and James More must go wanting, and will think his daughter has forgotten him.”

zh: 我从口袋里掏出六个便士，递给尼尔，吩咐他去办自己的差事。然后对她说：“那六个便士是伴随我从巴尔惠德过来的。”
en: I took sixpence from my pocket, gave it to Neil, and bade him go about his errand.Then to her, “That sixpence came with me by Balwhidder,” said I.

zh: “啊！”她说，“你不愧是格里格拉人的朋友！”
en: “Ah!” she said, “you are a friend to the Gregara!”

zh: “我也不想骗您，”我说，“我对格里格拉知之甚少，而对詹姆斯·莫尔和他的所作所为更不了解。但是自打我站在这个巷子里以后，我似乎对您有些了解了，如果您说我是‘卡特里奥娜小姐的朋友’，我觉得您倒是没有被欺骗。”
en: “I would not like to deceive you, either,” said I.“I know very little of the Gregara and less of James More and his doings, but since the while I have been standing in this close, I seem to know something of yourself; and if you will just say ‘a friend to Miss Catriona’ I will see you are the less cheated.”

zh: “人是不可能没有朋友的。”她说。
en: “The one cannot be without the other,” said she.

zh: “我会尽力而为。”我说。
en: “I will even try,” said I.

zh: “那你又会怎么看待我呀！”她喊道，“竟然和初次见面的陌生人拉手！”
en: “And what will you be thinking of myself!” she cried, “to be holding my hand to the first stranger!”

zh: “我只是在想您是一个好女儿。”我说。
en: “I am thinking nothing but that you are a good daughter,” said I.

zh: “我绝不可能不还这笔钱的，”她说，“你会在哪里落脚？”
en: “I must not be without repaying it,” she said; “where is it you stop!”

zh: “说实话，我尚无落脚之处，”我说，“我到这个城市还不到三个小时。不过要是您告诉我您住的方向，我就会大胆地为自己去找回那六个便士。”
en: “To tell the truth, I am stopping nowhere yet,” said I, “being not full three hours in the city; but if you will give me your direction, I will he no bold as come seeking my sixpence for myself.”

zh: “我能相信你那句话吗？”她问道。
en: “Will I can trust you for that?” she asked.

zh: “您不必担心。”我说。
en: “You need have little fear,” said I.

zh: “詹姆斯·莫尔也无法忍受借钱不还的，”她说，“我暂时在迪恩村外落脚，在河水的北边，和阿勒代斯的德拉蒙德·奥格尔维夫人一起，她是我很亲近的朋友，她会很高兴能感谢您。”
en: “James More could not bear it else,” said she.“I stop beyond the village of Dean, on the north side of the water, with Mrs. Drummond-Ogilvy of Allardyce, who is my near friend and will be glad to thank you.”

zh: “到时您会见到我的，就像我保证的，我会尽快去。”我说。接着，对于艾伦的记忆再次涌向我的脑海，我便匆忙告别了。
en: “You are to see me, then, so soon as what I have to do permits,” said I; and, the remembrance of Alan rolling in again upon my mind, I made haste to say farewell.

zh: 我不禁想到，就像我刚才那样，短暂的相识我们就感到特别无拘无束，转而又想到一位真正明智的年轻女士本应该表现得更加腼腆才是。我觉得是那位银行杂役把我从这一连串失礼的思绪中唤醒了。
en: I could not but think, even as I did so, that we had made extraordinary free upon short acquaintance, and that a really wise young lady would have shown herself more backward.I think it was the bank-porter that put me from this ungallant train of thought.

zh: “我本来以为你是个有点儿理智的小伙子，”他开始说起来，并努了努嘴，“一到了这大门口，你怎么就走不动了。一见美女，钱财分离。呃，你可真是个不懂事的毛头小子！”他喊道，“不过一个不检点的娘们而已！就哄得你晕头转向！”
en: “I thoucht ye had been a lad of some kind o’ sense,” he began, shooting out his lips.“Ye’re no likely to gang far this gate.A fule and his siller’s shune parted.Eh, but ye’re a green callant!” he cried, “an’ a veecious, tae!Cleikin’ up wi’ baubeejoes!”

zh: “要是你敢再说那位年轻女士……”我开始回嘴。
en: “If you dare to speak of the young lady…”I began.

zh: “女士！”他叫道，“掌控我们、保护我们，是什么女士？那是位女士吗？这城里就尽是女士了。女士们啊！嘿，看得出你根本就不太懂得女人的心！”
en: “Leddy!” he cried.“Haud us and safe us, whatten leddy?Ca’ thon a leddy?The toun’s fu’ o’ them.Leddies!Man, its weel seen ye’re no very acquant in Embro!”

zh: 一阵怒火涌上我心头。
en: A clap of anger took me.

zh: “好了，”我说，“带我去我跟你说的地方，闭上你的臭嘴！”
en: “Here,” said I, “lead me where I told you, and keep your foul mouth shut!”

zh: 虽然他不再直接对着我说，但是他也并没完全听我的，他边走边对着我放肆高歌，歌词含沙射影，而且声音特别难听刺耳——
en: He did not wholly obey me, for, though he no more addressed me directly, he very impudent sang at me as he went in a manner of innuendo, and with an exceedingly ill voice and ear—

zh: “玛丽·李沿街往下走，她的斗篷突然不见了，她低头往下瞅一瞅，看见她的睡衣露在外头。我们走到东又走到西，神魂颠倒，转向又晕头；我们走到东又走到西，对着玛丽·李殷勤追求。”
en: “As Mally Lee cam doun the street, her capuchin did flee,She cuist a look ahint her to see her negligee.And we’re a’ gaun east and wast, we’re a’ gann ajee,We’re a’ gaun east and wast courtin’ Mally Lee.”

zh: （1）引人注目的，打眼的
en: (1) Conspicuous.

zh: （2）乡下
en: (2) Country.

zh: （3）精灵
en: (3) The Fairies.

zh: 第二章　高地律师
en: CHAPTER II—THE HIGHLAND WRITER

zh: 查尔斯·斯图尔特律师住在一座阶梯的顶端，那阶梯是泥瓦匠所建过最长的，绝对有十五级之多。我到他家门前时，一位办事员已经把门打开，并告诉我他的主人就在里面。我几乎还来不及喘口气打发我那个杂役走。
en: Mr. Charles Stewart the Writer dwelt at the top of the longest stair ever mason set a hand to; fifteen flights of it, no less; and when I had come to his door, and a clerk had opened it, and told me his master was within, I had scarce breath enough to send my porter packing.

zh: “去你的走到东来又走到西！”我说着，从他手中拿过钱袋，便跟着办事员走了进去。
en: “Awa’ east and west wi’ ye!” said I, took the money bag out of his hands, and followed the clerk in.

zh: 外间是办公室，办事员的椅子在桌子边，桌上摊放着很多法律文件。内室的门是开着的，一个精神饱满的小个子男人坐在那里专心看着一份契约，我进去时，他连眼睛都没有抬一下。实际上，他的手指还在原处，好像准备让我出去好接着再继续他的研究。这让我很不高兴，而让我更不高兴的是，我觉得那位办事员已经摆出一副要偷听我们之间谈话的架势了。
en: The outer room was an office with the clerk’s chair at a table spread with law papers.In the inner chamber, which opened from it, a little brisk man sat poring on a deed, from which he scarce raised his eyes on my entrance; indeed, he still kept his finger in the place, as though prepared to show me out and fall again to his studies.This pleased me little enough; and what pleased me less, I thought the clerk was in a good posture to overhear what should pass between us.

zh: 我问他是不是查尔斯·斯图尔特律师。
en: I asked if he was Mr. Charles Stewart the Writer.

zh: “正是，”他说，“那么，如果为公平起见，请问你又是谁呢？”
en: “The same,” says he; “and, if the question is equally fair, who may you be yourself?”

zh: “你还从未听说过我的名字或者我这个人，”我说，“但是我从一个你很熟悉的朋友那里给你带来了一件信物。你很熟悉的，”我重复道，同时压低声音说，“但是也许目前你并不很想得到他的消息。我要向你陈述的这些事情具有相当的机密性。总之，我认为我们得私下谈谈。”
en: “You never heard tell of my name nor of me either,” said I, “but I bring you a token from a friend that you know well.That you know well,” I repeated, lowering my voice, “but maybe are not just so keen to hear from at this present being.And the bits of business that I have to propone to you are rather in the nature of being confidential.In short, I would like to think we were quite private.”

zh: 他二话没说便站了起来，一脸很不高兴地扔下文件，打发办事员去办一个差事，然后反手关上了房门。
en: He rose without more words, casting down his paper like a man ill-pleased, sent forth his clerk of an errand, and shut to the house-door behind him.

zh: “现在，先生，”他一边往回走一边说，“大胆说出你的想法，什么都不用害怕。尽管在你开始说之前，”他喊道，“我要告诉你我自己心中很不安！我预先告诉你，你不是姓斯图尔特就是斯图尔特家派你来的。这是一个好姓氏，是个我们家族子孙都不会看轻的姓氏。但是我开始害怕听到这个姓氏了。”
en: “Now, sir,” said he, returning, “speak out your mind and fear nothing; though before you begin,” he cries out, “I tell you mine misgives me!I tell you beforehand, ye’re either a Stewart or a Stewart sent ye.A good name it is, and one it would ill-become my father’s son to lightly.But I begin to grue at the sound of it.”

zh: “我名叫鲍尔弗，”我说，“肖斯的戴维·鲍尔弗。至于说派我来的人，我会让他的信物来说话。”接着我给他看了银纽扣。
en: “My name is called Balfour,” said I, “David Balfour of Shaws.As for him that sent me, I will let his token speak.”And I showed the silver button.

zh: “放到你口袋里去，先生！”他喊道，“你不需要说出名字。这该死的纽扣，我认得出他的这枚纽扣！真该死！他现在在哪里？”
en: “Put it in your pocket, sir!” cries he.“Ye need name no names.The deevil’s buckie, I ken the button of him!And de’il hae’t!Where is he now?"

zh: 我告诉他我不知道艾伦在哪里，但是他在靠近北边的某个安全的地方（或者他认为他在安全的地方），他会一直躲到帮他找到一艘船。至于怎样或者到哪里找他，则要经过他口头同意方可。
en: I told him I knew not where Alan was, but he had some sure place (or thought he had) about the north side, where he was to lie until a ship was found for him; and how and where he had appointed to be spoken with.

zh: “我一直都知道我会被我这个家所拖累而上绞架的，”他喊道，“唉，天哪！我相信这一天现在来了！给他弄一艘船，这是他说的！那谁来付这笔钱？这个家伙疯了！”
en: “It’s been always my opinion that I would hang in a tow for this family of mine,” he cried, “and, dod!I believe the day’s come now!Get a ship for him, quot’ he!And who’s to pay for it?The man’s daft!”

zh: “付钱这件事由我负责，斯图尔特先生。”我说,“这里有一大袋金币，如果不够，我还可以送更多过来。”
en: “That is my part of the affair, Mr. Stewart,” said I.“Here is a bag of good money, and if more be wanted, more is to be had where it came from.”

zh: “我不需要问一下你的政治立场？”他说。
en: “I needn’t ask your politics,” said he.

zh: “不需要，”我微笑着说，“因为我从小就是辉格党。”
en: “Ye need not,” said I, smiling, “for I’m as big a Whig as grows.”

zh: “等一下，等一下，”斯图尔特先生说，“这一切是怎么回事？一个辉格党？那你为什么带着艾伦的纽扣来这里？我发现你在插手的又是一桩什么样的秘密交易，辉格党先生？他是一个遭褫夺的叛党，还被控杀人，被人悬赏二百英镑要他的命。可是你要我来管他这件事，然后却告诉我说你是一个辉格党！我以前从没想到过居然有这样的辉格党，尽管我见过很多辉格党人。”
en: “Stop a bit, stop a bit,” says Mr. Stewart.“What’s all this?A Whig?Then why are you here with Alan’s button? and what kind of a black-foot traffic is this that I find ye out in, Mr. Whig?Here is a forfeited rebel and an accused murderer, with two hundred pounds on his life, and ye ask me to meddle in his business, and then tell me ye’re a Whig!I have no mind of any such Whigs before, though I’ve kent plenty of them.”

zh: “他是一个遭褫夺的叛党，可是更加遗憾的是，”我说道，“这个人是我的朋友。我只能希望他曾受过更好的引导。至于说他被控杀人，那是他倒霉，但他也是被冤枉的。”
en: “He’s a forfeited rebel, the more’s the pity,” said I, “for the man’s my friend.I can only wish he had been better guided.And an accused murderer, that he is too, for his misfortune; but wrongfully accused.”

zh: “我听到你是这么说的。”斯图尔特说。
en: “I hear you say so,” said Stewart.

zh: “不久以后，就不只是你会听到我这么说了。”我说，“艾伦·布雷克是无辜的，詹姆斯也是无辜的。”
en: “More than you are to hear me say so, before long,” said I.“Alan Breck is innocent, and so is James.”

zh: “哦！”他说，“这两个案子是连在一起的。如果艾伦没有涉案，詹姆斯就绝不会牵扯进去。”
en: “Oh!” says he, “the two cases hang together.If Alan is out, James can never be in.”

zh: 随即我简要介绍了我和艾伦的相识经过，告诉了他阿平凶杀案发生时我恰好在场，说起我们在石楠丛中的种种逃亡经历，以及我重新获得我的财产之事。“因此，先生，你现在已经了解这些事情的来龙去脉了，”我继续说，“而且你自己也看得出我是如何掺和进你的家族以及朋友的事情中的，这些事（看在我们大家的份上）我希望能够顺利一些、少点儿血腥。你自己也会明白：我这些事情是有某些特定背景的，随意选个律师来办是不合适的。没有更多要说的了，我只想问你是否会接下我要办的事情？”
en: Hereupon I told him briefly of my acquaintance with Alan, of the accident that brought me present at the Appin murder, and the various passages of our escape among the heather, and my recovery of my estate.“So, sir, you have now the whole train of these events,” I went on, “and can see for yourself how I come to be so much mingled up with the affairs of your family and friends, which (for all of our sakes) I wish had been plainer and less bloody.You can see for yourself, too, that I have certain pieces of business depending, which were scarcely fit to lay before a lawyer chosen at random.No more remains, but to ask if you will undertake my service?”

zh: “我还没有好好琢磨此事。不过既然你带来了艾伦的纽扣，就没有给我留下什么选择的余地了，”他说，“你有什么要交代的？”他拿起笔又问。
en: “I have no great mind to it; but coming as you do with Alan’s button, the choice is scarcely left me,” said he.“What are your instructions?” he added, and took up his pen.

zh: “首先一点就是要偷渡艾伦出国，”我说，“不过我没必要再重复了。”
en: “The first point is to smuggle Alan forth of this country,” said I, “but I need not be repeating that.”

zh: “我不可能忘记这一点的。”斯图尔特说。
en: “I am little likely to forget it,” said Stewart.

zh: “接下来一件事就是我还欠克卢尼一点儿钱，”我继续说，“对我来说要把钱转给他很麻烦，但对你来说却不成问题。就是两英镑五先令和三枚半便士的小银币。”
en: “The next thing is the bit money I am owing to Cluny,” I went on.“It would be ill for me to find a conveyance, but that should be no stick to you.It was two pounds five shillings and three-halfpence farthing sterling.”

zh: 他记了下来。
en: He noted it.

zh: “另外，”我说，“有一位亨德兰先生，是阿德格尔的一位持照牧师和传教士，我很想送些鼻烟到他手中。因为我猜想你和你在阿平的朋友（就在附近）一直有联系，毫无疑问，这件事情你可以和另外一件事一起办。”
en: “Then,” said I, “there’s a Mr. Henderland, a licensed preacher and missionary in Ardgour, that I would like well to get some snuff into the hands of; and, as I daresay you keep touch with your friends in Appin (so near by), it’s a job you could doubtless overtake with the other.”

zh: “大约多少钱的鼻烟？”他问道。
en: “How much snuff are we to say?” he asked.

zh: “我想是两英镑吧。”我说。
en: “I was thinking of two pounds,” said I.

zh: “两英镑。”他说。
en: “Two,” said he.

zh: “然后还有艾莉森·黑斯蒂姑娘，她住在莱姆基恩斯，”我说，“她曾帮助我和艾伦横渡福斯河。我在想如果我可以送她一件漂亮的礼拜服，正合她身份，让她可以穿着体面，这样会让我的良心得到安慰。因为事实上，我们两条命都多亏了她。”
en: “Then there’s the lass Alison Hastie, in Lime Kilns,” said I.“Her that helped Alan and me across the Forth.I was thinking if I could get her a good Sunday gown, such as she could wear with decency in her degree, it would be an ease to my conscience; for the mere truth is, we owe her our two lives.”

zh: “鲍尔弗先生，看到你这么节俭，我很高兴。”他一边记录一边说。
en: “I am glad to see you are thrifty, Mr. Balfour,” says he, making his notes.

zh: “要是我在得到财富的第一天就挥霍，那我会感到羞愧的，”我说，“但是现在，如果你可以算出所需的费用和你自己应得的报酬，我很想知道我是不是还可以拿回一些零用钱。不是我吝啬，不愿拿出全部金币来保证艾伦的安全，也不是我没有更多的钱。但是一天之内就已经提取了那么多钱，我认为要是我再回去要求提款，印象会很不好。只是一定要确保你的钱够用，”我补充说，“因为我实在不想再和你见面了。”
en: “I would think shame to be otherwise the first day of my fortune,” said I.“And now, if you will compute the outlay and your own proper charges, I would be glad to know if I could get some spending-money back.It’s not that I grudge the whole of it to get Alan safe; it’s not that I lack more; but having drawn so much the one day, I think it would have a very ill appearance if I was back again seeking, the next.Only be sure you have enough,” I added, “for I am very undesirous to meet with you again.”

zh: “好吧，看到你这么小心谨慎，我也很高兴。”那律师说，“不过我认为你把这么大一笔钱交给我处理是在冒险。”
en: “Well, and I’m pleased to see you’re cautious, too,” said the Writer.“But I think ye take a risk to lay so considerable a sum at my discretion.”

zh: 他说话的时候带着一丝冷笑。
en: He said this with a plain sneer.

zh: “我不得不冒这个险，”我回答道，“噢，还有一件事要请教你，就是给我指点一下住处吧，因为我还无处栖身呢。不过必须得让人觉得我是碰巧住到那里的，因为如果检察总长大人对你我相识心存戒备的话，那就什么事也办不成了。”
en: “I’ll have to run the hazard,” I replied.“O, and there’s another service I would ask, and that’s to direct me to a lodging, for I have no roof to my head.But it must be a lodging I may seem to have hit upon by accident, for it would never do if the Lord Advocate were to get any jealousy of our acquaintance.”

zh: “你大可以放心，”他说，“我永远都不会提起你的名字，先生。我相信就算检察总长不知道你的存在，也一样会很有同情心的。”
en: “Ye may set your weary spirit at rest,” said he.“I will never name your name, sir; and it’s my belief the Advocate is still so much to be sympathised with that he doesnae ken of your existence.”

zh: 我知道我让这个人产生误会了。
en: I saw I had got to the wrong side of the man.

zh: “那么，哪天去见见他应该很不错，”我说，“最迟到明天我拜访他的时候，他就会从闻所未闻而变成获悉此事了。”
en: “There’s a braw day coming for him, then,” said I, “for he’ll have to learn of it on the deaf side of his head no later than to-morrow, when I call on him.”

zh: “当你拜访他的时候！”斯图尔特先生重复道，“是我愚蠢，还是你犯傻呀！你去接近检察总长干什么！”
en: “When ye call on him!” repeated Mr. Stewart.“Am I daft, or are you!What takes ye near the Advocate!”

zh: “哦，只不过是去投案自首罢了。”我说。
en: “O, just to give myself up,” said I.

zh: “鲍尔弗先生，”他喊道，“你是在耍弄我吗？”
en: “Mr. Balfour,” he cried, “are ye making a mock of me?”

zh: “不，先生，”我说，“尽管我觉得你已经允许自己对我这么随便了。但是我得让你彻底明白，我丝毫没有闹着玩的意思。”
en: “No, sir,” said I, “though I think you have allowed yourself some such freedom with myself.But I give you to understand once and for all that I am in no jesting spirit.”

zh: “我也没有，”斯图尔特说，“而且我要让你明白（如果可以这么说的话）我越来越不喜欢你的举止表现了。你带着各种各样的要求到我这里来，这些要求会把我牵涉进一连串可疑的行为中，将来某一天也会让我成为那种很不受欢迎的人。然后你又告诉我，你一出我的办公室就会去和检察总长讲和！管他艾伦的纽扣在这里，还是艾伦的纽扣在那里，就是整个艾伦也不可能再收买我进一步插手此事了。”
en: “Nor yet me,” says Stewart.“And I give yon to understand (if that’s to be the word) that I like the looks of your behaviour less and less.You come here to me with all sorts of propositions, which will put me in a train of very doubtful acts and bring me among very undesirable persons this many a day to come.And then you tell me you’re going straight out of my office to make your peace with the Advocate!Alan’s button here or Alan’s button there, the four quarters of Alan wouldnae bribe me further in.”

zh: “听你这么说我可有点儿生气了，”我说，“不过也许我们可以避免你所反对的情况。除了投案自首，我实在想不出别的办法，但是也许你能够想出另外的办法。要是你能想出来的话，我是绝对不会拒绝的，我只会感到如释重负。因为我觉得和这位检察总长大人打交道可能于我自身不太有利。只有一件事情是很清楚的，那就是我得举证，因为我希望这样能保全艾伦的人格（这是他仅有的东西了）和詹姆斯的性命，保全詹姆斯的性命更是迫在眉睫。”
en: “I would take it with a little more temper,” said I, “and perhaps we can avoid what you object to.I can see no way for it but to give myself up, but perhaps you can see another; and if you could, I could never deny but what I would be rather relieved.For I think my traffic with his lordship is little likely to agree with my health.There’s just the one thing clear, that I have to give my evidence; for I hope it’ll save Alan’s character (what’s left of it), and James’s neck, which is the more immediate.”

zh: 他沉默了一小会儿，然后开口了：“小伙子啊，永远也不会有人让你去举这样的证的。”
en: He was silent for a breathing-space, and then, “My man,” said he, “you’ll never be allowed to give such evidence.”

zh: “我们将拭目以待，”我说，“只要我愿意，我就会很固执。”
en: “We’ll have to see about that,” said I; “I’m stiff-necked when I like.”

zh: “你这个十足的傻瓜！”斯图尔特喊道，“他们想要的是詹姆斯。詹姆斯得被绞死——艾伦也一样，只要他们能抓到他——但是詹姆斯无论如何都会被绞死的！为这样的事情去接近检察总长，你就看吧！他一定会找办法封住你的嘴。”
en: “Ye muckle ass!” cried Stewart, “it’s James they want; James has got to hang—Alan, too, if they could catch him—but James whatever!Go near the Advocate with any such business, and you’ll see! he’ll find a way to muzzle, ye.”

zh: “我相信那位检察总长不会那么坏。”我说。
en: “I think better of the Advocate than that,” said I.

zh: “让那个检察总长见鬼去吧！”他喊道，“关键是坎贝尔家的人，小伙子！你会招来他们整个家族的人群起而攻的，那位检察总长也一样。可怜的家伙！你居然看不出你处于什么样的境地，太奇怪了！如果你还没有办法管住自己的嘴，就会捅大娄子的。他们会把你推上被告席，你难道不明白？”他边喊边用一根手指戳着我的腿。
en: “The Advocate be dammed!” cries he.“It’s the Campbells, man!You’ll have the whole clanjamfry of them on your back; and so will the Advocate too, poor body!It’s extraordinar ye cannot see where ye stand!If there’s no fair way to stop your gab, there’s a foul one gaping.They can put ye in the dock, do ye no see that?” he cried, and stabbed me with one finger in the leg.

zh: “唉，”我说，“就在今天早晨另外一位律师对我说过同样的话。”
en: “Ay,” said I, “I was told that same no further back than this morning by another lawyer.”

zh: “那么他是谁？”斯图尔特问，“至少他说得在理。”
en: “And who was he?” asked Stewart, “He spoke sense at least.”

zh: 我告诉他说，务请原谅我不能说出那个人的名字，因为他是一位正派坚定的老辉格党，而且不想卷入这类事情中。
en: I told I must be excused from naming him, for he was a decent stout old Whig, and had little mind to be mixed up in such affairs.

zh: “我觉得全世界好像都搅和进来了！”斯图尔特喊道，“但是你跟他说了什么？”
en: “I think all the world seems to be mixed up in it!” cries Stewart.“But what said you?”

zh: “我告诉了他我和兰基勒在肖斯家的房屋前所交谈的内容。”
en: “I told him what had passed between Rankeillor and myself before the house of Shaws.”

zh: “那行了，你一样会被绞死的！”他说，“你会在詹姆斯·斯图尔特身旁被绞死。你命该如此。”
en: “Well, and so ye will hang!” said he.“Ye’ll hang beside James Stewart.There’s your fortune told.”

zh: “我希望结果不至于那么糟，”我说，“可是我绝不否认会有风险。”
en: “I hope better of it yet than that,” said I; “but I could never deny there was a risk.”

zh: “风险！”他说，然后又一次坐在那里沉默了，“我应该谢谢你对我的朋友如此忠心，你对他们表现出了极大的勇气，”他说，“如果你有力量支持他们的话。但是我要警告你，你涉水很深。我是不会把自己放在你的位置上的（我天生就是斯图尔特族人！），因为自从诺亚以后所有的斯图尔特人就一直是这样了。风险？唉！我已经冒过太多的风险了。但是试图冒险站在法庭上、站在坎贝尔陪审团和坎贝尔法官的面前，试图在坎贝尔的家乡为坎贝尔的不和而冒险——站在我的角度想想看，鲍尔弗，这是我力所不能及的。”
en: “Risk!” says he, and then sat silent again.“I ought to thank you for you staunchness to my friends, to whom you show a very good spirit,” he says, “if you have the strength to stand by it.But I warn you that you’re wading deep.I wouldn’t put myself in your place (me that’s a Stewart born!) for all the Stewarts that ever there were since Noah.Risk? ay, I take over-many; but to be tried in court before a Campbell jury and a Campbell judge, and that in a Campbell country and upon a Campbell quarrel—think what you like of me, Balfour, it’s beyond me.”

zh: “我猜，只是思维方式不同罢了，”我说，“之前我父亲就是这么教育我的。”
en: “It’s a different way of thinking, I suppose,” said I; “I was brought up to this one by my father before me.”

zh: “我向他致敬！他已经为该姓氏留下了一个正派的儿子，”他说，“可我不需要你来过分严厉地评判我。我的处境注定会很艰难。你看，先生，你告诉我说你是一个辉格党人。我在想那我是什么。肯定不是辉格党人，我不可能是辉格党人。但是——让我悄悄告诉你，小伙子——也许我也不会很热衷于其对立面吧。”
en: “Glory to his bones! he has left a decent son to his name,” says he.“Yet I would not have you judge me over-sorely.My case is dooms hard.See, sir, ye tell me ye’re a Whig: I wonder what I am.No Whig to be sure; I couldnae be just that.But—laigh in your ear, man—I’m maybe no very keen on the other side.”

zh: “真的是那样吗？”我叫道，“我认为像你这么睿智的人就该是这样的。”
en: “Is that a fact?” cried I.“It’s what I would think of a man of your intelligence.”

zh: “得了！你别奉承我了！”他叫道，“我们双方都很明智。但是就我个人而言，我并不特别想伤害乔治国王。至于说詹姆斯国王，上帝保佑他！在我看来他在大海对岸做得很好。我是一名律师，你知道的：我就喜好读读书、喝点酒、做一场好辩护、签一份好契约、在议会上与其他律师一起高谈阔论，也许有机会的话还喜欢周六晚上打打高尔夫球。你是从哪里弄来高地人的披肩和砍刀的？”
en: “Hut! none of your whillywhas!”(1) cries he.“There’s intelligence upon both sides.But for my private part I have no particular desire to harm King George; and as for King James, God bless him! he does very well for me across the water.I’m a lawyer, ye see: fond of my books and my bottle, a good plea, a well-drawn deed, a crack in the Parliament House with other lawyer bodies, and perhaps a turn at the golf on a Saturday at e’en.Where do ye come in with your Hieland plaids and claymores?”

zh: “哦，”我说，“事实上你几乎没有高地人的野性了。”
en: “Well,” said I, “it’s a fact ye have little of the wild Highlandman.”

zh: “几乎没有？”他说，“不对，小伙子！我生为高地人，所以每当部族的风笛吹响，翩翩起舞的舍我其谁！该部族和该姓氏都已逝去。正如你刚才说你自己的那样，我父亲教会了我这些，还让我拥有了一份不错的职业。要偷渡叛国者们出进，还有法国的招兵买马，真让人受够了！还要偷渡那些新兵，他们的恳求——恳求中透着悲哀！我这才帮年轻的阿德希尔运送了一个人，是我的堂兄，他要求通过婚约明确其财产——一份被褫夺的财产！我告诉他们那简直是荒唐，他们奢求得太多了！而且我为这些几乎跟我自己毫无关系的事奔波忙碌，很有可能还会毁掉我们双方——那是一个污点，会给我们烙上反叛的烙印，就像人们刻在钥匙上的名字一样！而我又能做什么？我是一个斯图尔特族人，你知道，就必须照料我的宗族与家人。随后就在昨天，我们斯图尔特族的一个青年被带到了城堡。为什么？我很清楚：1736年法案，为路易国王征兵。而你会看到，他会唤我去给他当律师，这又会给我的人格烙上另一个污点。说实话：要不是因为，按照希伯来语的说法，我也来自同一个宗族，对这种事情我要是不搁置一边、置之不理，那我就不是人！”
en: “Little?” quoth he.“Nothing, man!And yet I’m Hieland born, and when the clan pipes, who but me has to dance!The clan and the name, that goes by all.It’s just what you said yourself; my father learned it to me, and a bonny trade I have of it.Treason and traitors, and the smuggling of them out and in; and the French recruiting, weary fall it! and the smuggling through of the recruits; and their pleas—a sorrow of their pleas!Here have I been moving one for young Ardsheil, my cousin; claimed the estate under the marriage contract—a forfeited estate!I told them it was nonsense: muckle they cared!And there was I cocking behind a yadvocate that liked the business as little as myself, for it was fair ruin to the pair of us—a black mark, disaffected, branded on our hurdies, like folk’s names upon their kye!And what can I do?I’m a Stewart, ye see, and must fend for my clan and family.Then no later by than yesterday there was one of our Stewart lads carried to the Castle.What for?I ken fine: Act of 1736: recruiting for King Lewie.And you’ll see, he’ll whistle me in to be his lawyer, and there’ll be another black mark on my chara’ter!I tell you fair: if I but kent the heid of a Hebrew word from the hurdies of it, be dammed but I would fling the whole thing up and turn minister!”

zh: “真是艰难的处境。”我说。
en: “It’s rather a hard position,” said I.

zh: “注定艰难！”他叫道，“而正是这样才让我这么尊敬你——你不是斯图尔特人——却甘愿为斯图尔特人的事冒这么大的风险。至于为什么，我不知道，除非是一种责任感。”
en: “Dooms hard!” cries he.“And that’s what makes me think so much of ye—you that’s no Stewart—to stick your head so deep in Stewart business.And for what, I do not know: unless it was the sense of duty.”

zh: “我希望是那样。”我说。
en: “I hope it will be that,” said I.

zh: “那么，”他说，“这是一种高尚的品质。现在我的办事员就要回来了，先别走，我们吃顿便餐，我们三个人一起。吃完饭后，我会告诉你去找一个很正派的人，他会很乐意留你住宿的。而我也会填满你的口袋，甚至多得连你的口袋都装不下。因为办这件事情价格没有你想得那么高——甚至包括找一艘船也没那么贵。”
en: “Well,” says he, “it’s a grand quality.But here is my clerk back; and, by your leave, we’ll pick a bit of dinner, all the three of us.When that’s done, I’ll give you the direction of a very decent man, that’ll be very fain to have you for a lodger.And I’ll fill your pockets to ye, forbye, out of your ain bag.For this business’ll not be near as dear as ye suppose—not even the ship part of it.”

zh: 我给他打个手势，他的办事员已经走近，可以听到我们的谈话了。
en: I made him a sign that his clerk was within hearing.

zh: “没关系，你不必在意罗比。”他叫道，“他也是一个斯图尔特族的人，这家伙鬼着呢！他偷渡过很多法国新兵，他和天主教徒做的交易比他脸上的胡须还多。嗨，就是罗宾在处理我的这部分事务。罗布，要渡海的话找谁好？”
en: “Hoot, ye neednae mind for Robbie,” cries he.“A Stewart, too, puir deevil! and has smuggled out more French recruits and trafficking Papists than what he has hairs upon his face.Why, it’s Robin that manages that branch of my affairs.Who will we have now, Rob, for across the water!”

zh: “可以找安迪·斯库格尔，他在‘呼啸’号上。”罗布回答道，“前几天我看见了霍齐亚森，他好像正需要那船呢。还有就是塔姆·斯托博，但是我不太信任塔姆。我已经发现他和一些非常可疑的熟人在密谈，所以要不是重要人物的话，我是不会去找塔姆的。”
en: “There’ll be Andie Scougal, in the Thristle,” replied Rob.“I saw Hoseason the other day, but it seems he’s wanting the ship.Then there’ll be Tam Stobo; but I’m none so sure of Tam.I’ve seen him colloguing with some gey queer acquaintances; and if was anybody important, I would give Tam the go-by.”

zh: “这人的脑袋值二百英镑，罗宾。”斯图尔特说。
en: “The head’s worth two hundred pounds, Robin,” said Stewart.

zh: “天哪，那不会是艾伦·布雷克吧！”那办事员叫道。
en: “Gosh, that’ll no be Alan Breck!” cried the clerk.

zh: “正是艾伦。”他的主人说。
en: “Just Alan,” said his master.

zh: “很棘手啊！那得认真对待才行。”罗宾叫道，“那我找安迪试试，安迪是最佳人选。”
en: “Weary winds! that’s sayrious,” cried Robin.“I’ll try Andie, then; Andie’ll be the best.”

zh: “看来这是一桩大事情。”我说。
en: “It seems it’s quite a big business,” I observed.

zh: “鲍尔弗先生，事情还没有说完呢。”斯图尔特说。
en: “Mr. Balfour, there’s no end to it,” said Stewart.

zh: “刚才你的办事员提到一个名字，”我继续说道，“霍齐亚森。我想一定是我认识的那个人，‘契约号’双桅船上的霍齐亚森。你居然会去信任他吗？”
en: “There was a name your clerk mentioned,” I went on: “Hoseason.That must be my man, I think: Hoseason, of the brig Covenant.Would you set your trust on him?”

zh: “他对你和艾伦表现得是不大好，”斯图尔特先生说，“不过我认为这个人总体上来看还是相当不错的。如果他已经按照协议把艾伦带上船了的话，在我看来，他就已经证明自己是个可靠的生意人了。你怎么看，罗布？”
en: “He didnae behave very well to you and Alan,” said Mr. Stewart; “but my mind of the man in general is rather otherwise.If he had taken Alan on board his ship on an agreement, it’s my notion he would have proved a just dealer.How say ye, Rob?”

zh: “做这种交易没有比伊莱更诚实的船长了。”那个办事员说，“我信任伊莱——唉，就像信任骑士或者阿平本人一样。”他补充道。
en: “No more honest skipper in the trade than Eli,” said the clerk.“I would lippen to(2) Eli’s word—ay, if it was the Chevalier, or Appin himsel’,” he added.

zh: “那么是他把医生带来的，是吗？”那主人问道。
en: “And it was him that brought the doctor, wasnae’t?” asked the master.

zh: “正是这个人。”那个办事员说。
en: “He was the very man,” said the clerk.

zh: “那我想也是他把医生带回去的？”斯图尔特说。
en: “And I think he took the doctor back?” says Stewart.

zh: “是呀，他的毛皮袋塞得满满的了！”罗宾叫道，“而且伊莱知道那件事！”
en: “Ay, with his sporran full!” cried Robin.“And Eli kent of that!”(3)

zh: “唔，看来要看准一个人还真难。”我说。
en: “Well, it seems it’s hard to ken folk rightly,” said I.

zh: “那正是你进来时我忘记说的话，鲍尔弗先生！”那律师说道。
en: “That was just what I forgot when ye came in, Mr. Balfour!” says the Writer.

zh: （1）奉承话
en: (1) Flatteries.

zh: （2）信任
en: (2) Trust to.

zh: （3）这一点须参见卡梅伦医生的首次来访。
en: (3) This must have reference to Dr. Cameron on his first visit.—D. B.

zh: 第三章　我前往皮尔里格
en: CHAPTER III—I GO TO PILRIG

zh: 第二天早晨，在新入住的地方，我一醒来就赶紧起床，并穿上了新衣服。狼吞虎咽地吃完早餐, 我就开始了自己的冒险行程。艾伦嘛，我还可以抱希望，已经得到了照料。可是詹姆斯这事好像更难办一些，我不由地想到这件事也许会让我付出极大的代价，甚至会像所有我曾咨询过的人所说的那样。这好似我终于登上山顶却倒了下来。我曾经努力攀登，经历那么多艰难的考验，终于变得富有，得到了认可，穿上了城里人的衣服，而且在腰间配了一把剑，可是所有这一切只不过是为了在最后一刻自杀，而且还是最糟糕的一种自杀，就是在国王的指控下上绞架。
en: The next morning, I was no sooner awake in my new lodging than I was up and into my new clothes; and no sooner the breakfast swallowed, than I was forth on my adventurers.Alan, I could hope, was fended for; James was like to be a more difficult affair, and I could not but think that enterprise might cost me dear, even as everybody said to whom I had opened my opinion.It seemed I was come to the top of the mountain only to cast myself down; that I had clambered up, through so many and hard trials, to be rich, to be recognised, to wear city clothes and a sword to my side, all to commit mere suicide at the last end of it, and the worst kind of suicide, besides, which is to get hanged at the King’s charges.

zh: 我这么做是为了什么？我一边自问着，一边沿着大街往下走，并由利斯巷向北而出。首先我对自己说这是为了救詹姆斯·斯图尔特。我回忆起他的悲痛、他妻子的哭声以及我在那种情形下所作出的那么一两句承诺，这回忆毫无疑问强烈地影响了我。同时我想到：不论詹姆斯是死在他自己的床上还是绞刑架上，这件事都是（或者应该是）和作为我父亲儿子的我毫不相干的。诚然，他是艾伦的表亲，但是他和艾伦的关系那么远，所以最好的做法就是保持缄默，而让国王和阿盖尔公爵，还有成群的乌鸦，用他们自己的方式去啄食他们那位同族人的尸骨吧。我也不会忘记，我们一起经历患难的时侯，詹姆斯不论是对艾伦还是对我都没有表现过特别的担心。
en: What was I doing it for?I asked, as I went down the high Street and out north by Leith Wynd.First I said it was to save James Stewart; and no doubt the memory of his distress, and his wife’s cries, and a word or so I had let drop on that occasion worked upon me strongly.At the same time I reflected that it was (or ought to be) the most indifferent matter to my father’s son, whether James died in his bed or from a scaffold.He was Alan’s cousin, to be sure; but so far as regarded Alan, the best thing would be to lie low, and let the King, and his Grace of Argyll, and the corbie crows, pick the bones of his kinsman their own way.Nor could I forget that, while we were all in the pot together, James had shown no such particular anxiety whether for Alan or me.

zh: 接着我又想到，我这么做是为了正义。我认为正义这个词很贴切，并由此推论出（既然我们都已深陷于政治当中，该词对于我们每一个人来说都有点儿不便提起）这一切的关键还必须得是正义，任何无辜者的死亡都会是整个社会的创伤。再接下来，正是因为想到了弟兄的责怪让我转而考虑他的论点，让我觉得自己如果假装很关心这些重大的事情，那就很羞耻。同时这也向我说明，我只是一个夸夸其谈、自命不凡的小毛孩，对兰基勒和斯图尔特说了大话，结果受困于为满足自己大肆吹嘘的那种虚荣心了。不仅如此，他还会从另一方面抨击我，因为他指责我是狡猾的懦夫，只想冒极小的风险来换得更大的安全保障。毫无疑问，在我申明并澄清自己之前，任何一天我都有可能遇见芒戈·坎贝尔或者郡县的官员，一经认出，我就会因涉嫌阿平凶杀案而被捕。可是，同样毫无疑问，一旦我能够成功地发表声明，此后我就可以更加自由地呼吸了。但是当我正视并深思这个论点时，我又觉得没有什么可感到羞耻的了。至于其他，“这里有两条路，”我想着，“而两条路都通向同一个地方。如果我能救詹姆斯而他却被绞死了，这样就不公平。不过要是我说了那么多却又无所作为，那未免也太荒谬了。我已经事先夸下了海口，这对格伦斯的詹姆斯来说很幸运。不过对我自己也不是那么不幸，因为我有责任去做正确的事情。我有着绅士之名和相应的财富，我在本质上缺乏的就是那么一点点应尽的责任了。”随后我想到这是一种异教徒精神，于是在自己内心祷告，祈求给予我可能缺乏的勇气，祈求我可以像士兵奔赴战场那样勇往直前地去承担责任，然后像很多士兵那样可以平安归来。
en: Next it came upon me I was acting for the sake of justice: and I thought that a fine word, and reasoned it out that (since we dwelt in polities, at some discomfort to each one of us) the main thing of all must still be justice, and the death of any innocent man a wound upon the whole community.Next, again, it was the Accuser of the Brethren that gave me a turn of his argument; bade me think shame for pretending myself concerned in these high matters, and told me I was but a prating vain child, who had spoken big words to Rankeillor and to Stewart, and held myself bound upon my vanity to make good that boastfulness.Nay, and he hit me with the other end of the stick; for he accused me of a kind of artful cowardice, going about at the expense of a little risk to purchase greater safety.No doubt, until I had declared and cleared myself, I might any day encounter Mungo Campbell or the sheriff’s officer, and be recognised, and dragged into the Appin murder by the heels; and, no doubt, in case I could manage my declaration with success, I should breathe more free for ever after.But when I looked this argument full in the face I could see nothing to be ashamed of.As for the rest, “Here are the two roads,” I thought, “and both go to the same place.It’s unjust that James should hang if I can save him; and it would be ridiculous in me to have talked so much and then do nothing.It’s lucky for James of the Glens that I have boasted beforehand; and none so unlucky for myself, because now I’m committed to do right.I have the name of a gentleman and the means of one; it would be a poor duty that I was wanting in the essence.”And then I thought this was a Pagan spirit, and said a prayer in to myself, asking for what courage I might lack, and that I might go straight to my duty like a soldier to battle, and come off again scatheless, as so many do.

zh: 这一连串的推理让我态度更加坚决，虽然还远远没有打消我对自己周围危险的感觉，同时，我自己很有可能（如果我继续下去的话）会踏上绞架的阶梯的感觉也还在。那是一个普通、晴朗的早晨，但是却刮着东风。风中的丝丝寒意浸入我的血液，给我带来秋日的感觉，让我感觉到枯死的落叶，还有逝者躺在墓穴中的尸骨。若是我在命运之巅却为他人之事丧命的话，那似乎是有魔鬼在其中作祟了。在考尔顿山的山顶上，尽管还不是一年中放风筝娱乐的时节，还是有些孩子一边叫一边奔跑着在放风筝。这些风筝在空中显得很平静，我注意到有一个大风筝御风直上、飞得很高，可是接着突然坠落在棘豆丛里。见此情景，我不由联想到自己：“戴维也会有此下场。”
en: This train of reasoning brought me to a more resolved complexion; though it was far from closing up my sense of the dangers that surrounded me, nor of how very apt I was (if I went on) to stumble on the ladder of the gallows.It was a plain, fair morning, but the wind in the east.The little chill of it sang in my blood, and gave me a feeling of the autumn, and the dead leaves, and dead folks’ bodies in their graves.It seemed the devil was in it, if I was to die in that tide of my fortunes and for other folks’ affairs.On the top of the Calton Hill, though it was not the customary time of year for that diversion, some children were crying and running with their kites.These toys appeared very plain against the sky; I remarked a great one soar on the wind to a high altitude and then plump among the whins; and I thought to myself at sight of it, “There goes Davie.”

zh: 我所走的路要越过穆特山，然后从田野中斜坡上的一个小村庄的尽头穿过。那里家家户户都传出织布机的嗡嗡声，蜜蜂在花园里嬉闹，我看到那些邻居们在门阶上用奇怪的口音在聊天。后来我才发现这里是皮卡第，这个村庄里住着为利宁公司劳作的法国纺织工们。在这里我得到最新的指点，前往我的目的地皮尔里格。没走多远，就在路边上，我看见了一副绞架，上面有两个戴着镣铐被绞死的男子。按照习俗，他们全身浸透了焦油。风从他们身边吹过，镣铐哗哗作响，一些鸟在这两具怪异、摇晃的尸身周围盘旋并鸣叫着。这景象突然扑面而来，就像我的恐惧的写照，我简直不敢细看也不愿陷入这种很不舒服的感觉。正因为如此，当我转身想避开那绞架时，却差一点撞到一个古怪的老太婆。她坐在绞架的一个支柱后面，一边点着头，一边大声地自言自语着，还礼貌地挥手致意。
en: My way lay over Mouter’s Hill, and through an end of a clachan on the braeside among fields.There was a whirr of looms in it went from house to house; bees bummed in the gardens; the neighbours that I saw at the doorsteps talked in a strange tongue; and I found out later that this was Picardy, a village where the French weavers wrought for the Linen Company.Here I got a fresh direction for Pilrig, my destination; and a little beyond, on the wayside, came by a gibbet and two men hanged in chains.They were dipped in tar, as the manner is; the wind span them, the chains clattered, and the birds hung about the uncanny jumping-jacks and cried.The sight coming on me suddenly, like an illustration of my fears, I could scarce be done with examining it and drinking in discomfort.And, as I thus turned and turned about the gibbet, what should I strike on, but a weird old wife, that sat behind a leg of it, and nodded, and talked aloud to herself with becks and courtesies.

zh: “这两个人是谁，大妈？”我指着尸体问道。
en: “Who are these two, mother?”I asked, and pointed to the corpses.

zh: “你面善，必有福！”她喊道，“那是我的两个心肝宝贝，就是我那两个大心肝宝贝，是我亲爱的宝贝啊。”
en: “A blessing on your precious face!” she cried.“Twa joes(1) o’mine: just two o’ my old joes, my hinny dear.”

zh: “他们为什么遭受了绞刑？”我问。
en: “What did they suffer for?” I asked.

zh: “噢，仅仅为了这样的正当理由，”她说，“我早就对他们预言过这样的结局。两个苏格兰先令，别无其他的原因了，两个健康活泼的年轻人就为此而被绞死了！他们从布劳切顿的一个小孩那里拿了这些钱。”
en: “Ou, just for the guid cause,” said she.“Aften I spaed to them the way that it would end.Twa shillin’ Scots: no pickle mair; and there are twa bonny callants hingin’ for ‘t!They took it frae a wean(2) belanged to Brouchton.”

zh: “唉！”我对自己而不是对着那个痴傻的下贱女人说道，“他们就因为那么点小事而变成了这样一副模样？这的确是失去了一切呀。”
en: “Ay!” said I to myself, and not to the daft limmer, “and did they come to such a figure for so poor a business?This is to lose all indeed.”

zh: “把你的手掌给我，亲爱的，”她说，“让我预测一下你的命运。”
en: “Gie’s your loof, (3) hinny,” says she, “and let me spae your weird to ye.”

zh: “不用了，大妈，”我说，“我对自己已经看得够远了。对前头的事看得太远会很怪的。”
en: “No, mother,” said I, “I see far enough the way I am.It’s an unco thing to see too far in front.”

zh: “我在你的血脉里看到，”她说，“有一位漂亮的少女，她有双明亮的眼睛，还有一位衣着华丽的小个子男人和一个戴着扑粉假发的大人物。小伙子啊，那里还有绞架的阴影，就横立在你的道路上。把你的手掌给我，亲爱的，就让老梅伦来好好预测一下你的命运吧。”
en: “I read it in your bree,” she said.“There’s a bonnie lassie that has bricht een, and there’s a wee man in a braw coat, and a big man in a pouthered wig, and there’s the shadow of the wuddy, (4) joe, that lies braid across your path.Gie’s your loof, hinny, and let Auld Merren spae it to ye bonny.”

zh: 这两点猜测恰巧像是指艾伦和詹姆斯·莫尔的女儿，这深深地打击了我。我给她丢了半个便士，赶紧逃离这可怕的女人，而她则继续坐在受绞刑者那晃动的阴影下玩着算命的把戏。
en: The two chance shots that seemed to point at Alan and the daughter of James More struck me hard; and I fled from the eldritch creature, casting her a baubee, which she continued to sit and play with under the moving shadows of the hanged.

zh: 要不是这次遭遇，我沿利斯路堤道而下之行本来会更愉快一些的。老城墙在原野上一路延伸，以前我还从来没有看见过这样精耕细作的农田。此外，我很高兴能走这么远来到宁静的乡下。但是绞架下的镣铐声在我头脑中哗哗回响，还有那老巫婆的忧郁以及种种怪样，而且我还想到了那两具死尸，这些都啃噬着我的灵魂。上绞架看来是一桩严重的事情。一个人不论是为了两个苏格兰先令，还是（像斯图尔特先生那样）出于责任感，一旦他被涂上焦油、带上镣铐，而且被绞死了，似乎区别都不大了。戴维·鲍尔弗也可能被绞死，而其他青年有事路过时也会轻看他的，那痴傻的老妇人坐在绞架的一边预言他们的命运，还有清新文雅的少女从旁走过，她们会看向另一边，而且还捂着鼻子。我清清楚楚地看到了她们，她们长着灰色的眼睛，而且她们头上的纱罩颜色也是德拉蒙德风格的。
en: My way down the causeway of Leith Walk would have been more pleasant to me but for this encounter.The old rampart ran among fields, the like of them I had never seen for artfulness of agriculture; I was pleased, besides, to be so far in the still countryside; but the shackles of the gibbet clattered in my head; and the mope and mows of the old witch, and the thought of the dead men, hag-rode my spirits.To hang on a gallows, that seemed a hard case; and whether a man came to hang there for two shillings Scots, or (as Mr. Stewart had it) from the sense of duty, once he was tarred and shackled and hung up, the difference seemed small.There might David Balfour hang, and other lads pass on their errands and think light of him; and old daft limmers sit at a leg-foot and spae their fortunes; and the clean genty maids go by, and look to the other aide, and hold a nose.I saw them plain, and they had grey eyes, and their screens upon their heads were of the Drummed colours.

zh: 正因为如此，当皮尔里格映入我的眼帘时，虽然我的态度仍然相当坚定，但是我的精神却已经极度消沉了。在几片清新细嫩的树林中，一栋宜人的山形墙房子矗立在小路旁边。我走过去的时候，领主的马已经上好鞍具立在门边，而他本人则在书房内。他在书房里种种学术著作和乐器中接见了我，因为他不仅深谙哲学之道，还极富有音乐天赋。他首先非常友善地向我致意，然后在看完兰基勒的信后，他热心地表示他将听从我的安排。
en: I was thus in the poorest of spirits, though still pretty resolved, when I came in view of Pilrig, a pleasant gabled house set by the walkside among some brave young woods.The laird’s horse was standing saddled at the door as I came up, but himself was in the study, where he received me in the midst of learned works and musical instruments, for he was not only a deep philosopher but much of a musician.He greeted me at first pretty well, and when he had read Rankeillor’s letter, placed himself obligingly at my disposal.

zh: “有什么事情？戴维兄弟！”他说，“既然看样子我们是亲戚——我到底能为你做些什么！给普雷斯顿格兰奇捎句话！无疑那很容易做到。但是应该捎句什么话呢？”
en: “And what is it, cousin David!” said he—“since it appears that we are cousins—what is this that I can do for you!A word to Prestongrange!Doubtless that is easily given.But what should be the word?”

zh: “鲍尔弗先生，”我说，“如果我把整件事原原本本地告诉您，我的看法是（也是之前兰基勒的看法）您是不会愿意参与这件事情的。”
en: “Mr. Balfour,” said I, “if I were to tell you my whole story the way it fell out, it’s my opinion (and it was Rankeillor’s before me) that you would be very little made up with it.”

zh: “听你这么说，我感到很抱歉，我的本家亲戚。”他说。
en: “I am sorry to hear this of you, kinsman,” says he.

zh: “我是不该叨扰您的，鲍尔弗先生，”我说，“我既然已经承担此事，也就没有什么让我后悔的，您也不必对我感到抱歉，这只不过是人类共同的弱点而已。‘亚当的第一桩罪，就是缺乏最初的正确判断，以及我全部本性的堕落。’我只能回答这么多，我还希望可以得到指教去何处求助。”我说，因为我从他的神情中断定，如果我熟知《教义问答手册》，他会对我印象更好。“但是在世间诚信方面，我也没有大错误需要自责。我所遭遇的重重困难并非我意愿，（就我所知）也不是我的过错。我的难处在于我已经深陷复杂的政治漩涡之中，而对于这一点可以断定您会乐意不去深究的。”
en: “I must not take that at your hands, Mr. Balfour,” said I; “I have nothing to my charge to make me sorry, or you for me, but just the common infirmities of mankind.‘The guilt of Adam’s first sin, the want of original righteousness, and the corruption of my whole nature,’ so much I must answer for, and I hope I have been taught where to look for help,” I said; for I judged from the look of the man he would think the better of me if I knew my questions. (5)“But in the way of worldly honour I have no great stumble to reproach myself with; and my difficulties have befallen me very much against my will and (by all that I can see) without my fault.My trouble is to have become dipped in a political complication, which it is judged you would be blythe to avoid a knowledge of.”

zh: “那么，很好，戴维先生，”他回答，“看到你和兰基勒描述得完全一样，我很高兴。至于你所说的复杂的政治漩涡，你只不过是要我公正行事罢了。我的书房从来就不会受到怀疑，确实是在被怀疑的领域之外。问题是，”他说，“若是我对此事一无所知的话，我能够很好地帮助你吗？”
en: “Why, very well, Mr. David,” he replied, “I am pleased to see you are all that Rankeillor represented.And for what you say of political complications, you do me no more than justice.It is my study to be beyond suspicion, and indeed outside the field of it.The question is,” says he, “how, if I am to know nothing of the matter, I can very well assist you?”

zh: “那么，先生，”我说，“我建议您给那位大人写封信，就说我是一个出身于通情达理的好家庭的年轻人，而且颇具财力。我相信这两点都是事情的关键。”
en: “Why sir,” said I, “I propose you should write to his lordship, that I am a young man of reasonable good family and of good means: both of which I believe to be the case.”

zh: “我在兰基勒的信上已经看到这句话了，”鲍尔弗先生说，“而且我认为那是一个应对严峻局面的保证。”
en: “I have Rankeillor’s word for it,” said Mr. Balfour, “and I count that a warran-dice against all deadly.”

zh: “对此您还可以加上（如果您相信我说的都是真话），我是一个虔诚的教徒，忠实于乔治国王，而且也受过这样的教育。”我继续说道。
en: “To which you might add (if you will take my word for so much) that I am a good churchman, loyal to King George, and so brought up,” I went on.

zh: “这些都不会对你不利。”鲍尔弗先生说。
en: “None of which will do you any harm,” said Mr. Balfour.

zh: “那么您可以接着说，我是因紧要时刻、事关重大才去找大人的，事关国王陛下和司法管理。”我建议道。
en: “Then you might go on to say that I sought his lordship on a matter of great moment, connected with His Majesty’s service and the administration of justice,” I suggested.

zh: “因为我还没有听说这件事，”那位领主说，“我会觉得自己没有资格这么说。既然已经说出‘紧要时刻’，那么‘时刻’指什么也要说明白。至于其他的，我可以按照你的建议自己去说清楚的。”
en: “As I am not to hear the matter,” says the laird, “I will not take upon myself to qualify its weight.‘Great moment’ therefore falls, and ‘moment’ along with it.For the rest I might express myself much as you propose.”

zh: “那么，先生，”我一边说着，一边用大拇指揉了揉脖子，“接下来我恳切希望您能为我的安全保障作出一点承诺。”
en: “And then, sir,” said I, and rubbed my neck a little with my thumb, “then I would be very desirous if you could slip in a word that might perhaps tell for my protection.”

zh: “安全保障？”他说，“保障你的安全！这种说法有点儿让我沮丧。如果这件事真有这么危险的话，我自认我不大情愿被蒙在鼓里去掺和了。”
en: “Protection?” says he, “for your protection!Here is a phrase that somewhat dampens me.If the matter be so dangerous, I own I would be a little loath to move in it blindfold.”

zh: “我相信我两句话就能够说出关键所在。”我说。
en: “I believe I could indicate in two words where the thing sticks,” said I.

zh: “也许那样最好。”他说。
en: “Perhaps that would be the best,” said he.

zh: “好吧，就是阿平凶杀案一事。”我说。
en: “Well, it’s the Appin murder,” said I.

zh: 他举起双手。“先生！先生！”他叫道。
en: He held up both his hands.“Sirs! sirs!” cried he.

zh: 通过他的面部表情和声音，我觉得我已经失去这个帮手了。
en: I thought by the expression of his face and voice that I had lost my helper.

zh: “让我来解释……”我开始说。
en: “Let me explain...”I began.

zh: “我诚恳地谢谢你，我不想再听此事了，”他说，“我谢绝听到有关此事的更多信息。为了你和兰基勒的名声，或许也有点儿为你本人，我会竭尽所能帮助你。但是我不愿再听有关情况。我首先要明确的责任就是警告你。这趟水深不可测，戴维先生，况且你还年轻。一定要小心，务必三思。”
en: “I thank you kindly, I will hear no more of it,” says he.“I decline in toto to hear more of it.For your name’s sake and Rankeillor’s, and perhaps a little for your own, I will do what I can to help you; but I will hear no more upon the facts.And it is my first clear duty to warn you.These are deep waters, Mr. David, and you are a young man.Be cautious and think twice.”

zh: “应该说我不止是三思了，鲍尔弗先生，”我说，“我再次提醒您注意兰基勒的信，在信里（我希望而且相信）他已经表示赞成我的计划了。”
en: “It is to be supposed I will have thought oftener than that, Mr. Balfour,” said I, “and I will direct your attention again to Rankeillor’s letter, where (I hope and believe) he has registered his approval of that which I design.”

zh: “好，好，”他说，然后再次说道，“好，好！我将竭尽全力帮助你。”他拿出一支笔和纸，坐着思考了一会儿，开始仔细斟酌着写起来。“我猜兰基勒同意你的想法了？”不一会儿，他问道。
en: “Well, well,” said he; and then again, “Well, well!I will do what I can for you.”There with he took a pen and paper, sat a while in thought, and began to write with much consideration.“I understand that Rankeillor approved of what you have in mind?” he asked presently.

zh: “在讨论了一番之后，先生，他吩咐我以上帝的名义勇往直前。”我说。
en: “After some discussion, sir, he bade me to go forward in God’s name,” said I.

zh: “那就是出师之名了。”鲍尔弗先生说，又重新开始写起来。不久，他签了字，重读所写的内容，然后再次转向我。“好了，戴维先生，”他说，“这是一封介绍信，我会不密封就盖印章，就这样开着封交给你，按礼节是这么要求的。但是，由于我是在不知情的情况下写的，所以我将当着你的面读一读，这样你就可以弄清楚这封信最终是否能够保护你。
en: “That is the name to go in,” said Mr. Balfour, and resumed his writing.Presently, he signed, re-read what he had written, and addressed me again.“Now here, Mr. David,” said he, “is a letter of introduction, which I will seal without closing, and give into your hands open, as the form requires.But, since I am acting in the dark, I will just read it to you, so that you may see if it will secure your end—

zh: ‘皮尔里格，1751年8月26日
en: “PILRIG, August 26th, 1751.

zh: 大人，兹向您介绍本人的同宗表亲——肖斯的戴维·鲍尔弗乡绅，一位血统纯正、颇有财富的年轻绅士。此外，他还具备更可贵的优势，就是他曾受过神学教育，而其政治原则也完全符合阁下所望。我虽然没有参与鲍尔弗先生的机密，但是深知他有要事禀告，事关国王陛下和司法管理。而阁下的古道热肠众所周知，故寄望于阁下。我尚需补充一点：这位年轻绅士的一些朋友也知晓并认同其意图，他们充满希翼并焦灼观望事态之成败。’”
en: My Lord, — This is to bring to your notice my namesake and cousin, David Balfour Esquire of Shaws, a young gentleman of unblemished descent and good estate.He has enjoyed, besides, the more valuable advantages of a godly training, and his political principles are all that your lordship can desire.I am not in Mr. Balfour’s confidence, but I understand him to have a matter to declare, touching His Majesty’s service and the administration of justice; purposes for which your Lordship’s zeal is known.I should add that the young gentleman’s intention is known to and approved by some of his friends, who will watch with hopeful anxiety the event of his success or failure.

zh: “因此，”鲍尔弗先生继续说道，“我已经用惯常的溢美之词表态赞同了。你要注意我说的是‘你的一些朋友’。我希望你能够证明我用复数是正确的？”
en: “Whereupon,” continued Mr. Balfour, “I have subscribed myself with the usual compliments.You observe I have said ‘some of your friends’; I hope you can justify my plural?”

zh: “完美至极，先生，我的意图已经不止一个人知晓和认同了，”我说，“而您的信是我全部希望之所在，对此我由衷高兴地向您表示感谢。”
en: “Perfectly, sir; my purpose is known and approved by more than one,” said I.“And your letter, which I take a pleasure to thank you for, is all I could have hoped.”

zh: “我所能做的只有这么多了，”他说，“据我对你打算干涉之事的了解，我只能求上帝保佑这封信能派上用场了。”
en: “It was all I could squeeze out,” said he; “and from what I know of the matter you design to meddle in, I can only pray God that it may prove sufficient.”

zh: （1）心肝宝贝
en: (1) Sweetheart.

zh: （2）小孩
en: (2) Child.

zh: （3）手掌
en: (3) Palm.

zh: （4）绞架
en: (4) Gallows.

zh: （5）教义问答手册
en: (5) My Catechism.

zh: 第四章　检察总长普雷斯顿格兰奇大人
en: CHAPTER IV— LORD ADVOCATE PRESTONGRANGE

zh: 我的同宗招待我吃了一顿饭，他说这是“权尽同宗之谊”，而我认为我最好尽快赶回去。我没有别的想法，只想着要完成下一阶段的事，只想着自己要全力以赴。对于一个像我现在这样处境的人来说，虽然在走近大门时显出一副迟疑不决的样子，但是内心想进去的诱惑力却极其强烈。所以当我来到普雷斯顿格兰奇的府邸，却获悉他已经外出时，我愈发感到失望。那一刻以及随后的几个小时里，我以为那是真的。可是后来我可以肯定检察总长已经回家了，而且就在隔壁房间很愉快地和他的朋友们在一起。也许我来访之事已经被忘却了。要不是因为我一定要立即完成当众声明过的事情，才能良心安宁得以入眠，我好几次都想一走了之。起初我读了读书，因为他们领我去的那个小房间里摆放着各种各样的书籍。但是我担心读书也没什么用。天气转为多云，黄昏比平时来得更早。我所在的房间只有一扇窗户上有孔透光进来，最后我不得不放弃读书这种消遣方式（也仅仅为消遣而已），剩下的时间我只能心情沉重、无聊地等待着。附近一间房里人们的谈话声，古钢琴悠扬的乐声，一度还有一位女士的唱歌声，算是在陪伴我了。
en: My kinsman kept me to a meal, “for the honour of the roof,” he said; and I believe I made the better speed on my return.I had no thought but to be done with the next stage, and have myself fully committed; to a person circumstanced as I was, the appearance of closing a door on hesitation and temptation was itself extremely tempting; and I was the more disappointed, when I came to Prestongrange’s house, to be informed he was abroad.I believe it was true at the moment, and for some hours after; and then I have no doubt the Advocate came home again, and enjoyed himself in a neighbouring chamber among friends, while perhaps the very fact of my arrival was forgotten.I would have gone away a dozen times, only for this strong drawing to have done with my declaration out of hand and be able to lay me down to sleep with a free conscience.At first I read, for the little cabinet where I was left contained a variety of books.But I fear I read with little profit; and the weather falling cloudy, the dusk coming up earlier than usual, and my cabinet being lighted with but a loophole of a window, I was at last obliged to desist from this diversion (such as it was), and pass the rest of my time of waiting in a very burthensome vacuity.The sound of people talking in a near chamber, the pleasant note of a harpsichord, and once the voice of a lady singing, bore me a kind of company.

zh: 我不知道时辰，但是天早就黑了。当小房间的门打开时，借着其背后的灯光，我才发觉一个高个子男人站在门口。我立刻站了起来。
en: I do not know the hour, but the darkness was long come, when the door of the cabinet opened, and I was aware, by the light behind him, of a tall figure of a man upon the threshold.I rose at once.

zh: “有人吗？”他问道,“是谁在那里？”
en: “Is anybody there?” he asked.“Who in that?”

zh: “我是从皮尔里格领主那里带信来给检察总长大人的。”我说。
en: “I am bearer of a letter from the laird of Pilrig to the Lord Advocate,” said I.

zh: “你在这里已经等了很久吗？”
en: “Have you been here long?” he asked.

zh: “我不会贸然地估计有几个钟头了。”我说。
en: “I would not like to hazard an estimate of how many hours,” said I.

zh: “我还是头一遭听人这么说，”他一边回答，一边轻声笑了起来，“那帮小子肯定是把你给忘记了。不过你终究还是赶上趟了，因为我就是普雷斯顿格兰奇。”
en: “It is the first I hear of it,” he replied, with a chuckle.“The lads must have forgotten you.But you are in the bit at last, for I am Prestongrange.”

zh: 这么说着，他就从我面前走过，进了另一个房间，（根据他的示意）我跟了进去。在那里他点亮了一根蜡烛，然后站在办公桌前。这是一个长方形的房间，比例均衡，一排排全部摆放着书籍。角落里微弱闪烁的烛光隐隐照出那人英俊的面容和坚毅的表情。他的脸映着红光，双眼晶莹闪亮。在他坐下之前，我注意到他前后摇晃着。无疑，他刚刚吃过丰盛的晚餐，但是他的思路和语言仍然清晰流畅。
en: So saying, he passed before me into the next room, whither (upon his sign) I followed him, and where he lit a candle and took his place before a business-table.It was a long room, of a good proportion, wholly lined with books.That small spark of light in a corner struck out the man’s handsome person and strong face.He was flushed, his eye watered and sparkled, and before he sat down I observed him to sway back and forth.No doubt, he had been supping liberally; but his mind and tongue were under full control.

zh: “好吧，先生，你请坐，”他说，“让我们先看看皮尔里格的信吧。”
en: “Well, sir, sit ye down,” said he, “and let us see Pilrig’s letter.”

zh: 他先是粗略地浏览了一遍，看到我的姓名时，他抬头看看又低下头，但是我觉得我注意到了他在看最后几句话时注意力倍加集中，而且我敢肯定他看了两遍。在这期间你们可以猜想得到，我的心怦怦地在跳，因为我现在已经破釜沉舟，只能毅然走上战场了。
en: He glanced it through in the beginning carelessly, looking up and bowing when he came to my name; but at the last words I thought I observed his attention to redouble, and I made sure he read them twice.All this while you are to suppose my heart was beating, for I had now crossed my Rubicon and was come fairly on the field of battle.

zh: “我很高兴能与你相识，鲍尔弗先生。”他看完信后说,“让我给你来一杯红葡萄酒吧。”
en: “I am pleased to make your acquaintance, Mr. Balfour,” he said, when he had done.“Let me offer you a glass of claret.”

zh: “谢谢您的好意，大人，我认为这对我不太合适。”我说,“我来这里，正如信中所提到的，是为一些对我来说重要的事情。而且，因为我不太习惯喝酒，所以我有可能很快受到影响。”
en: “Under your favour, my lord, I think it would scarce be fair on me,” said I.“I have come here, as the letter will have mentioned, on a business of some gravity to myself; and, as I am little used with wine, I might be the sooner affected.”

zh: “由你决定好了。”他说,“但是如果你允许的话，我想我就自己来喝这瓶酒。”
en: “You shall be the judge,” said he.“But if you will permit, I believe I will even have the bottle in myself.”

zh: 他按了一个铃，接着一个男仆走了进来，按照所发的信号，带来了红酒和眼镜。
en: He touched a bell, and a footman came, as at a signal, bringing wine and glasses.

zh: “你确定不和我一起喝吗？”检察总长问道,“好，来为我们进一步的友谊干杯！我能用什么方式帮助你？”
en: “You are sure you will not join me?” asked the Advocate.“Well, here is to our better acquaintance!In what way can I serve you?”

zh: “我应该，也许，首先告诉您，大人，我在这里得到了您诚恳热切的招待。”我说。
en: “I should, perhaps, begin by telling you, my lord, that I am here at your own pressing invitation,” said I.

zh: “你只是从某个地方先认识了我吧，”他说，“因为我得承认我觉得在今晚之前我还从来没有听说过你。”
en: “You have the advantage of me somewhere,” said he, “for I profess I think I never heard of you before this evening.”

zh: “对，大人，我的名字对您来说确实很陌生。”我说，“然而您有一段时间曾经非常希望和我相识，而且还公开宣称过这一点。”
en: “Right, my lord; the name is, indeed, new to you,” said I.“And yet you have been for some time extremely wishful to make my acquaintance, and have declared the same in public.”

zh: “我希望你能给我提示一下。”他说，“我可不是丹尼尔。”
en: “I wish you would afford me a clue,” says he.“I am no Daniel.”

zh: “也许可以当做是这么回事，”我说，“如果说我是在开玩笑的话——其实又完全不是在开玩笑——我认为我可以向大人您索取两百英镑。”
en: “It will perhaps serve for such,” said I, “that if I was in a jesting humour—which is far from the case—I believe I might lay a claim on your lordship for two hundred pounds.”

zh: “此话怎讲？”他询问道。
en: “In what sense?” he inquired.

zh: “就算是给我个人提供的酬劳。”我说。
en: “In the sense of rewards offered for my person,” said I.

zh: 他断然将眼镜扔到一边，在椅子上笔直地坐了起来，先前他还是懒洋洋地靠在那里的。“我该如何理解？”他说。
en: He thrust away his glass once and for all, and sat straight up in the chair where he had been previously lolling.“What am I to understand?” said he.

zh: “一个十八岁左右、高大壮实的小伙子，”我引用原话说道，“低地口音、没有胡须。”
en: “A tall strong lad of about eighteen,” I quoted, “speaks like a Lowlander and has no beard.”

zh: “我听出那些话了，”他说，“要是你没有考虑周全，只是到这里来闹着玩的，这些话只可能对你的安全极为不利。”
en: “I recognise those words,” said he, “which, if you have come here with any ill-judged intention of amusing yourself, are like to prove extremely prejudicial to your safety.”

zh: “我的目的正在于此，”我回答说，“这完全跟生死一般重要，而您已经彻底明白我的意思了。我就是那个男孩，格伦努尔被射中时我正在和他说话。”
en: “My purpose in this,” I replied, “is just entirely as serious as life and death, and you have understood me perfectly.I am the boy who was speaking with Glenure when he was shot.”

zh: “（看见你在这里）我只能推测你是来为自己脱罪的。”他说。
en: “I can only suppose (seeing you here) that you claim to be innocent,” said he.

zh: “这个推论很清楚，”我说，“我是对乔治王非常忠诚的臣民，但是如果有什么要责怪我自己的话，那就是我本应该更加谨慎，不走进你的书斋的。”
en: “The inference is clear,” I said.“I am a very loyal subject to King George, but if I had anything to reproach myself with, I would have had more discretion than to walk into your den.”

zh: “那样我会很高兴的，”他说，“鲍尔弗先生，这起恐怖罪行影响极其恶劣，绝不能对其心慈手软。这是血淋淋的教训，惨不忍睹。血已经流向国王陛下和我们整个法律框架的直接对立面,是谁所为他们知道，都是些公然的敌对分子。这一点我非常清楚。我不否认我认为这桩罪行是直接针对国王陛下个人的。”
en: “I am glad of that,” said he.“This horrid crime, Mr. Balfour, is of a dye which cannot permit any clemency.Blood has been barbarously shed.It has been shed in direct opposition to his Majesty and our whole frame of laws, by those who are their known and public oppugnants.I take a very high sense of this.I will not deny that I consider the crime as directly personal to his Majesty.”

zh: “可是很遗憾，大人，”我有点儿冷淡地补充道，“应该是直接针对另一位可能并不为人知的重要人物吧。”
en: “And unfortunately, my lord,” I added, a little drily, “directly personal to another great personage who may be nameless.”

zh: “如果你说这些话还有什么含义的话，我必须告诉你我认为这些话对臣民是不适合的。要是这些话是在公开场合说的，我就会尽我的职责去加以留意了，”他说，“在我看来你还没有意识到你严峻的处境，否则你会更加小心，而不会去用这些藐视司法公正的话语来让你的处境恶化了。司法公正，在这个国家，在鄙人手中，是绝不偏袒任何人的。”
en: “If you mean anything by those words, I must tell you I consider them unfit for a good subject; and were they spoke publicly I should make it my business to take note of them,” said he.“You do not appear to me to recognise the gravity of your situation, or you would be more careful not to pejorate the same by words which glance upon the purity of justice.Justice, in this country, and in my poor hands, is no respecter of persons.”

zh: “您对我的话未免看得过重了，大人，”我说，“我只不过复述了国人的普通言谈而已，在我此番前来的路上到处都可以听到各种不同意见的人在这样议论。”
en: “You give me too great a share in my own speech, my lord,” said I.“I did but repeat the common talk of the country, which I have heard everywhere, and from men of all opinions as I came along.”

zh: “等你更为谨慎的时候，你就会明白这类言谈不宜去听，更不宜去复述，”检察总长说，“不过我认定你是没有恶意的。我们都尊敬的那个贵族在最近于附近发生的残暴行径中受伤了，这是事实，但他地位很高，不会受到诽谤的。阿盖尔公爵——你看我对你可是坦诚相待的——像我一样很关注此事，我们两个人一定会按照司法职责为效忠于国王陛下而行事的。在这个动荡的年代里，我希望所有人在家族怨仇方面都一样手脚干净。但是这件事碰巧的是，一位坎贝尔家族的人尽职牺牲了——难道只有坎贝尔家族的人自愿在这条路上冲锋陷阵？我想说，虽然本人不姓坎贝尔——何况他们那个大家庭的族长（为我们所有人的利益）正好还是现任的高等法院院长，在乡下的每一家小客栈里都有一些思想狭隘的人和心怀不满的人在热切地乱嚼舌头。而我发现连鲍尔弗先生这样的年轻绅士也如此草率轻信，让自己成为他们的应声虫了。”他就像在法庭上一样高谈阔论了一番，而后再次放低声音恢复了绅士的风度。“把所有这一切先放一边，”他说，“现在的问题是，我应该知道我要为你做些什么。”
en: “When you are come to more discretion you will understand such talk in not to be listened to, how much less repeated,” says the Advocate.“But I acquit you of an ill intention.That nobleman, whom we all honour, and who has indeed been wounded in a near place by the late barbarity, sits too high to be reached by these aspersions.The Duke of Argyle—you see that I deal plainly with you—takes it to heart as I do, and as we are both bound to do by our judicial functions and the service of his Majesty; and I could wish that all hands, in this ill age, were equally clean of family rancour.But from the accident that this is a Campbell who has fallen martyr to his duty—as who else but the Campbells have ever put themselves foremost on that path?I may say it, who am no Campbell—and that the chief of that great house happens (for all our advantages) to be the present head of the College of Justice, small minds and disaffected tongues are set agog in every changehouse in the country; and I find a young gentleman like Mr. Balfour so ill-advised as to make himself their echo.”So much he spoke with a very oratorical delivery, as if in court, and then declined again upon the manner of a gentleman.“All this apart,” said he.“It now remains that I should learn what I am to do with you.”

zh: “我却一直认为，应该是我聆听大人您的指教。”我说。
en: “I had thought it was rather I that should learn the same from your lordship,” said I.

zh: “呃，的确，”检察总长说，“可是，你看，你到我这里来是受到了大力推荐的。这封信上有个非常忠诚的辉格党人的签名。”他说，并且从桌上把信拿起来示意了一下。“而且——超越司法之外，鲍尔弗先生——总还会有些调整的可能性。我告诉你，我预先告诉你，你要更加注意保护自己，你的命运掌握在我一个人的手里。在这样的事情上（诚惶诚恐地说）我比国王陛下更有权力。要是你能让我高兴——当然是让我的良心感到满意——就我们的这次会面而言，我跟你保证，这事就你知我知。”
en: “Ay, true,” says the Advocate.“But, you see, you come to me well recommended.There is a good honest Whig name to this letter,” says he, picking it up a moment from the table.“And—extra-judicially, Mr, Balfour—there is always the possibility of some arrangement, I tell you, and I tell you beforehand that you may be the more upon your guard, your fate lies with me singly.In such a matter (be it said with reverence) I am more powerful than the King’s Majesty; and should you please me—and of course satisfy my conscience—in what remains to be held of our interview, I tell you it may remain between ourselves.”

zh: “什么意思？”我问。
en: “Meaning how?” I asked.

zh: “嗯，我的意思是这样的，鲍尔弗先生，”他说，“如果你让我满意，则无人会知晓你到过我的住所，你可能也注意到了我甚至连办事员都没有叫过来。”
en: “Why, I mean it thus, Mr. Balfour,” said he, “that if you give satisfaction, no soul need know so much as that you visited my house; and you may observe that I do not even call my clerk.”

zh: 我明白他在想什么了。“我想没有必要告诉任何人我此次的造访，”我说，“虽然我还不清楚我此行具体会有什么样的收获。我对此丝豪不感到惭愧。”
en: I saw what way he was driving.“I suppose it is needless anyone should be informed upon my visit,” said I, “though the precise nature of my gains by that I cannot see.I am not at all ashamed of coming here.”

zh: “而且没理由感到惭愧。”他带着鼓励的语气说，“（只要你小心）也不用担心有什么后果。”
en: “And have no cause to be,” says he, encouragingly.“Nor yet (if you are careful) to fear the consequences.”

zh: “大人，”我说，“在您的指教下说话，我不会那么容易被吓到的。”
en: “My lord,” said I, “speaking under your correction, I am not very easy to be frightened.”

zh: “而我肯定也不想吓唬你。”他说，“但是到了审讯的时候，我得警告你，除了回答我问你的问题，其他什么也别说。那有可能和你的安全息息相关。我有很大的决定权，这是真的，但那是有限度的。”
en: “And I am sure I do not seek to frighten you,” says he.“But to the interrogation; and let me warn you to volunteer nothing beyond the questions I shall ask you.It may consist very immediately with your safety.I have a great discretion, it is true, but there are bounds to it.”

zh: “我会尽量遵从大人您的忠告。”我说。
en: “I shall try to follow your lordship’s advice,” said I.

zh: 他在桌上铺开一张纸，写了一个标题。“顺便提一句，看来事件发生时你在现场，在莱特莫的树林里，就在枪击命案发生的那一刻，”他开始说，“这是巧合吗？”
en: He spread a sheet of paper on the table and wrote a heading.“It appears you were present, by the way, in the wood of Lettermore at the moment of the fatal shot,” he began.“Was this by accident?”

zh: “是巧合。”我说。
en: “By accident,” said I.

zh: “你怎么会和科林·坎贝尔在交谈呢？”他问。
en: “How came you in speech with Colin Campbell?” he asked.

zh: “我在向他打听去奥查恩的路。”我回答。
en: “I was inquiring my way of him to Aucharn,” I replied.

zh: 我注意到他没有记录这个回答。
en: I observed he did not write this answer down.

zh: “嗯，真的，”他说“我忘记这一点了。那么你知道吗，鲍尔弗先生？如果我是你，我就会尽可能少扯和这些斯图尔特家族的人之间的关系。最后可能会把我们的事情给搞复杂了。目前而言，我认为这些事情不是很重要。”
en: “H’m, true,” said he, “I had forgotten that.And do you know, Mr. Balfour, I would dwell, if I were you, as little as might be on your relations with these Stewarts.It might be found to complicate our business.I am not yet inclined to regard these matters as essential.”

zh: “我本来以为，大人，在这样的案子中所有的事实都同样重要。”我说。
en: “I had thought, my lord, that all points of fact were equally material in such a case,” said I.

zh: “你忘记了我们现在正在审问这些斯图尔特人，”他颇耐人寻味地回答道，“如果我们开始审问你，情形就会大不相同了。那我就会细细盘问这些我现在情愿略过不问的问题了。再继续：我在这份芒戈·坎贝尔的预审记录里看到你立刻跑上了山坡。为什么那么做？”
en: “You forget we are now trying these Stewarts,” he replied, with great significance.“If we should ever come to be trying you, it will be very different; and I shall press these very questions that I am now willing to glide upon.But to resume: I have it here in Mr. Mungo Campbell’s precognition that you ran immediately up the brae.How came that?”

zh: “不是立刻，大人，而是因为我看见了那个凶手。”
en: “Not immediately, my lord, and the cause was my seeing of the murderer.”

zh: “那么，你看见他了？”
en: “You saw him, then?”

zh: “就像我看见大人您一样清楚，尽管没有这么近。”
en: “As plain as I see your lordship, though not so near hand.”

zh: “你认识他吗？”
en: “You know him?”

zh: “再次碰到我应该认得出他。”
en: “I should know him again.”

zh: “你在追赶时没有那么幸运，所以，没有追上他？”
en: “In your pursuit you were not so fortunate, then, as to overtake him?”

zh: “我没有追上。”
en: “I was not.”

zh: “他是独自一个人吗？”
en: “Was he alone?”

zh: “他是独自一个人。”
en: “He was alone.”

zh: “附近再也没有别的人了？”
en: “There was no one else in that neighbourhood?”

zh: “艾伦·布雷克·斯图尔特离得不远，在一片小树林里。”
en: “Alan Breck Stewart was not far off, in a piece of a wood.”

zh: 检察总长放下了笔。“我觉得我们的意图有分歧，”他说，“你会发现这样只会证实你把自己耍了一把。”
en: The Advocate laid his pen down.“I think we are playing at cross purposes,” said he, “which you will find to prove a very ill amusement for yourself.”

zh: “我满足于能听从大人您的建议，只回答所问到的问题。”我说。
en: “I content myself with following your lordship’s advice, and answering what I am asked,” said I.

zh: “要明智地及时替自己考虑考虑，”他说，“我对你最为担忧关切，而你似乎对此并不领情，那么这一切（除非你更加小心）最终可能会徒劳无益的。
en: “Be so wise as to bethink yourself in time,” said he, “I use you with the most anxious tenderness, which you scarce seem to appreciate, and which (unless you be more careful) may prove to be in vain.”
