en: It was likely between one and two; the moon (as I have said) was down; a strongish wind, carrying a heavy wrack of cloud, had set in suddenly from the west; and we began our movement in as black a night as ever a fugitive or a murderer wanted.The whiteness of the path guided us into the sleeping town of Broughton, thence through Picardy, and beside my old acquaintance the gibbet of the two thieves.A little beyond we made a useful beacon, which was a light in an upper window of Lochend.Steering by this, but a good deal at random, and with some trampling of the harvest, and stumbling and falling down upon the banks, we made our way across country, and won forth at last upon the linky, boggy muirland that they call the Figgate Whins.Here, under a bush of whin, we lay down the remainder of that night and slumbered.

zh: 大约五点，黎明唤醒了我们。那是一个美丽的早晨，强劲的西风依然猛烈地吹着，但是所有的云块都已经被吹向了欧洲大陆。 艾伦已经坐起来自顾自地在微笑着。自打我们分开后，这还是我第一次看清我的朋友，我愉快地抬头看着他。他的背上依旧披着那件长长的大衣，不过（新的东西就是）他现在穿着一双过膝的针织长靴袜。毋庸置疑这些是为了进行伪装，但是，因为那天看起来很暖和，所以他那副样子非常不合时宜。
en: The day called us about five.A beautiful morning it was, the high westerly wind still blowing strong, but the clouds all blown away to Europe.Alan was already sitting up and smiling to himself.It was my first sight of my friend since we were parted, and I looked upon him with enjoyment.He had still the same big great-coat on his back; but (what was new) he had now a pair of knitted boot-hose drawn above the knee.Doubtless these were intended for disguise; but, as the day promised to be warm, he made a most unseasonable figure.

zh: “好吧，戴维，”他说，“难道这不是一个美好的早晨吗？这正是我们应该探路的好日子。 和在干草堆里面相比，已经有很大的变化了。你还在那里呼呼大睡的时候，我就已经完成了一件我也许很少做的事情。”
en: “Well, Davie,” said he, “is this no a bonny morning?Here is a day that looks the way that a day ought to.This is a great change of it from the belly of my haystack; and while you were there sottering and sleeping I have done a thing that maybe I do very seldom.”

zh: “那是什么事呢？”我说。
en: “And what was that?” said I.

zh: “哦，只不过做了祷告。”他说。
en: “O, just said my prayers,” said he.

zh: “按你一贯称呼的，我的那些绅士现在在哪里？”我问。
en: “And where are my gentry, as ye call them?” I asked.

zh: “天知道呀，”他说，“早晚我们肯定有机会见到他们。戴维，抬起脚来！出发，命运又一次开始了！而我们要做的就像是愉快地散一次步。”
en: “Gude kens,” says he; “and the short and the long of it is that we must take our chance of them.Up with your foot-soles, Davie!Forth, Fortune, once again of it!And a bonny walk we are like to have.”

zh: 于是我们沿着海滩向东走去，朝那个方向在埃斯克口附近，一片片盐场在冒着烟。毫无疑问，阳光一如既往地在亚瑟王王座和碧绿的彭特兰湾上闪烁着，那天艾伦很开心，好像也愿意呆在荨麻丛中。
en: So we went east by the beach of the sea, towards where the salt-pans were smoking in by the Esk mouth.No doubt there was a by-ordinary bonny blink of morning sun on Arthur’s Seat and the green Pentlands; and the pleasantness of the day appeared to set Alan among nettles.

zh: “我觉得自己像个傻瓜，”他说，“在这么好的日子却要离开苏格兰。这景致已经深印在我脑海中，我也许最好还是留在这里欣赏欣赏。”
en: “I feel like a gomeral,” says he, “to be leaving Scotland on a day like this.It sticks in my head; I would maybe like it better to stay here and hing.”

zh: “唉，但是你不会那么做的，艾伦。”我说。
en: “Ay, but ye wouldnae, Alan,” said I.

zh: “是不会，不过法国也是个好地方，”他解释道，“但还是有点儿不一样。我相信法国更漂亮，可惜它不是苏格兰。在那里的时候，我很喜欢它，伙计。可是我也有点儿厌烦苏格兰的草地和苏格兰的泥炭味了。”
en: “No, but what France is a good place too,” he explained; “but it’s some way no the same.It’s brawer I believe, but it’s no Scotland.I like it fine when I’m there, man; yet I kind of weary for Scots divots and the Scots peat-reek.”

zh: “如果那就是你要抱怨的所有事情，艾伦，那实在不算是什么大事。”我说。
en: “If that’s all you have to complain of, Alan, it’s no such great affair,” said I.

zh: “不论抱怨的是什么，那总让我不舒服，”他说，“而我刚刚才从那该死的干草堆里爬出来。”
en: “And it sets me ill to be complaining, whatever,” said he, “and me but new out of yon deil’s haystack.”

zh: “这么说你特别厌烦你的干草堆？”我问。
en: “And so you were unco weary of your haystack?” I asked.

zh: “无法形容有多厌烦。”他说，“准确地说，我并不是那么容易沮丧的人，但是我更喜欢头顶清澈的天空。我就像那个老布莱克·道格拉斯（难道不是吗？），喜欢听云雀高歌而不愿听老鼠吱吱叫。而那个地方，你要知道，戴维——那可是个非常适合藏身的地方，因为我随时都可以使用——那是一个从黎明到黄昏都很阴暗的深坑。那些天（或者夜晚，因为我哪里分得清楚是白天还是夜晚？）对我来说就像是漫漫冬日一样漫长。”
en: “Weary’s nae word for it,” said he.“I’m not just precisely a man that’s easily cast down; but I do better with caller air and the lift above my head.I’m like the auld Black Douglas (wasnae’t?) that likit better to hear the laverock sing than the mouse cheep.And yon place, ye see, Davie—whilk was a very suitable place to hide in, as I’m free to own—was pit mirk from dawn to gloaming.There were days (or nights, for how would I tell one from other?) that seemed to me as long as a long winter.”

zh: “那你怎么知道去赴约的时间？”我问。
en: “How did you know the hour to bide your tryst?” I asked.

zh: “大约晚上十一点钟的时候，那位主人给我带来肉和一点白兰地酒，还有一根蜡烛，可以吃饭的时候用。”他说，“因此，我狼吞虎咽一番后，就到赶往树林的时间了。我躺在那里，心烦而痛苦地等着你，戴维，”他说，并把手搭在我的肩上，“估摸着大约到什么时候就等了有两个小时——除非查利·斯图尔特来告诉我时间——然后又回到这该死的干草堆里。唉，真是度日如年啊，感谢主，我历经艰辛都熬过来了！”
en: “The goodman brought me my meat and a drop brandy, and a candle-dowp to eat it by, about eleeven,” said he.“So, when I had swallowed a bit, it would he time to be getting to the wood.There I lay and wearied for ye sore, Davie,” says he, laying his hand on my shoulder “and guessed when the two hours would be about by—unless Charlie Stewart would come and tell me on his watch—and then back to the dooms haystack.Na, it was a driech employ, and praise the Lord that I have warstled through with it!”

zh: “你是靠什么熬过来的？”我问。
en: “What did you do with yourself?” I asked.

zh: “信念，”他说，“这是我能拥有的最好的事情！有时侯我就玩玩手指关节。我特别会玩手指关节，不过那只是一个没人羡慕的可怜把戏而已。有时候我会编编歌曲。”
en: “Faith,” said he, “the best I could!Whiles I played at the knucklebones.I’m an extraordinar good hand at the knucklebones, but it’s a poor piece of business playing with naebody to admire ye.And whiles I would make songs.”

zh: “那些歌曲都是关于什么的？”我说。
en: “What were they about?” says I.

zh: “哦，关于鹿和石楠花的，”他说，“还有关于很久以前那些古代老部落首领的，再有就是一般歌曲所唱的内容了。然后，有时候我会假想我有一套风笛，而且我还在演奏呢。我吹奏一些壮美的曲调，我认为我吹得棒极了，我发誓有时候我都能听到观众的尖叫声！不过最重要的是曲子还演奏完了。”
en: “O, about the deer and the heather,” says he, “and about the ancient old chiefs that are all by with it lang syne, and just about what songs are about in general.And then whiles I would make believe I had a set of pipes and I was playing.I played some grand springs, and I thought I played them awful bonny; I vow whiles that I could hear the squeal of them!But the great affair is that it’s done with.”

zh: 之后，他要我再次讲述我的冒险经历，他也再次完整地听了一遍，听得更加细致而且特别赞许，时不时发誓说我是“一个奇特的少年俊杰”。
en: With that he carried me again to my adventures, which he heard all over again with more particularity, and extraordinary approval, swearing at intervals that I was “a queer character of a callant.”

zh: “所以你害怕西蒙·弗雷泽了？”他曾问道。
en: “So ye were frich’ened of Sim Fraser?” he asked once.

zh: “我当时确实害怕！”我叫道。
en: “In troth was I!” cried I.

zh: “我也一样会害怕的，戴维，”他说，“那的确是个可怕的家伙。不过也该说句公道话才合适。我可以告诉你他在战场上可是一个非常值得尊敬的人物。”
en: “So would I have been, Davie,” said he.“And that is indeed a driedful man.But it is only proper to give the deil his due: and I can tell you he is a most respectable person on the field of war.”

zh: “他有那么勇猛吗？”我问。
en: “Is he so brave?” I asked.

zh: “勇猛！”他说，“他就像我的钢刀一样勇猛。”
en: “Brave!” said he.“He is as brave as my steel sword.”

zh: 听说我决斗的事，他勃然大怒了。
en: The story of my duel set him beside himself.

zh: “想想那一点！”他叫道，“在科里纳基我曾教过你击剑的窍门。居然三次——三次被缴械！ 曾经教过你都是我人格上的一种耻辱！现在，站起来，拔出你的武器。在你能为你自己和我增添更多荣誉之前，你一步也别想跨出路上的这块地方。”
en: “To think of that!” he cried.“I showed ye the trick in Corrynakiegh too.And three times—three times disarmed!It’s a disgrace upon my character that learned ye!Here, stand up, out with your airn; ye shall walk no step beyond this place upon the road till ye can do yoursel’ and me mair credit.”

zh: “艾伦，”我说，“这简直是愚蠢之极。现在没有时间来上击剑课。”
en: “Alan,” said I, “this is midsummer madness.Here is no time for fencing lessons.”

zh: “我不能否认那一点，”他承认道，“但是三次呀，伙计！你就像个稻草人一样站在那里，然后像个兜着尿片的小狗跑去拾自己的剑！戴维，这个叫邓肯斯比的家伙肯定非比寻常！ 他绝对技艺超群。我要是有时间的话，我会立马回去亲自和他战一回合。那家伙一定是个宪兵军官。”
en: “I cannae well say no to that,” he admitted.“But three times, man!And you standing there like a straw bogle and rinning to fetch your ain sword like a doggie with a pocket-napkin!David, this man Duncansby must be something altogether by-ordinar!He maun be extraordinar skilly.If I had the time, I would gang straight back and try a turn at him mysel’.The man must be a provost.”

zh: “你这个糊涂的家伙，”我说，“你忘记了，那只是因为对手是我。”
en: “You silly fellow,” said I, “you forget it was just me.”

zh: “没忘记，”他说，“可是三次呀！”
en: “Na,” said he, “but three times!”

zh: “你自己知道的，我的确没那能耐。”我叫道。
en: “When ye ken yourself that I am fair incompetent,” I cried.

zh: “好吧，可是我还从来没有听人说过这等事情呢。”他说。
en: “Well, I never heard tell the equal of it,” said he.

zh: “我向你保证一件事，艾伦。”我说，“下一次我们再相聚的时候，我会学得更好。你不会继续承受一个不会击剑的朋友带给你的耻辱。”
en: “I promise you the one thing, Alan,” said I.“The next time that we forgather, I’ll be better learned.You shall not continue to bear the disgrace of a friend that cannot strike.”

zh: “唉，下一次！”他说，“那要到什么时候呢，嗯？”
en: “Ay, the next time!” says he.“And when will that be, I would like to ken?”

zh: “好吧，艾伦，关于那一点我也已经有些想法了，”我说，“我的计划是这样的。我的想法就是去当一名律师。”
en: “Well, Alan, I have had some thoughts of that, too,” said I; “and my plan is this.It’s my opinion to be called an advocate.”

zh: “那可是一种让人厌烦的行业，戴维，”艾伦说，“宁可去当个流氓都好一些。你去穿皇家军人的外套都胜过干那一行。”
en: “That’s but a weary trade, Davie,” says Alan, “and rather a blagyard one forby.Ye would be better in a king’s coat than that.”

zh: “但是毫无疑问那种方式会让我们再次相遇。”我叫道，“不过当你穿上法王路易的军外套，而我却穿上英王乔治的军外套时，我们将会有一场别致的会面。”
en: “And no doubt that would be the way to have us meet,” cried I.“But as you’ll be in King Lewie’s coat, and I’ll be in King Geordie’s, we’ll have a dainty meeting of it.”

zh: “那倒是有一些道理。”他承认道。
en: “There’s some sense in that,” he admitted

zh: “那么，就当一名律师，也只能这样。”我继续说道，“我认为对一个三次被缴械的绅士而言，这个行当更加适合。不过这件事的妙处在这一点：学习那种专业最好的学院之一就是荷兰的莱登学院——我的同族亲戚皮尔里格曾在那所学院学习过。现在，你怎么说，艾伦？难道一个皇家艾科塞兹军官学校的学生就不能请假，溜过边界，去申请当一名莱登的大学生？”
en: “An advocate, then, it’ll have to be,” I continued, “and I think it a more suitable trade for a gentleman that was three times disarmed.But the beauty of the thing is this: that one of the best colleges for that kind of learning—and the one where my kinsman, Pilrig, made his studies—is the college of Leyden in Holland.Now, what say you, Alan?Could not a cadet of Royal Ecossais get a furlough, slip over the marches, and call in upon a Leyden student?”

zh: “好吧，我认为他能！”他叫道，“你看，我深受我的上校德拉蒙德·梅尔福特伯爵的宠信。而且更重要的是我有一位堂兄弟是苏格兰—荷兰军团的陆军中校。我要告个假去看望霍尔基特的斯图尔特中校，这可是再合适不过了。而梅尔福特大人是那种做事非常细致严谨的人，像恺撒那样会写书，能从我的叙述中有所收获，他无疑会很高兴的。”
en: “Well, and I would think he could!” cried he.“Ye see, I stand well in with my colonel, Count Drummond-Melfort; and, what’s mair to the purpose I have a cousin of mine lieutenant-colonel in a regiment of the Scots-Dutch.Naething could be mair proper than what I would get a leave to see Lieutenant-Colonel Stewart of Halkett’s.And Lord Melfort, who is a very scienteefic kind of a man, and writes books like Caesar, would be doubtless very pleased to have the advantage of my observes.”

zh: “那么，梅尔福特大人是作家吗？”我问道，因为正像艾伦对军人很崇拜一样，我更多地仰慕著书立说的绅士。
en: “Is Lord Meloort an author, then?”I asked, for much as Alan thought of soldiers, I thought more of the gentry that write books.

zh: “正是一位作家，戴维。”他说，“人们会认为一位上校会有更适合他关注的事情。但是把那编成歌曲，我又能说什么呢？”
en: “The very same, Davie,” said he.“One would think a colonel would have something better to attend to.But what can I say that make songs?”

zh: “好吧，那么，”我说，“剩下的事就是把你在法国的通信地址留给我，我一到莱登就会把我的地址寄给你。”
en: “Well, then,” said I, “it only remains you should give me an address to write you at in France; and as soon as I am got to Leyden I will send you mine.”

zh: “最好是由我的族长把信转给我，”他说，“阿德希尔的查尔斯·斯图尔特先生，住在法国岛屿上的梅隆镇。也许要很长时间，也许只要很短的时间，不过信最终都会送到我的手上。”
en: “The best will be to write me in the care of my chieftain,” said he, “Charles Stewart, of Ardsheil, Esquire, at the town of Melons, in the Isle of France.It might take long, or it might take short, but it would aye get to my hands at the last of it.”

zh: 早餐我们在马瑟尔堡吃了黑线鳕鱼，在那里听艾伦大谈特谈让我感到很开心。在这温暖的早晨，他的长大衣和长靴袜特别打眼，也许是种暗示，说明他见多识广。但是艾伦讲话就像在谈生意，或者我应该说，就好像乐在其中。他忙着向房子的女主人夸赞黑线鳕鱼的美味。之后剩余的所有时间，他都在和女主人谈论他的胃受寒不适，表情严肃地叙述着种种症状和遭罪的样子，并且饶有兴趣地听她回答时所提供的那些老婆婆的治疗方法。
en: We had a haddock to our breakfast in Musselburgh, where it amused me vastly to hear Alan.His great-coat and boot-hose were extremely remarkable this warm morning, and perhaps some hint of an explanation had been wise; but Alan went into that matter like a business, or I should rather say, like a diversion.He engaged the goodwife of the house with some compliments upon the rizzoring of our haddocks; and the whole of the rest of our stay held her in talk about a cold he had taken on his stomach, gravely relating all manner of symptoms and sufferings, and hearing with a vast show of interest all the old wives’ remedies she could supply him with in return.

zh: 在来自爱丁堡的第一辆九便士马车到来之前，我们就离开了马瑟尔堡，因为（如艾伦所说）那样我们可能避免一场遭遇战。虽然风依然很强劲，但是天气温和，阳光灿烂，而艾伦遭的罪相应地也就更大了。他拉我离开普雷斯顿潘斯来到格拉德斯莫的战场，在那里他对那场战役的各个阶段长篇大论了一番。随后，迈着他一贯的那种轻快步子，我们向科肯齐前进了。虽然人们还在卡德尔夫人的作坊里制造运青鱼的车，但是科肯齐似乎是一个如荒漠般正在衰败的小镇，大约一半的房子都是废墟。不过酒店还算干净，而艾伦现在兴致正高，肯定要好好享受一瓶麦芽酒，然后会继续向一位新的幸运者讲述他胃寒不适的老故事，只不过现在其症状却完全不一样了。
en: We left Musselburgh before the first ninepenny coach was due from Edinburgh for (as Alan said) that was a rencounter we might very well avoid.The wind although still high, was very mild, the sun shone strong, and Alan began to suffer in proportion.From Prestonpans he had me aside to the field of Gladsmuir, where he exerted himself a great deal more than needful to describe the stages of the battle.Thence, at his old round pace, we travelled to Cockenzie.Though they were building herring-busses there at Mrs. Cadell’s, it seemed a desert-like, back-going town, about half full of ruined houses; but the ale-house was clean, and Alan, who was now in a glowing heat, must indulge himself with a bottle of ale, and carry on to the new luckie with the old story of the cold upon his stomach, only now the symptoms were all different.

zh: 我坐在那里听着，然后突然想起我几乎没有听到他向任何一位女人说过三句正经话，他总是在开她们玩笑，在揶揄并私下里嘲笑她们，而且他对这一类事情特别热衷和有兴趣。当那女主人（碰巧）被叫走后，我向他说起我对他有些这样的印象。
en: I sat listening; and it came in my mind that I had scarce ever heard him address three serious words to any woman, but he was always drolling and fleering and making a private mock of them, and yet brought to that business a remarkable degree of energy and interest.Something to this effect I remarked to him, when the good-wife (as chanced) was called away.

zh: “你想要什么？”他说，“一个男人和女性在一起的时候就应该表现出他最佳的一面，应该讲一点儿故事来哄她们开心，这些可怜的乖乖！这是你应该学会关注的，戴维。你应该掌握这些原则，这就像是一门手艺。 要知道，如果是一个年轻女子或者是一个美女，她是绝不会听我来谈论我的胃的，戴维。可是因为她们年纪太大无法再去寻找情人了，所以她们才会声称自己懂药理。为什么？我怎么知道的？我想，上帝就是这么造她们的。但是我认为一个男人如果连这一点都没有注意到，那他真是一个傻瓜。”
en: “What do ye want?” says he.“A man should aye put his best foot forrit with the womankind; he should aye give them a bit of a story to divert them, the poor lambs!It’s what ye should learn to attend to, David; ye should get the principles, it’s like a trade.Now, if this had been a young lassie, or onyways bonnie, she would never have heard tell of my stomach, Davie.But aince they’re too old to be seeking joes, they a’ set up to be apotecaries.Why?What do I ken?They’ll be just the way God made them, I suppose.But I think a man would be a gomeral that didnae give his attention to the same.”

zh: 这时，那位幸运的妇人回来了，他好像迫不及待地就转身离开我去重续他们之前的谈话了。 那位夫人先从艾伦的胃谈起，随后说到她自己在阿伯莱迪的一位好兄弟的病例，她絮絮叨叨地描述了那个人最后生病和死亡的情形。有时说得只是很乏味，有时则说得既乏味又可怕，因为她说起来还津津有味的。结果，我就深深陷入沉思之中，朝前面看着窗外的路，但对所看到的东西却几乎没有印象。不久，如果有人一直在看着我的话，他们可能就看到我起身了。
en: And here, the luckie coming back, he turned from me as if with impatience to renew their former conversation.The lady had branched some while before from Alan’s stomach to the case of a goodbrother of her own in Aberlady, whose last sickness and demise she was describing at extraordinary length.Sometimes it was merely dull, sometimes both dull and awful, for she talked with unction.The upshot was that I fell in a deep muse, looking forth of the window on the road, and scarce marking what I saw.Presently had any been looking they might have seen me to start.

zh: “我们把他的脚热敷了一下，”那女主人在说，“在他的腹部放了一块热石头，然后我们给他弄了些牛膝草和薄荷水，还在房里准备了上好的、干净的硫磺香液……”
en: “We pit a fomentation to his feet,” the good-wife was saying, “and a het stane to his wame, and we gied him hyssop and water of pennyroyal, and fine, clean balsam of sulphur for the hoast...”

zh: “先生，”我轻声插话说道，“我有一位朋友从房子旁边走过去了。”
en: “Sir,” says I, cutting very quietly in, “there’s a friend of mine gone by the house.”

zh: “你看见了？”艾伦回答道，好像这只是一桩小事。然后他说：“你刚才在说什么，夫人？”于是那令人厌烦的妇人又接着说了下去。
en: “Is that e’en sae?” replies Alan, as though it were a thing of small account.And then, “Ye were saying, mem?” says he; and the wearyful wife went on.

zh: 然而，不久他就给了她一枚两先令六便士的硬币，她必须到前面去找零钱。
en: Presently, however, he paid her with a half-crown piece, and she must go forth after the change.

zh: “是那个红头发的人吗？”艾伦问。
en: “Was it him with the red head?” asked Alan.

zh: “你说对了。”我说。
en: “Ye have it,” said I.

zh: “我在树林里是怎么跟你说的？”他叫道，“不过很奇怪他居然也会现身此处！他是藏在那条小巷里吗？”
en: “What did I tell you in the wood?” he cried.“And yet it’s strange he should be here too!Was he his lane?”

zh: “他藏身的小巷我可以看得到。”我说。
en: “His lee-lane for what I could see,” said I.

zh: “他身边有同伙吗？”他问道。
en: “Did he gang by?” he asked.

zh: “直看过去，”我说，“既不要朝右看也不要朝左看。”
en: “Straight by,” said I, “and looked neither to the right nor left.”

zh: “那就更奇怪了，”艾伦说，“我牢牢记住了，戴维，我们该动身了。可是去哪里呢？鬼才知道！这就像过去的日子清晰地再现了。”他叫道。
en: “And that’s queerer yet,” said Alan.“It sticks in my mind, Davie, that we should be stirring.But where to?—deil hae’t!This is like old days fairly,” cries he.

zh: “不过有一点大不相同了，”我说，“那就是现在我们的口袋里有钱了。”
en: “There is one big differ, though,” said I, “that now we have money in our pockets.”

zh: “另外还有一点大不相同，鲍尔弗先生，”他说，“就是现在我们身后有一群狗在跟着我们。他们嗅着气味，他们紧追不舍，戴维。这件事很麻烦，真见鬼了。”然后他坐在那里苦苦思索，他脸上的那副神情我非常熟悉。
en: “And another big differ, Mr. Balfour,” says he, “that now we have dogs at our tail.They’re on the scent; they’re in full cry, David.It’s a bad business and be damned to it.”And he sat thinking hard with a look of his that I knew well.

zh: “我正想说呢，幸运的夫人，”当那个女主人返回时，他说道，“你这家小酒馆后面有路出去吗？”
en: “I’m saying, Luckie,” says he, when the goodwife returned, “have ye a back road out of this change house?”

zh: 她告诉他有路出去，并告诉他小路会通向何方。
en: She told him there was and where it led to.

zh: “那么，先生，”他对我说，“我想这对我们来说会是一条最短的路。我在这里向你告别了，美丽的夫人，我永远也不会忘记你这里的肉桂水酒。”
en: “Then, sir,” says he to me, “I think that will be the shortest road for us.And here’s good-bye to ye, my braw woman; and I’ll no forget thon of the cinnamon water.”

zh: 我们从那妇人放蔬菜的院子走出，然后沿一条田间小道向上而去。艾伦警觉地环顾四周，确认我们是在乡间的一小片空洼地，已超出了追兵的视线，就坐了下来。
en: We went out by way of the woman’s kale yard, and up a lane among fields.Alan looked sharply to all sides, and seeing we were in a little hollow place of the country, out of view of men, sat down.

zh: “现在要开一个战时会议，戴维。”他说，“但是首先，给你上一点儿课。假设之前我像你一样，那老太太会怎么看待我们两个！只知道我们从后门出去而已。而她现在会想到什么？一位优秀、快活、待人友好、身体羸弱的男子，遭受着胃病的折磨，可怜的人啊！而且还真心同情她那位好兄弟。哦，伙计呀，戴维，学着掌握一些智慧吧！”
en: “Now for a council of war, Davie,” said he.“But first of all, a bit lesson to ye.Suppose that I had been like you, what would yon old wife have minded of the pair of us!Just that we had gone out by the back gate.And what does she mind now?A fine, canty, friendly, cracky man, that suffered with the stomach, poor body! and was real ta’en up about the goodbrother.O man, David, try and learn to have some kind of intelligence!”

zh: “我会努力学的，艾伦。”我说。
en: “I’ll try, Alan,” said I.

zh: “那么现在就来谈谈那个红头发的家伙，”他说，“他跑得快还是慢？”“介于两者之间，不快也不慢吧。”我说。
en: “And now for him of the red head,” says he; “was he gaun fast or slow?”“Betwixt and between,” said I.

zh: “这个家伙不是那种走路急匆匆的吧？”他问。
en: “No kind of a hurry about the man?” he asked.

zh: “从来没有一丝那样的迹象。”我说。
en: “Never a sign of it,” said I.

zh: “嗯！”艾伦说，“看起来很奇怪。今天早晨在温斯的时候，我们连他们的影子都没有看到。他从我们身边走过，似乎并没有注意到我们，但是现在他却出现在我们的路上了！天哪，戴维，我开始有点儿头绪了。我觉得他们在找的不是你，我认为他们找的是我。而且我想他们非常清楚他们要去哪里。”
en: “Nhm!” said Alan, “it looks queer.We saw nothing of them this morning on the Whins; he’s passed us by, he doesnae seem to be looking, and yet here he is on our road!Dod, Davie, I begin to take a notion.I think it’s no you they’re seeking, I think it’s me; and I think they ken fine where they’re gaun.”

zh: “他们清楚？”我问。
en: “They ken?” I asked.

zh: “我认为是安迪·斯库格尔出卖了我——他或者他的船员对这件事情有所了解——要不然就是查利的办事员，那也很遗憾。”艾伦说，“如果你只是想问我内心个人的想法，我觉得有人将会在吉兰沙滩掉脑袋。”
en: “I think Andie Scougal’s sold me—him or his mate wha kent some part of the affair—or else Charlie’s clerk callant, which would be a pity too,” says Alan; “and if you askit me for just my inward private conviction, I think there’ll be heads cracked on Gillane sands.”

zh: “艾伦，”我叫道，“如果你完全肯定有人在那里等着了，那就逃生吧。那就不会有什么掉脑袋的事情了。”
en: “Alan,” I cried, “if you’re at all right there’ll be folk there and to spare.It’ll be small service to crack heads.”

zh: “这倒不失为令人满意的办法。”艾伦说，“但是等一下，等一下，我在想——多亏这美妙的西风，我相信我还是有机会试一试的。是这样的，戴维。我要等黄昏到来之后才会如约去见斯库格尔。不过，”他说，“如果我能从西边借一点点风，我或许在那里会呆得久一点儿。”他说，“就呆在菲德拉岛后面等你。现在，要是你的那些绅士已经知道了那个地方，他们也就会知道约定的时间了。你明白我要干什么了吗，戴维？多亏了约翰尼·科普和其他红衣傻瓜，我才能对这片土地了如指掌。如果你已经做好准备要再次和艾伦·布雷克一起逃跑的话，我们就得折回海岸边，重新回到德尔顿附近的海滩。如果船在那里，我们就要想办法登上那艘船。如果船不在那里，我就只好返回我那讨厌的干草堆去了。但是不论走哪一条路，我们都得甩开你的那些绅士，就让他们用拇指去吹口哨好了。”
en: “It would aye be a satisfaction though,” says Alan.“But bide a bit; bide a bit; I’m thinking—and thanks to this bonny westland wind, I believe I’ve still a chance of it.It’s this way, Davie.I’m no trysted with this man Scougal till the gloaming comes.But,” says he, “if I can get a bit of a wind out of the west I’ll be there long or that,” he says, “and lie-to for ye behind the Isle of Fidra.Now if your gentry kens the place, they ken the time forbye.Do ye see me coming, Davie?Thanks to Johnnie Cope and other red-coat gomerals, I should ken this country like the back of my hand; and if ye’re ready for another bit run with Alan Breck, we’ll can cast back inshore, and come to the seaside again by Dirleton.If the ship’s there, we’ll try and get on board of her.If she’s no there, I’ll just have to get back to my weary haystack.But either way of it, I think we will leave your gentry whistling on their thumbs.”

zh: “我相信这里面有机会。”我说，“你带上我吧，艾伦！”
en: “I believe there’s some chance in it,” said I.“Have on with ye, Alan!”

zh: 第十三章 吉兰沙滩
en: CHAPTER XIII—GILLANE SANDS

zh: 就像艾伦当初在科普将军带领下行军一样，我靠艾伦带路也没得到什么好处，因为我几乎说不出我们走的是什么路。我觉得那是因为我们走得太快了。我们有时在飞跑，有时小跑，而其余时间也是迈着复仇一样的步伐在走。有两次，我们跑得最快的时候，都是和那些乡下人逆向奔跑的。虽然我们在转弯时撞到了第一个乡下人，但艾伦已经准备好，就像一支上了膛的步枪。
en: I did not profit by Alan’s pilotage as he had done by his marchings under General Cope; for I can scarce tell what way we went.It is my excuse that we travelled exceeding fast.Some part we ran, some trotted, and the rest walked at a vengeance of a pace.Twice, while we were at top speed, we ran against country-folk; but though we plumped into the first from round a corner, Alan was as ready as a loaded musket.

zh: “你看见我的马了吗？”他气喘吁吁地问道。
en: “Has ye seen my horse?” he gasped.

zh: “没有，老兄，我今天根本就没有看见过马。”那乡下人回答。
en: “Na, man, I haenae seen nae horse the day,” replied the countryman.

zh: 艾伦费了些时间跟他解释说我们“两人合骑一匹马”在旅行，我们的马居然跑掉了，恐怕已经跑回林顿的老家了。不仅如此，他还费力（虽然他已经没有剩下多少力气了）咒骂，说都是因为他自己倒霉再加上我愚蠢，才惹出这样的麻烦。
en: And Alan spared the time to explain to him that we were travelling “ride and tie”; that our charger had escaped, and it was feared he had gone home to Linton.Not only that, but he expended some breath (of which he had not very much left) to curse his own misfortune and my stupidity which was said to be its cause.

zh: “对他们不能说实话，”我们继续前行时，他对我说道，“应该要刻意给他们留下一种诚实、利于掩护自己的说法。如果人们不知道你在做什么，戴维，他们就会疑虑丛生；可是如果他们以为自己知道了，他们就会不再那么关注此事，就像不再关注我是怎么熬豌豆粥一样。”
en: “Them that cannae tell the truth,” he observed to myself as we went on again, “should be aye mindful to leave an honest, handy lee behind them.If folk dinnae ken what ye’re doing, Davie, they’re terrible taken up with it; but if they think they ken, they care nae mair for it than what I do for pease porridge.”

zh: 因为我们起先是向内陆走的，所以到最后我们的路就非常靠近北方了。阿伯莱迪的老教堂在左边，是一处标志性建筑；在右边则是贝里克郡法院高耸的尖顶。就这样我们又走到海边了，这里距离德尔顿不远。 从北贝里克郡向西到吉兰海角一线排列着四个小岛：克雷格利斯、拉姆、菲德拉，还有艾布劳，因其大小、形状各异而著称。菲德拉最特别，是座奇异的灰色小岛，有两个驼峰，一片废墟使之越发显眼。我留意到（随着我们越来越靠近它）这些废墟上的门或窗就像是大海窥视人间的眼睛。在菲德拉的庇护下，西风中有一处很好的锚泊地，在那里，从很远的地方，我们就可以看到“呼啸”号正在游弋。
en: As we had first made inland, so our road came in the end to lie very near due north; the old Kirk of Aberlady for a landmark on the left; on the right, the top of the Berwick Law; and it was thus we struck the shore again, not far from Dirleton.From north Berwick west to Gillane Ness there runs a string of four small islets, Craiglieth, the Lamb, Fidra, and Eyebrough, notable by their diversity of size and shape.Fidra is the most particular, being a strange grey islet of two humps, made the more conspicuous by a piece of ruin; and I mind that (as we drew closer to it) by some door or window of these ruins the sea peeped through like a man’s eye.Under the lee of Fidra there is a good anchorage in westerly winds, and there, from a far way off, we could see the Thistle riding.

zh: 面对这些小岛的海滨到处都是一片荒芜。这里渺无人烟，鲜有过客，或者说最多只是有些流浪的孩子在跑着嬉戏。吉兰是个小地方，在海角远远的一侧，德尔顿人都在内陆各地做生意，而那些北贝里克郡人则从他们的港口直接出海捕鱼，所以，没有几处海岸像这里一样人迹罕至了。我们匍匐着爬过地形各异的高地和洼谷时，擦亮眼睛观察着四周，我们的心在胸腔怦怦狂跳，但是我注意到阳光与海水如此明媚耀眼，一阵微风从弯腰的小草中拂过，还有那上蹦下跳的野兔和高高飞翔的海鸥带来一阵喧闹，所以那片荒芜之地在我看来竟然充满了勃勃生机。无疑从各个方面来看，这都不失为秘密登船的极好选择，只要这秘密一直保守得好。即使秘密给泄露了，而且该地也被监视了，我们也能不被察觉地爬到沙丘的前面，虽然他们可以直接俯视那片海滩和海面。
en: The shore in face of these islets is altogether waste.Here is no dwelling of man, and scarce any passage, or at most of vagabond children running at their play.Gillane is a small place on the far side of the Ness, the folk of Dirleton go to their business in the inland fields, and those of North Berwick straight to the sea-fishing from their haven; so that few parts of the coast are lonelier.But I mind, as we crawled upon our bellies into that multiplicity of heights and hollows, keeping a bright eye upon all sides, and our hearts hammering at our ribs, there was such a shining of the sun and the sea, such a stir of the wind in the bent grass, and such a bustle of down-popping rabbits and up-flying gulls, that the desert seemed to me, like a place alive.No doubt it was in all ways well chosen for a secret embarcation, if the secret had been kept; and even now that it was out, and the place watched, we were able to creep unperceived to the front of the sandhills, where they look down immediately on the beach and sea.

zh: 但是艾伦却停下了脚步。
en: But here Alan came to a full stop.

zh: “戴维，”他说，“这是一条难以穿越的通道！我们只有躺在这里才安全，但是我就无法靠近我的船或者靠近法国的海岸了。一旦我们起身向双桅帆船发出信号，那就是另一码事了。因为跟踪你的那些绅士会在哪里，你想一想？”
en: “Davie,” said he, “this is a kittle passage!As long as we lie here we’re safe; but I’m nane sae muckle nearer to my ship or the coast of France.And as soon as we stand up and signal the brig, it’s another matter.For where will your gentry be, think ye?”

zh: “也许他们还没有来，”我说，“而且即使他们来了，有一点显然于我们有利。他们全部会被安排来抓捕我们，千真万确。但是他们本来做好准备我们会从东边来的，而现在我们却在他们的西边。”
en: “Maybe they’re no come yet,” said I.“And even if they are, there’s one clear matter in our favour.They’ll be all arranged to take us, that’s true.But they’ll have arranged for our coming from the east and here we are upon their west.”

zh: “是啊，”艾伦说，“我真希望我们有些兵力，而这就是一场战斗，那我们就可以自如地操纵他们！可惜并非如此，戴维。照目前的情况，艾伦·布雷克一点儿也乐观不起来。我犹豫了，戴维。”
en: “Ay,” says Alan, “I wish we were in some force, and this was a battle, we would have bonnily out-manoeuvred them!But it isnae, Davit; and the way it is, is a wee thing less inspiring to Alan Breck.I swither, Davie.”

zh: “时机稍纵即逝，艾伦。”我说。
en: “Time flies, Alan,” said I.

zh: “我知道那一点。”艾伦说，“就像法国人说的，此外我一无所知。但这件事从头到尾都很可怕。哦！要是我知道跟踪你的那些绅士在哪里就好了！”
en: “I ken that,” said Alan.“I ken naething else, as the French folk say.But this is a dreidful case of heids or tails.O! if I could but ken where your gentry were!”

zh: “艾伦，”我说，“这根本不像你了。要当机立断，否则就没机会了。”
en: “Alan,” said I, “this is no like you.It’s got to be now or never.”

zh: “这根本不是我，他引用说，”艾伦唱着，带着一副介于羞愧和滑稽之间的奇怪表情，
en: “This is no me, quo’ he,” sang Alan, with a queer face betwixt shame and drollery.

zh: “既不是你也不是我，他引用说，既不是你也不是我。哇，不是，约翰尼伙计！既不是你也不是我。”
en: “Neither you nor me, quo’ he, neither you nor me.Wow, na, Johnnie man! neither you nor me.”

zh: 然后他突然在原地笔直站了起来，右手挥舞着一方手帕，向下行进走上了海滩。我自己也站了起来，但是却踯躅在后，审视着东边的沙丘。他的出现起初没有引起注意：斯库格尔没料到他会来得那么早，而跟踪我的那些绅士都在监视着另一个方向。跟着“呼啸”号上的人就醒悟过来了，他们似乎早已做好一切准备，因为甲板上只忙碌了顷刻，我们就看到一艘小艇从大船的尾部放了下来，而且那小艇开始轻快地驶向海岸。几乎就在同时，大约离吉兰海角半英里远的地方，一个男人的身影瞬间出现在沙丘上，挥舞着双臂。然而刹那间他又不见了，那里的海鸥仍旧自由地飞翔了一阵。
en: And then of a sudden he stood straight up where he was, and with a handkerchief flying in his right hand, marched down upon the beach.I stood up myself, but lingered behind him, scanning the sand-hills to the east.His appearance was at first unremarked: Scougal not expecting him so early, and my gentry watching on the other side.Then they awoke on board the Thistle, and it seemed they had all in readiness, for there was scarce a second’s bustle on the deck before we saw a skiff put round her stern and begin to pull lively for the coast.Almost at the same moment of time, and perhaps half a mile away towards Gillane Ness, the figure of a man appeared for a blink upon a sandhill, waving with his arms; and though he was gone again in the same flash, the gulls in that part continued a little longer to fly wild.

zh: 艾伦没有看见这些，他直盯着海面上那艘大船和小艇。
en: Alan had not seen this, looking straight to seaward at the ship and skiff.

zh: “一定会如料想的那样！”我告诉他的时候，他说道，“小艇会正好划到的，否则追兵就会搜索我栖身的陡峭岩石了。”
en: “It maun be as it will!” said he, when I had told him, “Weel may yon boatie row, or my craig’ll have to thole a raxing.”

zh: 那段海滩又长又平坦，在退潮时尤其适于散步。一条长满水芹的小河从海滩上的一处地方流过，奔向大海。沿着海滩尽头的那一堆堆沙丘就像镇上的城墙一样。我们的眼力无法查看到沙丘后面旷野中的动静，我们也不能加快小艇到来的速度。在那段令人煎熬的等待中，时间仿佛都停滞了。
en: That part of the beach was long and flat, and excellent walking when the tide was down; a little cressy burn flowed over it in one place to the sea; and the sandhills ran along the head of it like the rampart of a town.No eye of ours could spy what was passing behind there in the bents, no hurry of ours could mend the speed of the boat’s coming: time stood still with us through that uncanny period of waiting.

zh: “有一件事我想知道，”艾伦说，“我想知道那些绅士得到的命令。我们俩值四百英镑呢，如果他们拿枪对着我们，我们怎么办，戴维！他们从那条长长的沙堤顶部很好向我们射击的。
en: “There is one thing I would like to ken,” say Alan.“I would like to ken these gentry’s orders.We’re worth four hunner pound the pair of us: how if they took the guns to us, Davie!They would get a bonny shot from the top of that lang sandy bank.”

zh: “理论上是不可能的，”我说，“关键是他们不可能有长枪。这件事处理得极为隐秘。手枪他们还可能有，但绝不会有长枪。”
en: “Morally impossible,” said I.“The point is that they can have no guns.This thing has been gone about too secret; pistols they may have, but never guns.”

zh: “我相信你说得对，”艾伦说，“尽管我等那小艇已经等得不耐烦了。”
en: “I believe ye’ll be in the right,” says Alan.“For all which I am wearing a good deal for yon boat.”

zh: 于是他含住手指，就像对着狗一样对着那小艇吹起了口哨。
en: And he snapped his fingers and whistled to it like a dog.

zh: 现在小艇大概行驶了三分之一的路程，而我们自己则艰难地在海边上走着，结果柔软的沙子漫进了我的鞋子里。除了等待，我们别无他事可做，唯有放眼去看那小艇越爬越近。那绵长的沙丘横亘在面前，难以逾越，但见海鸥在上空忽闪而过，毫无疑问我们的敌人正在沙丘的后面集结待发。
en: It was now perhaps a third of the way in, and we ourselves already hard on the margin of the sea, so that the soft sand rose over my shoes.There was no more to do whatever but to wait, to look as much as we were able at the creeping nearer of the boat, and as little as we could manage at the long impenetrable front of the sandhills, over which the gulls twinkled and behind which our enemies were doubtless marshalling.

zh: “这是一个美丽、明亮、空气清新的地方，我们却要被射杀在这里，”艾伦突然说道，“伙计，我希望我有你那样的勇气！”
en: “This is a fine, bright, caller place to get shot in,” says Alan suddenly; “and, man, I wish that I had your courage!”

zh: “艾伦，”我叫道，“这是什么话呀！你就是勇气所铸就的，那就是男子汉的品质。要是没有别人可以证明的话，我本人就可以来证明。”
en: “Alan!” I cried, “what kind of talk is this of it!You’re just made of courage; it’s the character of the man, as I could prove myself if there was nobody else.”

zh: “那你就更加弄错了，”他说，“我和你的不同之处仅仅在于我对事物有较强的洞察力和理解力。但是说到成熟、冷静、顽强和极度的勇气，我连给你秉烛都不配。看看此刻在沙滩上的我们两个。我在这里是坐立不安，急于离开；而你在这里（就我所知）对于是否留下还三心二意的。 你觉得我能做到那一点或者愿意那么做吗？ 我根本不行! 首先，因为我既没有勇气也没有胆量；第二，因为我是个很有洞察力的人，就会先看透你这个家伙怎么想的。”
en: “And you would be the more mistaken,” said he.“What makes the differ with me is just my great penetration and knowledge of affairs.But for auld, cauld, dour, deadly courage, I am not fit to hold a candle to yourself.Look at us two here upon the sands.Here am I, fair hotching to be off; here’s you (for all that I ken) in two minds of it whether you’ll no stop.Do you think that I could do that, or would?No me!Firstly, because I havenae got the courage and wouldnae daur; and secondly, because I am a man of so much penetration and would see ye damned first.”

zh: “你又来了，是吗？”我叫道，“啊，艾伦好家伙，你可以骗那些老太太，但你绝对骗不了我。”
en: “It’s there ye’re coming, is it?” I cried.“Ah, man Alan, you can wile your old wives, but you never can wile me.”

zh: 想起我在树林里受到的诱惑，这使我坚强如钢。
en: Remembrance of my temptation in the wood made me strong as iron.

zh: “我还有个约会要赴。”我继续说道，“我与你的堂兄查利有约，我已经作出了承诺。”
en: “I have a tryst to keep,” I continued.“I am trysted with your cousin Charlie; I have passed my word.”

zh: “你要赶赴那美好的约会，”艾伦说，“只要有那些躲在荒野里的绅士，你就去不成。那怎么办？”他以非常唬人的严肃态度继续说，“只要告诉我，我的小子！ 你是否会像格兰奇夫人一样被绑架走？他们是否会用匕首捅进你的身体，然后把你埋在荒郊野外？或者是用别的办法，他们是否会把你带进监狱和詹姆斯关在一起？他们是不是值得信任的人？你是不是会把自己的脑袋伸进西蒙·弗雷泽和其他辉格党人的虎口里去？”他语气特别讥讽地补充说道。
en: “Braw trysts that you’ll can keep,” said Alan.“Ye’ll just mistryst aince and for a’ with the gentry in the bents.And what for?” he went on with an extreme threatening gravity.“Just tell me that, my mannie!Are ye to be speerited away like Lady Grange?Are they to drive a dirk in your inside and bury ye in the bents?Or is it to be the other way, and are they to bring ye in with James?Are they folk to be trustit?Would ye stick your head in the mouth of Sim Fraser and the ither Whigs?” he added with extraordinary bitterness.

zh: “艾伦，”我叫道，“他们都是些流氓和骗子，对此我完全同意你的看法。在这样一个盗贼横行的土地上就更有理由要有一位正派人士！我的承诺既已出口，我就一定会坚守的。我很久以前就对你的同族女亲戚说过，在任何危险面前我都绝不会犹豫。你还记得那句话吗？就是雷德·科林毙命的那天夜里。那么，我就无需赘言了。现在我不走了。普雷斯顿格兰奇曾答应过要保我一命。如果他是个随便作承诺的人，那我今天就只有去死了。”
en: “Alan,” cried I, “they’re all rogues and liars, and I’m with ye there.The more reason there should be one decent man in such a land of thieves!My word in passed, and I’ll stick to it.I said long syne to your kinswoman that I would stumble at no risk.Do ye mind of that?—the night Red Colin fell, it was.No more I will, then.Here I stop.Prestongrange promised me my life: if he’s to be mansworn, here I’ll have to die.”

zh: “好了，好了。”艾伦说。
en: “Aweel aweel,” said Alan.

zh: 这段时间我们都没有再看见跟踪我们的人或者听到他们的动静。事实上我们一直下意识地在捕捉他们的身影，他们的整个队伍（我后来才知道的）还没有赶到现场，他们正分布在前往吉兰的荒野中。 要把他们召集起来并带过来还真不容易，而小艇正在加速。此外，他们只不过是些胆小的家伙：只是一群高地牧贼，来自几个部落，没有绅士来当领头人，所以他们在海滩上对我和艾伦监视得越多，（我不能不认为）他们就越不愿意被我们发现。
en: All this time we had seen or heard no more of our pursuers.In truth we had caught them unawares; their whole party (as I was to learn afterwards) had not yet reached the scene; what there was of them was spread among the bents towards Gillane.It was quite an affair to call them in and bring them over, and the boat was making speed.They were besides but cowardly fellows: a mere leash of Highland cattle-thieves, of several clans, no gentleman there to be the captain and the more they looked at Alan and me upon the beach, the less (I must suppose) they liked the look of us.

zh: 不论是谁出卖的艾伦，都绝不会是船长。他亲自在小艇上掌舵并且在鼓励他的手下，像一个尽心办事的男子汉。他已经靠近了，小艇安全驶来——因为即将得救而感到兴奋，艾伦的脸已经绯红，而此时我们那些在荒野中的朋友，要么是因为绝望地发现猎物已经成功出逃，要么是因为希望能够吓唬吓唬安迪，突然发出了一阵混杂着几种声音的尖叫声。
en: Whoever had betrayed Alan it was not the captain: he was in the skiff himself, steering and stirring up his oarsmen, like a man with his heart in his employ.Already he was near in, and the boat securing—already Alan’s face had flamed crimson with the excitement of his deliverance, when our friends in the bents, either in their despair to see their prey escape them or with some hope of scaring Andie, raised suddenly a shrill cry of several voices.

zh: 这声音，从那片显得相当荒凉的海岸响起，真是太骇人了，于是艇上的人立刻停稳了。
en: This sound, arising from what appeared to be a quite deserted coast, was really very daunting, and the men in the boat held water instantly.

zh: “这是什么声音？”船长大声吆喝道，因为他已经到了近旁，能够轻易打招呼了。
en: “What’s this of it?” sings out the captain, for he was come within an easy hail.

zh: “我自由了。”艾伦说道，立即开始涉过浅水区奔向小艇，“戴维，”他说，停顿了一下，“戴维，难道你不来吗？我真舍不得离开你。”
en: “Freens o’mine,” says Alan, and began immediately to wade forth in the shallow water towards the boat.“Davie,” he said, pausing, “Davie, are ye no coming?I am swier to leave ye.”

zh: “毫发都不会动。”我说。
en: “Not a hair of me,” said I.

zh: 他站立了片刻，犹豫着，海水淹没到了他的膝盖。
en: “He stood part of a second where he was to his knees in the salt water, hesitating.

zh: “他一定要去库珀，必须去库珀。”他说，然后冲进深过腰部的水中，他被拉进小艇，小艇立刻驶向大船。
en: “He that will to Cupar, maun to Cupar,” said he, and swashing in deeper than his waist, was hauled into the skiff, which was immediately directed for the ship.

zh: 我站在他离开我的地方，双手反背在身后。艾伦坐在艇上转头望着我，小艇平稳地驶离了。突然我差点儿流下泪来，感觉自己是被遗弃在苏格兰的最孤独的青年。随后我转身背对着大海，面朝沙丘。看不见人影也听不到人声，太阳照耀在有湿有干的沙子上，风从荒原上吹过，海鸥发出一种单调的叫声。 我向海滩高处走去，沙蚤敏捷地在海岸边的乱草丛中跳跃。在那个不祥之地连鬼影子都看不到，也听不到任何声音。然而我知道那边有人在监视着我，带着某种隐秘的目的。他们绝不是士兵，否则早就袭击我并且把我带走了。他们绝对是一些受雇的普通流氓，想来坏我的事，也许是想绑架我，也许就想直接把我给杀了。 从那些参与此事的人的情况来看，更有可能是第一种人。从我对他们品性的了解以及他们对这桩事的热心来看，我认为第二种也很有可能。我的血都凉了，凉到心里去了。
en: I stood where he had left me, with my hands behind my back; Alan sat with his head turned watching me; and the boat drew smoothly away.Of a sudden I came the nearest hand to shedding tears, and seemed to myself the most deserted solitary lad in Scotland.With that I turned my back upon the sea and faced the sandhills.There was no sight or sound of man; the sun shone on the wet sand and the dry, the wind blew in the bents, the gulls made a dreary piping.As I passed higher up the beach, the sand-lice were hopping nimbly about the stranded tangles.The devil any other sight or sound in that unchancy place.And yet I knew there were folk there, observing me, upon some secret purpose.They were no soldiers, or they would have fallen on and taken us ere now; doubtless they were some common rogues hired for my undoing, perhaps to kidnap, perhaps to murder me outright.From the position of those engaged, the first was the more likely; from what I knew of their character and ardency in this business, I thought the second very possible; and the blood ran cold about my heart.

zh: 我有一个疯狂的想法，想要拔出我剑鞘中的剑。因为虽然我极不适合像绅士那样勇敢地去刀剑相对，但是我认为在混乱的战斗中我也可以给对方造成一些损伤。但我马上意识到抵抗是种愚蠢行为。这无疑是普雷斯顿格兰奇和弗雷泽一致同意的联合“行动”。前者，我非常确定，已经做了一些事情来保全我的性命。而后者则极有可能已经给尼尔和其同伙的耳朵里透露了一些相反的暗示。要是我亮出兵刃，也许我就会直接落入我最可怕的敌人手里，那我注定要完蛋了。
en: I had a mad idea to loosen my sword in the scabbard; for though I was very unfit to stand up like a gentleman blade to blade, I thought I could do some scathe in a random combat.But I perceived in time the folly of resistance.This was no doubt the joint “expedient” on which Prestongrange and Fraser were agreed.The first, I was very sure, had done something to secure my life; the second was pretty likely to have slipped in some contrary hints into the ears of Neil and his companions; and it I were to show bare steel I might play straight into the hands of my worst enemy and seal my own doom.

zh: 这么想着，我来到了海滩的顶端。我朝身后望了一眼，小艇正在靠近双桅船，艾伦在挥舞着手帕以示告别，对此我也挥了挥手作为回应。 艾伦本人在我的视野中缩成了一个小点儿，已经到我身前这个海角的出口旁边了。我把帽子紧扣在头上，咬紧牙关，径直朝我前面的环状沙堆上走去。因为陡峭，这个沙堆很难攀登，沙子就像脚下的水一样。不过最后我抓住了斜坡顶上那弯弯曲曲的长草，借此把自己拉到了一个合适的落脚点。 与此同时那些人行动了，东一个西一个地站了起来，有六、七个吧，是些衣衫破烂的地痞，每个人手里都握着一把匕首。情况很清楚，我闭上眼睛开始祈祷。 我再次睁开眼睛时，那帮流氓并没有朝我逼近多少，他们既不说话也不着急。所有的眼睛都看着我，给我一种奇怪的感觉，觉得他们的眼睛很亮，同时他们也害怕继续靠近我。我伸出空空的双手，于是有个人带着浓厚的高地口音问我是不是要投降。
en: These thoughts brought me to the head of the beach.I cast a look behind, the boat was nearing the brig, and Alan flew his handkerchief for a farewell, which I replied to with the waving of my hand.But Alan himself was shrunk to a small thing in my view, alongside of this pass that lay in front of me.I set my hat hard on my head, clenched my teeth, and went right before me up the face of the sand-wreath.It made a hard climb, being steep, and the sand like water underfoot.But I caught hold at last by the long bent-grass on the brae-top, and pulled myself to a good footing.The same moment men stirred and stood up here and there, six or seven of them, ragged-like knaves, each with a dagger in his hand.The fair truth is, I shut my eyes and prayed.When I opened them again, the rogues were crept the least thing nearer without speech or hurry.Every eye was upon mine, which struck me with a strange sensation of their brightness, and of the fear with which they continued to approach me.I held out my hands empty; whereupon one asked, with a strong Highland brogue, if I surrendered.

zh: “我抗议，”我说，“你们是否知道那个词的含义，我很怀疑这一点。”
en: “Under protest,” said I, “if ye ken what that means, which I misdoubt.”

zh: 听到那句话，他们就像一群鸟扑向腐肉一般，一拥而上扑向我，他们抓住我，拿走了我的剑，还拿走了我口袋里所有的钱，用粗大的绳索捆住我的手脚，然后把我丢在荒野中的一堆草丛里。在那里他们大致围成一个圈坐在他们的俘虏周围，默默注视着他，就像看着某样危险的东西，就像是脚上装了弹簧的一头狮子或者一只老虎。不久他们就放松了这种注意力。他们聚得更拢一些，开始用盖尔语交谈起来，颇具讽刺意味的是他们居然在我眼前就把我的财产给瓜分了。这个时候我感到安慰的是，从那个位置我可以看到我的朋友脱逃的过程。我看见小艇靠近了双桅船，然后被吊了上去，然后大船张满风帆，在小岛背后沿北贝里克郡驶向了外海。
en: At that word, they came all in upon me like a flight of birds upon a carrion, seized me, took my sword, and all the money from my pockets, bound me hand and foot with some strong line, and cast me on a tussock of bent.There they sat about their captive in a part of a circle and gazed upon him silently like something dangerous, perhaps a lion or a tiger on the spring.Presently this attention was relaxed.They drew nearer together, fell to speech in the Gaelic, and very cynically divided my property before my eyes.It was my diversion in this time that I could watch from my place the progress of my friend’s escape.I saw the boat come to the brig and be hoisted in, the sails fill, and the ship pass out seaward behind the isles and by North Berwick.

zh: 在大约两个小时的时间内，越来越多衣衫褴褛的高地人不断地聚拢过来。尼尔属于最先到的，直到后来这伙人肯定有将近二十个了。每新来一个人就会有一轮新的谈话，听起来都像是在抱怨和解释。不过我却注意到一件事，就是那些晚来的人没有一个分到了从我这里掠夺去的战利品。最后的讨论非常激烈而热切，所以我一度都认为他们是吵架了。讨论近尾声时，这帮人散去了，大部分人成群结队向西返回，只有三个人，即尼尔和另外两个人留下来担任岗哨看管囚犯。
en: In the course of two hours or so, more and more ragged Highlandmen kept collecting.Neil among the first, until the party must have numbered near a score.With each new arrival there was a fresh bout of talk, that sounded like complaints and explanations; but I observed one thing, none of those who came late had any share in the division of my spoils.The last discussion was very violent and eager, so that once I thought they would have quarrelled; on the heels of which their company parted, the bulk of them returning westward in a troop, and only three, Neil and two others, remaining sentries on the prisoner.

zh: “我可以说出一个人的名字，这个人会对你们今天的作为极不满意，尼尔·邓肯森。”其他人走开以后，我说道。
en: “I could name one who would be very ill pleased with your day’s work, Neil Duncanson,” said I, when the rest had moved away.

zh: 他答复我说，保证我会被善待，因为他知道我“和他的女主人相熟”。
en: He assured me in answer I should be tenderly used, for he knew he was “acquent wi’ the leddy.”

zh: 这就是我们所谈的全部内容，也没有其他任何人再出现在这片海岸上，直到太阳在高地群山之中落下，黄昏渐远，黑夜将至。那一刻才我注意到有一个洛锡安人骑着一匹农场的马穿过旷野朝我们走来，他身材颀长、消瘦，一副皮包骨的样子，面孔黑黝黝的。
en: This was all our talk, nor did any other son of man appear upon that portion of the coast until the sun had gone down among the Highland mountains, and the gloaming was beginning to grow dark.At which hour I was aware of a long, lean, bony-like Lothian man of a very swarthy countenance, that came towards us among the bents on a farm horse.

zh: “小伙子们，”他叫道，“你们有一份这样的文件吗？”他手里举着一份文件。尼尔立刻呈上了一份，来人借着一副牛角眼镜仔细阅读了，然后说一切无误，我们就是他在找的人，并立即下了马。随后我就被放到了他的马上，我的脚被捆在马肚子下，在这个低地人的引导下我们动身了。他走的这条路肯定是经过精心挑选的，因为整条路上我们只碰到了两个人——是一对恋人，而他们也许把我们当成了走私贩，一看到我们走近便逃走了。我们一度靠近南部的贝里克郡法院脚下，还有一次，在我们经过一些开阔的小山丘时，我发现了小村庄以及不远处小树林中教堂的古塔透出的点点灯光，但是都太远了无法呼救，就算我曾经想过要这么做的话。 最后我们再次听到了海浪的声音。当时有月光，虽然不是很亮。在月光下我可以看到坦特伦（雷德·道格拉斯的老首府）那三座巨大的城堡以及破损的城垛。马被拴在沟渠底的木桩上吃草，而我被带了进去，向前进了庭院，然后进入那个摇摇欲坠的石厅。在这里押解我的人就在人行道上生了一堆熊熊大火，因为夜晚很寒冷。我的手被松了绑，我被放在里面最当头的墙边，（那位低地人已经备好粮食）他给了我燕麦面包和一大罐法国白兰地酒。吃完之后，我又和那三个高地人单独在一起了。他们紧靠火堆旁坐着喝酒聊天，风从墙缝中吹进来，卷起阵阵浓烟，在城堡的顶端呼啸着。我可以听到悬崖下的海浪声，我内心已经对自己的生命安全打消了疑虑，而那天的忙碌也让我身心俱疲，我侧向一边就入睡了。
en: “Lads,” cried he, “has ye a paper like this?” and held up one in his hand.Neil produced a second, which the newcomer studied through a pair of horn spectacles, and saying all was right and we were the folk he was seeking, immediately dismounted.I was then set in his place, my feet tied under the horse’s belly, and we set forth under the guidance of the Lowlander.His path must have been very well chosen, for we met but one pair—a pair of lovers—the whole way, and these, perhaps taking us to be free-traders, fled on our approach.We were at one time close at the foot of Berwick Law on the south side; at another, as we passed over some open hills, I spied the lights of a clachan and the old tower of a church among some trees not far off, but too far to cry for help, if I had dreamed of it.At last we came again within sound of the sea.There was moonlight, though not much; and by this I could see the three huge towers and broken battlements of Tantallon, that old chief place of the Red Douglases.The horse was picketed in the bottom of the ditch to graze, and I was led within, and forth into the court, and thence into the tumble-down stone hall.Here my conductors built a brisk fire in the midst of the pavement, for there was a chill in the night.My hands were loosed, I was set by the wall in the inner end, and (the Lowlander having produced provisions) I was given oatmeal bread and a pitcher of French brandy.This done, I was left once more alone with my three Highlandmen.They sat close by the fire drinking and talking; the wind blew in by the breaches, cast about the smoke and flames, and sang in the tops of the towers; I could hear the sea under the cliffs, and, my mind being reassured as to my life, and my body and spirits wearied with the day’s employment, I turned upon one side and slumbered.

zh: 我无法猜出我是什么时候被唤醒的，只是月亮已经低斜，火堆也快熄灭了。我的脚现在已经松绑了，我被带着穿过废墟，沿一条陡峭的小路下到悬崖边，在那里我发现有条渔船停在岩石围成的避风处。我就这样被带上了船，我们开始在美丽的星光下起航离开海岸。
en: I had no means of guessing at what hour I was wakened, only the moon was down and the fire was low.My feet were now loosed, and I was carried through the ruins and down the cliff-side by a precipitous path to where I found a fisher’s boat in a haven of the rocks.This I was had on board of, and we began to put forth from the shore in a fine starlight.

zh: 第十四章 巴斯
en: CHAPTER XIV—THE BASS

zh: 我全然不知他们会把我带往何处，只是到处张望有没有船驶过。当时我脑海中闪过兰塞姆说的一个词——值二十镑的人们。 如果我要第二次面临先前那种被卖到种植园当奴隶的危险，我断定事情肯定会对我不利。不会有第二个艾伦，也不会有第二次海难以及闲置的院子可以指望了。我甚至看见了自己在鞭笞下种烟草的情景。这些想法让我不寒而栗，水面上的空气非常凛冽，小船的支架被寒露浸透了，我则在舵手身旁的位置上瑟瑟地发着抖。迄今在低地人中我只称呼过这个舵手为黑人，他名叫戴尔，人们通常称呼他布莱克·安迪。他感觉到我全身直打寒颤，于是非常和善地递给我一件满是鱼鳞的粗制夹克，我高兴地把这件夹克穿在了身上。
en: I had no thought where they were taking me; only looked here and there for the appearance of a ship; and there ran the while in my head a word of Ransome’s—the twenty-pounders.If I were to be exposed a second time to that same former danger of the plantations, I judged it must turn ill with me; there was no second Alan; and no second shipwreck and spare yard to be expected now; and I saw myself hoe tobacco under the whip’s lash.The thought chilled me; the air was sharp upon the water, the stretchers of the boat drenched with a cold dew: and I shivered in my place beside the steersman.This was the dark man whom I have called hitherto the Lowlander; his name was Dale, ordinarily called Black Andie.Feeling the thrill of my shiver, he very kindly handed me a rough jacket full of fish-scales, with which I was glad to cover myself.

zh: “我感谢您的这番好意，”我说，“我定会时刻铭记于心，力求报答的。您在这件事中非常负责任。您不像那些无知、野蛮的高地人，您知道法律是什么，也知道那些违法的人所冒的风险。”
en: “I thank you for this kindness,” said I, “and will make so free as to repay it with a warning.You take a high responsibility in this affair.You are not like these ignorant, barbarous Highlanders, but know what the law is and the risks of those that break it.”

zh: “我不是很清楚你怎么会成为法律通缉的极端分子，”他说，“还是在你人生最得意的时候。不过在这件事上我是按照一份契约行事的。”
en: “I am no just exactly what ye would ca’ an extremist for the law,” says he, “at the best of times; but in this business I act with a good warranty.”

zh: “你打算怎么处置我？”我问。
en: “What are you going to do with me?” I asked.

zh: “不会伤害你，”他说，“绝不会伤害你。我在想，你有强大的朋友。你也足够富有。”
en: “Nae harm,” said he, “nae harm ava’.Ye’ll have strong freens, I’m thinking.Ye’ll be richt eneuch yet.”

zh: 这时海面上开始落下一层灰幕，星星点点的粉红色和红色就像文火里燃烧的煤块一样，从东边显现了出来，与此同时那些鹅被唤醒了，于是开始在巴斯的顶端叫唤了起来。巴斯只是一座岩石悬崖，这一点人人皆知，但是这座悬崖很大，足以雕刻出一座城市来。 海浪特别小，但已在巨岩的底部周围冲击出了一处凹坑。随着黎明破晓，我可以越来越清楚地看见那座巨岩了。那笔直的峭壁绘满了海鸟粪，就像铺了一层晨霜一样，倾斜的峭壁顶端绿茵茵地布满了青草，成群的白鹅在悬崖的边缘鸣叫，而监狱的那些黢黑、残破的建筑物则紧靠在大海的边缘上。
en: There began to fall a greyness on the face of the sea; little dabs of pink and red, like coals of slow fire, came in the east; and at the same time the geese awakened, and began crying about the top of the Bass.It is just the one crag of rock, as everybody knows, but great enough to carve a city from.The sea was extremely little, but there went a hollow plowter round the base of it.With the growing of the dawn I could see it clearer and clearer; the straight crags painted with sea-birds’ droppings like a morning frost, the sloping top of it green with grass, the clan of white geese that cried about the sides, and the black, broken buildings of the prison sitting close on the sea’s edge.

zh: 见此景象，我霎时明白真相了。
en: At the sight the truth came in upon me in a clap.

zh: “这就是你们带我去的地方！”我叫道。
en: “It’s there you’re taking me!” I cried.

zh: “只不过是去巴斯而已，小老弟，”他说，“在你之前有些老圣徒在那里呆过，我怀疑你到这里完全就是来坐牢的呢。”
en: “Just to the Bass, mannie,” said he: “Whaur the auld saints were afore ye, and I misdoubt if ye have come so fairly by your preeson.”

zh: “但是现在没有人住在那里了，”我叫道,“那个地方早就是一片废墟了。”
en: “But none dwells there now,” I cried; “the place is long a ruin.”

zh: “对那些塘鹅来说，这倒是个最为可喜的变化。”安迪冷冷地说道。
en: “It’ll be the mair pleisand a change for the solan geese, then,” quoth Andie dryly.

zh: 天色慢慢变亮了，我注意到在船舱的底部，在一堆渔民用来压舱的大石头中间，有几个小桶和篮子，还有备用的燃料。所有这些都被卸下船运到悬崖峭壁上去了。 安迪，我，还有我那三个高地人（我称他们为我的，尽管是另外一种意义上的）一起登上了岸。小船再次划离时，太阳还没有升起。桨架上的船桨声从悬崖处传出回声，留下我们在这与世隔绝的地方被幽禁起来了。
en: The day coming slowly brighter I observed on the bilge, among the big stones with which fisherfolk ballast their boats, several kegs and baskets, and a provision of fuel.All these were discharged upon the crag.Andie, myself, and my three Highlanders (I call them mine, although it was the other way about), landed along with them.The sun was not yet up when the boat moved away again, the noise of the oars on the thole-pins echoing from the cliffs, and left us in our singular reclusion:

zh: 安迪·戴尔曾是巴斯的长官（我戏谑地这么称呼他），立刻就成了牧羊人兼那片小而富裕的土地的看守人。他得照料大约十二只羊，这些羊已经靠吃斜坡上的青草给养肥了，这些动物就像放牧在大教堂的屋顶上一样。此外他还负责照料栖息在峭壁上的那些塘鹅，他额外的收入正来源于此。仔鹅美味可口，通常的市价都达两先令一只，而且都是美食家们欣然前来付款的。即使老鹅也因为其油和羽毛而颇有价值。直到今天北贝里克郡的牧师们仍会花一部分津贴来付帐买塘鹅，这（在一些人的眼里）使该教区成为了一个人人梦寐以求的教区。为了履行好这几项职责，也为了保护这些塘鹅免遭偷猎，安迪时常睡在峭壁上与塘鹅一起共度时日。我们发现这个人在那里非常自在，就像农夫呆在自己的农场一样。他吩咐我们所有人都得背一些包裹，我急忙去帮忙做这件事，之后他带着我们从一扇上了锁的大门走进，这扇门是此岛唯一的入口。穿过堡垒的断垣残壁，就到达地方长官的住房了。通过烟囱里的灰烬以及房间角落里的一张卧榻，我们明白了那里就是他平常居住的地方。
en: Andie Dale was the Prefect (as I would jocularly call him) of the Bass, being at once the shepherd and the gamekeeper of that small and rich estate.He had to mind the dozen or so of sheep that fed and fattened on the grass of the sloping part of it, like beasts grazing the roof of a cathedral.He had charge besides of the solan geese that roosted in the crags; and from these an extraordinary income is derived.The young are dainty eating, as much as two shillings a-piece being a common price, and paid willingly by epicures; even the grown birds are valuable for their oil and feathers; and a part of the minister’s stipend of North Berwick is paid to this day in solan geese, which makes it (in some folks’ eyes) a parish to be coveted.To perform these several businesses, as well as to protect the geese from poachers, Andie had frequent occasion to sleep and pass days together on the crag; and we found the man at home there like a farmer in his steading.Bidding us all shoulder some of the packages, a matter in which I made haste to bear a hand, he led us in by a looked gate, which was the only admission to the island, and through the ruins of the fortress, to the governor’s house.There we saw by the ashes in the chimney and a standing bed-place in one corner, that he made his usual occupation.

zh: 这张床，他现在主动提出来给我用，理由是他猜到我会提出要得到绅士待遇。
en: This bed he now offered me to use, saying he supposed I would set up to be gentry.

zh: “我的绅士身份和我睡的地方没有一点关系，”我说，“我要赞美主，我曾睡过艰苦的地方，现在可以怀着感激的心情再睡同样艰苦的地方。 我在这里的这段时间，安迪先生，如果那是你的名字的话，我会做好分内的事，和你们其他人在一起。不过另一方面我要请你宽恕我对你的嘲弄，对此我承认我是有点儿恶意。”
en: “My gentrice has nothing to do with where I lie,” said I.“I bless God I have lain hard ere now, and can do the same again with thankfulness.While I am here, Mr. Andie, if that be your name, I will do my part and take my place beside the rest of you; and I ask you on the other hand to spare me your mockery, which I own I like ill.”

zh: 听到这番话，他略微嘟囔了几句，但是似乎在表示赞同。的确，他是一位精明、明事理的人，还是一位善良的辉格党人和长老会成员。他每天都读袖珍《圣经》，既有能力又热心于认真讨论宗教信仰，颇倾向于长老会的极端行为。他的道德观带有一种较让人怀疑的色彩。我发现他做走私生意陷得很深，而且他还利用坦特伦的废墟作仓库来走私军火。 至于说收税官，我相信他认为这里的生活不值一文。但是洛锡安海岸的那块地方至今都还是荒蛮之地，那里的老百姓像苏格兰其他地方的一样粗野。
en: He grumbled a little at this speech, but seemed upon reflection to approve it.Indeed, he was a long-headed, sensible man, and a good Whig and Presbyterian; read daily in a pocket Bible, and was both able and eager to converse seriously on religion, leaning more than a little towards the Cameronian extremes.His morals were of a more doubtful colour.I found he was deep in the free trade, and used the rains of Tantallon for a magazine of smuggled merchandise.As for a gauger, I do not believe he valued the life of one at half-a-farthing.But that part of the coast of Lothian is to this day as wild a place, and the commons there as rough a crew, as any in Scotland.

zh: 在我被关押期间发生的一件事情令人难以忘怀，因为这件事很久以后都还有影响。当时有一艘叫“海马”号的战舰就驻扎在海湾处，舰长是帕利泽。碰巧这艘战舰在九月份巡航，定期在法夫和洛锡安之间往返航行，并进行测量以防出现沉船危险。有一天清早，天气晴朗，在距我们东面约两英里的地方有人看到了该战舰，它放下一只小船，似乎是想查看磷火岩和魔鬼丛，那一带是海岸边出了名的危险区域。不久我们再次看到了那只小船，小船顺风而来，径直驶向了巴斯。这对安迪和那些高地人来说很棘手——我被扣押之事整个就是秘密进行的，而现在，一位海军舰长也许要鲁莽地登岸，就算事态不进一步恶化，这件事看样子也会被公开了。我势单力薄，又不像艾伦能以一当十，我对这艘战舰究竟是否会有可能改善我的处境完全没有底。方方面面都考虑了以后，我向安迪发誓一定好好表现，而且绝对顺从，然后我们脚步轻快地爬到岩石顶部，都在那里躺了下来，就在悬崖的边缘，不过观测点与隐蔽处各自不同。“海马”号笔直驶来，我觉得它已经要撞过来了，我们（头晕目眩地向下望去）可以看到舰上的水手们均各就各位，而且可以听到测深员在测水铅锤前的传报声。然后那军舰突然掉转方向并且发起了猛烈的炮击，我都不知道有多少大炮。岩石在雷鸣般的炮声中摇动，烟雾飘过我们的头顶，不计其数的塘鹅成群飞起，其数量之多令人难以置信。听到鹅群的尖叫声，看到鹅群闪烁的翅膀，使我感到无比好奇。我猜想帕利泽舰长靠巴斯这么近，只是为了满足这种有点儿孩子气的快感。为此他最终将付出不小的代价。在他靠近的过程中，我有机会观察到那艘舰上的索具，正因如此，后来我在数英里之外都认得出该舰。这种方法（在上帝的保佑下）也使我从一位朋友那里避开一场大灾难，并因对帕利泽舰长本人深感失望而痛心不已。
en: One incident of my imprisonment is made memorable by a consequence it had long after.There was a warship at this time stationed in the Firth, the Seahorse, Captain Palliser.It chanced she was cruising in the month of September, plying between Fife and Lothian, and sounding for sunk dangers.Early one fine morning she was seen about two miles to east of us, where she lowered a boat, and seemed to examine the Wildfire Rocks and Satan’s Bush, famous dangers of that coast.And presently after having got her boat again, she came before the wind and was headed directly for the Base.This was very troublesome to Andie and the Highlanders; the whole business of my sequestration was designed for privacy, and here, with a navy captain perhaps blundering ashore, it looked to become public enough, if it were nothing worse.I was in a minority of one, I am no Alan to fall upon so many, and I was far from sure that a warship was the least likely to improve my condition.All which considered, I gave Andie my parole of good behaviour and obedience, and was had briskly to the summit of the rock, where we all lay down, at the cliff’s edge, in different places of observation and concealment.The Seahorse came straight on till I thought she would have struck, and we (looking giddily down) could see the ship’s company at their quarters and hear the leadsman singing at the lead.Then she suddenly wore and let fly a volley of I know not how many great guns.The rock was shaken with the thunder of the sound, the smoke flowed over our heads, and the geese rose in number beyond computation or belief.To hear their screaming and to see the twinkling of their wings, made a most inimitable curiosity; and I suppose it was after this somewhat childish pleasure that Captain Palliser had come so near the Bass.He was to pay dear for it in time.During his approach I had the opportunity to make a remark upon the rigging of that ship by which I ever after knew it miles away; and this was a means (under Providence) of my averting from a friend a great calamity, and inflicting on Captain Palliser himself a sensible disappointment.

zh: 我一直都呆在那块岩石上，我们生活得很好。我们有一些低度麦芽酒和白兰地，还有燕麦片，清早和夜晚我们都用燕麦片煮粥喝。不时有小船从卡斯尔顿过来，给我们带来四分之一头羊肉，因为岩石上的羊我们都不能碰，这是专门养来卖的。遗憾的是，那些塘鹅已经过了可以捕食的季节，我们也就随它们去。我们自己钓鱼，但更多的时候是让塘鹅为我们捕鱼。一注意到有一只塘鹅捕了鱼，就赶紧在它吞下之前夺过其猎物。
en: All the time of my stay on the rock we lived well.We had small ale and brandy, and oatmeal, of which we made our porridge night and morning.At times a boat came from the Castleton and brought us a quarter of mutton, for the sheep upon the rock we must not touch, these being specially fed to market.The geese were unfortunately out of season, and we let them be.We fished ourselves, and yet more often made the geese to fish for us: observing one when he had made a capture and searing him from his prey ere he had swallowed it.

zh: 这个地方奇异的自然景观，以及由此造就的种种奇珍异玩，让我忙得不亦乐乎。因为不可能逃跑，所以我得以有完全的自由。于是凡是人迹可到之处，我都不断地去小岛的表面到处探险。监狱中的那座旧花园仍然值得观赏，鲜花和盆栽植物生长繁茂，在一丛灌木上还挂着一些熟樱桃。 在稍低洼之处伫立着一个小礼拜堂，或者是个修道室。那是由谁修建或者谁曾居住于此，都已经无人可以知晓了，想到其年代久远就足以引发许多遐想。那座监狱，我现在和那些高地山贼就一起露宿在那里，也是一处满载人文和神迹历史的地方。我觉得很奇怪，如此众多的圣徒和殉道者应该是最近才到过那里的，居然连一页他们的经书都没有留下，或者说在墙上居然连一个名字都没有刻。倒是那些粗鲁的士兵小伙子爬上城垛站岗值哨时，在附近到处留下了纪念物——大部分都是破烟斗，其数量之多令人惊讶，还有就是他们大衣上的金属钮扣。 有时候我觉得自己可能听见了地牢里传出的殉道者们虔诚地唱赞美诗的声音，看见了士兵们带着闪闪发光的风笛在城墙上踏步，当时黎明正从他们身后的北海升起。
en: The strange nature of this place, and the curiosities with which it abounded, held me busy and amused.Escape being impossible, I was allowed my entire liberty, and continually explored the surface of the isle wherever it might support the foot of man.The old garden of the prison was still to be observed, with flowers and pot-herbs running wild, and some ripe cherries on a bush.A little lower stood a chapel or a hermit’s cell; who built or dwelt in it, none may know, and the thought of its age made a ground of many meditations.The prison, too, where I now bivouacked with Highland cattle-thieves, was a place full of history, both human and divine.I thought it strange so many saints and martyrs should have gone by there so recently, and left not so much as a leaf out of their Bibles, or a name carved upon the wall, while the rough soldier lads that mounted guard upon the battlements had filled the neighbourhood with their mementoes—broken tobacco-pipes for the most part, and that in a surprising plenty, but also metal buttons from their coats.There were times when I thought I could have heard the pious sound of psalms out of the martyr’s dungeons, and seen the soldiers tramp the ramparts with their glinting pipes, and the dawn rising behind them out of the North Sea.

zh: 无疑正是安迪和他讲的那些故事让我的头脑中充满了这些幻想。他特别熟悉和这块岩石有关的那个故事的种种细节，细致到列兵们的名字，因为他父亲就曾在那里当过同样的列兵。此外，他很有天赋，生来就有讲故事的才能，所以他讲的人物栩栩如生，似乎可以开口说话，他说的事情犹如发生在你面前。他的这份天赋加上我的专心听讲把我们拉在一起，让我们更亲近了。说老实话，我不能否认我喜欢他，不久我看出他也喜欢我。的确，最初我只是刻意想博得他的好感而已。偏僻的环境（就当前而言）造成的影响超出我的预料，但是还没过多久我们这对囚犯和看守竟成为了一对好朋友。
en: No doubt it was a good deal Andie and his tales that put these fancies in my head.He was extraordinarily well acquainted with the story of the rock in all particulars, down to the names of private soldiers, his father having served there in that same capacity.He was gifted besides with a natural genius for narration, so that the people seemed to speak and the things to be done before your face.This gift of his and my assiduity to listen brought us the more close together.I could not honestly deny but what I liked him; I soon saw that he liked me; and indeed, from the first I had set myself out to capture his good-will.An odd circumstance (to be told presently) effected this beyond my expectation; but even in early days we made a friendly pair to be a prisoner and his gaoler.

zh: 如果我再装出一副呆在巴斯完全让人不愉快的样子，那就是昧着自己的良心了。在我看来这里是个安全的地方，好像我是逃到这里来摆脱麻烦的。没有东西能对我造成伤害。物质上来说就不可能，有岩石和深海，使我免遭新的阴谋设计。我感到我的生命很安全，我的声誉也安全，有时候我就任由自己像享受偷来的水那样自得其乐。但还有些时候我的想法则会截然不同，我会想起自己对兰基勒和斯图尔特曾经多么强烈地表白过。我会反思自己在巴斯上面的囚禁生活，只能看着法夫和洛锡安大部分的海岸，是一件我更应该想办法解决而不该长期忍耐的事情。至少在上面提到的两位绅士眼里，我肯定会被看成是一个只会吹牛的懦夫。 现在我对此却看得很淡。我告诉自己只要能赢得卡特里奥娜·德拉蒙德的芳心，其他人的意见都只是空谈和废话而已。于是乎我便抛下一切陷入对恋人的沉思冥想中，这倒是可以让自己满心欢愉，可在旁人看来我如此虚度光阴肯定非常惊讶。但是不久恐惧又促使我从另一个方面去考虑。我因自尊造成的巨大恐慌而内心动摇，看来这些想象中的严厉评判有可能大家都认为还公正呢。 随之就会产生另外一连串的想法，我刚一开始想到他人对我本人的评判，就不由想到了地牢里的詹姆斯·斯图尔特以及他妻子的哀号恸哭。于是，确实，激情开始在我心里燃起，我无法再原谅自己坐在这里无所事事了，就好像（如果我还是个真正的男子汉）我可以飞离或是游泳离开这个安全之地似的。我这么以自责为乐真是太滑稽可笑了，所以我就越发刻意地去赢得安迪·戴尔的好感。
en: I should trifle with my conscience if I pretended my stay upon the Bass was wholly disagreeable.It seemed to me a safe place, as though I was escaped there out of my troubles.No harm was to be offered me; a material impossibility, rock and the deep sea, prevented me from fresh attempts; I felt I had my life safe and my honour safe, and there were times when I allowed myself to gloat on them like stolen waters.At other times my thoughts were very different, I recalled how strong I had expressed myself both to Rankeillor and to Stewart; I reflected that my captivity upon the Bass, in view of a great part of the coasts of Fife and Lothian, was a thing I should be thought more likely to have invented than endured; and in the eyes of these two gentlemen, at least, I must pass for a boaster and a coward.Now I would take this lightly enough; tell myself that so long as I stood well with Catriona Drummond, the opinion of the rest of man was but moonshine and spilled water; and thence pass off into those meditations of a lover which are so delightful to himself and must always appear so surprisingly idle to a reader.But anon the fear would take me otherwise; I would be shaken with a perfect panic of self-esteem, and these supposed hard judgments appear an injustice impossible to be supported.With that another train of thought would he presented, and I had scarce begun to be concerned about men’s judgments of myself, than I was haunted with the remembrance of James Stewart in his dungeon and the lamentations of his wife.Then, indeed, passion began to work in me; I could not forgive myself to sit there idle: it seemed (if I were a man at all) that I could fly or swim out of my place of safety; and it was in such humours and to amuse my self-reproaches that I would set the more particularly to win the good side of Andie Dale.

zh: 最后，在一个晴朗的早晨，当我们两个人单独在岩石顶上时，我隐隐向他暗示可以行贿。他看着我，把头往后一扬，朗声大笑起来。
en: At last, when we two were alone on the summit of the rock on a bright morning, I put in some hint about a bribe.He looked at me, cast back his head, and laughed out loud.

zh: “哎，你真有趣，戴尔先生，”我说，“但是也许只要瞟一眼那张票据，你就会改变口气的。”
en: “Ay, you’re funny, Mr. Dale,” said I, “but perhaps if you’ll glance an eye upon that paper you may change your note.”

zh: 那些愚蠢的高地人抓我的时候从我这里拿走的只是一些硬币，而我现在给安迪看的票据则是一份大不列颠利嫩公司开具的数额相当可观的提款单。
en: The stupid Highlanders had taken from me at the time of my seizure nothing but hard money, and the paper I now showed Andie was an acknowledgment from the British Linen Company for a considerable sum.

zh: 他看了票据。“说真的，你根本不是做那种事的人。”他说。“我认为那张票据也许会改变你的看法。”我说。
en: He read it.“Troth, and ye’re nane sae ill aff,” said he.“I thought that would maybe vary your opinions,” said I.

zh: “嚯！”他说，“那说明你有能力行贿，但我是绝不受贿的。”
en: “Hout!” said he.“It shows me ye can bribe; but I’m no to be bribit.”

zh: “我们过一会儿再讨论那件事，”我说，“首先，我要告诉你我知道我在跟你谈什么。你得到命令要把我扣留在这里直到9月21号星期四以后。”
en: “We’ll see about that yet a while,” says I.“And first, I’ll show you that I know what I am talking.You have orders to detain me here till after Thursday, 21st September.”

zh: “你一点儿都没有弄错，”安迪说，“我会让你走的，拘禁命令要到23号星期六才会解除。”
en: “Ye’re no a’thegether wrong either,” says Andie.“I’m to let you gang, bar orders contrair, on Saturday, the 23rd.”

zh: 我不由地感觉到这种安排里面暗藏着极大的阴谋。那样我再次现身时正好错过按时出庭，那么即便我执意要陈述一番，人们也会更加怀疑我所述的事实。这么一想反倒激起了我的战斗意志。
en: I could not but feel there was something extremely insidious in this arrangement.That I was to re-appear precisely in time to be too late would cast the more discredit on my tale, if I were minded to tell one; and this screwed me to fighting point.

zh: “那么，安迪，既然你了解这个世界，就听我说说，边听边思考吧。”我说，“我知道这件事牵涉到一些大人物，而我也毫不怀疑你已经知晓他们的名字了。自打这件事一开始，我就已经见过其中的一些人了，而且我还当着他们的面说过我的想法。但是我犯的是一种什么样的罪呢？或者说我又触犯了一条什么样的律法呢？8月30日我被那些衣衫破烂的高地佬抓捕，被带到一堆古老的石头里。那个石头堆现在既不是堡垒也不是监狱（无论它曾经是什么），而只是巴斯岩石上那个猎场看守人的小屋。9月23日我又会再次被释放，和我第一次被捕时一样隐秘。你认为这听起来像是合法的吗？或者听起来还公正吗？或者说难道这听起来不正像是一桩让涉足其中的人感到羞耻的卑鄙龌龊的阴谋吗？”
en: “Now then, Andie, you that kens the world, listen to me, and think while ye listen,” said I.“I know there are great folks in the business, and I make no doubt you have their names to go upon.I have seen some of them myself since this affair began, and said my say into their faces too.But what kind of a crime would this be that I had committed? or what kind of a process is this that I am fallen under?To be apprehended by some ragged John-Hielandman on August 30th, carried to a rickle of old stones that is now neither fort nor gaol (whatever it once was) but just the gamekeeper’s lodge of the Bass Rock, and set free again, September 23rd, as secretly as I was first arrested—does that sound like law to you? or does it sound like justice? or does it not sound honestly like a piece of some low dirty intrigue, of which the very folk that meddle with it are ashamed?”

zh: “我无法反驳你，肖斯。这桩事看起来特别卑劣无耻，”安迪说，“如果我们不是那种守规矩、地道的辉格党人和正统的长老会成员的话，我就会看出他们不是约旦人和耶路撒冷人了，或者我早就着手管这件事了。”
en: “I canna gainsay ye, Shaws.It looks unco underhand,” says Andie.“And werenae the folk guid sound Whigs and true-blue Presbyterians I would has seen them ayont Jordan and Jeroozlem or I would have set hand to it.”

zh: “洛瓦特勋爵也是个优秀的辉格党人，”我说，“而且是一位主要的长老会成员。”
en: “The Master of Lovat’ll be a braw Whig,” says I, “and a grand Presbyterian.”

zh: “我对他一无所知，”他说，“我和洛瓦特家族没有打过交道。”
en: “I ken naething by him,” said he.“I hae nae trokings wi’ Lovats.”

zh: “不，你将要打交道的是普雷斯顿格兰奇。”我说。
en: “No, it’ll be Prestongrange that you’ll be dealing with,” said I.

zh: “啊，但是我不会告诉你那种事的。”安迪说。
en: “Ah, but I’ll no tell ye that,” said Andie.

zh: “我也没有什么必要去了解。”我反驳道。
en: “Little need when I ken,” was my retort.

zh: “只有一件事情是你可以肯定的，肖斯，”安迪说，“那就是（你尽可以试试）我不是在和你个人打交道，而且我将来也不会。”他补充说。
en: “There’s just the ae thing ye can be fairly sure of, Shaws,” says Andie.“And that is that (try as ye please) I’m no dealing wi’ yoursel’; nor yet I amnae goin’ to,” he added.

zh: “好吧，安迪，我知道我得和你把话说清楚。”我回答说。我告诉了他很多我认为有必要说的实际情况。
en: “Well, Andie, I see I’ll have to be speak out plain with you,” I replied.And told him so much as I thought needful of the facts.

zh: 他相当认真地听我说，我说完以后，他似乎还独自思考了一阵。
en: He heard me out with some serious interest, and when I had done, seemed to consider a little with himself.

zh: “肖斯，”他最后说，“我只能赤手空拳来应对。照你说的这种情况，这件事是很奇怪，而且不是很可信。不过我完全不是在提醒你，那件事绝对不是你以为的那样。至于你本人，在我看来你似乎是一个颇为正派的年轻人。但是我年纪比你大而且也更为谨慎，也许在处事上看得比你要远一点点。现在这件事对你来说既清楚又简单。如果我把你留在这里，对你本人并没什么损害。不但不会有损害，我认为你这么做反而会处理得更好。对你的族人也没有什么损害——只不过多一个高地人被绞死而已——天知道，总算是摆脱了！另一方面，如果我把你给放了，对我可就会大为不利了。所以，我以一个合格的辉格党、一个忠诚的朋友的身份跟你说，也以一个担忧的朋友的身份告诉自己，事实很清楚，我认为你将不得不和安迪还有塘鹅一起呆在这里。”
en: “Shaws,” said he at last, “I’ll deal with the naked hand.It’s a queer tale, and no very creditable, the way you tell it; and I’m far frae minting that is other than the way that ye believe it.As for yoursel’, ye seem to me rather a dacent-like young man.But me, that’s aulder and mair judeecious, see perhaps a wee bit further forrit in the job than what ye can dae.And here the maitter clear and plain to ye.There’ll be nae skaith to yoursel’ if I keep ye here; far free that, I think ye’ll be a hantle better by it.There’ll be nae skaith to the kintry—just ae mair Hielantman hangit—Gude kens, a guid riddance!On the ither hand, it would be considerable skaith to me if I would let you free.Sae, speakin’ as a guid Whig, an honest freen’ to you, and an anxious freen’ to my ainsel’, the plain fact is that I think ye’ll just have to bide here wi’ Andie an’ the solans.”

zh: “安迪，”我把手放在他的膝盖上说道，“这个高地人是无辜的。”
en: “Andie,” said I, laying my hand upon his knee, “this Hielantman’s innocent.”

zh: “唉，那是很令人惋惜，”他说，“但是你看，在这个世界上，上帝就是这样造万物的，我们未必就可以得到我们想要的东西。”
en: “Ay, it’s a peety about that,” said he.“But ye see, in this warld, the way God made it, we cannae just get a’thing that we want.”

zh: 第十五章 布莱克·安迪关于托德·拉普莱克的故事
en: CHAPTER XV—BLACK ANDIE’S TALE OF TOD LAPRAIK

zh: 到现在为止，我还很少谈及那几个高地人。他们三个人全部都是詹姆斯·莫尔的随从，都和这桩事关他们主人性命的指控非常相关。他们都懂一两句英语，但是尼尔是唯一自认为足以进行一般交流的人，对此（在他登上船之后）他的同伴却常常持相反的看法。他们都是很顺从而单纯的人，从他们褴褛的衣衫和粗俗的样子来看，人们很难想到他们居然表现得这么殷勤有礼，自然而然就像是我和安迪的三个仆人了。
en: I have yet said little of the Highlanders.They were all three of the followers of James More, which bound the accusation very tight about their master’s neck.All understood a word or two of English, but Neil was the only one who judged he had enough of it for general converse, in which (when once he got embarked) his company was often tempted to the contrary opinion.They were tractable, simple creatures; showed much more courtesy than might have been expected from their raggedness and their uncouth appearance, and fell spontaneously to be like three servants for Andie and myself.

zh: 住在这那个与世隔绝的地方，在古老坍塌的监狱废墟里，置身于海浪和海鸟那永无止境的怪异声音中，我觉得自己早就从中感觉到迷信导致的恐惧效果了。 在无事可做的时候，要么他们就会躺下来睡觉，他们的这种欲望好像永远不会满足似的，要么尼尔就会讲一些故事来让其他人开心，但是似乎讲的总是一些令人恐怖而紧张的故事。如果这两样都不能让大家高兴的话——或许有两个人在睡觉，而第三个人无论如何都无法像他们那样入睡——我就会看到他坐着、聆听、环顾周围，情绪逐渐不安起来，于是他的脸开始发白，双手紧握，整个人就像一张绷紧弦的弓。我一直没有弄清楚这种恐惧从何而来，但是看到他们那副样子也会受感染的，而且我们呆的这个地方本来就容易让人感到恐慌。我在英语中找不到词汇来描述这种恐慌，但是安迪却一直用同一个苏格兰的词语来表达这种感觉。
en: Dwelling in that isolated place, in the old falling ruins of a prison, and among endless strange sounds of the sea and the sea-birds, I thought I perceived in them early the effects of superstitious fear.When there was nothing doing they would either lie and sleep, for which their appetite appeared insatiable, or Neil would entertain the others with stories which seemed always of a terrifying strain.If neither of these delights were within reach—if perhaps two were sleeping and the third could find no means to follow their example—I would see him sit and listen and look about him in a progression of uneasiness, starting, his face blenching, his hands clutched, a man strung like a bow.The nature of these fears I had never an occasion to find out, but the sight of them was catching, and the nature of the place that we were in favourable to alarms.I can find no word for it in the English, but Andie had an expression for it in the Scots from which he never varied.

zh: “唉，”他会说，“巴斯，一个怪异的地方。”
en: “Ay,” he would say, “its an unco place, the Bass.”

zh: 正是这样我总会想到这个词。这里夜晚怪异，白天也很怪异。还有很怪异的塘鹅的鸣叫声、海浪的拍击声，以及岩石的回声，都不断地在我们耳边回响。天气温和的时候，这里尤其怪异。当海浪巨大的时候，就会咆哮着撞击岩石，像雷声和军队的战鼓声一样，听起来既骇人又欢快。所以在平静的日子里，一个人听着听着就会吓到自己——不仅仅是高地人如此，因为我亲自实验过几次，各种低沉的噪声时常在岩石的回廊中萦绕，久久回响。
en: It is so I always think of it.It was an unco place by night, unco by day; and these were unco sounds, of the calling of the solans, and the plash of the sea and the rock echoes, that hung continually in our ears.It was chiefly so in moderate weather.When the waves were anyway great they roared about the rock like thunder and the drums of armies, dreadful but merry to hear; and it was in the calm days that a man could daunt himself with listening—not a Highlandman only, as I several times experimented on myself, so many still, hollow noises haunted and reverberated in the porches of the rock.

zh: 这让我想起曾经听过的一个故事，以及我听故事时的情景，那个故事大大改变了我们的生活状态，对我离开那里也产生了极大的影响。事情发生在一天夜里，我在火堆旁陷入了沉思，（我回想起了艾伦教的那首小调）就开始吹起了口哨。一只手放到我的手臂上，是尼尔的声音叫我别吹了，因为那首曲调不是“吉祥的音乐”。
en: This brings me to a story I heard, and a scene I took part in, which quite changed our terms of living, and had a great effect on my departure.It chanced one night I fell in a muse beside the fire and (that little air of Alan’s coming back to my memory) began to whistle.A hand was laid upon my arm, and the voice of Neil bade me to stop, for it was not “canny musics.”

zh: “不吉祥？”我问，“那怎么可能？”
en: “Not canny?” I asked.“How can that be?”

zh: “喏，”他说，“这是一个妖怪唱的，而她是想要那个人项上的脑袋。”
en: “Na,” said he; “it will be made by a bogle and her wanting ta heid upon his body.”(1)

zh: “嗯，”我说，“这里不可能有什么妖怪，尼尔，因为他们不可能有心思来吓唬塘鹅的。”
en: “Well,” said I, “there can be no bogles here, Neil; for it’s not likely they would fash themselves to frighten geese.”

zh: “啊？”安迪说，“你居然是那么想的！但是我可以告诉你，这里就算没有妖怪，也有更厉害的。”
en: “Ay?” says Andie, “is that what ye think of it!But I’ll can tell ye there’s been waur nor bogles here.”

zh: “什么会比妖怪更厉害，安迪？”我说。
en: “What’s waur than bogles, Andie?” said I.

zh: “巫师们。”他说，“或者说至少有一个巫师。那也是一个离奇的故事，”他补充说，“如果你们愿意听，我就讲给你们听。”
en: “Warlocks,” said he.“Or a warlock at the least of it.And that’s a queer tale, too,” he added.“And if ye would like, I’ll tell it ye.”

zh: 当然我们的想法都很一致，甚至连那三个高地人中英语最不济的那位都下定决心要竭尽全力地去听。
en: To be sure we were all of the one mind, and even the Highlander that had the least English of the three set himself to listen with all his might.

zh: 托德·拉普莱克的故事
en: THE TALE OF TOD LAPRAIK

zh: 我的父亲，塔姆·戴尔，愿他在天之灵得到安息，年轻时曾是个野性十足、颇不安分的小子，既没有什么才智也没有什么德行。他好色、贪杯，喜欢狂欢纵饮。但是说起做诚实可敬的事情来，我却从没听说他有什么大的用处。他不停地换差事，最后还报名去当了兵，就驻守在这座堡垒里，戴尔家族到巴斯的第一个人就是以这种方式落脚的。那次服役可遭罪了！长官就只顾酿自己的酒，这似乎也太不可思议了。岩石上所需的供给都是从河流海滨运来的，但是出过一回船迷航的事，结果那段时间他们就只好靠捕鱼和射杀塘鹅为食了。 对整个王国来说，那段日子正在大搞宗教迫害。这个堡垒的死囚牢房里关满了圣徒和殉教者，关了多年，这件事根本就不值得那么做。尽管塔姆·戴尔带着一杆明火枪在那里，是一个单身大兵，正如我前面所说，他既好色又贪杯，但是这个人的头脑中倒不只是想着站岗的职责。他还想着苏格兰教会的荣耀，那段时间他看到上帝的圣徒误入歧途，为此他怒火丛生，同时也为自己还得拿着枪（或者扛着明火枪）参与如此黑暗的勾当而感到羞愧。每当夜晚他在这里站岗的时候，这个地方完全是个风口，也许是冬日的严寒撕裂了墙壁。他听到有一个囚犯开始唱起圣歌来，接着其余的人都加了进来，于是从不同的狱室或者地牢里都传来了唱赞美诗的声音，我完全可以说——结果海洋中的这座古老悬崖就好像是天堂的一个部分了。沉重的羞愧感压在了他的灵魂上，他的罪恶不断浮现在他面前，就像巴斯这块巨岩那么庞大，而他主要的罪孽就是参与了对基督教教会的破坏和捣乱。不过实际上他是在抵挡圣灵。白天到来，同伴们都起床了，而他已痛下决心要离开。
en: My faither, Tam Dale, peace to his banes, was a wild, sploring lad in his young days, wi’ little wisdom and little grace.He was fond of a lass and fond of a glass, and fond of a ran-dan; but I could never hear tell that he was muckle use for honest employment.Frae ae thing to anither, he listed at last for a sodger and was in the garrison of this fort, which was the first way that ony of the Dales cam to set foot upon the Bass.Sorrow upon that service!The governor brewed his ain ale; it seems it was the warst conceivable.The rock was proveesioned free the shore with vivers, the thing was ill-guided, and there were whiles when they but to fish and shoot solans for their diet.To crown a’, thir was the Days of the Persecution.The perishin’ cauld chalmers were all occupeed wi’ sants and martyrs, the saut of the yearth, of which it wasnae worthy.And though Tam Dale carried a firelock there, a single sodger, and liked a lass and a glass, as I was sayin,’ the mind of the man was mair just than set with his position.He had glints of the glory of the kirk; there were whiles when his dander rase to see the Lord’s sants misguided, and shame covered him that he should be haulding a can’le (or carrying a firelock) in so black a business.There were nights of it when he was here on sentry, the place a’ wheesht, the frosts o’ winter maybe riving in the wa’s, and he would hear ane o’ the prisoners strike up a psalm, and the rest join in, and the blessed sounds rising from the different chalmers—or dungeons, I would raither say—so that this auld craig in the sea was like a pairt of Heev’n.Black shame was on his saul; his sins hove up before him muckle as the Bass, and above a’, that chief sin, that he should have a hand in hagging and hashing at Christ’s Kirk.But the truth is that he resisted the spirit.Day cam, there were the rousing compainions, and his guid resolves depairtit.

zh: 那些日子，在巴斯住着一位圣人，他的名字叫先知佩登。你们应该已经听人说过先知佩登的故事。从那以后就再也没有他的踪影，而很多人都弄不清楚从前是否曾有过他这么个人。他完全就像是一截泥炭，看起来吓人，听起来也吓人，他的神情就像是到了世界末日的审判。他的声音就像塘鹅的叫声一样在人们的耳边嗡嗡地响个不停，他说的话语就像炭火一样炙热烤人。
en: In thir days, dwalled upon the Bass a man of God, Peden the Prophet was his name.Ye’ll have heard tell of Prophet Peden.There was never the wale of him sinsyne, and it’s a question wi’ mony if there ever was his like afore.He was wild’s a peat-hag, fearsome to look at, fearsome to hear, his face like the day of judgment.The voice of him was like a solan’s and dinnle’d in folks’ lugs, and the words of him like coals of fire.

zh: 当时岩石上有一位少女，而我认为她没什么事情可做，因为那根本不是正派女人呆的地方。不过她好像很漂亮，而且她和塔姆·戴尔一拍即合。事情是这样发生的：佩登正在花园里自己的小屋内做祷告，这时塔姆和那位少女走了过来，那少女做什么不好偏偏要大声笑着去嘲笑那位圣人的虔诚祷告？他起身看着他们两个人，塔姆一看到他的神情，膝盖就不停地磕碰打颤。但是他说话的时候，语气中透露的不是愤怒而是悲伤。“可怜的东西，可怜的东西！”他看着那少女说道，“我听到你尖叫着嘲笑我，”他说，“可是上帝已经为你备下死期，在那令人吃惊的审判时刻，你也会这样尖叫一次的！”之后不久她和两三个士兵在悬崖上漫步，那天天气很晴朗。突然一阵大风刮来，卷住了她的外套，连同她的提包和随身行李一起都给刮走了。而让那些士兵印象最深的就是她坠落时发出了一声尖叫。
en: Now there was a lass on the rock, and I think she had little to do, for it was nae place far decent weemen; but it seems she was bonny, and her and Tam Dale were very well agreed.It befell that Peden was in the gairden his lane at the praying when Tam and the lass cam by; and what should the lassie do but mock with laughter at the sant’s devotions?He rose and lookit at the twa o’ them, and Tam’s knees knoitered thegether at the look of him.But whan he spak, it was mair in sorrow than in anger.“Poor thing, poor thing!” says he, and it was the lass he lookit at, “I hear you skirl and laugh,” he says, “but the Lord has a deid shot prepared for you, and at that surprising judgment ye shall skirl but the ae time!”Shortly thereafter she was daundering on the craigs wi’ twa-three sodgers, and it was a blawy day.There cam a gowst of wind, claught her by the coats, and awa’ wi’ her bag and baggage.And it was remarked by the sodgers that she gied but the ae skirl.

zh: 毫无疑问这个判决对塔姆·戴尔产生了一些影响。但是事情已经过去了，而他一点儿都没有好转。有一天他和另外一个士兵发生了争吵。“我碰到鬼了！”塔姆叫道，因为他喜欢用亵渎神灵的话来诅咒发誓。佩登就在那边盯着他看，眼神睿智而悲伤。佩登的长眉倒立、目光如炬，灰色的披肩在胸前飘拂，他伸出了手，指尖上是黑黑的指甲——因为他从来就不关注自己的身体。“嘿，嘿，可怜的人！”他叫道，“可怜而愚蠢的人！他居然说‘我碰到鬼了’，而我却看见魔鬼就在他的腋下。”相信自己有罪并渴望神的宽恕这种想法像深深的海洋一样淹没了塔姆，他掷下手中的长枪——“我将不再举起武器反抗基督的意志！”他说，结果也正应了神的话语。最初有一番激烈的争论，但是长官看到他决心已定，就同意让他退伍了。于是他就走了，在北贝里克郡定居并且结了婚，而且从那天起他与诚实的人们交往并赢得了自己的好名声。
en: Nae doubt this judgment had some weicht upon Tam Dale; but it passed again and him none the better.Ae day he was flyting wi’ anither sodger-lad.“Deil hae me!” quo’ Tam, for he was a profane swearer.And there was Peden glowering at him, gash an’ waefu’; Peden wi’ his lang chafts an’ luntin’ een, the maud happed about his kist, and the hand of him held out wi’ the black nails upon the finger-nebs—for he had nae care of the body.“Fy, fy, poor man!” cries he, “the poor fool man!Deil hae me, quo’ he; an’ I see the deil at his oxter.”The conviction of guilt and grace cam in on Tam like the deep sea; he flang doun the pike that was in his hands—“I will nae mair lift arms against the cause o’ Christ!” says he, and was as gude’s word.There was a sair fyke in the beginning, but the governor, seeing him resolved, gied him his discharge, and he went and dwallt and merried in North Berwick, and had aye a gude name with honest folk free that day on.

zh: 巴斯是在1706年落入达隆勃莱家族手中的，当时有两个人负责管理这个地方。这两个人都能胜任，因为他们都当过驻防的士兵，都熟知捕猎塘鹅的门道、捕猎的时节及其价值。此外他们两个人都是——或者他们似乎都像是——认真的专业人员和善于交际的人。他们中的第一个就是塔姆·戴尔，我的父亲。 第二个就是拉普莱克，大多数时候人们称之为托德·拉普莱克，不过到底是因为他的名字还是因为他的脾性才这样称呼他，我就从来没有听人说过了。好，塔姆在拉普莱克行巫术的时候去找过他，还带了我，我那时还是个蹒跚学步、需要牵着手走的孩子。托德住在苏格兰教堂以北的一条深深的巷子里。那是条幽暗神秘的小巷，此外，那座教堂从詹姆斯六世起就一直名声不好，女王在海上的时候这里还闹过鬼。至于说托德的房屋，就在小巷子的最尽头，对此很了解的人都很不喜欢这里。那天大门敞开着，于是我和我父亲就径直走了进去。 托德在行巫术时是个织布工，他的织布机就立在客厅里。 他就坐在那里，是一个非常肥胖、皮肤苍白得就像抹了油脂的家伙。他的脸上带着一种诡异的微笑，让我看到就深感厌恶。他的手在吱吱嘎嘎地穿着梭子，但是他的双眼却紧紧地闭着。我们对着他喊他的名字，我们围在他那聋了似的耳朵边叫喊着，我们摇动着他的肩膀。根本就没有一点儿用！他就坐在他的纱卷堆上，吱吱嘎嘎地穿着梭子，脸上一副皮笑肉不笑的样子。
