zh: 但是做祷告并不很难，行动起来就难了。她在场时，如果是我先开始表现出亲密，我发现我就很难掌控随后的局面。但是整天和她坐在同一间房屋里，却要假装专心在看海纳修斯的书，那又是我力所不能及的。所以我只好采取权宜之计，就是尽自己最大的可能不呆在家里。我按时出去上课，坐在教室里，却常常不太专心。前几天我在一个笔记本里发现那段时间有套测试题就没有做完，而是在后面写了一篇有教训意义的讲稿，实际上笔记本里还潦草地抄了几句很糟糕的诗。不过我从没有想到我的拉丁文学习掌握得要比我预想的好很多。很不幸，这么做的弊和利几乎一样多。我受考验的时间是少一些了，但我相信，只要随着时间持续下去，我经受的考验会更加严峻。因为她长时间被单独留下，等我回去，她迎接我的时候就越来越热情，这种热情几欲使我乖乖就范。对这些友善的表示，我只能粗暴地予以拒绝，但我的拒绝有时却无情地伤害了她，我只好又放下身段好心地去弥补我给她感情上造成的伤害。所以我们的时光就这样时而开心，时而痛苦，在争执和失望中流逝，我几乎可以说（如果可以说得礼貌一点儿）我已经被钉在十字架上了。
en: But prayer is not very difficult, and the hitch comes in practice.In her presence, and above all if I allowed any beginning of familiarity, I found I had very little command of what should follow.But to sit all day in the same room with her, and feign to be engaged upon Heineccius, surpassed my strength.So that I fell instead upon the expedient of absenting myself so much as I was able; taking out classes and sitting there regularly, often with small attention, the test of which I found the other day in a note-book of that period, where I had left off to follow an edifying lecture and actually scribbled in my book some very ill verses, though the Latinity is rather better than I thought that I could ever have compassed.The evil of this course was unhappily near as great as its advantage.I had the less time of trial, but I believe, while the time lasted, I was tried the more extremely.For she being so much left to solitude, she came to greet my return with an increasing fervour that came nigh to overmaster me.These friendly offers I must barbarously cast back; and my rejection sometimes wounded her so cruelly that I must unbend and seek to make it up to her in kindness.So that our time passed in ups and downs, tiffs and disappointments, upon the which I could almost say (if it may be said with reverence) that I was crucified.

zh: 我烦恼的根源在于卡特里奥娜特别天真，对此我并不是那么奇怪，而是充满了同情和赞赏。她似乎从来没有想过我们的处境，从来没有感觉到我的种种努力。她对我任何心软的表现都满心欢愉地予以回应，而当我迫不得已再次对自己加以克制时，她又总是不掩饰自己的懊恼。有时我暗自思忖：“要不是她深坠情网，执意想嫁给我的话，她几乎不可能表现得这么殷勤。”于是我会再一次惊讶于女性的单纯，（每逢这种时刻）我都觉得我不值得她屈尊以待。
en: The base of my trouble was Catriona’s extraordinary innocence, at which I was not so much surprised as filled with pity and admiration.She seemed to have no thought of our position, no sense of my struggles; welcomed any mark of my weakness with responsive joy; and when I was drove again to my retrenchments, did not always dissemble her chagrin.There were times when I have thought to myself, “If she were over head in love, and set her cap to catch me, she would scarce behave much otherwise;” and then I would fall again into wonder at the simplicity of woman, from whom I felt (in these moments) that I was not worthy to be descended.

zh: 所有的事情中，有一点特别能表现出我们之间的冲突，那就是她的衣服的问题。我的行李紧跟着很快就从鹿特丹运了过来，而她的则是从赫尔沃埃特运来的。可以这么说，她现在有两种衣服，我们互相都越来越清楚（我根本说不出是怎么回事），她表示友好时就会穿我给她买的衣服，反之就会穿她自己的衣服。她那是有意在打击我，而且（可以这么说）是在表示她不再心存感激，对此我内心也已经感觉到了，但是我一般很明智，不会表现出已经注意到这种情况。
en: There was one point in particular on which our warfare turned, and of all things, this was the question of her clothes.My baggage had soon followed me from Rotterdam, and hers from Helvoet.She had now, as it were, two wardrobes; and it grew to be understood between us (I could never tell how) that when she was friendly she would wear my clothes, and when otherwise her own.It was meant for a buffet, and (as it were) the renunciation of her gratitude; and I felt it so in my bosom, but was generally more wise than to appear to have observed the circumstance.

zh: 但是有一次，的确，我自己表现出的那种幼稚比她更为严重。事情是这样的。我下课回来时，一门心思在想着她，满怀无尽的爱恋，此外还有深深的烦恼。这种烦恼开始渐渐淡出我的思绪，这时我在一扇窗户里瞥见了一些插花，荷兰人非常精于此道。我一时冲动就为卡特里奥娜买了一枝。我不知道那枝花的名称，不过那花是粉红色的，而我认为她同样会欣赏，于是满腔柔情蜜意带回家给她。我走的时候她本来穿着我给她的衣服，可是我回去时却发现她已经全换掉了，而且脸色也随之全变了。我从头到脚只看了她一眼，就咬紧牙关，猛然推开窗户，把花给扔到了院子里，随后（在狂怒和谨慎之间）我又冲出房屋，出去时还用力把门给摔上了。
en: Once, indeed, I was betrayed into a childishness greater than her own; it fell in this way.On my return from classes, thinking upon her devoutly with a great deal of love and a good deal of annoyance in the bargain, the annoyance began to fade away out of my mind; and spying in a window one of those forced flowers, of which the Hollanders are so skilled in the artifice, I gave way to an impulse and bought it for Catriona.I do not know the name of that flower, but it was of the pink colour, and I thought she would admire the same, and carried it home to her with a wonderful soft heart.I had left her in my clothes, and when I returned to find her all changed and a face to match, I cast but the one look at her from head to foot, ground my teeth together, flung the window open, and my flower into the court, and then (between rage and prudence) myself out of that room again, of which I slammed the door as I went out.

zh: 在陡峭的楼梯上我差一点儿绊倒，这让我清醒了过来，于是我立刻开始注意到自己的行为非常愚蠢。我没有按原来的打算到街上去，而是去了房前的庭院，那里一向都很僻静，在那里我看见我买的花（我花的钱远超过它的实际价值）就挂在那棵掉光叶子的树上。我站在运河边上，看着河面上的冰。那些乡下人穿着冰鞋一溜而过，我嫉妒他们。我对于目前所处的困境一筹莫展，也根本没办法返回我刚离开的房间。无疑我内心的情感秘密现在已经全部暴露，而且更为糟糕的是，与此同时我（带着顽童的劣性）还对我那无助的客人表现得很粗野无礼。
en: On the steep stair I came near falling, and this brought me to myself, so that I began at once to see the folly of my conduct.I went, not into the street as I had purposed, but to the house court, which was always a solitary place, and where I saw my flower (that had cost me vastly more than it was worth) hanging in the leafless tree.I stood by the side of the canal, and looked upon the ice.Country people went by on their skates, and I envied them.I could see no way out of the pickle I was in no way so much as to return to the room I had just left.No doubt was in my mind but I had now betrayed the secret of my feelings; and to make things worse, I had shown at the same time (and that with wretched boyishness) incivility to my helpless guest.

zh: 我想她肯定已经从那扇敞开的窗户看见我了。好像我没有站多久就听到冰冻的雪地上传来了嘎吱嘎吱的脚步声，我有点儿愤怒地转过身（因为我不愿思绪被打断），就看见卡特里奥娜走了过来。她的穿着又全部换回来了，一直到脚上的织花长袜。
en: I suppose she must have seen me from the open window.It did not seem to me that I had stood there very long before I heard the crunching of footsteps on the frozen snow, and turning somewhat angrily (for I was in no spirit to be interrupted) saw Catriona drawing near.She was all changed again, to the clocked stockings.

zh: “我们今天不去散步了吗？”她说。
en: “Are we not to have our walk to-day?” said she.

zh: 我困惑地看着她。“你的胸针到哪里去了？”我说。
en: I was looking at her in a maze.“Where is your brooch?” says I.

zh: 她把手放在胸前，满面绯红。“我把它给忘记了，”她说，“我会很快跑上楼去拿，然后我们真的会去散步吧？”
en: She carried her hand to her bosom and coloured high.“I will have forgotten it,” said she.“I will run upstairs for it quick, and then surely we’ll can have our walk?”

zh: 她最后那句话中恳求的语气让我心意动摇了。我说不出话也发不出声音，只能点点头作为回答。她离开我的时候，我爬上树把花取了下来，而我在她再次返回时又把花献给了她。
en: There was a note of pleading in that last that staggered me; I had neither words nor voice to utter them; I could do no more than nod by way of answer; and the moment she had left me, climbed into the tree and recovered my flower, which on her return I offered her.

zh: “我是为你买的花，卡特里奥娜。”我说。
en: “I bought it for you, Catriona,” said I.

zh: 她用胸针把花别在胸前正中间，我已经可以温和地进行思考了。
en: She fixed it in the midst of her bosom with the brooch, I could have thought tenderly.

zh: “这件事我一点都没有处理好。”我又说道，脸也红了。
en: “It is none the better of my handling,” said I again, and blushed.

zh: “我还是会好好珍惜它的，对此你尽可以放心。”她说。
en: “I will be liking it none the worse, you may be sure of that,” said she.

zh: 那天我们没有说太多的话，她似乎想着要含蓄一点儿，尽管并不是不近人情。至于我，在我们散步的时候，到我们回家以后，再到我看着她把我送的花放进装了水的花瓶里，这整段时间里我一直都在暗自思忖，女人真是让人捉摸不透啊！ 我在想，那一刻，要是她还没有察觉到我的爱，那她就是世上最愚蠢的家伙了。跟着我又在想，也许她肯定早就已经察觉到了（作为一个具有女性把握分寸本能的聪明女孩），只是对这一点隐藏不露而已。
en: We did not speak so much that day; she seemed a thought on the reserve, though not unkindly.As for me, all the time of our walking, and after we came home, and I had seen her put my flower into a pot of water, I was thinking to myself what puzzles women were.I was thinking, the one moment, it was the most stupid thing on earth she should not have perceived my love; and the next, that she had certainly perceived it long ago, and (being a wise girl with the fine female instinct of propriety) concealed her knowledge.

zh: 我们每天都去散步。在外面的街上我觉得更安全，我可以稍微放松一点儿警戒心。首先，这里没有海纳修斯。这样一来这段时间不仅对我自己是一种放松，而且对我那位可怜的女孩来说也特别开心。当我在约定的时间前后回来时，一般我都会发现她早已经穿戴好了，因充满期待而容光焕发。她会尽量延长那段散步的时间，好像害怕（我也一样）回去的时刻。在莱登附近几乎没有一块田野或者河畔，也几乎没有一条街道或者小巷是我们没有漫步徘徊过的。除散步去这些地方之外，我吩咐她一步也不要离开我们的住处。这样做是担心她遇见什么熟人，那就会使我们的处境非常困难。出于同样的担心，我也从不让她去教堂，甚至连我自己都不去。但是我们尽力设法在自己的房间里悄悄地做祷告——我希望自己是很有诚意地在祷告，但是我确信自己已经心猿意马了。实际上，再没有比这更能打动我的了：我们俩跪拜在上帝的面前，就像丈夫和妻子一样。
en: We had our walk daily.Out in the streets I felt more safe; I relaxed a little in my guardedness; and for one thing, there was no Heineccius.This made these periods not only a relief to myself, but a particular pleasure to my poor child.When I came back about the hour appointed, I would generally find her ready dressed, and glowing with anticipation.She would prolong their duration to the extreme, seeming to dread (as I did myself) the hour of the return; and there is scarce a field or waterside near Leyden, scarce a street or lane there, where we have not lingered.Outside of these, I bade her confine herself entirely to our lodgings; this in the fear of her encountering any acquaintance, which would have rendered our position very difficult.From the same apprehension I would never suffer her to attend church, nor even go myself; but made some kind of shift to hold worship privately in our own chamber—I hope with an honest, but I am quite sure with a very much divided mind.Indeed, there was scarce anything that more affected me, than thus to kneel down alone with her before God like man and wife.

zh: 有一天大雪纷飞。我想我们不可能再冒昧地出去散步了，然而我非常惊讶地发现她已经穿戴整齐在等着我了。
en: One day it was snowing downright hard.I had thought it not possible that we should venture forth, and was surprised to find her waiting for me ready dressed.

zh: “不去散步我才不干呢。”她叫道，“戴维，在房子里时，你从来都不是个好男孩。只有到户外我才不用再担心你了。我想我们两个最好变成埃及人，就住在路边算了。”
en: “I will not be doing without my walk,” she cried.“You are never a good boy, Davie, in the house; I will never be caring for you only in the open air.I think we two will better turn Egyptian and dwell by the roadside.”

zh: 那天对我们来说是最美好的一次散步了，她在纷纷扬扬的大雪中依偎着我。雪花飘落下来，在我们身上融化，水滴像眼泪一样凝在她光滑的脸颊上，然后滑落进她微笑的嘴角。我似乎浑身充满了力量，样子犹如巨人。我觉得我可能已经追到她了，并且和她一起奔向世界的尽头。真令人难以置信，我们一起一直在谈论着自由和甜蜜。
en: That was the best walk yet of all of them; she clung near to me in the falling snow; it beat about and melted on us, and the drops stood upon her bright cheeks like tears and ran into her smiling mouth.Strength seemed to come upon me with the sight like a giant’s; I thought I could have caught her up and run with her into the uttermost places in the earth; and we spoke together all that time beyond belief for freedom and sweetness.

zh: 我们走回房门口时已经是深夜了。她把我的手臂放在她的胸前。“非常感谢你给我如此美好的时光。”她说，她的声音很深沉。
en: It was the dark night when we came to the house door.She pressed my arm upon her bosom.“Thank you kindly for these same good hours,” said she, on a deep note of her voice.

zh: 听闻此言我立刻开始担心起来，赶紧提醒自己要警惕。我们刚一进房间点上灯，她就看到了那位研究海纳修斯的学生露出了那副熟悉、冷峻而坚毅的面容。无疑她比以往受的伤害更大，而我自己也清楚，要继续保持生分也比以往更困难。 甚至在吃饭的时候，我都不敢解开衣扣，也很少抬眼去看她。可是很快我又变回平时的样子，似乎比以前更加心不在焉，理解力也更不如从前。我想，就像我曾经读到过的，我可以听到自己的心跳，就像一座八天才上一次发条的摆钟。虽然我竭力地假装在学习，但我还是有部分眼光透过书页落在卡特里奥娜的身上。她坐在地板上，靠在我的大行李包旁边，炉火照亮了她，在她身上照耀和闪烁着，使她在炉火神奇的光色中忽明忽暗的。她时而凝视着炉火，时而又看看我。见此，我陷入对自己的恐慌中，于是去翻海纳修斯的书页，犹如教堂里在寻找经文的教徒。
en: The concern in which I fell instantly on this address, put me with the same swiftness on my guard; and we were no sooner in the chamber, and the light made, than she beheld the old, dour, stubborn countenance of the student of Heineccius.Doubtless she was more than usually hurt; and I know for myself, I found it more than usually difficult to maintain any strangeness.Even at the meal, I durst scarce unbuckle and scarce lift my eyes to her; and it was no sooner over than I fell again to my civilian, with more seeming abstraction and less understanding than before.Methought, as I read, I could hear my heart strike like an eight-day clock.Hard as I feigned to study, there was still some of my eyesight that spilled beyond the book upon Catriona.She sat on the floor by the side of my great mail, and the chimney lighted her up, and shone and blinked upon her, and made her glow and darken through a wonder of fine hues.Now she would be gazing in the fire, and then again at me; and at that I would be plunged in a terror of myself, and turn the pages of Heineccius like a man looking for the text in church.

zh: 她突然大声叫喊起来。“哦，为什么我父亲还没有来？”她叫喊着，顿时泪如雨下。
en: Suddenly she called out aloud.“O, why does not my father come?” she cried, and fell at once into a storm of tears.

zh: 我跳起来，把海纳修斯的书猛然丢进火中，跑向她的身边，伸出一只手臂拥住她抽泣的身体。
en: I leaped up, flung Heineccius fairly in the fire, ran to her side, and cast an arm around her sobbing body.

zh: “你不爱你的朋友。”她猛力推开我说，“我也可以很高兴的，只要你想让我高兴！”接着她又说：“哦，我到底做了什么让你这么讨厌我？”
en: She put me from her sharply, “You do not love your friend,” says she.“I could be so happy too, if you would let me!”And then, “O, what will I have done that you should hate me so?”

zh: “讨厌你！”我叫道，紧紧抓着她，“你这个瞎了眼的姑娘，你一点儿也看不见我内心的痛苦吗？难道你不觉得，我坐在那里读我刚烧掉的那本该死的破书时，除了你我一点儿都没有想别的任何事情吗？夜复一夜，我看着你独自一人坐在那里，我心里难受得想哭。但我能做什么？你在这里受到我的尊重，你为此就要惩罚我吗？难道为此你就要抛弃钟爱你的仆人吗？”
en: “Hate you!” cries I, and held her firm.“You blind less, can you not see a little in my wretched heart?Do you not think when I sit there, reading in that fool-book that I have just burned and be damned to it, I take ever the least thought of any stricken thing but just yourself?Night after night I could have grat to see you sitting there your lone.And what was I to do?You are here under my honour; would you punish me for that?Is it for that that you would spurn a loving servant?”

zh: 听到这话，她突然轻轻动了一下，就朝我依偎了过来。我把她的脸抬向我，吻了她的脸庞，然后她就埋下头靠在我胸前，紧紧地抱着我。我像个醉汉一样，只觉得眼前一阵天旋地转。随后就听见她声音很小在说话，那声音是蒙在我的衣服里传出来的。
en: At the word, with a small, sudden motion, she clung near to me.I raised her face to mine, I kissed it, and she bowed her brow upon my bosom, clasping me tight.I saw in a mere whirl like a man drunken.Then I heard her voice sound very small and muffled in my clothes.

zh: “你真的吻了她吗？”她问。
en: “Did you kiss her truly?” she asked.

zh: 这一问太出乎我的意料之外了，我感到非常震惊。
en: There went through me so great a heave of surprise that I was all shook with it.

zh: “格兰特小姐吗？”我叫道，完全乱了方寸，“是的，我叫她跟我吻别，她就那么做了。”
en: “Miss Grant?” I cried, all in a disorder.“Yes, I asked her to kiss me good-bye, the which she did.”

zh: “啊，好吧！”她说，“不管怎么说，你也已经吻过我了。”
en: “Ah, well!” said she, “you have kissed me too, at all events.”

zh: 听到这句既奇怪又甜蜜的话，我明白我们已经陷得太深。我站起身，把她也扶了起来。
en: At the strangeness and sweetness of that word, I saw where we had fallen; rose, and set her on her feet.

zh: “这样做真的不行，”我说，“这样做真的、真的不行。哦，卡特琳，卡特琳！”接着我停顿了一下，梗着什么话都说不出来。“去你床上睡觉吧。”我接着说，“去你床上睡觉，去吧。”
en: “This will never do,” said I.“This will never, never do.O Catrine, Catrine!”Then there came a pause in which I was debarred from any speaking.And then, “Go away to your bed,” said I.“Go away to your bed and leave me.”

zh: 她像个孩子一样听我的话转过身去了，随后，我知道她又在门口停住了。
en: She turned to obey me like a child, and the next I knew of it, had stopped in the very doorway.

zh: “晚安，戴维！”她说。
en: “Good night, Davie!” said she.

zh: “哦，晚安，亲爱的！”我叫道，随着内心真挚情感的爆发，我又把她拽向身边，好像都要把她给折断了。接着我使劲把她推出了这间房，用力把门关上，然后独自站着。
en: “And O, good night, my love!” I cried, with a great outbreak of my soul, and caught her to me again, so that it seemed I must have broken her.The next moment I had thrust her from the room, shut to the door even with violence, and stood alone.

zh: 现在牛奶已经泼出，话已经出口，真情也已告白。我像一个不可靠的男人，已经偷偷爬进了那可怜的少女的情感世界。她在我掌握之中，好像很脆弱、天真，极易得到或者受到伤害。那么是什么防护武器被我给丢了呢？看来似乎是那个海纳修斯的象征，我一直用的防护武器，如今已经被我给烧了。我很后悔，然而在我心里又找不到理由来责备自己犯了这么大的错误。对于她天真的大胆或者刚才她那种哭泣时的诱惑，我似乎都已经无力抵抗了。而且我越是想找借口原谅自己，就使我犯的过错显得越大——我处于这么有利的地位，我好像正是利用了对方的毫无防备啊。
en: The milk was spilt now, the word was out and the truth told.I had crept like an untrusty man into the poor maid’s affections; she was in my hand like any frail, innocent thing to make or mar; and what weapon of defence was left me?It seemed like a symbol that Heineccius, my old protection, was now burned.I repented, yet could not find it in my heart to blame myself for that great failure.It seemed not possible to have resisted the boldness of her innocence or that last temptation of her weeping.And all that I had to excuse me did but make my sin appear the greater—it was upon a nature so defenceless, and with such advantages of the position, that I seemed to have practised.

zh: 现在我们身上还会发生什么事呢？好像我们不能再住在同一个地方了。可是我又该去哪里呢？或者她又该去哪里呢？我们既没有选择的机会，本身也没有犯过错，然而为生活所逼我们却被困在这么一个狭窄的地方了。我有个疯狂的想法，就是立刻结婚，不过跟着我又打消了这个念头。她还是个孩子，她还不了解自己的内心。我对她的软弱感到惊讶，我绝不能让这种令人惊异的情况发展下去。我必须要保护她，不仅让她不受责备，还要让她自由地来选择我。
en: What was to become of us now?It seemed we could no longer dwell in the one place.But where was I to go? or where she?Without either choice or fault of ours, life had conspired to wall us together in that narrow place.I had a wild thought of marrying out of hand; and the next moment put it from me with revolt.She was a child, she could not tell her own heart; I had surprised her weakness, I must never go on to build on that surprisal; I must keep her not only clear of reproach, but free as she had come to me.

zh: 我在炉火前坐了下来，一边反省，一边懊悔，不断敲打自己的脑袋苦思摆脱的办法，却徒劳无益。大约凌晨两点的时候，炉火只剩两三点余烬，而这个房间还有整座城市都在沉睡，我察觉到隔壁房间有小声的哭泣声。她以为我睡着了，那可怜的人儿，她为自己的软弱而后悔——或许（上帝帮助她）她会把它称为鲁莽——在夜晚万籁俱寂时，她在用泪水安慰自己。柔情与痛苦，爱恋与忏悔，还有怜悯，都在我心灵深处挣扎，我似乎有责任来安慰她让她不再哭泣。
en: Down I sat before the fire, and reflected, and repented, and beat my brains in vain for any means of escape.About two of the morning, there were three red embers left and the house and all the city was asleep, when I was aware of a small sound of weeping in the next room.She thought that I slept, the poor soul; she regretted her weakness—and what perhaps (God help her!) she called her forwardness—and in the dead of the night solaced herself with tears.Tender and bitter feelings, love and penitence and pity, struggled in my soul; it seemed I was under bond to heal that weeping.

zh: “哦，尽力原谅我！”我大声喊道，“尽力、尽力原谅我。让我们忘记一切，如果不能忘记，就让我们尽力去忘记吧！”
en: “O, try to forgive me!”I cried out, “try, try to forgive me.Let us forget it all, let us try if we’ll no can forget it!”

zh: 没有传来应答声，但是抽泣声停止了。我说完之后双手十指紧扣，在那里站了很久。随后夜晚的寒气袭来，我不禁浑身打了个寒战，我觉得自己的理性再次觉醒了。
en: There came no answer, but the sobbing ceased.I stood a long while with my hands still clasped as I had spoken; then the cold of the night laid hold upon me with a shudder, and I think my reason reawakened.

zh: “你根本就管不了这件事，戴维，”我想，“聪明一点儿就上床睡觉吧，要是能睡着就去试一试。明天你就会知道该怎么办了。”
en: “You can make no hand of this, Davie,” thinks I.“To bed with you like a wise lad, and try if you can sleep.To-morrow you may see your way.”

zh: 第二十五章 詹姆斯·莫尔归来
en: CHAPTER XXV—THE RETURN OF JAMES MORE

zh: 我很晚入睡而且睡得很不安稳，第二天，一阵敲门声把我叫醒了。我跑去打开门，刹时几欲晕倒，各种矛盾的心情涌上心头，其中主要还是痛苦，因为站在门口的正是詹姆斯·莫尔，他穿着粗糙的拉布拉斯卡尔外套，戴着一顶特别大的镶花边的帽子。
en: I was called on the morrow out of a late and troubled slumber by a knocking on my door, ran to open it, and had almost swooned with the contrariety of my feelings, mostly painful; for on the threshold, in a rough wraprascal and an extraordinary big laced hat, there stood James More.

zh: 也许如果没有私心杂念，我本应该高兴才对，因为我有种感觉，觉得这个人的到来就像是应验了我们的祈祷一样。我过去一直都在说卡特里奥娜和我是肯定要分开的，说得自己都烦了，而且我一直都在想着让我们分开的办法，想得头都疼了。现在这办法自己用两条腿走来了，可是我心里却怎么也高兴不起来。然而，现在应该这么看，这个人一来，即使未来的重担我可以卸下，目前面临的境况却更黑暗险恶。所以，在我第一次穿着衬衫和裤子站在他面前的时候，我认为我就像个被子弹射中的人一样不由地向后跳了一步。
en: I ought to have been glad perhaps without admixture, for there was a sense in which the man came like an answer to prayer.I had been saying till my head was weary that Catriona and I must separate, and looking till my head ached for any possible means of separation.Here were the means come to me upon two legs, and joy was the hindmost of my thoughts.It is to be considered, however, that even if the weight of the future were lifted off me by the man’s arrival, the present heaved up the more black and menacing; so that, as I first stood before him in my shirt and breeches, I believe I took a leaping step backward like a person shot.

zh: “啊，”他说，“我终于找到你了，鲍尔弗先生。”他向我伸出他那双修长的大手，我心存疑虑地握住他的手（同时意识到自己正站在门口的位置，好像带有拒绝他进来的意思）。“我们的事情好像搅在一起了，这太不寻常了。”他继续说，“我应该向你道歉，很遗憾打搅了你的生活，我自己就是因为相信那个口是心非的普雷斯顿格兰奇而陷入其圈套的。要向你承认我居然曾经相信过律师，我都觉得是耻辱。”他耸了耸肩，颇有一种法国式的风格。“但是实际上这个人很会花言巧语。”他说，“现在看起来在我女儿这件事上你也运用得很得心应手，还烦请尊驾告诉我你是受了谁的指点。”
en: “Ah,” said he, “I have found you, Mr, Balfour.”And offered me his large, fine hand, the which (recovering at the same time my post in the doorway, as if with some thought of resistance) I took him by doubtfully.“It is a remarkable circumstance how our affairs appear to intermingle,” he continued.“I am owing you an apology for an unfortunate intrusion upon yours, which I suffered myself to be entrapped into by my confidence in that false-face, Prestongrange; I think shame to own to you that I was ever trusting to a lawyer.”He shrugged his shoulders with a very French air.“But indeed the man is very plausible,” says he.“And now it seems that you have busied yourself handsomely in the matter of my daughter, for whose direction I was remitted to yourself.”

zh: “先生，我想，”我一副很痛苦的样子说道，“我们两个人有必要好好解释一下。”
en: “I think, sir,” said I, with a very painful air, “that it will be necessary we two should have an explanation.”

zh: “没有什么误会吧？”他问，“我的联络人，斯普罗特先生——”
en: “There is nothing amiss?” he asked.“My agent, Mr. Sprott—”

zh: “看在上帝的份上，缓和一下你的语气吧！”我叫道，“我们解释清楚之前不要让她听到。”
en: “For God’s sake moderate your voice!” I cried.“She must not hear till we have had an explanation.”

zh: “她住在这个地方？”他叫道。
en: “She is in this place?” cries he.

zh: “那就是她房间的门。”我说。
en: “That is her chamber door,” said I.

zh: “你和她单独住在这里？”他问道。
en: “You are here with her alone?” he asked.

zh: “我还能叫谁和我们住在一起？”我叫道。
en: “And who else would I have got to stay with us?” cries I.

zh: 说句公道话，我承认他脸色变白了。
en: I will do him the justice to admit that he turned pale.

zh: “这很不寻常，”他说，“这种状况很不寻常。你说对了，我们必须好好解释清楚。”
en: “This is very unusual,” said he.“This is a very unusual circumstance.You are right, we must hold an explanation.”

zh: 他这么一边说着一边从我面前走过，而我必须得承认这个高个子的老无赖那一刻倒显得特别有威严。他现在第一次打量了一下我的房间，这一点（可以这么说）是我从他的眼神里观察到的。一缕朝阳闪耀着透过窗户玻璃照射进来，照出了我的床、我的行李包、要洗的碗碟以及有点儿凌乱的衣服，而那个熄了火的壁炉是我房间唯一的设施。房间没什么不好，但是看起来简陋又寒冷，像乞丐住的地方。想到这个地方是给一位年轻女士来栖身，就觉得特别不适合。与此同时，我脑海中回想起了我帮她买的那些衣服，而我觉得这种贫穷和挥霍的鲜明对比会给人留下一种很糟糕的印象。
en: So saying he passed me by, and I must own the tall old rogue appeared at that moment extraordinary dignified.He had now, for the first time, the view of my chamber, which I scanned (I may say) with his eyes.A bit of morning sun glinted in by the window pane, and showed it off; my bed, my mails, and washing dish, with some disorder of my clothes, and the unlighted chimney, made the only plenishing; no mistake but it looked bare and cold, and the most unsuitable, beggarly place conceivable to harbour a young lady.At the same time came in on my mind the recollection of the clothes that I had bought for her; and I thought this contrast of poverty and prodigality bore an ill appearance.

zh: 他环顾我的房间想找个座，结果发现除了我的床之外他别无地方可坐，他就在床边找个地方坐了下来。我关好门后，也只好和他坐在一起了。无论如何这场特殊的会谈该结束了，这场谈话要尽可能在不吵醒卡特里奥娜的前提下进行，所以一件很有必要的事情就是我们要坐得近而且说话声音要轻。但是我几乎无法想象我们会是怎样的一对。他穿着大衣，和我房间的寒冷倒特别相称，我却穿着衬衫和马裤在瑟瑟发抖；他摆出一幅审判官的架势，而我（不论我看起来像什么）都强烈地感觉到自己就是那个听见最后一声号响的人。
en: He looked all about the chamber for a seat, and finding nothing else to his purpose except my bed, took a place upon the side of it; where, after I had closed the door, I could not very well avoid joining him.For however this extraordinary interview might end, it must pass if possible without waking Catriona; and the one thing needful was that we should sit close and talk low.But I can scarce picture what a pair we made; he in his great coat which the coldness of my chamber made extremely suitable; I shivering in my shirt and breeks; he with very much the air of a judge; and I (whatever I looked) with very much the feelings of a man who has heard the last trumpet.

zh: “好了吗？”他说。
en: “Well?” says he.

zh: “好了。”我开始说，却发现自己说不下去了。
en: And “Well,” I began, but found myself unable to go further.

zh: “你告诉我她在这里？”他又说，但是此刻却有一种不耐烦的口气，这似乎又让我振作起来了。
en: “You tell me she is here?” said he again, but now with a spice of impatience that seemed to brace me up.

zh: “她就在这个房子里。”我说，“我知道这种情势是可以称作不寻常。但是你得想一想整件事情从一开始就多么不寻常。有个年轻女士登上了欧洲海岸，身上居然只有两个先令和一个半便士。她按指示去找赫尔沃埃特的那个叫斯普洛特人。我听你称他为你的联络员。我所能说的是，一提到你的名字他除了责备和咒骂其他什么都没做，甚至连代为保管你女儿的行李，我都还必须从自己的口袋里掏钱付给他才行。德拉蒙德先生，这就是你说的不寻常状况，如果你喜欢那样称呼的话。如果你愿意，就是这种处境残忍地摆在她的面前。”
en: “She is in this house,” said I, “and I knew the circumstance would be called unusual.But you are to consider how very unusual the whole business was from the beginning.Here is a young lady landed on the coast of Europe with two shillings and a penny halfpenny.She is directed to yon man Sprott in Helvoet.I hear you call him your agent.All I can say is he could do nothing but damn and swear at the mere mention of your name, and I must fee him out of my own pocket even to receive the custody of her effects.You speak of unusual circumstances, Mr. Drummond, if that be the name you prefer.Here was a circumstance, if you like, to which it was barbarity to have exposed her.”

zh: “但是有一点我实在不明白，”詹姆斯说，“我女儿本来托付给一些可靠的人了，我把他们的名字给忘记了。”“这人的名字叫格比。”我说，“无疑格比先生本来应该陪她在赫尔沃埃特上岸的。但是他没有上岸，德拉蒙德先生，而我认为你可以感谢主，因为我当时提出了代替他的位置。”
en: “But this is what I cannot understand the least,” said James.“My daughter was placed into the charge of some responsible persons, whose names I have forgot.”“Gebbie was the name,” said I; “and there is no doubt that Mr. Gebbie should have gone ashore with her at Helvoet.But he did not, Mr. Drummond; and I think you might praise God that I was there to offer in his place.”

zh: “不久我就会捎话给格比先生的。”他说，“至于你自己，我想对于承担这样的一个重任来说，也许你还是有点儿太年轻了。”
en: “I shall have a word to say to Mr. Gebbie before long,” said he.“As for yourself, I think it might have occurred that you were somewhat young for such a post.”

zh: “但是当时并不是除了我之外还有别的人可以选择，而是除我之外就没有人愿意承担这个责任了。”我叫道，“没有人愿意代替我的位置，而我必须得说我觉得你对我所做的一切几乎没有表现出一点儿感激之情。”
en: “But the choice was not between me and somebody else, it was between me and nobody,” cried I.“Nobody offered in my place, and I must say I think you show a very small degree of gratitude to me that did.”

zh: “我要等我更详细地了解清楚我欠的人情以后再说。”他说。
en: “I shall wait until I understand my obligation a little more in the particular,” says he.

zh: “确实，我觉得从你的表情就看得出来。”我说，“你的孩子为人所弃，她在欧洲就被人彻底给抛弃了，身上只有不到两个先令，当地的语言也说不出两句。我不得不说这件事情做得真好啊！我把她带到了这个地方。我给了她妹妹的名分和温情。所有这一切不花钱是办不成的，但是我几乎不需要任何暗示。做这些事情是因为我尊重这位年轻女士的人品，而且我也认为这是一件美事，如果我想在她父亲面前赞美她的话。”
en: “Indeed, and I think it stares you in the face, then,” said I.“Your child was deserted, she was clean flung away in the midst of Europe, with scarce two shillings, and not two words of any language spoken there: I must say, a bonny business!I brought her to this place.I gave her the name and the tenderness due to a sister.All this has not gone without expense, but that I scarce need to hint at.They were services due to the young lady’s character which I respect; and I think it would be a bonny business too, if I was to be singing her praises to her father.”

zh: “你是个年轻人。”他开始说。
en: “You are a young man,” he began.

zh: “我听到你这么告诉我了。”我说，感觉很生气。
en: “So I hear you tell me,” said I, with a good deal of heat.

zh: “你是个非常年轻的人，”他重复道，“或者说你应该已经明白这么做的重要性了。”
en: “You are a very young man,” he repeated, “or you would have understood the significancy of the step.”

zh: “我觉得你说的太轻巧了吧。”我叫道，“那我该怎么做？ 其实，我本可以雇一个体面而贫穷的女人作为第三个人加入我们当中的，不过我要声明在此之前我从来就没有这么想过！但是我要到哪里去找这么个女人？我自己都还是个外国人呢。德拉蒙德先生，对你的看法我要指出的是，那样还是要我掏腰包花钱的。因为现在我正是这样做的，我不得不为你的疏忽而付出代价。对此只能说明一个事实，那就是你太没有爱心，太粗心，所以连女儿都给弄丢了。”
en: “I think you speak very much at your ease,” cried I.“What else was I to do?It is a fact I might have hired some decent, poor woman to be a third to us, and I declare I never thought of it until this moment!But where was I to find her, that am a foreigner myself?And let me point out to your observation, Mr. Drummond, that it would have cost me money out of my pocket.For here is just what it comes to, that I had to pay through the nose for your neglect; and there is only the one story to it, just that you were so unloving and so careless as to have lost your daughter.”

zh: “家住玻璃屋，不可乱抛石。”他说，“我们弄清楚德拉蒙德小姐的行为之后再坐下来评判她的父亲吧。”
en: “He that lives in a glass house should not be casting stones,” says he; “and we will finish inquiring into the behaviour of Miss Drummond before we go on to sit in judgment on her father.”

zh: “不过我才不会上当相信你这样的态度呢。”我说，“德拉蒙德小姐的人品根本不用质疑，这一点她的父亲应该知道。我的人品也一样清白，我要告诉你这一点。只有两种方法供你选择。一种就是像一个绅士对待另一个绅士那样来向我表达你的谢意，其他就不再多说。另一种（如果你觉得难办，还不满意的话）就是把我所花的钱还给我，这事就此了结。”
en: “But I will be entrapped into no such attitude,” said I.“The character of Miss Drummond is far above inquiry, as her father ought to know.So is mine, and I am telling you that.There are but the two ways of it open.The one is to express your thanks to me as one gentleman to another, and to say no more.The other (if you are so difficult as to be still dissatisfied) is to pay me, that which I have expended and be done.”

zh: 他一只手举在空中，似乎想让我平静下来。“你看，你看，”他说，“你结论下得未免太快了，你结论下得未免太快了，鲍尔弗先生。我学会了更耐心，这倒是一件好事情。不过我相信你忘记了我还没有见到我女儿呢。”
en: He seemed to soothe me with a hand in the air.“There, there,” said he.“You go too fast, you go too fast, Mr. Balfour.It is a good thing that I have learned to be more patient.And I believe you forget that I have yet to see my daughter.”

zh: 我开始对他的话放心了一点儿，而我发觉我一提到我们之间的钱的问题时，这家伙的态度也发生了变化。
en: I began to be a little relieved upon this speech and a change in the man’s manner that I spied in him as soon as the name of money fell between us.

zh: “我在想这样会更合适——如果你肯原谅我在你面前穿得太随便的话——我出去，你跟她单独见面？”我说。
en: “I was thinking it would be more fit—if you will excuse the plainness of my dressing in your presence—that I should go forth and leave you to encounter her alone?” said I.

zh: “我很乐意听从你的安排！”他说，他所说的话很礼貌，没有一点儿不当。
en: “What I would have looked for at your hands!” says he; and there was no mistake but what he said it civilly.

zh: 我觉得情况还是越来越好了，然后我在开始穿紧身裤时，想起了这个家伙在普雷斯顿格兰奇家那副厚颜无耻的乞丐嘴脸，我决定去追逐似乎属于我的胜利。
en: I thought this better and better still, and as I began to pull on my hose, recalling the man’s impudent mendicancy at Prestongrange’s, I determined to pursue what seemed to be my victory.

zh: “如果你有心在莱登呆上一段时间的话，”我说，“这个房间就任由你支配好了，我很容易给自己另找一个住的地方。这样的话，我们就可以尽可能少搬东西，只需要一个人换换地方就行了。”
en: “If you have any mind to stay some while in Leyden,” said I, “this room is very much at your disposal, and I can easy find another for myself: in which way we shall have the least amount of flitting possible, there being only one to change.”

zh: “为什么，先生，”他说，作出胸襟宽大的样子，“我认为我是为国王效劳而贫穷的，这并不可耻。我毫不隐瞒地告诉你我的事情牵涉太多，目前我甚至都不可能完成我的旅程。”
en: “Why, sir,” said he, making his bosom big, “I think no shame of a poverty I have come by in the service of my king; I make no secret that my affairs are quite involved; and for the moment, it would be even impossible for me to undertake a journey.”

zh: “到你有机会和你的朋友们沟通此事的时候吧，”我说，“如果你把自己看成是我的客人的话，也许对你可能更方便吧（当然这对于我本人也是一件荣幸的事情）？”
en: “Until you have occasion to communicate with your friends,” said I, “perhaps it might be convenient for you (as of course it would be honourable to myself) if you were to regard yourself in the light of my guest?”

zh: “先生，”他说，“既然你这么坦诚地提出帮助，我认为我也特别以自己能效仿这种坦诚为荣。你的帮助，戴维先生，你有这种我最尊重的品格。你属于那种能给绅士以帮助却从不多说一句话的人。我是一个老兵了，”他说，一副很厌恶的样子环顾着我的房间，“你不必担心我会成为你的累赘。我经常在堤边吃饭，在沟里喝水，而且下雨天都没地方遮雨的。”
en: “Sir,” said he, “when an offer is frankly made, I think I honour myself most to imitate that frankness.Your hand, Mr. David; you have the character that I respect the most; you are one of those from whom a gentleman can take a favour and no more words about it.I am an old soldier,” he went on, looking rather disgusted-like around my chamber, “and you need not fear I shall prove burthensome.I have ate too often at a dyke-side, drank of the ditch, and had no roof but the rain.”

zh: “我正要告诉你，”我说，“我们的早餐通常是早晨这个时候送过来。我打算现在就去那个小酒馆，吩咐他们再给你加一份早餐，并且推迟一个小时再送餐，这样好给你空出点儿时间和你女儿见面。”
en: “I should be telling you,” said I, “that our breakfasts are sent customarily in about this time of morning.I propose I should go now to the tavern, and bid them add a cover for yourself and delay the meal the matter of an hour, which will give you an interval to meet your daughter in.”

zh: 据我看来，听到这话时他鼓了鼓鼻孔。“哦，一个小时，”他说，“那也许太久了。就半个小时吧，鲍尔弗先生，或者说就二十分钟。我会在这段时间把一切处理好的。顺便问一句，”他补充说，拉住我的外套拦着我，“你早晨都喝些什么，是麦芽酒还是葡萄酒？”
en: Methought his nostrils wagged at this.“O, an hour” says he.“That is perhaps superfluous.Half an hour, Mr. David, or say twenty minutes; I shall do very well in that.And by the way,” he adds, detaining me by the coat, “what is it you drink in the morning, whether ale or wine?”

zh: “坦率地告诉你，先生，”我说，“除了少量的冷水我什么都不喝。”
en: “To be frank with you, sir,” says I, “I drink nothing else but spare, cold water.”

zh: “啧，啧，”他说，“那会对胃有很大损害的，要记住一位老战士的话。我们家乡的烈酒也许是最有益健康的了，不过那是这里找不到的，所以退而求其次，就喝莱茵白葡萄酒或者一种勃艮第白葡萄酒吧。”
en: “Tut-tut,” says he, “that is fair destruction to the stomach, take an old campaigner’s word for it.Our country spirit at home is perhaps the most entirely wholesome; but as that is not come-at-able, Rhenish or a white wine of Burgundy will be next best.”

zh: “我会视为己责，确保能给你提供。”我说。
en: “I shall make it my business to see you are supplied,” said I.

zh: “哎呀，很好，”他说，“戴维先生，你可真不失为一个男子汉。”
en: “Why, very good,” said he, “and we shall make a man of you yet, Mr. David.”

zh: 至此，可以说我的心思根本不在他身上，倒是有种匪夷所思的想法，觉得他好像在证明他是我的岳父。我全部的注意力都集中在他的女儿身上，我决定对她传递信息，警示她有客来访。因此，我走到门边，一边在门上敲着，一边透过门上的窗格喊道：“德拉蒙德小姐，现在你父亲终于来了。”
en: By this time, I can hardly say that I was minding him at all, beyond an odd thought of the kind of father-in-law that he was like to prove; and all my cares centred about the lass his daughter, to whom I determined to convey some warning of her visitor.I stepped to the door accordingly, and cried through the panels, knocking thereon at the same time: “Miss Drummond, here is your father come at last.”

zh: 随后我就出去办我的事，却（因为这两句话）把我自己的好事给破坏得一塌糊涂了。
en: With that I went forth upon my errand, having (by two words) extraordinarily damaged my affairs.

zh: 第二十六章 三人行
en: CHAPTER XXVI—THE THREESOME

zh: 我是否应该受这么多的责备，也许更应该说是否应该接受同情，我都只能留待他人去评价了。我的机敏（我也是非常机敏之辈）似乎对女士没有那么有效。毫无疑问，在我唤醒她的那一刻，我就在想这件事会给詹姆斯·莫尔留下强烈的印象。同样的，等我回来和大家一起坐下来吃早餐时，我还是对那位年轻女士保持着尊重和距离。我认为这是我做的最明智的一件事。她的父亲曾经怀疑过我对她的友谊是否清白，所以我首先要做的事情就是消除其怀疑。但是卡特里奥娜也有她的理由。 我们曾分享过那温存和激情的一幕，也曾互相给予并得到过爱抚：我曾经粗暴地把她从我身边推开，也曾在夜晚从一间房向另一间房大声地呼唤她；她曾经历几个小时的失眠和哭泣，可以想见她伏枕夜思中从未缺过我的身影。回想到此，我惊醒过来，依着很不习惯的拘谨礼节称呼她为德拉蒙德小姐，而且自那以后我都对她保持很大的距离，相当尊重，结果使她完全错误地理解了我的个人感情。她确实受到了令人难以置信的伤害，居然以为我觉得后悔了，在试图打退堂鼓了！
en: Whether or not I was to be so much blamed, or rather perhaps pitied, I must leave others to judge.My shrewdness (of which I have a good deal, too) seems not so great with the ladies.No doubt, at the moment when I awaked her, I was thinking a good deal of the effect upon James More; and similarly when I returned and we were all sat down to breakfast, I continued to behave to the young lady with deference and distance; as I still think to have been most wise.Her father had cast doubts upon the innocence of my friendship; and these, it was my first business to allay.But there is a kind of an excuse for Catriona also.We had shared in a scene of some tenderness and passion, and given and received caresses: I had thrust her from me with violence; I had called aloud upon her in the night from the one room to the other; she had passed hours of wakefulness and weeping; and it is not to be supposed I had been absent from her pillow thoughts.Upon the back of this, to be awaked, with unaccustomed formality, under the name of Miss Drummond, and to be thenceforth used with a great deal of distance and respect, led her entirely in error on my private sentiments; and she was indeed so incredibly abused as to imagine me repentant and trying to draw off!

zh: 我们之间的问题似乎在于这一点：虽然我（自从第一眼看到他的大帽子起）一门心思只想着詹姆斯·莫尔、他的归来和他的怀疑，但是卡特里奥娜几乎没有感觉到这些，我都可以说她根本就没有注意到。她所有的烦恼和行为都和我们之间前一天晚上所发生的事情有关。这一方面可以解释为她性格单纯而大胆，另一方面则是因为詹姆斯·莫尔在和我会面时太过仓促，或者是我的邀请堵住了他的嘴，他还没和她女儿谈起这件事。因此，吃早餐的时候，很快就显出我们的意见相左了。我本来希望她穿她自己的衣服，却发现她（好像把她父亲给忘记了）穿着我给她买的最漂亮的衣服，而她知道（或者认为）我是很欣赏她穿这套衣服的。我本来指望能看到她模仿我，对感情保持距离，而且做得既很到位又很正式。相反，我却发现她脸带红晕、透着野性，双眸明亮异常，而且带着一副痛苦而多变的神情。她语气温柔地呼唤着我的名字，就像一位担心而多疑的妻子在询问并顺从着我的想法和意愿。
en: The trouble betwixt us seems to have been this: that whereas I (since I had first set eyes on his great hat) thought singly of James More, his return and suspicions, she made so little of these that I may say she scarce remarked them, and all her troubles and doings regarded what had passed between us in the night before.This is partly to be explained by the innocence and boldness of her character; and partly because James More, having sped so ill in his interview with me, or had his mouth closed by my invitation, said no word to her upon the subject.At the breakfast, accordingly, it soon appeared we were at cross purposes.I had looked to find her in clothes of her own: I found her (as if her father were forgotten) wearing some of the best that I had bought for her, and which she knew (or thought) that I admired her in.I had looked to find her imitate my affectation of distance, and be most precise and formal; instead I found her flushed and wild-like, with eyes extraordinary bright, and a painful and varying expression, calling me by name with a sort of appeal of tenderness, and referring and deferring to my thoughts and wishes like an anxious or a suspected wife.

zh: 但这并没有持续多久。因为我看见她竟然毫不顾及自己的种种利害关系，那可是我曾经危及而现在正在尽力补救的，所以我对她加倍冷淡，以作为给这个女孩的一点教训。她越是向前靠近，我就向后退得越远；她越是暴露我们之间的亲密程度，我就越发刻意保持礼貌。直到后来连她父亲（如果他不是全神贯注大吃特吃的话）也许都注意到了我们之间这种截然相反的表现。在这期间，她突然彻底改变了态度，于是我大大地松了口气，告诉自己，她终于接受我的暗示了。
en: But this was not for long.As I behold her so regardless of her own interests, which I had jeopardised and was now endeavouring to recover, I redoubled my own coldness in the manner of a lesson to the girl.The more she came forward, the farther I drew back; the more she betrayed the closeness of our intimacy, the more pointedly civil I became, until even her father (if he had not been so engrossed with eating) might have observed the opposition.In the midst of which, of a sudden, she became wholly changed, and I told myself, with a good deal of relief, that she had took the hint at last.

zh: 我整天都在上课，或者在找新的住处。虽然我们惯常散步的时间只能悲惨地被我慢慢打发掉，但我还是得承认总体上我还是很高兴的。我的道路已经扫清，那位女孩已经再次得到合适的保护，那位父亲还感到满意或者至少已经接受了，而我自己则可以自由地、有尊严地把我的爱进行到底。吃晚饭的时候，正如我们每餐吃饭时一样，又是詹姆斯·莫尔在说话。只要还有人可以相信他，毫无疑问，他讲起来头头是道。不过我跟着就会更为详细地谈到他。吃完饭，他站起身，穿上他的长大衣，看着我（就像我想的那样），说他有事要外出。我认为这是在暗示我也要走，于是我就站起身来。那位女孩在我进门时几乎没有跟我打过招呼，这时却转眼看着我，眼睛睁得大大的在示意恳求我留下。我站在他们中间，就像一条出了水的鱼一样，转身看看这个又看看那个。两个人好像都没看见我，她盯着地面，而他在扣大衣，这让我尴尬到了极点。这种满不在乎的样子在她这边意味着满腔的怒火就要爆发。他那边，我觉得也让人非常担忧。我确信一场暴风雨即将来临。考虑到主要的危险会在他那里，我转向他，把自己（可以说）交由他安排了。
en: All day I was at my classes or in quest of my new lodging; and though the hour of our customary walk hung miserably on my hands, I cannot say but I was happy on the whole to find my way cleared, the girl again in proper keeping, the father satisfied or at least acquiescent, and myself free to prosecute my love with honour.At supper, as at all our meals, it was James More that did the talking.No doubt but he talked well if anyone could have believed him.But I will speak of him presently more at large.The meal at an end, he rose, got his great coat, and looking (as I thought) at me, observed he had affairs abroad.I took this for a hint that I was to be going also, and got up; whereupon the girl, who had scarce given me greeting at my entrance, turned her eyes upon me wide open with a look that bade me stay.I stood between them like a fish out of water, turning from one to the other; neither seemed to observe me, she gazing on the floor, he buttoning his coat: which vastly swelled my embarrassment.This appearance of indifference argued, upon her side, a good deal of anger very near to burst out.Upon his, I thought it horribly alarming; I made sure there was a tempest brewing there; and considering that to be the chief peril, turned towards him and put myself (so to speak) in the man’s hands.

zh: “德拉蒙德先生，我能为您做点什么？”我说。
en: “Can I do anything for you, Mr. Drummond?” says I.

zh: 他憋住了一个哈欠，我再次觉得这他这是在装样子。“哎呀，戴维先生，”他说，“既然你那么好心提出帮忙，那就不妨带我去某某酒馆（他给了我酒馆的名称），我希望到那里去和一些老战友相会。”
en: He stifled a yawn, which again I thought to be duplicity.“Why, Mr. David,” said he, “since you are so obliging as to propose it, you might show me the way to a certain tavern” (of which he gave the name) “where I hope to fall in with some old companions in arms.”

zh: 没有再说什么，我就拿起帽子和披风，准备陪他前往。
en: There was no more to say, and I got my hat and cloak to bear him company.

zh: “至于你，”他对他的女儿说，“你最好上床睡觉去。我会回来很晚，‘早睡早起，美丽的姑娘眼睛亮’。”
en: “And as for you,” say he to his daughter, “you had best go to your bed.I shall be late home, and Early to bed and early to rise, gars bonny lasses have bright eyes.”

zh: 于是他非常温柔地吻了她，然后让我走在他前面先出门。 这件事就这么结束了（正是我的意图），几乎不可能再说什么告别的话，但我注意到她没有看我，我以为那是因为她害怕詹姆斯·莫尔。
en: Whereupon he kissed her with a good deal of tenderness, and ushered me before him from the door.This was so done (I thought on purpose) that it was scarce possible there should be any parting salutation; but I observed she did not look at me, and set it down to terror of James More.

zh: 到那个酒馆还有一段距离。他一路上说的事情我一点都不感兴趣，到酒馆门口以后他说了些客套话就把我打发走了。随后我就走向我的新住处，那里没有炉火让我取暖，也没有人与我交往，只有我自己的种种思绪。我的思绪还是很清晰的，但是我远没有料到卡特里奥娜会转过来针对我。我觉得我们俩已经互盟誓约，我觉得我们曾经过于亲昵、言语热烈，很难把我们分开，但是至少保持那么几步的距离是非常必要的策略。我主要关心的就是我的这个准岳父是个什么样的人，但是他根本就不是我愿意选择的那种人。至于我最快应该什么时候对他说这件事，这一点很微妙，得多方考虑。首先，每当我一想到自己还太年轻，我就会急得满脸通红，几乎觉得自己内心都要打消这个念头了。只是一旦我没有加以解释就让他们离开莱登的话，也许我就会彻底失去她了。其次，我们这种很不合规矩的情形已经被看见了，而且那天早晨我并没有给詹姆斯·莫尔一个满意的解决方案。我得出结论，总体看来，拖延不会有任何损害，但是我也不会拖延太久。随后我就心满意足地爬上了我那冰冷的床。
en: It was some distance to that tavern.He talked all the way of matters which did not interest me the smallest, and at the door dismissed me with empty manners.Thence I walked to my new lodging, where I had not so much as a chimney to hold me warm, and no society but my own thoughts.These were still bright enough; I did not so much as dream that Catriona was turned against me; I thought we were like folk pledged; I thought we had been too near and spoke too warmly to be severed, least of all by what were only steps in a most needful policy.And the chief of my concern was only the kind of father-in-law that I was getting, which was not at all the kind I would have chosen: and the matter of how soon I ought to speak to him, which was a delicate point on several sides.In the first place, when I thought how young I was I blushed all over, and could almost have found it in my heart to have desisted; only that if once I let them go from Leyden without explanation, I might lose her altogether.And in the second place, there was our very irregular situation to be kept in view, and the rather scant measure of satisfaction I had given James More that morning.I concluded, on the whole, that delay would not hurt anything, yet I would not delay too long neither; and got to my cold bed with a full heart.

zh: 第二天，因为詹姆斯·莫尔似乎对我房间的简陋略有抱怨，所以我就提出多添置一些家具。下午随搬运工一起搬着桌椅过来时，我发现那个女孩又是独自留在那里。她很客气地招呼我进去，但很快就缩回自己的房间，还把房门给关上了。我布置好家具，然后付钱把那些人打发走了，这样她可以听见他们走了。我想她会立刻再次出来和我讲话。我还是等了一会儿，然后才去敲她的房门。
en: The next day, as James More seemed a little on the complaining hand in the matter of my chamber, I offered to have in more furniture; and coming in the afternoon, with porters bringing chairs and tables, found the girl once more left to herself.She greeted me on my admission civilly, but withdrew at once to her own room, of which she shut the door.I made my disposition, and paid and dismissed the men so that she might hear them go, when I supposed she would at once come forth again to speak to me.I waited yet awhile, then knocked upon her door.

zh: “卡特里奥娜！”我叫道。
en: “Catriona!” said I.

zh: 我话音未落，门就马上打开了，我觉得她肯定就站在门后听。她一动不动地在那里站了一会儿，但是她的眼睛有一种难以名状的神情，像是非常苦恼。
en: The door was opened so quickly, even before I had the word out, that I thought she must have stood behind it listening.She remained there in the interval quite still; but she had a look that I cannot put a name on, as of one in a bitter trouble.

zh: “我们今天也不去散步了吗？”我支支吾吾地问道。
en: “Are we not to have our walk to-day either?” so I faltered.

zh: “我谢谢你了。”她说，“既然我父亲已经回家，我就没有那么多心思散步了。”
en: “I am thanking you,” said she.“I will not be caring much to walk, now that my father is come home.”

zh: “可是我想他已经出去了，只留下你一个人在这里。”我说。
en: “But I think he has gone out himself and left you here alone,” said I.

zh: “你认为这么说让人听着舒服吗？”她问。
en: “And do you think that was very kindly said?” she asked.

zh: “我并没有恶意，”我回答说，“什么事情让你苦恼，卡特里奥娜？我对你做了什么，你就这么不理我了？”
en: “It was not unkindly meant,” I replied.“What ails you, Catriona?What have I done to you that you should turn from me like this?”

zh: “我根本就没有不理你。”她很小心地说道，“我会永远感激曾经善待过我的朋友，我将尽我所能去做他的朋友。 不过现在我父亲詹姆斯·莫尔又回来了，情况就不一样了，所以我想有些说过的话、做过的事最好还是忘记吧。我将尽我所能做你的朋友，如果那样还不够尽全力……如果那样尽的力还不够多……那也不劳你费心！我是不会让你为我考虑过多的。你对我说过的话是对的，我还太年轻，接受不了忠告，而我希望你会记住我只不过是个孩子。无论如何，我不愿意失去你的友谊。”
en: “I do not turn from you at all,” she said, speaking very carefully.“I will ever be grateful to my friend that was good to me; I will ever be his friend in all that I am able.But now that my father James More is come again, there is a difference to be made, and I think there are some things said and done that would be better to be forgotten.But I will ever be your friend in all that I am able, and if that is not all that...if it is not so much...Not that you will be caring!But I would not have you think of me too hard.It was true what you said to me, that I was too young to be advised, and I am hoping you will remember I was just a child.I would not like to lose your friendship, at all events.”

zh: 她开始说这话的时候脸色苍白，但是她的话还没有说完，血色上涌，她就满脸通红了。因此，不只是她说的话，还有她的脸色以及她颤抖的双手，都让我心软了下来。我第一次意识到，我真是大错特错了，居然让这个孩子处于这样的境地，害她陷入了一时的软弱，现在站在我的面前像一个蒙受了羞辱的人。
en: She began this very pale; but before she was done, the blood was in her face like scarlet, so that not her words only, but her face and the trembling of her very hands, besought me to be gentle.I saw, for the first time, how very wrong I had done to place the child in that position, where she had been entrapped into a moment’s weakness, and now stood before me like a person shamed.

zh: “德拉蒙德小姐，”我说，然后就卡壳了， 于是我只好再一次从头开始说，“我希望你能读懂我的心，”我叫道，“你会察觉到我对你的尊重没有减少。如果可能的话，应该说我对你的尊重还增加了。这只不过是我们所犯的错误造成的结果，既然结果已经如此，现在还是说得越少越好。 关于我们在这里生活的一切，我向你保证我永远不会透露半个字，我还可以向你保证我永远也不会再去想它，不过这对我来说是一份永远珍贵的回忆。至于说朋友，你在这里有一位甘愿为你牺牲生命的朋友。”
en: “Miss Drummond,” I said, and stuck, and made the same beginning once again, “I wish you could see into my heart,” I cried.“You would read there that my respect is undiminished.If that were possible, I should say it was increased.This is but the result of the mistake we made; and had to come; and the less said of it now the better.Of all of our life here, I promise you it shall never pass my lips; I would like to promise you too that I would never think of it, but it’s a memory that will be always dear to me.And as for a friend, you have one here that would die for you.”

zh: “我谢谢你了。”她说。
en: “I am thanking you,” said she.

zh: 我们默默地站了一会儿，而我自己内心的悲伤开始占据上风，因为我一切的梦想可悲地失落了，我的爱已失去，就像最初那样，又只剩下我一个人孤独地在这个世界上了。
en: We stood awhile silent, and my sorrow for myself began to get the upper hand; for here were all my dreams come to a sad tumble, and my love lost, and myself alone again in the world as at the beginning.

zh: “好吧，”我说，“我们永远都会是朋友，这一点是肯定的。但这也是一种告别：它毕竟是一种告别。我永远都会认识德拉蒙德小姐，但这却是我与我的卡特里奥娜的告别。”
en: “Well,” said I, “we shall be friends always, that’s a certain thing.But this is a kind of farewell, too: it’s a kind of a farewell after all; I shall always ken Miss Drummond, but this is a farewell to my Catriona.”

zh: 我看着她，与其说我看清楚她了，不如说在我的眼里她似乎变得高大了，更加光彩照人了。我想我当时肯定是失去理智了，因为我再一次大声喊着她的名字，向她迈了一步并伸出了双手。
en: I looked at her; I could hardly say I saw her, but she seemed to grow great and brighten in my eyes; and with that I suppose I must have lost my head, for I called out her name again and made a step at her with my hands reached forth.

zh: 她像是受到了惊吓，直往后退缩，她的脸绯红。血液刚一涌上她的脸颊，我就不禁急血攻心，因为见此情景，我颇感忏悔和担忧。我无法为自己找到托辞，只好在她面前深深鞠了个躬，然后万念俱灰地走出了房间。
en: She shrank back like a person struck, her face flamed; but the blood sprang no faster up into her cheeks, than what it flowed back upon my own heart, at sight of it, with penitence and concern.I found no words to excuse myself, but bowed before her very deep, and went my ways out of the house with death in my bosom.

zh: 我觉得随后大约五天都没有什么变化。我只有吃饭时偶尔见到她，当然那时会有詹姆斯·莫尔在旁。如果我们单独相处，哪怕是片刻，我都注意保持相当的距离，对她敬重有加，因为我脑海中总是浮现出这位女孩畏缩的神情、涨红的脸庞，我内心对她怜惜有加，无法用语言形容。我为自己感到难过，我没必要老是想着那一点的，因为我立刻就竭力补救了，只是力所不能及而已。不过事实上，我也替那位女孩难过，所以除偶尔那么几次，我很少对她发脾气了。她的辩解说得很好，她已经被置于不公正的境地。如果她欺骗了她自己和我的话，那也只不过是不得已而为之罢了。
en: I think it was about five days that followed without any change.I saw her scarce ever but at meals, and then of course in the company of James More.If we were alone even for a moment, I made it my devoir to behave the more distantly and to multiply respectful attentions, having always in my mind’s eye that picture of the girl shrinking and flaming in a blush, and in my heart more pity for her than I could depict in words.I was sorry enough for myself, I need not dwell on that, having fallen all my length and more than all my height in a few seconds; but, indeed, I was near as sorry for the girl, and sorry enough to be scarce angry with her save by fits and starts.Her plea was good; she had been placed in an unfair position; if she had deceived herself and me, it was no more than was to have been looked for.

zh: 而另一方面，她现在非常非常孤独。她父亲在她身边的时候倒也不失为一位亲切的家长，但他时常要出去处理自己的种种事情，加上还要寻欢作乐，所以他就会毫不愧疚或者毫不注意地就把她给忽视了。他一有钱就在酒店过夜，次数多得我都数不清楚了。甚至就在这几天，他有一次就没有赶回来吃饭，最后他没有在，只好就我和卡特里奥娜两个人一起吃的饭。那是一次晚饭，我一吃完饭就赶紧离开了，我想她宁可单独呆着，对此她表示同意（尽管看起来有些奇怪），但我很相信她。实际上，我觉得自己只不过是那位女孩的眼中钉，时刻在提醒着她曾经一度软弱过，而这是她极不愿意想起的。所以她现在肯定是独自坐在我和她曾经度过欢乐时光的房间里，就在闪烁的壁炉火光下，那火光曾照耀我们度过的很多艰难而温情的时刻。在那里，她肯定是独坐着，在思忖着作为一个少女，她自己曾经极不符合身份地表达过她的情感，而且这种情感还被拒绝了。而与此同时，我却会独自在另一个地方，反思着自己（每当我很想发火的时候）在人性的脆弱以及女性的微妙情感方面的教训。总之，我想永远不会有人像这两个可怜的傻瓜那样因为极大的误会而害得自己闷闷不乐。
en: And for another thing she was now very much alone.Her father, when he was by, was rather a caressing parent; but he was very easy led away by his affairs and pleasures, neglected her without compunction or remark, spent his nights in taverns when he had the money, which was more often than I could at all account for; and even in the course of these few days, failed once to come to a meal, which Catriona and I were at last compelled to partake of without him.It was the evening meal, and I left immediately that I had eaten, observing I supposed she would prefer to be alone; to which she agreed and (strange as it may seem) I quite believed her.Indeed, I thought myself but an eyesore to the girl, and a reminder of a moment’s weakness that she now abhorred to think of.So she must sit alone in that room where she and I had been so merry, and in the blink of that chimney whose light had shone upon our many difficult and tender moments.There she must sit alone, and think of herself as of a maid who had most unmaidenly proffered her affections and had the same rejected.And in the meanwhile I would be alone some other place, and reading myself (whenever I was tempted to be angry) lessons upon human frailty and female delicacy.And altogether I suppose there were never two poor fools made themselves more unhappy in a greater misconception.

zh: 至于詹姆斯，他并没有多注意我们，或者说除了他的钱袋、他的胃口和他自己的空谈外，他不关心任何事。他曾向我借过一小笔钱，还没过十二个小时，就在三十分钟前，他又第二次借钱，我拒绝了。借不借给他钱，他都同样心情很好。实际上，他表现出的一种宽宏大量的气度倒是真适合好好影响影响他女儿。他在谈话中常常表现出这一点，而且这个人仪表堂堂、处事有方，这一切很协调地融合在一起。所以一个没有跟他打过什么交道的人，要么就难以看透他，要么就会对他持有一股狂热的偏见，几乎都可能上他的当了。在我看来，见过一两次面后，他就像印刷品一样清晰了。我知道他自私透顶，可同时却一副完全清白的样子。我听着他高谈阔论（关于战争和“一个老兵”，还有“一个可怜的高地绅士”以及“我的国家和朋友的力量”之类），我都可以去鹦鹉学舌了。
en: As for James, he paid not so much heed to us, or to anything in nature but his pocket, and his belly, and his own prating talk.Before twelve hours were gone he had raised a small loan of me; before thirty, he had asked for a second and been refused.Money and refusal he took with the same kind of high good nature.Indeed, he had an outside air of magnanimity that was very well fitted to impose upon a daughter; and the light in which he was constantly presented in his talk, and the man’s fine presence and great ways went together pretty harmoniously.So that a man that had no business with him, and either very little penetration or a furious deal of prejudice, might almost have been taken in.To me, after my first two interviews, he was as plain as print; I saw him to be perfectly selfish, with a perfect innocency in the same; and I would hearken to his swaggering talk (of arms, and “an old soldier,” and “a poor Highland gentleman,” and “the strength of my country and my friends”) as I might to the babbling of a parrot.

zh: 奇怪的是我感觉他自己也相信他胡吹的一些话，或者有时候相信。我认为他一直都太虚伪，所以他在撒谎时自己都不太有感觉了。只是有一点，他沮丧的时候确实很真诚。有几次他特别沉默寡言，很真挚，可能也很依赖人，他拉着卡特里奥娜的手就像个大孩子。他向我乞求说只要我对他有一点爱都不要抛弃他，其实我已经做到了，只不过更多是出于对他女儿的爱。他会催逼，实际上是恳求我们说话来让他开心，这对处于我们这种关系的人来说是一件很难办的事。他会再一次突发感慨，为自己的故土和朋友深深惋惜，或者突然就用盖尔语唱起歌来。
en: The odd thing was that I fancy he believed some part of it himself, or did at times; I think he was so false all through that he scarce knew when he was lying; and for one thing, his moments of dejection must have been wholly genuine.There were times when he would be the most silent, affectionate, clinging creature possible, holding Catriona’s hand like a big baby, and begging of me not to leave if I had any love to him; of which, indeed, I had none, but all the more to his daughter.He would press and indeed beseech us to entertain him with our talk, a thing very difficult in the state of our relations; and again break forth in pitiable regrets for his own land and friends, or into Gaelic singing.

zh: “这是我故乡的一首悲歌小调，”他会说，“看见一位士兵哭泣，你可能会觉得奇怪，可是实际上悲歌会让你有一个亲近的朋友。”他说，“但是这首歌的曲调已经融进我的血液，这些歌词是我发自心底的吟唱。当我想起那红色的山峰和山间鸣唱的野鸟，还有那壮观的、奔腾而下的溪流时，我就不会为自己在敌人面前哭泣而觉得羞耻了。”然后他又会唱起歌来，而且还会为我翻译部分歌词，只是语焉不详，而且明显表现出对英语的不屑。“这里是说，”他会说，“太阳已经落山，战事就要结束，可是勇敢的首领却失败了。而这里是说星星看着他们逃亡到陌生的国度或者阵亡在红色的山峰上。他们永远都不能再发出战斗的怒吼声，或者在山谷中的小溪里洗涤他们的双脚。但是只要你稍懂一点点盖尔语的话，你都会哭泣的，因为盖尔语里的这些话只可意会不可言传，所以用英语告诉你只是徒具其表罢了。”
en: “This is one of the melancholy airs of my native land,” he would say.“You may think it strange to see a soldier weep, and indeed it is to make a near friend of you,” says he.“But the notes of this singing are in my blood, and the words come out of my heart.And when I mind upon my red mountains and the wild birds calling there, and the brave streams of water running down, I would scarce think shame to weep before my enemies.”Then he would sing again, and translate to me pieces of the song, with a great deal of boggling and much expressed contempt against the English language.“It says here,” he would say, “that the sun is gone down, and the battle is at an end, and the brave chiefs are defeated.And it tells here how the stars see them fleeing into strange countries or lying dead on the red mountain; and they will never more shout the call of battle or wash their feet in the streams of the valley.But if you had only some of this language, you would weep also because the words of it are beyond all expression, and it is mere mockery to tell you it in English.”

zh: 那么，我想在这件事上有很多都是徒具其表的，不是这种形式就是那一种。然而我还是有种感觉，我觉得正是这种感觉让我恨透他了。当我确信他的一半痛苦是因为他前一天晚上在酒馆酗了酒时，我一看见卡特里奥娜这么关心这个老无赖，她看见他哭就会跟着哭，我就觉得心如刀割。有几次我都忍不住很想借给他一大笔钱，彻底解决他的事情，但是这样一来我可能就再也见不到卡特里奥娜了，对此我可还没有做好准备。此外，把我那珍贵的金钱用在这么一个简直不能算男子汉的人身上，那也有违我的良心。
en: Well, I thought there was a good deal of mockery in the business, one way and another; and yet, there was some feeling too, for which I hated him, I think, the worst of all.And it used to cut me to the quick to see Catriona so much concerned for the old rogue, and weeping herself to see him weep, when I was sure one half of his distress flowed from his last night’s drinking in some tavern.There were times when I was tempted to lend him a round sum, and see the last of him for good; but this would have been to see the last of Catriona as well, for which I was scarcely so prepared; and besides, it went against my conscience to squander my good money on one who was so little of a husband.

zh: 第二十七章 两个人之间的一场较量
en: CHAPTER XXVII—A TWOSOME

zh: 我想大约是在第五天吧，至少我知道詹姆斯的情绪有点儿忧郁，这时我收到了三封信。第一封是艾伦写来的，信中提出要到莱登来看我。另外两封信都是从苏格兰寄来的，而且都是因为同一件事情，即我叔叔已经过世，我完全继承属于我的财产了。当然，兰基勒的那封信纯粹是就事论事，而格兰特小姐的信则恰如其人，与其说是睿智，不如说是诙谐更贴切些。她的信里满篇都在责怪我没有给她写信（尽管凭我这点智慧我又该怎么去写呢）。她还净写了些拿卡特里奥娜打趣的话，这让我当着卡特里奥娜的面读信时很伤自尊。
en: I believe it was about the fifth day, and I know at least that James was in one of his fits of gloom, when I received three letters.The first was from Alan, offering to visit me in Leyden; the other two were out of Scotland and prompted by the same affair, which was the death of my uncle and my own complete accession to my rights.Rankeillor’s was, of course, wholly in the business view; Miss Grant’s was like herself, a little more witty than wise, full of blame to me for not having written (though how was I to write with such intelligence?)and of rallying talk about Catriona, which it cut me to the quick to read in her very presence.

zh: 当然，我是在自己的房间里发现这几封信的，当时我正要去吃晚饭，所以我打开信读的那一刹那就非常意外地公布了这个消息。我们三个人听闻此消息都很开心，但都没有预料到接下来会发生不好的结果。在同一天收到三封信本来就很巧了，而那些信送达我手上时恰好詹姆斯·莫尔又和我在同一个房间里。要是我早管住了自己的嘴，也许就可以防止由此引发的所有事情了。但事实却是在阿格里科拉进入苏格兰之前或者亚伯拉罕动身去旅行之前，这一切就已经命中注定了。
en: For it was of course in my own rooms that I found them, when I came to dinner, so that I was surprised out of my news in the very first moment of reading it.This made a welcome diversion for all three of us, nor could any have foreseen the ill consequences that ensued.It was accident that brought the three letters the same day, and that gave them into my hand in the same room with James More; and of all the events that flowed from that accident, and which I might have prevented if I had held my tongue, the truth is that they were preordained before Agricola came into Scotland or Abraham set out upon his travels.

zh: 我首先打开的自然是艾伦的信，而且更自然的是我会对他的来访谈些看法。不过我注意到詹姆斯立刻一副关切的样子坐了起来。
en: The first that I opened was naturally Alan’s; and what more natural than that I should comment on his design to visit me? but I observed James to sit up with an air of immediate attention.

zh: “不是那个涉嫌阿平凶杀案的艾伦·布雷克吧？”他询问道。
en: “Is that not Alan Breck that was suspected of the Appin accident?” he inquired.

zh: 我告诉他，“是的，正是同一个人。”于是他开始打听我们的这位熟人艾伦以及他在法国的生活习惯，对此我也不甚了解，可是他这样却耽误了我一些时间，害我不能看别的信件。随后他又进一步打听艾伦现在提出了什么样的来访计划。
en: I told him, “Ay,” it was the same; and he withheld me some time from my other letters, asking of our acquaintance, of Alan’s manner of life in France, of which I knew very little, and further of his visit as now proposed.

zh: “我们所有被褫夺的乡亲还是有点儿团结的，”他解释说，“此外，我了解这位绅士，虽然他的血统不正，实际上他根本没有权利使用斯图尔特这个姓氏，但是他在德拉莫西的那段日子却很受人们敬佩。他在那里的所作所为像个战士。如果说有些人，他们的名字就不必说了，也表现得很好的话，结局就不至于如此令人悲叹、不堪回首了。当时有两个人拼尽了全力，正是这一点把我们俩联系在一起了。”他说。
en: “All we forfeited folk hang a little together,” he explained, “and besides I know the gentleman: and though his descent is not the thing, and indeed he has no true right to use the name of Stewart, he was very much admired in the day of Drummossie.He did there like a soldier; if some that need not be named had done as well, the upshot need not have been so melancholy to remember.There were two that did their best that day, and it makes a bond between the pair of us,” says he.

zh: 我差一点儿忍不住要向他开口询问了，而且心里非常希望艾伦当时在场，就可以更近一步去了解他的身世。虽然，有人告诉过我，那件事情着实非比寻常。
en: I could scarce refrain from shooting out my tongue at him, and could almost have wished that Alan had been there to have inquired a little further into that mention of his birth.Though, they tell me, the same was indeed not wholly regular.

zh: 与此同时，我打开了格兰特小姐的信，而且忍不住发出了一声惊呼。
en: Meanwhile, I had opened Miss Grant’s, and could not withhold an exclamation.

zh: “卡特里奥娜！”我忘乎所以地喊道，自从她父亲来后这还是我第一次直呼其名，“我发达了，我现在真正是肖斯的领主了——我叔父终于死了。”
en: “Catriona,” I cried, forgetting, the first time since her father was arrived, to address her by a handle, “I am come into my kingdom fairly, I am the laird of Shaws indeed—my uncle is dead at last.”

zh: 她拍着双手从座位上跳了起来。接下来我们两个人马上都意识到我们实在没有理由为此欢欣雀跃，于是我们面对面站着，悲哀地互相凝视着对方。
en: She clapped her hands together leaping from her seat.The next moment it must have come over both of us at once what little cause of joy was left to either, and we stood opposite, staring on each other sadly.

zh: 但是詹姆斯却立即表现出一副伪君子模样。 “我的女儿，”他说，“难道这就是我那堂姐教你的行为礼节吗？戴维先生刚失去了一位亲友，我们首先应该对他痛失亲人表示慰问才是。”
en: But James showed himself a ready hypocrite.“My daughter,” says he, “is this how my cousin learned you to behave?Mr. David has lost a new friend, and we should first condole with him on his bereavement.”

zh: “说实话，先生，”我有点儿生气地转向他说道，“我做不出这样的表情。他的死是我得到的最大的喜讯。”
en: “Troth, sir,” said I, turning to him in a kind of anger, “I can make no such great faces.His death is as blithe news as ever I got.”

zh: “这正是一位优秀战士的哲学，”詹姆斯说，“这就是芸芸众生之路，我们肯定都会死的，都会死的。如果你那么不喜欢这位绅士的话，那么，很好！不过至少我们要祝贺你继承了财产。”
en: “It’s a good soldier’s philosophy,” says James.“’Tis the way of flesh, we must all go, all go.And if the gentleman was so far from your favour, why, very well!But we may at least congratulate you on your accession to your estates.”

zh: “我也不能那么说。”我还是怒气冲冲地回答说，“这是一份丰厚的财产，不过对于一个已经富足却孤单无伴的男人而言又有什么意义呢？我生活节俭，已经有一笔可观的收入了。但是只有这个家伙死了，我才感到称心，虽然我为此感到羞愧却又不得不承认这一点！我看不出一个人怎么会通过这种变故来变富。”
en: “Nor can I say that either,” I replied, with the same heat.“It is a good estate; what matters that to a lone man that has enough already?I had a good revenue before in my frugality; and but for the man’s death—which gratifies me, shame to me that must confess it!—I see not how anyone is to be bettered by this change.”

zh: “好了，好了，”他说，“你的感情发泄得过于强烈了，或许你从来没有觉得自己会如此孤单。这里有三封信，也就意味着有三个人是希望你好的，何况我还可以说出两个人来，他们现在就在这间房里。我认识你的时间虽然不是太长，但是卡特里奥娜，每当我们俩单独在一起时，总是对你赞不绝口。”
en: “Come, come,” said he, “you are more affected than you let on, or you would never make yourself out so lonely.Here are three letters; that means three that wish you well; and I could name two more, here in this very chamber.I have known you not so very long, but Catriona, when we are alone, is never done with the singing of your praises.”

zh: 她听到这话有点儿生气，抬头看着他，于是他立刻转移话题谈论另外一件事情，即我的财产多少，（晚餐时的大部分时间）他继续兴致勃勃勃地在详细谈论着该话题。不过他没有打算掩饰他的意图，他对这件事情过于关注，而我也知道会发生什么事情。晚饭还没吃完，他就直白地表露他的意图了。他提醒卡特里奥娜说还有一件事情，然后就吩咐她去办理。“我认为你办这件事情不会超过一个小时，”他补充道，“而戴维朋友会好心陪伴我直到你回来的。她没说一句话便急忙照他的吩咐去办事了。我不知道她是否明白了，我认为是没有。但我非常满意，坐在那里竭力在想着接下来会发生什么。
en: She looked up at him, a little wild at that; and he slid off at once into another matter, the extent of my estate, which (during the most of the dinner time) he continued to dwell upon with interest.But it was to no purpose he dissembled; he had touched the matter with too gross a hand: and I knew what to expect.Dinner was scarce ate when he plainly discovered his designs.He reminded Catriona of an errand, and bid her attend to it.“I do not see you should be one beyond the hour,” he added, “and friend David will be good enough to bear me company till you return.”She made haste to obey him without words.I do not know if she understood, I believe not; but I was completely satisfied, and sat strengthening my mind for what should follow.

zh: 她离开后就把门关了，这时那个家伙向后靠在椅背上，带着一种轻松温和的表情对我发话了。只有一样东西出卖了他，那就是他的脸。他的脸上突然布满了星星点点晶亮的汗珠。
en: The door had scarce closed behind her departure, when the man leaned back in his chair and addressed me with a good affectation of easiness.Only the one thing betrayed him, and that was his face; which suddenly shone all over with fine points of sweat.

zh: “我很高兴能和你单独谈谈，”他说，“因为在我们第一次见面时，有些话你就误解了，我一直都想跟你解释清楚的。我女儿的态度是毋庸置疑的。你的也一样，那么我会用我的剑来对付所有的反对者，以促成这件好事。但是我亲爱的戴维，这个世界对人是很苛刻的——这一点有谁会比我更清楚呢？还是从先父在世起（愿上帝保佑他！），我就一直生活在一个诽谤中伤恣意泛滥的世界里了。那是我们不得不面对的，我和你不能不考虑这一点，我们必须得考虑这一点。”他摇头晃脑，像是布道坛上的一位牧师。
en: “I am rather glad to have a word alone with you,” says he, “because in our first interview there were some expressions you misapprehended and I have long meant to set you right upon.My daughter stands beyond doubt.So do you, and I would make that good with my sword against all gainsayers.But, my dear David, this world is a censorious place—as who should know it better than myself, who have lived ever since the days of my late departed father, God sain him! in a perfect spate of calumnies?We have to face to that; you and me have to consider of that; we have to consider of that.”And he wagged his head like a minister in a pulpit.

zh: “德拉蒙德先生，你想要什么样的结果？”我说，“如果你能直奔主题，我将不胜感激。”
en: “To what effect, Mr. Drummond?” said I.“I would be obliged to you if you would approach your point.”

zh: “哎呀，哎呀，”他笑着说，“的确是有个性！这也是我最欣赏的。不过，我尊敬的朋友，问题是有时候会有一些小麻烦的。”他斟满了一杯葡萄酒。“虽然你我相识不久，却一见如故，这个问题不会困扰我们很久。问题的关键，不需要我跟你说，就是我女儿。首先，我从没有想过要责怪你。在那种不幸的环境下，你还能做什么呢？确实，我也想不出。”
en: “Ay, ay,” said he, laughing, “like your character, indeed! and what I most admire in it.But the point, my worthy fellow, is sometimes in a kittle bit.”He filled a glass of wine.“Though between you and me, that are such fast friends, it need not bother us long.The point, I need scarcely tell you, is my daughter.And the first thing is that I have no thought in my mind of blaming you.In the unfortunate circumstances, what could you do else?’Deed, and I cannot tell.”

zh: “我为此谢谢你。”我说，带有很强的戒备心理。
en: “I thank you for that,” said I, pretty close upon my guard.

zh: “此外我还研究过你的性格。”他继续说道，“你才华出众，但似乎能力平平，这不要紧。权衡之下，我很高兴地向你宣布：我已经决定从两种可选方法中选定第二种了。”
en: “I have besides studied your character,” he went on; “your talents are fair; you seem to have a moderate competence, which does no harm; and one thing with another, I am very happy to have to announce to you that I have decided on the latter of the two ways open.”

zh: “恐怕是我愚钝，”我说，“是哪两种方法？”
en: “I am afraid I am dull,” said I.“What ways are these?”

zh: 他对着我皱紧了眉头，样子让人生畏，然后他放下翘着的二郎腿。“哎呀，先生，”他说，“我觉得我没必要对处于你这样地位的绅士来详细描述吧。要么就是我割断你的喉咙，要么就是你娶我的女儿。”
en: He bent his brows upon me formidably and uncrossed his legs.“Why, sir,” says he, “I think I need scarce describe them to a gentleman of your condition; either that I should cut your throat or that you should marry my daughter.”

zh: “你终于愿意把话挑明了。”我说。
en: “You are pleased to be quite plain at last,” said I.

zh: “我认为从一开始我就说得很明白！”他粗鲁地叫喊道，“鲍尔弗先生，我是一个小心谨慎的家长。不过我感谢上帝，我是个很耐心而且处事谨慎的人。先生，很多当父亲的会马上拽着你，要么就去教堂结婚，要么就去野外决斗了。我尊重你的人品——”
en: “And I believe I have been plain from the beginning!” cries he robustiously.“I am a careful parent, Mr. Balfour; but I thank God, a patient and deleeborate man.There is many a father, sir, that would have hirsled you at once either to the altar or the field.My esteem for your character—”

zh: “德拉蒙德先生，”我打断他的话，“如果你真的对我还有一丝尊重的话，我请你说话语气节制一点儿。你大可不必对一个与你同处一室的绅士口出恶言，何况他还对你关照有加。”
en: “Mr. Drummond,” I interrupted, “if you have any esteem for me at all, I will beg of you to moderate your voice.It is quite needless to rowt at a gentleman in the same chamber with yourself and lending you his best attention.”

zh: “是啊，真的是这样。”他说，立即改了腔调，“你一定要谅解一位父亲的激动情绪。”
en: “Why, very true,” says he, with an immediate change.“And you must excuse the agitations of a parent.”

zh: “那么我理解你，”我继续说道，“因为我根本不在意你的另一种选择，很遗憾那也许只是你提出的选择而已——我的理解是假如我愿意提出牵你女儿的手，你会鼓励我这么做？”
en: “I understand you then,” I continued—“for I will take no note of your other alternative, which perhaps it was a pity you let fall—I understand you rather to offer me encouragement in case I should desire to apply for your daughter’s hand?”

zh: “我无法更好地表达我的想法，”他说，“不过我想我们会一起处理好的。”
en: “It is not possible to express my meaning better,” said he, “and I see we shall do well together.”

zh: “那就不得而知了。”我说，“不过我也没必要有所隐瞒，我对你说的那位女士怀有最温柔的情感，而且即使在梦里，我都无法想象会有比得到她更好的运气了。”
en: “That remains to be yet seen,” said I.“But so much I need make no secret of, that I bear the lady you refer to the most tender affection, and I could not fancy, even in a dream, a better fortune than to get her.”

zh: “我对此确信无疑，我对你也很有把握，戴维。”他叫道，并向我伸出手。
en: “I was sure of it, I felt certain of you, David,” he cried, and reached out his hand to me.

zh: 我拨开他的手。“你太性急了，德拉蒙德先生。”我说，“有些条件还需要创造，而且前进的道路上还有困难，我并不完全清楚我们怎样才能克服这个困难。我已经告诉你了，在我这方面，是毫不反对这桩婚姻的，但是我有充足的理由认为那位年轻女士颇为反对。”
en: I put it by.“You go too fast, Mr. Drummond,” said I.“There are conditions to be made; and there is a difficulty in the path, which I see not entirely how we shall come over.I have told you that, upon my side, there is no objection to the marriage, but I have good reason to believe there will be much on the young lady’s.”

zh: “这完全无关紧要，”他说，“我保证让她接受。”
en: “This is all beside the mark,” says he.“I will engage for her acceptance.”

zh: “我想你是忘记了，德拉蒙德先生，”我说，“我们俩谈话这段时间，我已经发现你三番两次说一些让人生厌的话了。我决不会请任何人来插手这位年轻女士的事情。我在这里只谈论也只考虑我们两个人的事，而且我希望你明白，我不会让人硬塞给自己一个妻子，更不会让人硬塞一个丈夫给那位年轻的女士。”
en: “I think you forget, Mr. Drummond,” said I, “that, even in dealing with myself, you have been betrayed into two-three unpalatable expressions.I will have none such employed to the young lady.I am here to speak and think for the two of us; and I give you to understand that I would no more let a wife be forced upon myself, than what I would let a husband be forced on the young lady.”

zh: 他坐着，对我怒目而视，像是满腹狐疑而且满腔怒火的样子。
en: He sat and glowered at me like one in doubt and a good deal of temper.

zh: “所以解决的方法只能是那样，”我下结论说，“只要德拉蒙德小姐心甘情愿，我就会娶她，而且会非常开心。但是只要她有丝毫的不情愿，对此我有理由担心——我就绝不会娶她。”
en: “So that is to be the way of it,” I concluded.“I will marry Miss Drummond, and that blithely, if she is entirely willing.But if there be the least unwillingness, as I have reason to fear—marry her will I never.”

zh: “好，好，”他说，“这是一件小事。她一回来，我就探探她的口风，希望能让你安心——”
en: “Well well,” said he, “this is a small affair.As soon as she returns I will sound her a bit, and hope to reassure you—”

zh: 但是我再次打断了他的话。“德拉蒙德先生，你绝不能插手，否则这件事就作罢，那你就到别处去给你女儿物色一个丈夫吧。”我说，“我才是唯一的当事人和唯一的裁判。我要让自己完全满意，其他任何人都休想干涉——尤其是你。”
en: But I cut in again.“Not a finger of you, Mr. Drummond, or I cry off, and you can seek a husband to your daughter somewhere else,” said I.“It is I that am to be the only dealer and the only judge.I shall satisfy myself exactly; and none else shall anyways meddle—you the least of all.”

zh: “听我说，先生！”他叫嚷道，“你是什么人，凭什么要去当裁判？”
en: “Upon my word, sir!” he exclaimed, “and who are you to be the judge?”

zh: “新郎吧，我认为。”我说。
en: “The bridegroom, I believe,” said I.

zh: “你这是狡辩，”他叫道，“你枉顾事实。那个女孩，我的女儿，根本就没有选择的余地。她的名誉已经毁了。”
en: “This is to quibble,” he cried.“You turn your back upon the fact.The girl, my daughter, has no choice left to exercise.Her character is gone.”

zh: “那么我请你原谅，”我说，“但是这件事情虽说是在她、你和我之间，然而事情并非如此。
en: “And I ask your pardon,” said I, “but while this matter lies between her and you and me, that is not so.”

zh: “我有什么保障！”他叫道，“难道我要让我女儿的名声全凭运气吗？”
en: “What security have I!” he cried.“Am I to let my daughter’s reputation depend upon a chance?”

zh: “你早就应该想到这一点的，”我说，“在你任意妄为失去她之前就该想到，而不是在那之后，那时就太晚了。我绝不会为你的疏忽承担责任，也没有哪个活人能吓唬住我。我意已决，不论发生什么，我都不会有丝毫偏离。你和我就一起坐在这里直到她回来。她回来时你一个字都不要提，也不要透露一点儿神情，我和她再继续我们的谈话。如果她能让我确信她愿意走这一步，那么我就会去做；如果她不能，我就不会做。”
en: “You should have thought of all this long ago,” said I, “before you were so misguided as to lose her; and not afterwards when it is quite too late.I refuse to regard myself as any way accountable for your neglect, and I will be browbeat by no man living.My mind is quite made up, and come what may, I will not depart from it a hair’s breadth.You and me are to sit here in company till her return: upon which, without either word or look from you, she and I are to go forth again to hold our talk.If she can satisfy me that she is willing to this step, I will then make it; and if she cannot, I will not.”

zh: 他像被刺到了一样，从椅子上跳了起来。“我能看透你的伎俩，”他叫道，“你想劝她去拒绝！”
en: He leaped out of his chair like a man stung.“I can spy your manoeuvre,” he cried; “you would work upon her to refuse!”

zh: “也许是，也许不是，”我说，“无论如何，就得那样去解决。”
en: “Maybe ay, and maybe no,” said I.“That is the way it is to be, whatever.”

zh: “那要是我拒绝呢？”他叫道。
en: “And if I refuse?” cries he.

zh: “那么，德拉蒙德先生，那就只好来一场你死我活的决斗了。”我说。
en: “Then, Mr. Drummond, it will have to come to the throat-cutting,” said I.

zh: 这个人身材高大，手臂长得几乎可以与其父媲美，而且据说他剑术娴熟。我说这话时其实很害怕，更不必说他还是卡特里奥娜的父亲了。不过我也许没有必要惊慌。从我住处的简陋——他似乎没有注意到他女儿的衣服，那些衣服他其实都没见过——从我不愿意给他借钱这个事实，他已经坚信我很贫穷了。突然有消息说及我的财产，这使他确信自己的判断错误了，于是他就孤注一掷做出了这次冒险的举动，而且他现在执意这么做，所以我相信他宁愿忍受一切都不会选择去决斗的。
en: What with the size of the man, his great length of arm in which he came near rivalling his father, and his reputed skill at weapons, I did not use this word without trepidation, to say nothing at all of the circumstance that he was Catriona’s father.But I might have spared myself alarms.From the poorness of my lodging—he does not seem to have remarked his daughter’s dresses, which were indeed all equally new to him—and from the fact that I had shown myself averse to lend, he had embraced a strong idea of my poverty.The sudden news of my estate convinced him of his error, and he had made but the one bound of it on this fresh venture, to which he was now so wedded, that I believe he would have suffered anything rather than fall to the alternative of fighting.

zh: 他继续跟我争论了好一会儿，直到我偶然说出一句话才让他安静下来。
en: A little while longer he continued to dispute with me, until I hit upon a word that silenced him.

zh: “如果我发现你如此反对我和你女儿单独见面，”我说，“我只能假设你有充足的理由认为我的想法是对的，她真的不愿意嫁给我。”
en: “If I find you so averse to let me see the lady by herself,” said I, “I must suppose you have very good grounds to think me in the right about her unwillingness.”

zh: 他喋喋不休地在辩解着。
en: He gabbled some kind of an excuse.

zh: “但是这一切只会使我们双方精疲力竭，”我补充说，“所以我认为我们最好是很明智地保持沉默。”
en: “But all this is very exhausting to both of our tempers,” I added, “and I think we would do better to preserve a judicious silence.”

zh: 我们就这样保持着沉默，一直到那位姑娘回来，而且我想当时如果有人看见我们的话，一定觉得我们的样子很好笑。
en: The which we did until the girl returned, and I must suppose would have cut a very ridiculous figure had there been any there to view us.

zh: 第二十八章 剩下我孤独在此
en: CHAPTER XXVIII—IN WHICH I AM LEFT ALONE

zh: 我给卡特里奥娜开了门，并在门口拦住了她。
en: I opened the door to Catriona and stopped her on the threshold.

zh: “你父亲希望我们去散散步。”我说。
en: “Your father wishes us to take our walk,” said I.

zh: 她朝詹姆斯·莫尔望去，他点了点头。见此，她就像一个受过训练的士兵一样，转身就和我一起走了。
en: She looked to James More, who nodded, and at that, like a trained soldier, she turned to go with me.

zh: 我们走的是一条曾经走过的老路。那条路我们过去经常一起走，而过去的那种幸福是我无法言说的。我比她落后了半步，这样我就可以观察她而不被其察觉。她那双小巧的鞋子敲击地面的声音听起来特别动听而又伤感。我觉得那一刻很奇特，我居然同时如此靠近两种不同的结果，走在两种命运的中间。我不知道我是最后一次听到这些脚步声呢，还是这些声音会一直陪我走进走出，直到死亡将我们分开。
en: We took one of our old ways, where we had gone often together, and been more happy than I can tell of in the past.I came a half a step behind, so that I could watch her unobserved.The knocking of her little shoes upon the way sounded extraordinary pretty and sad; and I thought it a strange moment that I should be so near both ends of it at once, and walk in the midst between two destinies, and could not tell whether I was hearing these steps for the last time, or whether the sound of them was to go in and out with me till death should part us.

zh: 她甚至回避看我，只是一味地在前面走着，好像她已经猜到了将会发生的事情。我明白我必须趁着勇气尚未耗尽赶紧开口说话，可是我却不知道该从何说起。这位姑娘实际上等于被迫投入了我的怀抱，而且已经在恳求我的克制，在这种困境中，任何过分的压力似乎都不合情理，然而要完全避免这么做就得显出一副冷酷无情的样子。在这种极端的矛盾中，我无助地站着，可能都已经在咬手指了。因此，当我终于开口说话时，可以说我是随口说出的。
en: She avoided even to look at me, only walked before her, like one who had a guess of what was coming.I saw I must speak soon before my courage was run out, but where to begin I knew not.In this painful situation, when the girl was as good as forced into my arms and had already besought my forbearance, any excess of pressure must have seemed indecent; yet to avoid it wholly would have a very cold-like appearance.Between these extremes I stood helpless, and could have bit my fingers; so that, when at last I managed to speak at all, it may be said I spoke at random.

zh: “卡特里奥娜，”我说，“我现在处于很难堪的境地，或者说，我们两个人都一样。如果你答应让我先把话说完，而且在我说完之前不打断我，那我将不胜感激。”
en: “Catriona,” said I, “I am in a very painful situation; or rather, so we are both; and I would be a good deal obliged to you if you would promise to let me speak through first of all, and not to interrupt me till I have done.”

zh: 她爽快地答应了。
en: She promised me that simply.

zh: “那么，”我说，“我要说的话很难开口，而且我很清楚我没有权利这么说。自从上周五我们俩之间说过那些话之后，我就没有权利再说什么了。我们之间一直如此纠缠不清（当然全是我的错），我非常清楚我唯有尽量保持沉默，我也尽力这么做了，而且我根本没有想过要再次打扰你。但是，亲爱的，现在已经变得很有必要这么做了，此外也别无他法。你看，我的财产已经落到我的名下，这样就使我成为了更好的配偶。而且这件——这件事情也就显得不像以前那样荒唐可笑了。 此外，我想既然我们之间的事情已经如此纠缠不清（正如我刚才说的），那么就顺其自然，岂不更好？在我看来，这件事情中的这个部分被过分地夸大了，如果我是你，我就不会对此有两种不同的想法。只不过我提到这件事情也对，因为毫无疑问它对詹姆斯·莫尔有一些影响。然后我又想我们以前在这个城市一起住的时候一直都是非常开心的。我认为我们一起相处得很好。亲爱的，如果你回头看看……”
en: “Well,” said I, “this that I have got to say is very difficult, and I know very well I have no right to be saying it.After what passed between the two of us last Friday, I have no manner of right.We have got so ravelled up (and all by my fault) that I know very well the least I could do is just to hold my tongue, which was what I intended fully, and there was nothing further from my thoughts than to have troubled you again.But, my dear, it has become merely necessary, and no way by it.You see, this estate of mine has fallen in, which makes of me rather a better match; and the—the business would not have quite the same ridiculous-like appearance that it would before.Besides which, it’s supposed that our affairs have got so much ravelled up (as I was saying) that it would be better to let them be the way they are.In my view, this part of the thing is vastly exagerate, and if I were you I would not wear two thoughts on it.Only it’s right I should mention the same, because there’s no doubt it has some influence on James More.Then I think we were none so unhappy when we dwelt together in this town before.I think we did pretty well together.If you would look back, my dear—”

zh: “我既不会向后看也不会向前看。”她打断了我的话，“只要告诉我一件事：这是我父亲要做的吧？”
en: “I will look neither back nor forward,” she interrupted.“Tell me the one thing: this is my father’s doing?”

zh: “他同意我这么做的，”我说，“他同意我向你求婚。”我再次说道，更像是在恳求她的感情。但是她不为我所动，在我说话中间就打断了我。
en: “He approves of it,” said I.“He approved I that I should ask your hand in marriage,” and was going on again with somewhat more of an appeal upon her feelings; but she marked me not, and struck into the midst.

zh: “是他叫你做的！”她大喊道，“你否认也没意义，你自己都说了你根本就没有想过。是他叫你做的。”
en: “He told you to!” she cried.“It is no sense denying it, you said yourself that there was nothing farther from your thoughts.He told you to.”

zh: “他先说起这件事的，如果你想那么说的话。”我开始说。
en: “He spoke of it the first, if that is what you mean,” I began.

zh: 她走得更快了，直视着前方。但是听到这句话，她脑袋里有点儿嗡嗡作响，所以我想她可能会跑了。
en: She was walking ever the faster, and looking fain in front of her; but at this she made a little noise in her head, and I thought she would have run.

zh: “如果没有这件事，”我继续说，“在上周五你说过那番话之后，我就绝不会这么不识趣来求婚了。但是当他几乎是在要求我的时候，那我该怎么办？”
en: “Without which,” I went on, “after what you said last Friday, I would never have been so troublesome as make the offer.But when he as good as asked me, what was I to do?”

zh: 她停住脚步转身对着我。
en: She stopped and turned round upon me.

zh: “那么，无论如何都要回绝。”她叫道，“这件事情到此为止。”
en: “Well, it is refused at all events,” she cried, “and there will be an end of that.”

zh: 然后她又开始朝前走去。
en: And she began again to walk forward.

zh: “我想我是不可能期待有更好的结果了，”我说，“但是我觉得在这最后结束之时你可以尽量对我和善一点儿吧。我不理解你为什么要对我这么苛刻。我一直非常爱你，卡特里奥娜——我最后一次这么叫你，对你也不会有什么伤害了。我已经尽我所能作出最大的努力了，我仍然在尽力，只是对自己无法做得更好而感到烦恼。你居然以对我苛刻无情为乐，这让我觉得很奇怪。”
en: “I suppose I could expect no better,” said I, “but I think you might try to be a little kind to me for the last end of it.I see not why you should be harsh.I have loved you very well, Catriona—no harm that I should call you so for the last time.I have done the best that I could manage, I am trying the same still, and only vexed that I can do no better.It is a strange thing to me that you can take any pleasure to be hard to me.”

zh: “我不是冲着你来的，”她说，“我是冲着那个人，冲着我的父亲来的。”
en: “I am not thinking of you,” she said, “I am thinking of that man, my father.”

zh: “好吧，就那么办吧，也行！”我说，“那么办，我对你也会有用，我必须对你有用才行。亲爱的，我们非常有必要和你父亲商量商量，因为我们这下子谈崩了，生气的人就会是詹姆斯·莫尔。”
en: “Well, and that way, too!” said I.“I can be of use to you that way, too; I will have to be.It is very needful, my dear, that we should consult about your father; for the way this talk has gone, an angry man will be James More.”

zh: 她再次停了下来。“那是因为我丢脸了？”她问道。
en: She stopped again.“It is because I am disgraced?” she asked.

zh: “那是他的想法，”我回答道，“但是我已经跟你说过不要在意。”
en: “That is what he is thinking,” I replied, “but I have told you already to make nought of it.”

zh: “这对我来说全都一样，”她叫道，“我宁愿丢脸！”
en: “It will be all one to me,” she cried.“I prefer to be disgraced!”

zh: 我不知道该怎么回答才好，所以就一声不吭地站着。
en: I did not know very well what to answer, and stood silent.

zh: 她刚才那么叫喊之后，心里似乎有什么东西在沸腾，跟着立刻就爆发了：“所有这一切都是什么意思？为什么要把这一切羞辱都加在我的头上？戴维·鲍尔弗，你怎么敢这样？”
