en: There seemed to be something working in her bosom after that last cry; presently she broke out, “And what is the meaning of all this?Why is all this shame loundered on my head?How could you dare it, David Balfour?”

zh: “我亲爱的，”我说，“我还能怎么做呢？”
en: “My dear,” said I, “what else was I to do?”

zh: “我不是你的亲爱的，”她说，“我不准你用这几个词称呼我。”
en: “I am not your dear,” she said, “and I defy you to be calling me these words.”

zh: “我没在想我用的词，”我说，“我的心在为你泣血，德拉蒙德小姐。不论我说什么，可以肯定我很同情你的艰难处境。但是有一点儿我希望你考虑一下，就是我们是不是应该呆久一点儿来平静地讨论这件事情，因为我们两个人回去的时候，肯定会有一场争吵的。相信我，这件事情需要我们俩平心静气地来解决。”
en: “I am not thinking of my words,” said I.“My heart bleeds for you, Miss Drummond.Whatever I may say, be sure you have my pity in your difficult position.But there is just the one thing that I wish you would bear in view, if it was only long enough to discuss it quietly; for there is going to be a collieshangie when we two get home.Take my word for it, it will need the two of us to make this matter end in peace.”

zh: “好。”她说。她的双颊飞起一片红晕。“他说要跟你决斗吗？”她说。
en: “Ay,” said she.There sprang a patch of red in either of her cheeks.“Was he for fighting you?” said she.

zh: “是的，他是那么说的。”我说。
en: “Well, he was that,” said I.

zh: 她发出一种可怕的大笑声。“无论如何，这事是完了！”她叫道。然后她转向我。“我和我父亲还真是一对好搭档，”她说，“不过我感谢仁慈的上帝居然还有人比我们更不如。 我感谢仁慈的上帝让我看清你这副模样。永远不会再有女孩子会看得起你了。”
en: She gave a dreadful kind of laugh.“At all events, it is complete!” she cried.And then turning on me.“My father and I are a fine pair,” said she, “but I am thanking the good God there will be somebody worse than what we are.I am thanking the good God that he has let me see you so.There will never be the girl made that will not scorn you.”

zh: 我一直都保持着极度的耐心，但是这也太过分了。
en: I had borne a good deal pretty patiently, but this was over the mark.

zh: “你没有权利那样对我说话，”我说，“我所做的一切都只是为你好，或者说试图为你好。而这就是我得到的回报！哦，这太过分了。”
en: “You have no right to speak to me like that,” said I.“What have I done but to be good to you, or try to be?And here is my repayment!O, it is too much.”

zh: 她直盯着我，露出一种可恨的微笑。“懦夫！”她说。
en: She kept looking at me with a hateful smile.“Coward!” said she.

zh: “你嗓子里蹦出的词和你父亲的一样！”我叫道，“今天为了你的权益，我已经向他挑战了。我会再次向他挑战，这个卑鄙小人，我才不管我们当中哪一个会倒下呢！来吧，”我说，“我们一起回住处去。让我们了结这件事情，让我和你们这帮高地佬彻底了结吧！我死的时候你会看到你想看的一切！”
en: “The word in your throat and in your father’s!” I cried.“I have dared him this day already in your interest.I will dare him again, the nasty pole-cat; little I care which of us should fall!Come,” said I, “back to the house with us; let us be done with it, let me be done with the whole Hieland crew of you!You will see what you think when I am dead.”

zh: 她对着我摇摇头，带着同样的微笑，我简直想揍她了。
en: She shook her head at me with that same smile I could have struck her for.

zh: “哦，让你的笑见鬼去吧！”我叫道，“今天我已经见过你那位了不起的父亲的微笑了，不过他笑错了对象而已。当然，我倒不是说他害怕。”我急忙补充道，“但是他宁可选择另一个办法来解决。”
en: “O, smile away!” I cried.“I have seen your bonny father smile on the wrong side this day.Not that I mean he was afraid, of course,” I added hastily, “but he preferred the other way of it.”

zh: “是怎么回事？”她问。
en: “What is this?” she asked.

zh: “当时我提出要和他拔剑决斗。”我说。
en: “When I offered to draw with him,” said I.

zh: “你曾对詹姆斯·莫尔提出拔剑决斗!”她叫道。
en: “You offered to draw upon James More!” she cried.

zh: “我是这么做的，”我说，“却发现他退缩了，否则我们怎么会在这里？”
en: “And I did so,” said I, “and found him backward enough, or how would we be here?”

zh: “这么做是有含义的吧，”她说，“你这到底是什么意思？”
en: “There is a meaning upon this,” said she.“What is it you are meaning?”

zh: “他要逼你接受我，”我回答说，“而我不同意那么做。我说你应该是自由的，所以我必须和你单独谈谈，我真没有想到居然会是这么一场谈话！他说：‘要是我拒绝呢？’‘那么，德拉蒙德先生，那就只好来一场你死我活的决斗了。’我说，‘因为我不会让人硬塞给自己一个妻子，更不会让人硬塞一个丈夫给那位年轻的女士。’这就是我说过的话，这是一位朋友说过的话。为此我付出了多大的代价呀！现在你按自己的意愿明确地拒绝了我，那么不论是在高地还是其外，都不会有什么父亲可以强加这桩婚姻了。我会保证你的意愿受到尊重，我会一如既往地把这看成是自己的事情。但是我觉得你也许应该有礼貌，哪怕是装出有点儿感激的样子都好。实际上，我以为你更了解我！我对你表现得虽然不是很好，但那只是软弱。可是你居然认为我是懦夫，而且是那么一种懦夫——哦，我的姑娘，这可是致命的一击啊！”
en: “He was to make you take me,” I replied, “and I would not have it.I said you should be free, and I must speak with you alone; little I supposed it would be such a speaking!‘And what if I refuse?’ said he.—‘Then it must come to the throat-cutting,’ says I, ‘for I will no more have a husband forced on that young lady, than what I would have a wife forced upon myself.’  These were my words, they were a friend’s words; bonnily have I paid for them!Now you have refused me of your own clear free will, and there lives no father in the Highlands, or out of them, that can force on this marriage.I will see that your wishes are respected; I will make the same my business, as I have all through.But I think you might have that decency as to affect some gratitude.‘Deed, and I thought you knew me better!I have not behaved quite well to you, but that was weakness.And to think me a coward, and such a coward as that—O, my lass, there was a stab for the last of it!”

zh: “戴维，那我该怎么想？”她叫道，“哦，这件事太可怕了！我和我的家人，”她说这话时带着一种可怜的哭腔，“我和我的家人都不配和你说话。哦，我应该在大街上向你下跪，我应该吻你的手请求宽恕！”
en: “Davie, how would I guess?” she cried.“O, this is a dreadful business!Me and mine,”—she gave a kind of a wretched cry at the word—“me and mine are not fit to speak to you.O, I could be kneeling down to you in the street, I could be kissing your hands for forgiveness!”

zh: “我会保留从你那里得到的吻，”我叫道，“我会保留我想要的吻和值得保留的吻，但我绝不要忏悔的吻。”
en: “I will keep the kisses I have got from you already,” cried I.“I will keep the ones I wanted and that were something worth; I will not be kissed in penitence.”

zh: “那对这个可怜的女孩你还能怎么想？”她说。
en: “What can you be thinking of this miserable girl?” says she.

zh: “这一阵子我一直想告诉你的！”我说，“你最好别理我。如果你不理我，你就不会再让我不快乐，你就可以去照顾你的父亲詹姆斯·莫尔，和他在一起，你就像是有一个奇怪的线轴一样可以围着他转了。”
en: “What I am trying to tell you all this while!” said I, “that you had best leave me alone, whom you can make no more unhappy if you tried, and turn your attention to James More, your father, with whom you are like to have a queer pirn to wind.”

zh: “哦，我一定会独自和这样一个人一起去闯荡世界的！”她叫道，而且似乎费了很大的劲想克制住自己。“不过不会再为此麻烦你了，”她说，“他不了解我的内心是什么本性。他将为今天付出昂贵的代价，非常、非常昂贵的代价，他一定会付的。”
en: “O, that I must be going out into the world alone with such a man!” she cried, and seemed to catch herself in with a great effort.“But trouble yourself no more for that,” said she.“He does not know what kind of nature is in my heart.He will pay me dear for this day of it; dear, dear, will he pay.”

zh: 她转过身，开始走回家，我就陪着她。见此，她停了下来。
en: She turned, and began to go home and I to accompany her.At which she stopped.

zh: “我要一个人回去，”她说，“我必须单独见他。”
en: “I will be going alone,” she said.“It is alone I must be seeing him.”

zh: 我恼怒万分地在街上转了一会儿，内心暗忖自己是基督教国度被利用得最惨的青年了。愤怒令我窒息，对我来说深呼吸固然不错，可是莱登似乎已经没有足够的空气供我呼吸，而我觉得自己就像一个沉在海底的人，已经要爆炸了。我在街角停下来嘲笑了自己一会儿，笑得很大声，结果有个过路人都在看我了，这才让我清醒过来。
en: Some little time I raged about the streets, and told myself I was the worst used lad in Christendom.Anger choked me; it was all very well for me to breathe deep; it seemed there was not air enough about Leyden to supply me, and I thought I would have burst like a man at the bottom of the sea.I stopped and laughed at myself at a street corner a minute together, laughing out loud, so that a passenger looked at me, which brought me to myself.

zh: “好吧，”我想，“我当傻瓜、笨蛋和软蛋已经当得够久了。是结束的时候了。这是个沉重的教训，千万别和那种该死的性别扯上瓜葛，那自始至终都会是对男人的毁灭。上帝知道在遇见她之前我有多么快乐，上帝知道永不再见她之后我又可以快乐无比了。”
en: “Well,” I thought, “I have been a gull and a ninny and a soft Tommy long enough.Time it was done.Here is a good lesson to have nothing to do with that accursed sex, that was the ruin of the man in the beginning and will be so to the end.God knows I was happy enough before ever I saw her; God knows I can be happy enough again when I have seen the last of her.”

zh: 似乎对我来说，最重要的事情就是看着他们离开。我的头脑中强烈地缠绕着这个念头，马上有点儿恶毒地想到：当戴维·鲍尔弗不再充当他们的奶牛时，他们的生活将会多么穷困啊。想到此，我自己都大吃了一惊，我心里的想法完全倒过来了。我还在生气，也还在恨她。然而我觉得这是我自找的，但她不该遭这个罪。
en: That seemed to me the chief affair: to see them go.I dwelled upon the idea fiercely; and presently slipped on, in a kind of malevolence, to consider how very poorly they were likely to fare when Davie Balfour was no longer by to be their milk-cow; at which, to my very own great surprise, the disposition of my mind turned bottom up.I was still angry; I still hated her; and yet I thought I owed it to myself that she should suffer nothing.

zh: 这种想法立刻驱使我回了家，结果发现行李已经搬到外面，而且已经捆好就放在门边，种种迹象表明他们父女俩才争吵过。卡特里奥娜就像个木偶，詹姆斯·莫尔则喘着粗气，他的脸上气得红一块白一块的，而他的鼻子也扭向了一边。我一进去，那女孩就看向他，带着一种坚定、清澈、阴沉的眼神，那种眼神也许紧跟着就会招来一顿打。那眼神与其说含着命令不如说含着蔑视，可是我看到詹姆斯·莫尔居然接受了，我觉得很惊讶。很明显他已经被女儿狠狠说过一顿了，而且我看得出这个女孩肯定比我想象得要厉害，而这个男人的雅量也出乎我的预料。
en: This carried me home again at once, where I found the mails drawn out and ready fastened by the door, and the father and daughter with every mark upon them of a recent disagreement.Catriona was like a wooden doll; James More breathed hard, his face was dotted with white spots, and his nose upon one side.As soon as I came in, the girl looked at him with a steady, clear, dark look that might have been followed by a blow.It was a hint that was more contemptuous than a command, and I was surprised to see James More accept it.It was plain he had had a master talking-to; and I could see there must be more of the devil in the girl than I had guessed, and more good humour about the man than I had given him the credit of.

zh: 至少，他开始称呼我鲍尔弗先生了，而且很坦率地从受到的教训开始说起。不过他没有说太多，因为他的声音刚因为傲慢有点儿提高，卡特里奥娜就插话了。
en: He began, at least, calling me Mr. Balfour, and plainly speaking from a lesson; but he got not very far, for at the first pompous swell of his voice, Catriona cut in.

zh: “我来告诉你詹姆斯·莫尔的意思是什么，”她说，“他的意思是我们跑来找你，就像乞丐一样，而且我们对你不是很好，我们为自己的忘恩负义和无礼行为深感羞愧。现在我们正想走，也希望你忘记我们。可是我父亲钱财使用不当，所以如果你不给我们再多一些施舍的话，我们连这一点都无法做到。因为我们就是那样的人，不管怎么说，就是乞丐和食客而已。”
en: “I will tell you what James More is meaning,” said she.“He means we have come to you, beggar-folk, and have not behaved to you very well, and we are ashamed of our ingratitude and ill-behaviour.Now we are wanting to go away and be forgotten; and my father will have guided his gear so ill, that we cannot even do that unless you will give us some more alms.For that is what we are, at an events, beggar-folk and sorners.”

zh: “对不起，德拉蒙德小姐，”我说，“我必须亲自和你父亲谈谈。”
en: “By your leave, Miss Drummond,” said I, “I must speak to your father by myself.”

zh: 她一言不发，也不多看一眼，就走进自己的房间并关上了门。
en: She went into her own room and shut the door, without a word or a look.

zh: “你要原谅她，鲍尔弗先生，”詹姆斯·莫尔说，“她根本不懂礼数。”
en: “You must excuse her, Mr. Balfour,” says James More.“She has no delicacy.”

zh: “我到这里来不是为了和你讨论那一点的，”我说，“而是来打发你走的。为此，我必须谈谈你的处境。现在，德拉蒙德先生，我对你的事情所给予的关照已经比你原来要求的还多了。我知道你在问我借钱的时候，自己其实还有钱。我知道自从到莱登以后，你的钱还更多了，虽然你甚至对你女儿都隐瞒了这一点。”
en: “I am not here to discuss that with you,” said I, “but to be quit of you.And to that end I must talk of your position.Now, Mr. Drummond, I have kept the run of your affairs more closely than you bargained for.I know you had money of your own when you were borrowing mine.I know you have had more since you were here in Leyden, though you concealed it even from your daughter.”

zh: “我请你说话注意一点儿。我再也不会上钩了，”他爆发了，“我讨厌她，也讨厌你。对于作父亲的来说，这是怎样一桩该死的交易啊！我已经知道该用什么话来形容我了——”说到这里他突然停了下来。“先生，这既是一颗战士的心，也是一颗父亲的心。”他把手放在胸口继续说道，“作为这两种身份我都受到了伤害——我请你说话注意一点儿。”
en: “I bid you beware.I will stand no more baiting,” he broke out.“I am sick of her and you.What kind of a damned trade is this to be a parent!I have had expressions used to me—”There he broke off.“Sir, this is the heart of a soldier and a parent,” he went on again, laying his hand on his bosom, “outraged in both characters—and I bid you beware.”

zh: “如果你让我把话说完，”我说，“你会发现我说的对你有好处。”
en: “If you would have let me finish,” says I, “you would have found I spoke for your advantage.”

zh: “我亲爱的朋友，”他叫道，“我知道我也许仰仗了你慷慨好施的性格。”
en: “My dear friend,” he cried, “I know I might have relied upon the generosity of your character.”

zh: “老兄！你能让我说说话吗？”我说，“事实上我根本无法发现你是富还是穷。但是我的想法是，你的钱由于来路神秘，所以数量还是有点儿不够。但我决定不让你的女儿缺钱花。如果我敢和她本人说的话，你可以肯定我是绝对不会托付给你的，因为我对你了如指掌，你这些虚夸的高谈阔论对我而言都是空话。然而，我相信你这样做终究是出于对女儿的关心。我现在的做法都以此信念为基础，事情就是这样。”
en: “Man! will you let me speak?” said I.“The fact is that I cannot win to find out if you are rich or poor.But it is my idea that your means, as they are mysterious in their source, so they are something insufficient in amount; and I do not choose your daughter to be lacking.If I durst speak to herself, you may be certain I would never dream of trusting it to you; because I know you like the back of my hand, and all your blustering talk is that much wind to me.However, I believe in your way you do still care something for your daughter after all; and I must just be doing with that ground of confidence, such as it is.”

zh: 随后，我和他约好让他和我联系，至于说他的着落和卡特里奥娜的生活保障，我都考虑到了，并给了他一小笔生活补贴。
en: Whereupon, I arranged with him that he was to communicate with me, as to his whereabouts and Catriona’s welfare, in consideration of which I was to serve him a small stipend.

zh: 他非常热心地听我说出对这件事情的安排。在我说完以后，他大声叫喊道：“我亲爱的朋友，我亲爱的孩子，这比其他任何事情都更像你的做派！我会像战士一样忠诚地待你——”
en: He heard the business out with a great deal of eagerness; and when it was done, “My dear fellow, my dear son,” he cried out, “this is more like yourself than any of it yet!I will serve you with a soldier’s faithfulness—”

zh: “别再让我听到这些话！”我说，“你已经让我烦透了，一听到‘战士’这个词我就倒胃口。我们的交易已经谈妥，我现在出去，半小时以后回来，到时候我希望你已经从我的房间消失了。”
en: “Let me hear no more of it!” says I.“You have got me to that pitch that the bare name of soldier rises on my stomach.Our traffic is settled; I am now going forth and will return in one half-hour, when I expect to find my chambers purged of you.”

zh: 我给了他们充裕的时间。我担心的一点就是怕我会再次见到卡特里奥娜，因为泪水和柔情都已在我心中，而我还怀有怒气，像是在保持那一点点尊严。也许一个小时过去了。太阳已经落山，一弯细细的新月紧随其后，跃然挂在黄昏那片腥红色的天幕上，东边也已经有星星闪烁了。最后当我进入我的房间时，已经入夜。我点燃一根细蜡烛，审视着各个房间。在第一间房里，我并没有发现能唤醒我对远去之人的回忆的东西，但是在第二间房间地板的一个角落里，我发现了一小堆东西，霎时我的心都跳到嗓子眼上了。她离开的时候把我曾经给她的所有东西都留了下来。这个打击让我内心一阵痛楚，也许因为这是最后一次心痛了，我扑倒在那堆衣物上，举止痴傻让我无法言说。
en: I gave them good measure of time; it was my one fear that I might see Catriona again, because tears and weakness were ready in my heart, and I cherished my anger like a piece of dignity.Perhaps an hour went by; the sun had gone down, a little wisp of a new moon was following it across a scarlet sunset; already there were stars in the east, and in my chambers, when at last I entered them, the night lay blue.I lit a taper and reviewed the rooms; in the first there remained nothing so much as to awake a memory of those who were gone; but in the second, in a corner of the floor, I spied a little heap that brought my heart into my mouth.She had left behind at her departure all that she had ever had of me.It was the blow that I felt sorest, perhaps because it was the last; and I fell upon that pile of clothing and behaved myself more foolish than I care to tell of.

zh: 夜深了，严霜凛冽，我的牙齿咯咯作响，我再次恢复了一点儿男子汉的气概，开始反思自己。看见那些凌乱的衣裙和缎带，还有她更换的衣服，以及那些绣花长袜，我再也无法忍受。如果我想恢复自己坚定的意志，我清楚自己必须在清晨前处理好这一切。我的第一个念头就是一把火烧了它们，但是一方面我秉性一贯反对浪费，另一方面把这些她贴身穿过的东西都烧掉似乎也太狠心了。房间的角落里有个衣橱，我决定把它们全收进去。我就这么做了，为此花了很长时间，虽然叠衣服的确不需要什么技巧，但我叠得非常仔细，而且时不时地我的眼泪就会滴落在上面。我魂不守舍，身体疲惫不堪，仿佛跑了几英里一样，而且像受到打击那般痛楚。当我叠着一条她经常围在脖子上的方巾时，我注意到方巾的一角被整整齐齐地剪掉了。那是一条颜色很漂亮的方巾，我曾经常夸赞其色彩亮丽。我记得有一次她围着这条方巾，我还跟她说（以开玩笑的方式）她围了我的颜色。霎时闪现了一线希望，就像是一股暖流涌上心头，可顷刻间我又陷入新的绝望中。因为那角方巾被皱巴巴地揉成一团，扔在了地板上的另一个地方。
en: Late in the night, in a strict frost, and my teeth chattering, I came again by some portion of my manhood and considered with myself.The sight of these poor frocks and ribbons, and her shifts, and the clocked stockings, was not to be endured; and if I were to recover any constancy of mind, I saw I must be rid of them ere the morning.It was my first thought to have made a fire and burned them; but my disposition has always been opposed to wastery, for one thing; and for another, to have burned these things that she had worn so close upon her body seemed in the nature of a cruelty.There was a corner cupboard in that chamber; there I determined to bestow them.The which I did and made it a long business, folding them with very little skill indeed but the more care; and sometimes dropping them with my tears.All the heart was gone out of me, I was weary as though I had run miles, and sore like one beaten; when, as I was folding a kerchief that she wore often at her neck, I observed there was a corner neatly cut from it.It was a kerchief of a very pretty hue, on which I had frequently remarked; and once that she had it on, I remembered telling her (by way of a banter) that she wore my colours.There came a glow of hope and like a tide of sweetness in my bosom; and the next moment I was plunged back in a fresh despair.For there was the corner crumpled in a knot and cast down by itself in another part of the floor.

zh: 但是当我和自己辩解时，我又开始充满希望了。她颇为孩子气地剪下那块方巾角显示了她的柔情，不过她又把它给扔掉了，这却有点儿令人费解。我更倾向于第一种想法而不是第二种，那样我会更加高兴，因为与其担心她是出于一时的怨恨而把它给扔掉了，倒不如想想她曾经想过要留作纪念的。
en: But when I argued with myself, I grew more hopeful.She had cut that corner off in some childish freak that was manifestly tender; that she had cast it away again was little to be wondered at; and I was inclined to dwell more upon the first than upon the second, and to be more pleased that she had ever conceived the idea of that keepsake, than concerned because she had flung it from her in an hour of natural resentment.

zh: 第二十九章 我们在敦刻尔克会面
en: CHAPTER XXIX—WE MEET IN DUNKIRK.

zh: 总之，在随后的日子里，我很少再那么痛苦难受，而是拥有了许多充满希望和快乐的时光。我全身心地投入到不懈的学习中，以此熬过了艾伦来之前的那段时间，也可以通过詹姆斯·莫尔得知卡特里奥娜的消息。我们分开的那段时间我总共收到过三封信。一封信告诉我他们已经到达法国的敦刻尔克镇，没过多久，詹姆斯就独自因私事离开了那里。他那是去英国会见霍尔德内斯大人，我大笔的钱竟然用于帮他支付这类费用，我想到这一点就难受。但是与恶人交往，或者说和詹姆斯·莫尔交往也一样，必须要特别提防。他外出离开的这段时间，我如期收到了他的另一封信。那封信提到了给他的生活补贴的使用情况。他处事很小心，事先就写好了信，然后留给卡特里奥娜寄出的。我们通信之事引起了她的怀疑，所以他刚一离开她就拆开了信的封签。因此，我收到的信开始是詹姆斯·莫尔的笔迹：
en: Altogether, then, I was scare so miserable the next days but what I had many hopeful and happy snatches; threw myself with a good deal of constancy upon my studies; and made out to endure the time till Alan should arrive, or I might hear word of Catriona by the means of James More.I had altogether three letters in the time of our separation.One was to announce their arrival in the town of Dunkirk in France, from which place James shortly after started alone upon a private mission.This was to England and to see Lord Holderness; and it has always been a bitter thought that my good money helped to pay the charges of the same.But he has need of a long spoon who soups with the de’il, or James More either.During this absence, the time was to fall due for another letter; and as the letter was the condition of his stipend, he had been so careful as to prepare it beforehand and leave it with Catriona to be despatched.The fact of our correspondence aroused her suspicions, and he was no sooner gone than she had burst the seal.What I received began accordingly in the writing of James More:

zh: “我亲爱的先生，承蒙眷顾，汇款已经如期收到，我要为遵照协议寄来的这笔款项表示感谢。所有款项均会如实用在我的女儿身上，她很好，也希望她亲爱的朋友会记得她。我发现她心情相当忧郁，但相信上帝的仁慈会令她恢复。我们的生活方式非常孤单，不过我们可以哼唱家乡山区那忧郁的歌曲来聊以自慰，还可以在海边散步，那大海紧邻着苏格兰。对我来说，带着身上的五处伤躺在格拉德斯莫田野上的那些时日更加美好。我已经在一家法国贵族的养马场里找到事做了，在这里我的经验受到了重视。但是，我亲爱的先生，薪酬却极度不相称，我都不好意思说起。所以你的汇款对我女儿过舒适的生活显得更加有必要了，尽管我想老朋友的看法还是会更好一些。
en: “My dear Sir,—Your esteemed favour came to hand duly, and I have to acknowledge the inclosure according to agreement.It shall be all faithfully expended on my daughter, who is well, and desires to be remembered to her dear friend.I find her in rather a melancholy disposition, but trust in the mercy of God to see her re-established.Our manner of life is very much alone, but we solace ourselves with the melancholy tunes of our native mountains, and by walking up the margin of the sea that lies next to Scotland.It was better days with me when I lay with five wounds upon my body on the field of Gladsmuir.I have found employment here in the haras of a French nobleman, where my experience is valued.But, my dear Sir, the wages are so exceedingly unsuitable that I would be ashamed to mention them, which makes your remittances the more necessary to my daughter’s comfort, though I daresay the sight of old friends would be still better.

zh: “我亲爱的先生，你真挚、顺从的仆人，詹姆斯·麦格雷戈·德拉蒙德”
en: “My dear Sir,“Your affectionate, obedient servant,“JAMES MACGREGOR DRUMMOND.”

zh: 下面接着又变成了卡特里奥娜的笔迹。
en: Below it began again in the hand of Catriona:-

zh: “不要相信他，这一切都是谎言——卡特里奥娜·麦格雷戈·德拉蒙德”
en: “Do not be believing him, it is all lies together,—C. M. D.”

zh: 她不仅增加了这句附言，而且我觉得她肯定已经把这封信压了一阵子，因为这封信在预定的时间过了很久才收到，而且紧跟着就收到了第三封信。在这两封信的中间，艾伦到了，和他愉快的交谈给我带来了另外一种生活。他把我介绍给他苏格兰裔荷兰籍的堂兄，那个人酒量之大超乎我想象，而除此之外他别无其他的兴趣。我多次受邀参加愉快的晚宴，我也回请过一些，但这一切对我的悲伤却于事无补。我们两个人（我是指艾伦和我自己，根本不算那位堂兄）就我和詹姆斯·莫尔父女之间的实质关系讨论了很多。我自然不好意思详述细节，不过艾伦并没有因为我这么做而打算对此事少评论一些。
en: Not only did she add this postscript, but I think she must have come near suppressing the letter; for it came long after date, and was closely followed by the third.In the time betwixt them, Alan had arrived, and made another life to me with his merry conversation; I had been presented to his cousin of the Scots-Dutch, a man that drank more than I could have thought possible and was not otherwise of interest; I had been entertained to many jovial dinners and given some myself, all with no great change upon my sorrow; and we two (by which I mean Alan and myself, and not at all the cousin) had discussed a good deal the nature of my relations with James More and his daughter.I was naturally diffident to give particulars; and this disposition was not anyway lessened by the nature of Alan’s commentary upon those I gave.

zh: “我对这件事情还摸不清头脑，”他说，“但是给我的印象就是你已经把自己弄成个呆子了。没有几个人会比我艾伦·布雷克更有经验，但我根本不记得听说过像你这位一样的少女。从你说的情况来看，这件事情不大可能成。戴维，你肯定把事情弄得一团糟了。”
en: “I cannae make heed nor tail of it,” he would say, “but it sticks in my mind ye’ve made a gowk of yourself.There’s few people that has had more experience than Alan Breck: and I can never call to mind to have heard tell of a lassie like this one of yours.The way that you tell it, the thing’s fair impossible.Ye must have made a terrible hash of the business, David.”

zh: “有时我也和你的想法一样。”我说。
en: “There are whiles that I am of the same mind,” said I.

zh: “奇怪的是你对她好像还有几分迷恋啊！”艾伦说。
en: “The strange thing is that ye seem to have a kind of fancy for her too!” said Alan.

zh: “是刻骨铭心，艾伦，”我说，“我觉得我会把这份感情一直带到坟墓里去。”
en: “The biggest kind, Alan,” said I, “and I think I’ll take it to my grave with me.”

zh: “好，我说不过你，随你便吧！”他总结说。
en: “Well, ye beat me, whatever!” he would conclude.

zh: 我给他看了卡特里奥娜写有附言的那封信。“又来了！”他叫道，“不能否认这位卡特里奥娜处事还得体，而且很有见地！至于说詹姆斯·莫尔，这个人就像鼓一样，其实腹内空空、外强中干。不过我绝不否认他在格拉德斯莫战役中的战斗的确很英勇，而且他所说的身受五处伤也是实话。但是他已经失去首领的地位了。”
en: I showed him the letter with Catriona’s postscript.“And here again!” he cried.“Impossible to deny a kind of decency to this Catriona, and sense forby!As for James More, the man’s as boss as a drum; he’s just a wame and a wheen words; though I’ll can never deny that he fought reasonably well at Gladsmuir, and it’s true what he says here about the five wounds.But the loss of him is that the man’s boss.”

zh: “你看，艾伦，”我说，“把那位少女留在如此卑鄙的人的手中，这确实有违我的本意。”
en: “Ye see, Alan,” said I, “it goes against the grain with me to leave the maid in such poor hands.”

zh: “你找不到比他更卑鄙的人了。”他承认道，“但是你打算如何处理这件事？你要知道，戴维，男女之间的事情就是这样的。那些女人根本就是不可理喻的。她们要么喜欢一个男人，那这个人就一切都好；要不然她们就讨厌他，那你就可以省省力气了——你做什么都白搭。她们具有双面性——为你卖掉自己大衣的是她们，走在路上对你瞧都不瞧一眼的也是她们。女人就是那个样子，而你似乎就是一个大傻瓜，连好坏都分不清。”
en: “Ye couldnae weel find poorer,” he admitted.“But what are ye to do with it?It’s this way about a man and a woman, ye see, Davie: The weemenfolk have got no kind of reason to them.Either they like the man, and then a’ goes fine; or else they just detest him, and ye may spare your breath—ye can do naething.There’s just the two sets of them—them that would sell their coats for ye, and them that never look the road ye’re on.That’s a’ that there is to women; and you seem to be such a gomeral that ye cannae tell the tane frae the tither.”

zh: “是啊，恐怕对我来说还真是如此。”我说。
en: “Well, and I’m afraid that’s true for me,” said I.

zh: “然而没有比这更容易的事了！”艾伦叫道，“我能够轻松教你知道事情的真相。但是在我看来你好像天生看不见似的，而这正是困难所在。”
en: “And yet there’s naething easier!” cried Alan.“I could easy learn ye the science of the thing; but ye seem to me to be born blind, and there’s where the deefficulty comes in.”

zh: “难道你就不能帮帮我吗？”我问道，“你不正擅长于此吗？”
en: “And can you no help me?”I asked, “you that are so clever at the trade?”

zh: “你要明白，戴维，我当时可没在这里。”他说，“我就像一个战地指挥官，手下除了一个瞎子再没别的人可派去侦察。那他能看到什么呢？不过我印象很深的却是，你有点儿过于没用了。我要是你的话，我就会再找她试试看。”
en: “Ye see, David, I wasnae here,” said he.“I’m like a field officer that has naebody but blind men for scouts and éclaireurs; and what would he ken?But it sticks in my mind that ye’ll have made some kind of bauchle; and if I was you I would have a try at her again.”

zh: “你会这样做吗，艾伦伙计？”我说。
en: “Would ye so, man Alan?” said I.

zh: “我当然会。”他说。
en: “I would e’en’t,” says he.

zh: 第三封信到我手里的时候，我们正在进行此类深谈，而你们以后将会看到这封信来得正是时候。詹姆斯声称有些担心他女儿的健康，我却认为他女儿再健康不过了。他在信里说尽了我的好话，最后提议说我应该去敦刻尔克看望他们。
en: The third letter came to my hand while we were deep in some such talk: and it will be seen how pat it fell to the occasion.James professed to be in some concern upon his daughter’s health, which I believe was never better; abounded in kind expressions to myself; and finally proposed that I should visit them at Dunkirk.

zh: “现在你正享受着和我的老伙伴斯图尔特先生相伴的乐趣吧。”他写道，“为何不陪他一起回法国一趟呢？我有一些很特别的消息要说给斯图尔特先生听。无论如何，能和一位老战友、一位同样有勇气的人见面，我会很高兴的。至于你，我亲爱的先生，我和我女儿会为能接待我们的恩人而感到骄傲，我们把你视为儿子和兄弟。事实证明那位法国贵族是一个最为卑劣贪婪之徒，所以我必须得离开那家养马场了。因此，你会发现我们有点儿落魄地寄居在在沙丘上一个名叫巴赞的男子开的客栈里。但是情况变得更明朗了，我毫不怀疑我们会一起度过一些非常愉快的日子，到时我和斯图尔特先生可以回忆我们的军旅生活，而我女儿和你可以按照更适合你们这个年龄的方式自娱自乐。至少我请求斯图尔特先生务必来访，我找他有事，所以将敞开大门欢迎他来。”
en: “You will now be enjoying the society of my old comrade Mr. Stewart,” he wrote.“Why not accompany him so far in his return to France?I have something very particular for Mr. Stewart’s ear; and, at any rate, I would be pleased to meet in with an old fellow-soldier and one so mettle as himself.As for you, my dear sir, my daughter and I would be proud to receive our benefactor, whom we regard as a brother and a son.The French nobleman has proved a person of the most filthy avarice of character, and I have been necessitate to leave the haras.You will find us in consequence a little poorly lodged in the auberge of a man Bazin on the dunes; but the situation is caller, and I make no doubt but we might spend some very pleasant days, when Mr. Stewart and I could recall our services, and you and my daughter divert yourselves in a manner more befitting your age.I beg at least that Mr. Stewart would come here; my business with him opens a very wide door.”

zh: “这个人想找我做什么？”读到这里时，艾伦叫道，“他想找你要的已经够清楚了——就是钱。但是他想找艾伦·布雷克要什么呢？”
en: “What does the man want with me?” cried Alan, when he had read.“What he wants with you in clear enough—it’s siller.But what can he want with Alan Breck?”

zh: “哦，那只是个借口，”我说，“他还是在撮合这桩婚姻，我内心也希望我们能够修成正果。而他邀请你是因为他以为没有你我就不太可能去。”
en: “O, it’ll be just an excuse,” said I.“He is still after this marriage, which I wish from my heart that we could bring about.And he asks you because he thinks I would be less likely to come wanting you.”

zh: “好吧，但愿我明白了。”艾伦说，“我和他从来都不对路，我们过去常像一对风笛手那样互相咧嘴一笑而已。‘吹点儿什么让我听听！’他这么说。我想这件事背后另有文章，以后我们会弄清楚的。哎呀，我在想，去看看他到底想干什么也挺好玩的！而且到时候还可以见见你的那位姑娘。你觉得怎么样，戴维？你愿和艾伦一起骑马去吗？”
en: “Well, I wish that I kent,” says Alan.“Him and me were never onyways pack; we used to girn at ither like a pair of pipers.‘Something for my ear,’ quo’ he!I’ll maybe have something for his hinder-end, before we’re through with it.Dod, I’m thinking it would be a kind of divertisement to gang and see what he’ll be after!Forby that I could see your lassie then.What say ye, Davie?Will ye ride with Alan?”

zh: 你们可以肯定我是不会退缩的，而艾伦的假期即将休完，所以我们马上就一起踏上了冒险之旅。
en: You may be sure I was not backward, and Alan’s furlough running towards an end, we set forth presently upon this joint adventure.

zh: 那是一月份的一天傍晚，我们终于骑马到了敦刻尔克城。我们在柱子上拴好马，找了一个向导带我们去巴赞的旅馆，那个旅馆位于城墙外。夜已经很深，所以我们是最后出城的人，我们过桥的时候就听到城门在背后关上了。身前是一片灯火辉煌的市郊，我们花了好一会儿工夫才穿过去，随后我们拐进了一条黑暗的小巷，不久就发现我们在黑夜中正涉沙而行，还能够听到海浪的拍岸声。我们就这样走了一段时间，几乎都是靠听声音来跟着向导走的。于是我开始想他也许给我们带错路了，这时我们来到了一个小斜坡的顶部，然后看到黑暗中有一扇窗户里透出一丝微弱的灯光。
en: It was near dark of a January day when we rode at last into the town of Dunkirk.We left our horses at the post, and found a guide to Bazin’s Inn, which lay beyond the walls.Night was quite fallen, so that we were the last to leave that fortress, and heard the doors of it close behind us as we passed the bridge.On the other side there lay a lighted suburb, which we thridded for a while, then turned into a dark lane, and presently found ourselves wading in the night among deep sand where we could hear a bullering of the sea.We travelled in this fashion for some while, following our conductor mostly by the sound of his voice; and I had begun to think he was perhaps misleading us, when we came to the top of a small brae, and there appeared out of the darkness a dim light in a window.

zh: “瞧，那就是巴赞客栈。”向导说。
en: “Voilà l’auberge à Bazin,” says the guide.

zh: 艾伦咂了咂嘴。“也太偏僻了一点儿。”他说，听他的语气我觉得他不大满意。
en: Alan smacked his lips.“An unco lonely bit,” said he, and I thought by his tone he was not wholly pleased.

zh: 不一会儿，我们已站在那栋房子的底层了，整个底层都在一套公寓里，边上有楼梯通往客房，靠墙摆着长椅子和桌子，有一边尽头是炉火，另一边尽头是一排排的酒瓶和地窖门。那位巴赞是一个样貌丑陋的大个子男人，他告诉我们那位苏格兰绅士出门了，他不知道去了哪里，不过那位年轻的女士在上面，他会上去叫她下来见我们。
en: A little after, and we stood in the lower storey of that house, which was all in the one apartment, with a stairs leading to the chambers at the side, benches and tables by the wall, the cooking fire at the one end of it, and shelves of bottles and the cellar-trap at the other.Here Bazin, who was an ill-looking, big man, told us the Scottish gentleman was gone abroad he knew not where, but the young lady was above, and he would call her down to us.

zh: 我从胸前掏出那块缺了角的方巾，然后在我的颈部打了个结。我可以听见自己的心跳，而艾伦则带着有点儿好笑的表情拍着我的肩膀，我差点儿忍不住要训他一顿了。但是并没有等多长时间。我听到她的脚步声从头顶走过，接着看见她出现在楼梯上。她非常平静地走了下来，脸色苍白地跟我打了招呼，显得有点儿拘谨，或者有点儿不安，她那种态度让我特别沮丧。
en: I took from my breast that kerchief wanting the corner, and knotted it about my throat.I could hear my heart go; and Alan patting me on the shoulder with some of his laughable expressions, I could scarce refrain from a sharp word.But the time was not long to wait.I heard her step pass overhead, and saw her on the stair.This she descended very quietly, and greeted me with a pale face and a certain seeming of earnestness, or uneasiness, in her manner that extremely dashed me.

zh: “我父亲，詹姆斯·莫尔很快就会回来。他看见你会很高兴的。”她说。然后突然她满脸通红，两眼发亮，话就停在了嘴边。我确信她看见那块方巾了。她只是慌乱了一小会儿，但是我认为她是带着新的兴奋心情转身去欢迎艾伦的。“你就是他的朋友艾伦·布雷克？”她叫道，“我无数遍听他谈起过你。我对你的勇敢和善良仰慕已久了。”
en: “My father, James More, will be here soon.He will be very pleased to see you,” she said.And then of a sudden her face flamed, her eyes lightened, the speech stopped upon her lips; and I made sure she had observed the kerchief.It was only for a breath that she was discomposed; but methought it was with a new animation that she turned to welcome Alan.“And you will be his friend, Alan Breck?” she cried.“Many is the dozen times I will have heard him tell of you; and I love you already for all your bravery and goodness.”

zh: “好，好，”艾伦说，一边握着她的手在打量着她，“这么说，我终于见到这位年轻的女士了！戴维，你的描述能力也太差劲了。”
en: “Well, well,” says Alan, holding her hand in his and viewing her, “and so this is the young lady at the last of it!David, ye’re an awful poor hand of a description.”

zh: 我不知道我曾否听他说话如此扣人心扉，他的声音听起来就像在唱歌。
en: I do not know that ever I heard him speak so straight to people’s hearts; the sound of his voice was like song.

zh: “什么！他曾经向你描述过我吗？”她叫道。
en: “What? will he have been describing me?” she cried.

zh: “自从我出法国以后听说过一点儿！”他说，“此外还听说过一点儿，那是在苏格兰的一个夜晚，在银磨坊边的小树林里。但是你要高兴一点儿，亲爱的！你比他说的要漂亮多了。现在有一件事可以肯定，我和你一定会成为一对好朋友的。我现在有一点儿像是戴维的随从，我就像一个小孩紧跟在他身后。他关心什么，我就会关心什么——全靠神圣的主啊！他们都会关心我的! 所以现在你知道该怎样和艾伦·布雷克相处了，而且你会发现在这种交往中你几乎不会有损失。他虽然不是很俊美，但他对他所爱的人却很忠实。”
en: “Little else of it since I ever came out of France!” says he, “forby a bit of a speciment one night in Scotland in a shaw of wood by Silvermills.But cheer up, my dear!ye’re bonnier than what he said.And now there’s one thing sure; you and me are to be a pair of friends.I’m a kind of a henchman to Davie here; I’m like a tyke at his heels; and whatever he cares for, I’ve got to care for too—and by the holy airn! they will care for me! So now you can see what way you stand with Alan Breck, and ye’ll find ye’ll hardly lose on the transaction.He’s no very bonnie, my dear, but he’s leal to them he loves.”

zh: “我从内心感谢你的这番好话。”她说，“我尊敬勇敢诚实的人，我都找不到任何话来答谢你。”
en: “I thank you from my heart for your good words,” said she.“I have that honour for a brave, honest man that I cannot find any to be answering with.”

zh: 旅行者比较自由，因此我们有时间等待詹姆斯·莫尔，于是我们三个人坐下来一起吃饭。艾伦让卡特里奥娜坐在他身旁，尽心服侍着她：他先从他的玻璃杯中倒酒给她喝，他一直友善殷勤地围着她转，却从不会让我有任何嫉妒的机会，他自顾自不停地说了很多话，说话的口气那么快乐，让我和她都忘记了尴尬。要是有人看见我们当时的情形，肯定会认为艾伦是老朋友而我是陌生人。的确，我经常喜欢并羡慕着这个家伙，但我从来没有像那天晚上那么喜欢和羡慕他。我不由对自己说（有时我颇有忘记的危险）他不仅有很多生活经验，除此之外他还以自己的方式表现出很强的天赋能力。至于卡特里奥娜，她好像完全忘乎所以了，她的笑声像响亮的铃声，她的脸如五月的清晨一样清丽。而我自己，虽然也很高兴，却也有一点点忧愁，觉得和我的朋友一比较，自己既木讷又愚笨，所以很不适合进入年轻女孩的生活，也许反而会减少她的快乐。
en: Using travellers’ freedom, we spared to wait for James More, and sat down to meat, we threesome.Alan had Catriona sit by him and wait upon his wants: he made her drink first out of his glass, he surrounded her with continual kind gallantries, and yet never gave me the most small occasion to be jealous; and he kept the talk so much in his own hand, and that in so merry a note, that neither she nor I remembered to be embarrassed.If any had seen us there, it must have been supposed that Alan was the old friend and I the stranger.Indeed, I had often cause to love and to admire the man, but I never loved or admired him better than that night; and I could not help remarking to myself (what I was sometimes rather in danger of forgetting) that he had not only much experience of life, but in his own way a great deal of natural ability besides.As for Catriona, she seemed quite carried away; her laugh was like a peal of bells, her face gay as a May morning; and I own, although I was well pleased, yet I was a little sad also, and thought myself a dull, stockish character in comparison of my friend, and very unfit to come into a young maid’s life, and perhaps ding down her gaiety.

zh: 不过如果说那是我所处的位置的话，至少我发现自己也并不孤独，因为詹姆斯·莫尔突然回来了，那个女孩就变成了一块石头。随后的整个晚上，我的眼睛不停地在注视着她，直到她找了个借口回去睡觉了。我可以证明她后来再也没有笑过，也很少说话，大多数时间都只是看着她眼前的桌面。所以我真的非常惊讶，她居然从那么专注热诚（就像刚才那样）变得满心厌恶和憎恨。
en: But if that was like to be my part, I found that at least I was not alone in it; for, James More returning suddenly, the girl was changed into a piece of stone.Through the rest of that evening, until she made an excuse and slipped to bed, I kept an eye upon her without cease; and I can bear testimony that she never smiled, scarce spoke, and looked mostly on the board in front of her.So that I really marvelled to see so much devotion (as it used to be) changed into the very sickness of hate.

zh: 关于詹姆斯·莫尔，我毋庸赘言，你们已经知道这个人，对他的本性也已经了解，而且我也厌倦了去写他的那些谎言。他那天喝得太多，没有跟我们说几句任何有用途的话。至于他要和艾伦说的事情，就只有留待次日再和他私下交流了。
en: Of James More it is unnecessary to say much; you know the man already, what there was to know of him; and I am weary of writing out his lies.Enough that he drank a great deal, and told us very little that was to any possible purpose.As for the business with Alan, that was to be reserved for the morrow and his private hearing.

zh: 要推诿是很容易的，因为我和艾伦骑了四天的马，都非常疲倦了，所以卡特里奥娜走后我们没有坐多久。
en: It was the more easy to be put off, because Alan and I were pretty weary with four day’s ride, and sat not very late after Catriona.

zh: 很快我们就单独进了一个房间，那里面只有一张单人床让我们临时凑合着睡。艾伦带着奇怪的微笑看着我。
en: We were soon alone in a chamber where we were to make-shift with a single bed.Alan looked on me with a queer smile.

zh: “你这个大傻瓜！”他说。
en: “Ye muckle ass!” said he.

zh: “你那么说是什么意思？”我叫道。
en: “What do ye mean by that?” I cried.

zh: “什么意思？我是什么意思！真是奇怪，戴维伙计。”他说，“你真是蠢到家了。”
en: “Mean?What do I mean!It’s extraordinar, David man,” say he, “that you should be so mortal stupit.”

zh: 我再次求他说出来。
en: Again I begged him to speak out.

zh: “那好，是这样的，”他说，“我告诉过你有两种女人——她们会为了你而卖掉自己的衣裙，但还有另外一种人的。你就为自己好好努力一番吧，我的俊小伙！不过你心里到底有什么打算呢？”
en: “Well, it’s this of it,” said he.“I told ye there were the two kinds of women—them that would sell their shifts for ye, and the others.Just you try for yoursel, my bonny man!But what’s that neepkin at your craig?”

zh: 我告诉了他。
en: I told him.

zh: “我觉得问题就出在这里。”他说。
en: “I thocht it was something thereabout” said he.

zh: 尽管我缠着他磨了好长时间，但他不肯再多说一个字了。
en: Nor would he say another word though I besieged him long with importunities.

zh: 第三十章 来自船上的信
en: CHAPTER XXX—THE LETTER FROM THE SHIP

zh: 白天我们发现，小客栈立在那里，显得尤其孤零零的。那个客栈紧紧贴着大海，而你根本就看不见，因为客栈四周都围绕着粗糙的沙丘。实际上，那里只有一样可以算是景致之类的东西，就是矗立在斜坡上方的一个风车的两片风叶，就像驴的两只耳朵，但是驴身却完全隐匿起来了。奇怪的是（起风了之后，因为起初风平浪静）居然看见风叶旋转了起来，随后隐身在小沙丘后面的这类巨大的风叶都旋转起来了。几乎没有大路从那里经过，但是有不少小路弯弯曲曲地从四面八方通向巴赞先生客栈的门。实际上，巴赞先生从事很多种行当，但没有一种是正当的，而他的客栈算是他生计中最好的了。走私者经常光顾这家客栈，打算渡海的政治间谍和已遭褫夺的人也来这里等待他们的行程。而我觉得很可能背后还有更严重的情况，因为在那个房子里可能有一家人被灭门，只是无人知晓罢了。
en: Daylight showed us how solitary the inn stood.It was plainly hard upon the sea, yet out of all view of it, and beset on every side with scabbit hills of sand.There was, indeed, only one thing in the nature of a prospect, where there stood out over a brae the two sails of a windmill, like an ass’s ears, but with the ass quite hidden.It was strange (after the wind rose, for at first it was dead calm) to see the turning and following of each other of these great sails behind the hillock.Scarce any road came by there; but a number of footways travelled among the bents in all directions up to Mr. Bazin’s door.The truth is, he was a man of many trades, not any one of them honest, and the position of his inn was the best of his livelihood.Smugglers frequented it; political agents and forfeited persons bound across the water came there to await their passages; and I daresay there was worse behind, for a whole family might have been butchered in that house and nobody the wiser.

zh: 我睡得很少，而且极不安稳。离天亮还早，我就悄悄地从我的伙伴身边溜下床，在炉火边取暖或者在门前来回踱着步。破晓时阴霾浓重，但是过了一会儿，突然从西边刮来一阵风，把云猛地吹散，让阳光透射下来，而且驱使风车旋转了起来。阳光中带着些许春天的气息，或者说在我的心里是这样的。巨大的风叶一个接一个地从山丘后出现，这让我觉得饶有趣味。有时我可以听到机械装置嘎吱一响。一直到那天的八点半，我都觉得这片沉闷、荒凉的地方就像是天堂一般。
en: I slept little and ill.Long ere it was day, I had slipped from beside my bedfellow, and was warming myself at the fire or walking to and fro before the door.Dawn broke mighty sullen; but a little after, sprang up a wind out of the west, which burst the clouds, let through the sun, and set the mill to the turning.There was something of spring in the sunshine, or else it was in my heart; and the appearing of the great sails one after another from behind the hill, diverted me extremely.At times I could hear a creak of the machinery; and by half-past eight of the day, and I thought this dreary, desert place was like a paradise.

zh: 随着日子一天天过去，却没有一个人来这里，我开始对所有这一切感到一种我无法解释的不安。我觉得不对劲，似乎会有麻烦。风车的风叶在小山后升了又降，就像是有人在窥视。这附近和这个房子的确都非常奇怪，居然把一位少女带到这里来居住，这简直离奇得让人无法想象。
en: For all which, as the day drew on and nobody came near, I began to be aware of an uneasiness that I could scarce explain.It seemed there was trouble afoot; the sails of the windmill, as they came up and went down over the hill, were like persons spying; and outside of all fancy, it was surely a strange neighbourhood and house for a young lady to be brought to dwell in.

zh: 早餐时，我们去晚了，显然詹姆斯·莫尔处于某种危险或者是困扰之中。很明显艾伦也意识到这一点了，而且密切地观察他。这一边表现得口是心非，而另一边则保持着高度警惕，这让我如坐针毡。早餐刚一结束，詹姆斯似乎就开始道歉了。他在镇上有个私人约会（就是和那位他曾告诉过我的法国贵族），要到中午才回来，请我们谅解他。期间，他把他女儿远远地拉到房间的另一头，似乎很急切地说了些话，而她则半倾着身子在听。
en: At breakfast, which we took late, it was manifest that James More was in some danger or perplexity; manifest that Alan was alive to the same, and watched him close; and this appearance of duplicity upon the one side, and vigilance upon the other, held me on live coals.The meal was no sooner over than James seemed to come began to make apologies.He had an appointment of a private nature in the town (it was with the French nobleman, he told me), and we would please excuse him till about noon.Meanwhile he carried his daughter aside to the far end of the room, where he seemed to speak rather earnestly and she to listen with much inclination.

zh: “我对詹姆斯这个人越来越不喜欢了。”艾伦说，“詹姆斯这个人有些不对劲，虽然我不该为此感到奇怪，但是我艾伦·布雷克今天要留心他才是。戴维，我最好去见见你那位法国贵族。而且我想你也可以找到自己要做的事，就是去征求一下你那位姑娘的意见，为你们的恋情增添一些新意。你就明明白白地告诉她——跟她说你当初就是一个大傻瓜。然后，如果我是你，当然你也可以做得很自然，我就会向她编造谎言说我处于某种危险中，女人就喜欢那样。”
en: “I am caring less and less about this man James,” said Alan.“There’s something no right with the man James, and I shouldnae wonder but what Alan Breck would give an eye to him this day.I would like fine to see yon French nobleman, Davie; and I daresay you could find an employ to yoursel, and that would be to speir at the lassie for some news o’ your affair.Just tell it to her plainly—tell her ye’re a muckle ass at the off-set; and then, if I were you, and ye could do it naitural, I would just mint to her I was in some kind of a danger; a’ weemenfolk likes that.”

zh: “我做不出，艾伦，我不可能做得很自然。”我说道，嘲弄似地模仿着他。
en: “I cannae lee, Alan, I cannae do it naitural,” says I, mocking him.

zh: “那你就更蠢了！”他说，“那么你可以告诉她是我建议你这么做的，她听了一定会笑的。那也不失为很好的办法，对此我不会觉得奇怪。但是看看你们这一对！要不是因为我对这位少女很有把握，而她也非常喜欢和信任艾伦的话，那我会觉得这件事都有点儿像在哄骗你了。”
en: “The more fool you!” says he.“Then ye’ll can tell her that I recommended it; that’ll set her to the laughing; and I wouldnae wonder but what that was the next best.But see to the pair of them!If I didnae feel just sure of the lassie, and that she was awful pleased and chief with Alan, I would think there was some kind of hocus-pocus about you.”

zh: “那么，艾伦，她和你相处很开心吗？”我问。
en: “And is she so pleased with ye, then, Alan?” I asked.

zh: “她对我评价甚高，”他说，“而我不像你，我是那种分得清真假的人。 她是那么做的——她对艾伦评价甚高。的确如此！我自己对艾伦评价也很好。肖斯，如果你允许的话，我要从你那些事务中抽一会儿身，这样我可以看看詹姆斯在干什么。”
en: “She thinks a heap of me,” says he.“And I’m no like you: I’m one that can tell.That she does—she thinks a heap of Alan.And troth!I’m thinking a good deal of him mysel; and with your permission, Shaws, I’ll be getting a wee yont amang the bents, so that I can see what way James goes.”

zh: 他们相继离开，只剩下我独自一人在早餐桌边。詹姆斯去了敦刻尔克，艾伦尾随他而去，卡特里奥娜上楼回她自己的房间了。我很清楚她在尽量避免单独和我在一起。然而我为此却很不开心，满脑子想着在那些人回来之前要想办法让她跟我见一次面。总之，对我来说似乎最好是按照艾伦说的去做。如果我先到沙丘中看不见的地方，晴朗的早晨会吸引她前往，而一旦我在野外碰上她，那我可就称心如意了。
en: One after another went, till I was left alone beside the breakfast table; James to Dunkirk, Alan dogging him, Catriona up the stairs to her own chamber.I could very well understand how she should avoid to be alone with me; yet was none the better pleased with it for that, and bent my mind to entrap her to an interview before the men returned.Upon the whole, the best appeared to me to do like Alan.If I was out of view among the sandhills, the fine morning would decoy her forth; and once I had her in the open, I could please myself.

zh: 说做就做。我到沙丘下隐蔽处没呆多长时间，她就在客栈的门口出现了。她环顾四周，（看见没人）就沿着一条直通海边的小路出发了，而我则跟在她后面。我不急着让她知道我在那里。她走得离我越远，我肯定她就越难以听到我行走时衣服的摩擦声。地面上全都是沙子，要悄无声息地跟着她还是很容易的。小路越走越高，最后来到了山丘之顶。于是我第一次看到了客栈藏身的这一片旷野有多荒凉。那里一个人都看不到，也看不见任何人的房子，只有巴赞的客栈和那个风车。再稍远一点儿，大海呈现在眼前，两三艘船漂在海面上，美丽如画。其中有一艘船靠得特别近，那是一艘很大的船。当我认出其海马的标志时，我产生了新的怀疑并觉得很吃惊。为什么一艘英国船会这么靠近法国？为什么艾伦被带到了这附近，而这个地方远得根本没有任何救援的希望？詹姆斯·莫尔的女儿当天会走向海边，这是偶然的，还是设计好的？
en: No sooner said than done; nor was I long under the bield of a hillock before she appeared at the inn door, looked here and there, and (seeing nobody) set out by a path that led directly seaward, and by which I followed her.I was in no haste to make my presence known; the further she went I made sure of the longer hearing to my suit; and the ground being all sandy it was easy to follow her unheard.The path rose and came at last to the head of a knowe.Thence I had a picture for the first time of what a desolate wilderness that inn stood hidden in; where was no man to be seen, nor any house of man, except just Bazin’s and the windmill.Only a little further on, the sea appeared and two or three ships upon it, pretty as a drawing.One of these was extremely close in to be so great a vessel; and I was aware of a shock of new suspicion, when I recognised the trim of the Seahorse.What should an English ship be doing so near in to France?Why was Alan brought into her neighbourhood, and that in a place so far from any hope of rescue? and was it by accident, or by design, that the daughter of James More should walk that day to the seaside?

zh: 在沙丘前我赶紧走上前去跟在她的后面，而且走上了海滩。这段路既长又荒凉，我中途看到有一只单人小战船给吊上去了，还有一个军官在指挥，他在沙滩上踱着步，像是在等候。我在大片的乱草丛中坐下，乱草把我掩蔽了起来。我寻思着下一步该做什么。卡特里奥娜径直走向那艘小船，那个军官礼貌地接待了她，他们一起说了几句话，我看见一封信转了手，接着卡特里奥娜就开始往回走。与此同时，那艘船驶离，向“海马”号开去，好像它就是为这一件事来欧洲大陆的。但是我注意到那位军官留了下来，他随即消失在荒野中。
en: Presently I came forth behind her in the front of the sandhills and above the beach.It was here long and solitary; with a man-o’-war’s boat drawn up about the middle of the prospect, and an officer in charge and pacing the sands like one who waited.I sat down where the rough grass a good deal covered me, and looked for what should follow.Catriona went straight to the boat; the officer met her with civilities; they had ten words together; I saw a letter changing hands; and there was Catriona returning.At the same time, as if this were all her business on the Continent, the boat shoved off and was headed for the Seahorse.But I observed the officer to remain behind and disappear among the bents.

zh: 我不太喜欢这件事情，而且我对此考虑得越多就越不喜欢。那位军官是找艾伦呢，还是找卡特里奥娜呢？卡特里奥娜低着头走近了，她一直看着沙滩，形成了一幅如此温柔的画面，我真无法忍受去怀疑她的清白。接下来，她抬起脸认出了我。她似乎有点儿犹豫，然后再次走过来，不过走得更慢了，我想她的脸色已经变了。这么一想，我心中所有的一切——恐惧、怀疑、对朋友生命的关心——完全被淹没了。我站起身，满怀希望地站在那里等着她。
en: I liked the business little; and the more I considered of it, liked it less.Was it Alan the officer was seeking? or Catriona?She drew near with her head down, looking constantly on the sand, and made so tender a picture that I could not bear to doubt her innocence.The next, she raised her face and recognised me; seemed to hesitate, and then came on again, but more slowly, and I thought with a changed colour.And at that thought, all else that was upon my bosom—fears, suspicions, the care of my friend’s life—was clean swallowed up; and I rose to my feet and stood waiting her in a drunkenness of hope.

zh: 她走近时，我对她说了声“早上好”，她镇定自若地回应了我。
en: I gave her “good morning” as she came up, which she returned with a good deal of composure.

zh: “你会原谅我跟踪了你吗？”我说。
en: “Will you forgive my having followed you?” said I.

zh: “我知道你总是出于一片好意。”她回答说，随后突然有点儿发作道，“但是你为什么总是给那个人钱！绝对不可以。”
en: “I know you are always meaning kindly,” she replied; and then, with a little outburst, “but why will you be sending money to that man!It must not be.”

zh: “我从来都没有给过他，”我说，“而是给你的，这一点你很清楚。”
en: “I never sent it for him,” said I, “but for you, as you know well.”

zh: “但你没有权利给我们中的任何一个,”她说，“戴维，这是不对的。”
en: “And you have no right to be sending it to either one of us,” she said.“David, it is not right.”

zh: “这是不对，这完全错了。”我说，“我祈祷上帝会帮助这个愚笨的家伙（如果完全有可能的话）变得更好。卡特里奥娜，这种生活根本不适合你过。请原谅我这么说，但是那个人真不配当父亲来照顾你。”
en: “It is not, it is all wrong,” said I, “and I pray God he will help this dull fellow (if it be at all possible) to make it better.Catriona, this is no kind of life for you to lead; and I ask your pardon for the word, but yon man is no fit father to take care of you.”

zh: “不要说起他，甚至不要提！”她这么叫道。
en: “Do not be speaking of him, even!” was her cry.

zh: “我不需要再说起他。我现在想到的不是他，哦，相信我！ ”我说，“我只考虑一件事。我现在已经独自在莱登呆这么长的时间了。我就是在学习的时候，都还在想着这件事。接着艾伦来了，我参加了他们的士兵盛宴，但是那个时候我还是在想着同一件事。有你在我身旁时，我想的还是和以前一样。卡特里奥娜，你看看我颈上的这条方巾！你曾经剪掉了一个角，然后把给它扔了。方巾上的颜色现在都是你的颜色，我把它们系在了心上。亲爱的，我不能没有你。哦，试着容忍我吧！”
en: “And I need speak of him no more; it is not of him that I am thinking, O, be sure of that!” says I.“I think of the one thing.I have been alone now this long time in Leyden; and when I was by way of at my studies, still I was thinking of that.Next Alan came, and I went among soldier-men to their big dinners; and still I had the same thought.And it was the same before, when I had her there beside me.Catriona, do you see this napkin at my throat!You cut a corner from it once and then cast it from you.They’re your colours now; I wear them in my heart.My dear, I cannot be wanting you.O, try to put up with me!”

zh: 我迈步走到她前面，阻拦她继续前行。
en: I stepped before her so as to intercept her walking on.

zh: “尽量宽容我，”我在说着，“尽量宽容我一点儿吧。”
en: “Try to put up with me,” I was saying, “try and bear me with a little.”

zh: 她还是一言不发，我内心涌上一阵恐惧，就像对死亡的恐惧一般。
en: Still she had never the word, and a fear began to rise in me like a fear of death.

zh: “卡特里奥娜，”我叫道，死死盯着她，“我又做错了吗？我完全失去机会了吗？”
en: “Catriona,” I cried, gazing on her hard, “is it a mistake again?Am I quite lost?”

zh: 她抬脸对着我，屏住了呼吸。
en: She raised her face to me, breathless.

zh: “你需要我，戴维，这是真的？”她说，我几乎听不见她说的话。
en: “Do you want me, Davie, truly?” said she, and I scarce could hear her say it.

zh: “我真的需要，”我说，“哦，你肯定知道——我真的需要。”
en: “I do that,” said I.“O, sure you know it—I do that.”

zh: “我再也没有什么可以付出或者收回的了。”她说，“如果你想让我送你一件礼物的话，我从第一天起就已经完全是你的了！”她说。
en: “I have nothing left to give or to keep back,” said she.“I was all yours from the first day, if you would have had a gift of me!” she said,

zh: 当时我们在山坡顶上。那个地方风很大而且很显眼，即使从那艘英国船上都能看见我们。但我还是在她面前的沙滩上跪了下来，抱着她的双膝，爆发出一阵暴风雨般的哭声，我觉得那哭声都让自己崩溃了。我情绪激动、心乱如麻，我脑海中的所有思绪已经被完全打乱。我不知道自己身在何处。我已经忘记了自己为什么快乐，我只知道她弯下腰，我感觉到她拥我入怀，并用脸爱抚着我，还听见她急促地说了一些话。
en: This was on the summit of a brae; the place was windy and conspicuous, we were to be seen there even from the English ship; but I kneeled down before her in the sand, and embraced her knees, and burst into that storm of weeping that I thought it must have broken me.All thought was wholly beaten from my mind by the vehemency of my discomposure.I knew not where I was.I had forgot why I was happy; only I knew she stooped, and I felt her cherish me to her face and bosom, and heard her words out of a whirl.

zh: “戴维，”她说，“哦，戴维，你是这样想我的啊！你就是这样关心可怜的我！哦，戴维，戴维！”
en: “Davie,” she was saying, “O, Davie, is this what you think of me!Is it so that you were caring for poor me!O, Davie, Davie!”

zh: 说着，她也哭泣起来，我们的泪水在满心欢喜中融汇在一起。
en: With that she wept also, and our tears were commingled in a perfect gladness.

zh: 可能直到那天的十点我才清醒地意识到何等的幸运已经降临到我的身上。和她相对而坐，握着她的手，凝视着她的面庞，我像孩子一样欢快大笑起来，呼唤着她那些好笑而可亲的名字。我从来没有见过像敦刻尔克的旷野这么美丽的地方。山丘上那些风车的风叶轻快地转动着，犹如奏响了一首乐曲。
en: It might have been ten in the day before I came to a clear sense of what a mercy had befallen me; and sitting over against her, with her hands in mine, gazed in her face, and laughed out loud for pleasure like a child, and called her foolish and kind names.I have never seen the place that looked so pretty as those bents by Dunkirk; and the windmill sails, as they bobbed over the knowe, were like a tune of music.

zh: 要不是我偶然提起她父亲，把我们带回了现实，我都不知道这种忘记一切而沉浸于自己的世界的状态会持续多久。
en: I know not how much longer we might have continued to forget all else besides ourselves, had I not chanced upon a reference to her father, which brought us to reality.

zh: “我的小朋友，”我一遍又一遍地呼唤着她，很高兴用这样的声音唤回往昔的回忆，我的视线扫过她的脸庞，继而看向稍远的地方——“我的小朋友，现在你完全是我的。你永远是我的，我的小朋友，那个人再也不算什么了。”
en: “My little friend,” I was calling her again and again, rejoicing to summon up the past by the sound of it, and to gaze across on her, and to be a little distant—“My little friend, now you are mine altogether; mine for good, my little friend and that man’s no longer at all.”

zh: 她的脸倏地发白了，她从我手中抽回了自己的手。
en: There came a sudden whiteness in her face, she plucked her hands from mine.

zh: “戴维，带我离开他！”她叫道，“有些事情不对劲，他不诚实。一定会有什么事情不对劲，我现在心里感到非常恐惧。不管怎么说，他想要那艘英国皇家军舰干什么呢？这句话又是什么意思？”她拿出了那封信。“我的心里很不安，这件事肯定会对艾伦不利。打开信，戴维——打开信看看。”
en: “Davie, take me away from him!” she cried.“There’s something wrong; he’s not true.There will be something wrong; I have a dreadful terror here at my heart.What will he be wanting at all events with that King’s ship?What will this word be saying?”And she held the letter forth.“My mind misgives me, it will be some ill to Alan.Open it, Davie—open it and see.”

zh: 我拿过信，看着它，然后摇了摇头。
en: I took it, and looked at it, and shook my head.

zh: “不，”我说，“这违背我的原则，我不能打开别人的信。”
en: “No,” said I, “it goes against me, I cannot open a man’s letter.”

zh: “不去救你的朋友了？”她叫道。
en: “Not to save your friend?” she cried.

zh: “我说不准，”我说，“我不想这么做。要是我真的有把握就好了！”
en: “I cannae tell,” said I.“I think not.If I was only sure!”

zh: “你只需要拆开封签！”她说。
en: “And you have but to break the seal!” said she.

zh: “我知道，”我说，“但是这件事违背我的原则。”
en: “I know it,” said I, “but the thing goes against me.”

zh: “就在这里吧，”她说，“我自己来打开这封信。”
en: “Give it here,” said she, “and I will open it myself.”

zh: “你也不能。”我说， “你更不能。这件事牵涉到你父亲，还有他的名誉，亲爱的，虽然我们两个人都对此心怀疑虑。毫无疑问，这个地方显得有点儿危险，那艘英国军舰在这里，你父亲还从那里接到了一封信，还有那个军官也还在岸上。他不会是独自一人的，肯定还有很多人和他一起。我想这一刻就有人在监视着我们。唉，无疑，这封信应该要打开才行。但是不管怎么说，都不该由你或者我来打开。”
en: “Nor you neither,” said I.“You least of all.It concerns your father, and his honour, dear, which we are both misdoubting.No question but the place is dangerous-like, and the English ship being here, and your father having word from it, and yon officer that stayed ashore.He would not be alone either; there must be more along with him; I daresay we are spied upon this minute.Ay, no doubt, the letter should be opened; but somehow, not by you nor me.”

zh: 就这样我想了又想，我的头脑中满是一种危险感和对隐藏敌人的担心，这时我看见艾伦了，他在跟踪詹姆斯之后又回来了，现在正一个人在沙丘之间走着。他穿着他的军大衣，当然，很是威风凛凛。但是当我想到那件外衣对他没有好处时，我不由得打了个寒颤。要是他一旦被抓而且被扔到小艇上，再被带上“海马”号战舰，他就会是一个逃亡者，一个叛逆者，他现在就是一个已经被判刑的杀人犯。
en: I was about thus far with it, and my spirit very much overcome with a sense of danger and hidden enemies, when I spied Alan, come back again from following James and walking by himself among the sand-hills.He was in his soldier’s coat, of course, and mighty fine; but I could not avoid to shudder when I thought how little that jacket would avail him, if he were once caught and flung in a skiff, and carried on board of the Seahorse, a deserter, a rebel, and now a condemned murderer.

zh: “那里，”我说，“那里有个人才最有权利去打开这封信，或者不打开，只要他认为合适。”
en: “There,” said I, “there is the man that has the best right to open it: or not, as he thinks fit.”

zh: 说完，我就大声喊他的名字，而且我们俩都站了起来好让他看到。
en: With which I called upon his name, and we both stood up to be a mark for him.

zh: “如果就是如此——如果还更加耻辱——你能够忍受吗？”她问道，目光灼灼地看着我。
en: “If it is so—if it be more disgrace—will you can bear it?” she asked, looking upon me with a burning eye.

zh: “我还只见过你一次的时候，你曾问过我一个同样的问题。”我说，“你认为我是怎么回答的呢？如果我正如我想的那样喜欢你——哦，但是我喜欢你更甚！我会在他的绞架下和你结婚。”
en: “I was asked something of the same question when I had seen you but the once,” said I.“What do you think I answered?That if I liked you as I thought I did—and O, but I like you better!—I would marry you at his gallows’ foot.”

zh: 血涌上她的脸，她紧紧扑过来靠在我身上，握住我的手，于是我们就这样等待着艾伦。
en: The blood rose in her face; she came close up and pressed upon me, holding my hand: and it was so that we awaited Alan.

zh: 他带着一种古怪的微笑走了过来。“戴维，我怎么告诉你来着？”他说。
en: He came with one of his queer smiles.“What was I telling ye, David?” says he.

zh: “万事皆有定时，艾伦。”我说，“但是时间很紧。你怎么这么快？在我们的这位朋友面前，你可以坦率地说出来。”
en: “There is a time for all things, Alan,” said I, “and this time is serious.How have you sped?You can speak out plain before this friend of ours.”

zh: “我做了一件蠢事。”他说。
en: “I have been upon a fool’s errand,” said he.

zh: “那么，我怀疑我们不比你做得好。”我说，“总之，这里有件大事需要你来定夺。你看见这个了吗？”我指着那艘军舰继续说道，“那就是‘海马’号，舰长是帕利泽。”
en: “I doubt we have done better than you, then,” said I; “and, at least, here is a great deal of matter that you must judge of.Do you see that?”I went on, pointing to the ship.“That is the Seahorse, Captain Palliser.”

zh: “我应该也看见过这艘军舰。”艾伦说，“这艘战舰停泊在福斯海湾时，我曾经颇为之紧张犯愁。但是帕利泽靠得这么近是怎么回事？”
en: “I should ken her, too,” says Alan.“I had fyke enough with her when she was stationed in the Forth.But what ails the man to come so close?”

zh: “我先告诉你他为什么来这里吧。”我说，“是为了给詹姆斯·莫尔送这封信。为什么他送完信后就留在这里了，到底可能和什么事情有关，为什么那个军官要藏匿在这荒野里，是否有可能他只是独自一人——我宁愿你多为自己考虑考虑。”
en: “I will tell you why he came there first,” said I.“It was to bring this letter to James More.Why he stops here now that it’s delivered, what it’s likely to be about, why there’s an officer hiding in the bents, and whether or not it’s probable that he’s alone—I would rather you considered for yourself.”

zh: “一封给詹姆斯·莫尔的信？”他说。
en: “A letter to James More?” said he.

zh: “正是。”我说。
en: “The same,” said I.

zh: “好，我还可以告诉你更多的情况。”艾伦说，“昨天晚上在你熟睡之后，我听到那个人跟一个说法语的人在密谈，然后小客栈的门打开跟着又关上了。”
en: “Well, and I can tell ye more than that,” said Alan.“For the last night, when you were fast asleep, I heard the man colloguing with some one in the French, and then the door of that inn to be opened and shut.”

zh: “艾伦，”我叫道，“你整晚上都在睡觉，我在这里可以证明的。”
en: “Alan!” cried I, “you slept all night, and I am here to prove it.”

zh: “哎呀，但是我永远不相信艾伦，不论他是睡着的还是醒着的！”他说，“但是看样子情况不妙。让我们来看看那封信吧。”
en: “Ay, but I would never trust Alan whether he was asleep or waking!” says he.“But the business looks bad.Let’s see the letter.”

zh: 我把信给了他。
en: I gave it him.

zh: “卡特里奥娜，”他说，“你得原谅我，亲爱的。我的身家性命可全都押在是否传递这封信上了，我不得不拆开这个封签。”
en: “Catriona,” said he, “you have to excuse me, my dear; but there’s nothing less than my fine bones upon the cast of it, and I’ll have to break this seal.”

zh: “这正是我希望的。”卡特里奥娜说。
en: “It is my wish,” said Catriona.

zh: 他打开信，粗粗浏览了一遍，然后猛然在空中挥了挥手。
en: He opened it, glanced it through, and flung his hand in the air.

zh: “这个可恶的卑鄙小人！”他说，然后把那张信纸塞进他的口袋，“走，我们一起去拿东西。这个地方会是我的葬身之地。”然后他开始向客栈走去。
en: “The stinking brock!” says he, and crammed the paper in his pocket.“Here, let’s get our things together.This place is fair death to me.”And he began to walk towards the inn.

zh: 还是卡特里奥娜先开口说话了。“他把你给出卖了？”她问。
en: It was Catriona that spoke the first.“He has sold you?” she asked.

zh: “是的，亲爱的，”艾伦说，“不过多亏了你和戴维，我还来得及赶紧逃离他。就让我靠我的马来赢吧。”他补充道。
en: “Sold me, my dear,” said Alan.“But thanks to you and Davie, I’ll can jink him yet.Just let me win upon my horse,” he added.

zh: “卡特里奥娜必须和我们一起走，”我说，“她可以不再和那个人来往。我和她就要结婚了。”听见此话，她把我的手紧握在她的身边。
en: “Catriona must come with us,” said I.“She can have no more traffic with that man.She and I are to be married.”At which she pressed my hand to her side.

zh: “你们是刚才决定要结婚的吗？”艾伦一边向后看一边说道，“这是你们两人做过的最好的一件事！我不得不说，我亲爱的，你们是真正美满的一对。”
en: “Are ye there with it?” says Alan, looking back.“The best day’s work that ever either of you did yet!And I’m bound to say, my dawtie, ye make a real, bonny couple.”

zh: 他沿那条路把我们带到紧靠风车的附近，在那里我注意到有一个穿海员裤子的人在风车后面偷窥着我们。只是，当然，我们看到了他的背影而已。
en: The way that he was following brought us close in by the windmill, where I was aware of a man in seaman’s trousers, who seemed to be spying from behind it.Only, of course, we took him in the rear.

zh: “艾伦，你看！”
en: “See, Alan!”

zh: “干嘛呢！”他说，“这是我的事情。”
en: “Wheesht!” said, he, “this is my affairs.”

zh: 毫无疑问，那个人因为风车的哗哗声不太听得到声音，所以在他注意到我们之前，我们就起身靠近了他。跟着他转过身来，我们发现他是个红褐色面庞的彪形大汉。
en: The man was, no doubt, a little deafened by the clattering of the mill, and we got up close before he noticed.Then he turned, and we saw he was a big fellow with a mahogany face.

zh: “我想，先生，”艾伦说，“你会说英语吧？”
en: “I think, sir,” says Alan, “that you speak the English?”

zh: “不，先生。”他说，其法语口音糟糕透了。
en: “Non, monsieur,” says he, with an incredible bad accent.

zh: “不，先生。”艾伦模仿他的腔调叫道，“他们在‘海马’号上面就是那样教你法语的吗？你这个傻瓜、大笨蛋，现在就让我这个苏格兰人用靴子狠踹你这个英格兰人的屁股一脚吧！”
en: “Non, monsieur,” cries Alan, mocking him.“Is that how they learn you French on the Seahorse?Ye muckle, gutsey hash, here’s a Scots boot to your English hurdies!”

zh: 那个人还来不及逃跑，艾伦就跳起来向他扑过去，他一脚把那个人踹了个狗啃泥。然后他站起身，面带凶狠的笑容，看着那个人爬起身来，撒腿跑进沙丘里了。
en: And bounding on him before he could escape, he dealt the man a kick that laid him on his nose.Then he stood, with a savage smile, and watched him scramble to his feet and scamper off into the sand-hills.

zh: “不过现在正是我甩开这些草包的时候了！”艾伦说，然后用最快的速度继续赶路，我们仍然跟着，来到了巴赞客栈的后门。
en: “But it’s high time I was clear of these empty bents!” said Alan; and continued his way at top speed, and we still following, to the backdoor of Bazin’s inn.

zh: 我们进门时碰巧面对面遇见了詹姆斯·莫尔，他正好从另一扇门进来。
en: It chanced that as we entered by the one door we came face to face with James More entering by the other.

zh: “这边！”我对卡特里奥娜说，“快！你上楼去收拾行李。这种场面不适合你。”
en: “Here!” said I to Catriona, “quick! upstairs with you and make your packets; this is no fit scene for you.”

zh: 这时詹姆斯和艾伦在这个长房间的正中碰面了。她紧挨着他们身旁走过，到楼梯处。我看到她往上走了几步又回头看了他们一眼，不过没有停步。事实上，他们是值得看一看的。他们相见时，艾伦摆出一副最谦恭友好的样子，但是却带有浓厚的挑衅意味，所以詹姆斯嗅出了这个人有危险，就像嗅出房子里有烟一样，于是他就做好准备应对突然攻击。
en: In the meanwhile James and Alan had met in the midst of the long room.She passed them close by to reach the stairs; and after she was some way up I saw her turn and glance at them again, though without pausing.Indeed, they were worth looking at.Alan wore as they met one of his best appearances of courtesy and friendliness, yet with something eminently warlike, so that James smelled danger off the man, as folk smell fire in a house, and stood prepared for accidents.

zh: 时间紧迫。艾伦的处境孤立无援，而他的敌人就在周围，这也许都可以把恺撒给吓倒了。艾伦没有因此而有任何改变，他还是带着那种惯有的嘲讽、开玩笑的架势开始了面谈。
en: Time pressed.Alan’s situation in that solitary place, and his enemies about him, might have daunted Caesar.It made no change in him; and it was in his old spirit of mockery and daffing that he began the interview.

zh: “对你来说又是美好的一天，德拉蒙德先生。”他说，“你那边在忙的是什么生意？”
en: “A braw good day to ye again, Mr. Drummond,” said he.“What’ll yon business of yours be just about?”

zh: “嗨，这是私事，说来话长。”詹姆斯说，“我想最好等到我们吃饭的时候再说吧。”
en: “Why, the thing being private, and rather of a long story,” says James, “I think it will keep very well till we have eaten.”

zh: “我可没那么肯定。”艾伦说，“我心里想着要么现在就谈，要么永远不谈。因为事实上我和鲍尔弗先生得到了一点儿信息，所以我们正在考虑出路。”
en: “I’m none so sure of that,” said Alan.“It sticks in my mind it’s either now or never; for the fact is me and Mr. Balfour here have gotten a line, and we’re thinking of the road.”

zh: 我看见詹姆斯的眼睛里有点儿惊讶，但他牢牢克制住了自己。
en: I saw a little surprise in James’s eye; but he held himself stoutly.

zh: “要让你重新心平气和，我只有一句话要说，”他说，“那就是我所做的生意的名目。”
en: “I have but the one word to say to cure you of that,” said he, “and that is the name of my business.”

zh: “那就说说看，”艾伦说，“哈！是谁在打戴维的主意？”
en: “Say it then,” says Alan.“Hout! wha minds for Davie?”

zh: “这件事情可以让我们两个人都成为富翁。”詹姆斯说。
en: “It is a matter that would make us both rich men,” said James.

zh: “你告诉我的就是那件事？”艾伦叫道。
en: “Do you tell me that?” cries Alan.

zh: “是啊，先生，”詹姆斯说，“事实明摆着，就是克卢尼的宝藏。”
en: “I do, sir,” said James.“The plain fact is that it is Cluny’s Treasure.”

zh: “不！”艾伦叫道，“你听说过那件事？”
en: “No!” cried Alan.“Have ye got word of it?”

zh: “我知道那个地方，斯图尔特先生，而且还可以带你去那里。”詹姆斯说。
en: “I ken the place, Mr. Stewart, and can take you there,” said James.

zh: “这真是再好不过了！”艾伦说，“好吧，我很高兴来到敦刻尔克。如此说来，这就是你的交易，是吗？我在想，对半分？”
en: “This crowns all!” says Alan.“Well, and I’m glad I came to Dunkirk.And so this was your business, was it?Halvers, I’m thinking?”

zh: “就是这桩交易，先生。”詹姆斯说。
en: “That is the business, sir,” said James.

zh: “好，好，”艾伦说道，然后用同样的孩子般好奇的语调说，“那么，这件事情和‘海马’号无关？”他问。
en: “Well, well,” said Alan; and then in the same tone of childlike interest, “it has naething to do with the Seahorse, then?” he asked,

zh: “和什么？”詹姆斯说。
en: “With what?” says James.

zh: “或者说，和刚才我在那边的风车后面对他屁股踹了一脚的那个家伙无关？”艾伦追问道，“嘿，伙计！是和你这个人渣有关啊！我口袋里还揣着帕利泽的信呢。詹姆斯·莫尔，你和这事有关联。你永远都别想再到正派人面前露脸了。”
en: “Or the lad that I have just kicked the bottom of behind yon windmill?” pursued Alan.“Hut, man! have done with your lees!I have Palliser’s letter here in my pouch.You’re by with it, James More.You can never show your face again with dacent folk.”

zh: 詹姆斯闻听此言大吃一惊。他僵立了一阵，一动不动而且脸色煞白，然后他一股怒火升了起来。
en: James was taken all aback with it.He stood a second, motionless and white, then swelled with the living anger.

zh: “你这个杂种，你是在对我说话吗？”他咆哮道。
en: “Do you talk to me, you bastard?” he roared out.

zh: “你这个下贱的畜生！”艾伦叫道，然后对着他一顿破口大骂，接下来刹那间他们就刀剑相接了。
en: “Ye glee’d swine!” cried Alan, and hit him a sounding buffet on the mouth, and the next wink of time their blades clashed together.

zh: 听到第一声钢剑撞击声，我本能地从冲突中往后一跃。接下来我看见，詹姆斯惊险地避开一剑，我都以为他被刺死了。我心底升起一种想法，这是那个女孩的父亲，在某种意义上几乎可以说就是我自己的父亲，于是我拔剑跑过去想把他们分开。
en: At the first sound of the bare steel I instinctively leaped back from the collision.The next I saw, James parried a thrust so nearly that I thought him killed; and it lowed up in my mind that this was the girl’s father, and in a manner almost my own, and I drew and ran in to sever them.

zh: “退后，戴维！你疯了！你这该死的家伙，退后！”艾伦吼叫道，“你自己会脑袋开花的！”
en: “Keep back, Davie!Are ye daft!Damn ye, keep back!” roared Alan.“Your blood be on your ain heid then!”

zh: 我把他们的剑锋压下了两次。我被撞在墙上，一阵晕眩，然后再次跳回到他们中间。他们没有注意我，两个人都狂怒地互相对刺着。我永远也想不到自己是怎么避免被刺到的，或者怎么避免刺伤这两个死敌中的任何一个的。整件事情对我就像是一段梦境，期间我听见楼梯上传来一声大叫，接着卡特里奥娜就闪现在她父亲的前面。就在此时，我的剑尖碰到了什么东西，变弯了。我抽回剑时，剑已经染红。我看见鲜血在女孩的方巾上涌出，我站在那里，心里很难受。
en: I beat their blades down twice.I was knocked reeling against the wall; I was back again betwixt them.They took no heed of me, thrusting at each other like two furies.I can never think how I avoided being stabbed myself or stabbing one of these two Rodomonts, and the whole business turned about me like a piece of a dream; in the midst of which I heard a great cry from the stair, and Catriona sprang before her father.In the same moment the point of my sword encountered some thing yielding.It came back to me reddened.I saw the blood flow on the girl’s kerchief, and stood sick.

zh: “你是要在我眼前杀了他吗？干脆连他的女儿我也一并杀了吧！”她叫道。
en: “Will you be killing him before my eyes, and me his daughter after all!” she cried.

zh: “亲爱的，是我在跟他斗。”艾伦说，然后走过去，坐在桌旁。他双臂交叉，那柄未入鞘的剑还握在手里。
en: “My dear, I have done with him,” said Alan, and went, and sat on a table, with his arms crossed and the sword naked in his hand.

zh: 她在詹姆斯面前站了一会儿，喘着气，睁着大大的眼睛，然后突然转身面对着他。
en: Awhile she stood before the man, panting, with big eyes, then swung suddenly about and faced him.

zh: “滚！”她这么说道，“带着你的耻辱滚出我的视线，让我和清白的人呆在一起。我是阿尔平的女儿！你这阿尔平子孙的耻辱，滚！”
en: “Begone!” was her word, “take your shame out of my sight; leave me with clean folk.I am a daughter of Alpin!Shame of the sons of Alpin, begone!”

zh: 这番话说得充满激情，让我从自己剑上沾染血迹的恐惧中清醒了过来。他们俩面对面站着，她的方巾上染有红色的血迹，而他的脸色则苍白得像块破布。我太了解他了——我知道这番话一定刺穿了他内心的敏感之处，但是他还在竭力地虚张声势。
en: It was said with so much passion as awoke me from the horror of my own bloodied sword.The two stood facing, she with the red stain on her kerchief, he white as a rag.I knew him well enough—I knew it must have pierced him in the quick place of his soul; but he betook himself to a bravado air.

zh: “怎么，”他一边把剑收入鞘中一边说着，但是他发光的眼睛仍然在盯着艾伦，“如果这场恶斗已经结束了，那我就去拿我的旅行箱——”
en: “Why,” says he, sheathing his sword, though still with a bright eye on Alan, “if this brawl is over I will but get my portmanteau—”

zh: “不许从这个地方拿旅行箱出去，除非我同意。”艾伦说。
en: “There goes no pockmantie out of this place except with me,” says Alan.

zh: “先生！”詹姆斯叫道。
en: “Sir!” cries James.

zh: “詹姆斯·莫尔，”艾伦说，“这位女士，你的女儿，将要嫁给我的朋友戴维，看在这个份上，我就让你全身而退。但是你要听我的忠告，不要再参与作恶，否则悔之晚矣。你恐怕想不到，我的好脾气可是有限度的。”
en: “James More,” says Alan, “this lady daughter of yours is to marry my friend Davie, upon the which account I let you pack with a hale carcase.But take you my advice of it and get that carcase out of harm’s way or ower late.Little as you suppose it, there are leemits to my temper.”

zh: “该死，先生，可是我的钱还在那里！”詹姆斯说。
en: “Be damned, sir, but my money’s there!” said James.

zh: “我也在为此烦心呢，”艾伦说，一副滑稽的表情，“但是现在，你要明白，那都是我的了。”随后他更加严肃地说：“我忠告你，詹姆斯·莫尔，你给我离开这栋房子。”
en: “I’m vexed about that, too,” says Alan, with his funny face, “but now, ye see, it’s mines.”And then with more gravity, “Be you advised, James More, you leave this house.”

zh: 詹姆斯似乎在心里盘算了一会儿，不过他应该是想到已经领教够艾伦的剑术了，因为他突然对着我们脱下帽子（一副倒霉透顶的脸色）向我们依次道别了。随后他就走了。
en: James seemed to cast about for a moment in his mind; but it’s to be thought he had enough of Alan’s swordsmanship, for he suddenly put off his hat to us and (with a face like one of the damned) bade us farewell in a series.With which he was gone.

zh: 与此同时，我就像被解开了魔咒。
en: At the same time a spell was lifted from me.

zh: “卡特里奥娜，”我叫道，“那是我——是我的剑。哦，你伤得重吗？”
en: “Catriona,” I cried, “it was me—it was my sword.O, are you much hurt?”

zh: “我知道，戴维，我虽然疼，却爱着你。你只不过是为了防卫那个坏人，我的父亲。看！”她说，并且让我看流血的剑伤，“要知道，现在你已经让我成为大丈夫了。我将像一位老兵那样身带剑伤了。”
en: “I know it, Davie, I am loving you for the pain of it; it was done defending that bad man, my father.See!” she said, and showed me a bleeding scratch, “see, you have made a man of me now.I will carry a wound like an old soldier.”

zh: 我为她受的伤很轻而感到欣慰，而对她勇敢天性的爱恋也激励了我。我拥住她，亲吻那处伤口。
en: Joy that she should be so little hurt, and the love of her brave nature, supported me.I embraced her, I kissed the wound.

zh: “我就不可以吻一吻吗？我可是从不失去任何机会的。”艾伦说，随即把我推到一边，并抓住卡特里奥娜的一边肩膀，“亲爱的，”他说，“你是阿平家族真正的女儿。众所周知，他是一个了不起的男子汉，不过他也会为你而感到非常自豪的。如果将来我要结婚的话，我为我的子女寻找的母亲也一定是你这样的人。我以国王的名义发誓，我说的是真心话。”
en: “And am I to be out of the kissing, me that never lost a chance?” says Alan; and putting me aside and taking Catriona by either shoulder, “My dear,” he said, “you’re a true daughter of Alpin.By all accounts, he was a very fine man, and he may weel be proud of you.If ever I was to get married, it’s the marrow of you I would be seeking for a mother to my sons.And I bear’s a king’s name and speak the truth.”

zh: 他带着非常热烈而又钦慕的口吻说了这番话，让她感到很甜蜜，而且通过她又把甜蜜传给了我。这似乎彻底擦净了詹姆斯·莫尔给我们带来的一切耻辱。接下来他又恢复了原样。
en: He said it with a serious heat of admiration that was honey to the girl, and through her, to me.It seemed to wipe us clean of all James More’s disgraces.And the next moment he was just himself again.

zh: “可是现在对不起，我亲爱的，”他说，“这次干得是很漂亮，但是艾伦·布雷克这个可怜的家伙，比起他一直在担心的，离绞架就更近一些了。天哪！我觉得从这个地方离开还真不错。”
en: “And now by your leave, my dawties,” said he, “this is a’ very bonny; but Alan Breck’ll be a wee thing nearer to the gallows than he’s caring for; and Dod!I think this is a grand place to be leaving.”

zh: 这句话让我们恢复了一点儿理智。 艾伦跑上楼，然后拿来了我们的鞍包和詹姆斯·莫尔的旅行箱，而我则捡起了卡特里奥娜先前掉在楼梯上的小包。接着我们就动身离开了那座危机重重的房子。这时巴赞一边叫喊一边打着手势拦住了我们的去路。在我们拔剑相斗时他急忙躲到桌子底下去了，但是现在他却勇猛得如狮子一般。原来他是要我们付账。有一张椅子给摔坏了，艾伦就坐在他的餐桌旁边，而詹姆斯·莫尔已经跑了。
en: The word recalled us to some wisdom.Alan ran upstairs and returned with our saddle-bags and James More’s portmanteau; I picked up Catriona’s bundle where she had dropped it on the stair; and we were setting forth out of that dangerous house, when Bazin stopped the way with cries and gesticulations.He had whipped under a table when the swords were drawn, but now he was as bold as a lion.There was his bill to be settled, there was a chair broken, Alan had sat among his dinner things, James More had fled.

zh: “给你，”我叫道，“你自己算算吧。”跟着我扔给他几个路易，因为我觉得没有时间去算账了。
en: “Here,” I cried, “pay yourself,” and flung him down some Lewie d’ors; for I thought it was no time to be accounting.

zh: 他扑向那些钱，我们从他身边经过，跑向前面的开阔地。那座房子的三面都有海员在匆匆忙忙地包抄过来。靠我们更近一点儿的地方，詹姆斯·莫尔挥舞着他的帽子好像在催促他们。在他身后就是风车旋转的风叶，像是一个傻瓜在高高地举着手。
en: He sprang upon that money, and we passed him by, and ran forth into the open.Upon three sides of the house were seamen hasting and closing in; a little nearer to us James More waved his hat as if to hurry them; and right behind him, like some foolish person holding up his hands, were the sails of the windmill turning.

zh: 艾伦只瞥了一眼，然后就躬下身子跑起来。他提的詹姆斯·莫尔的旅行箱很有分量，不过我觉得他宁可丢了性命也不愿意丢掉他复仇的战利品。他这一跑，我也只好跟着他跑，看到那个女孩能紧跟在我身边，让我感到惊奇和狂喜。
en: Alan gave but one glance, and laid himself down to run.He carried a great weight in James More’s portmanteau; but I think he would as soon have lost his life as cast away that booty which was his revenge; and he ran so that I was distressed to follow him, and marvelled and exulted to see the girl bounding at my side.

zh: 我们一出现，他们那一方就抛弃了一切伪装。那些船员大声叫喊，互相招呼着追赶我们。开始我们领先了大约两百码，但是毕竟他们都穿着篷布靴，双腿向外弯曲，在这种行动中就不可能指望比我们灵敏了。我认为他们都有武器，不过在法国的土地上他们不敢使用手枪。当我发觉我们不仅占有领先优势，而且距离还拉开了一些之后，马上就觉得形势没有那么紧张了。总体来说，只要当时的情势持续下去，就会惊险而紧张。敦刻尔克仍然很远，当我们猛然冲上那个小山丘时，才发现山丘另一边有一个连的守军在演习行军，我终于能真正理解艾伦说的话了。
en: As soon as we appeared, they cast off all disguise upon the other side; and the seamen pursued us with shouts and view-hullohs.We had a start of some two hundred yards, and they were but bandy-legged tarpaulins after all, that could not hope to better us at such an exercise.I suppose they were armed, but did not care to use their pistols on French ground.And as soon as I perceived that we not only held our advantage but drew a little away, I began to feel quite easy of the issue.For all which, it was a hot, brisk bit of work, so long as it lasted; Dunkirk was still far off; and when we popped over a knowe, and found a company of the garrison marching on the other side on some manoeuvre, I could very well understand the word that Alan had.

zh: 他立刻停止奔跑，擦拭着额头说：“他们真的很强，那些法国人。”
en: He stopped running at once; and mopping at his brow, “They’re a real bonny folk, the French nation,” says he.

zh: 尾声
en: CONCLUSION

zh: 一安全进入敦刻尔克的城墙内，我们马上就当前的处境举行了一个很有必要的战时会议。我们是通过武力威逼把一位女儿从其父亲身边带走的，任何法官都会要求立刻把她送还给他，而且还极有可能把我和艾伦关进监狱。尽管在帕利泽舰长的信中有对我们有利的证据，但是我和卡特里奥娜都不愿意将其公诸于众。考虑到各个方面，似乎最稳妥的办法就是带这位女孩去巴黎，把她交给她自己的族长，波哈尔狄的麦格雷戈，他会很乐意帮助他这位女亲戚。另一方面，根本就不用急着让詹姆斯在其他人面前丢脸。
en: No sooner were we safe within the walls of Dunkirk than we held a very necessary council-of-war on our position.We had taken a daughter from her father at the sword’s point; any judge would give her back to him at once, and by all likelihood clap me and Alan into jail; and though we had an argument upon our side in Captain Palliser’s letter, neither Catriona nor I were very keen to be using it in public.Upon all accounts it seemed the most prudent to carry the girl to Paris to the hands of her own chieftain, Macgregor of Bohaldie, who would be very willing to help his kinswoman, on the one hand, and not at all anxious to dishonour James upon other.

zh: 只是我们的行程很缓慢，因为卡特里奥娜虽然善于奔跑，但是骑马却不行，自从1745年以后她就很少再登上马鞍了。但我们最终还是在安息日的清早成功抵达了巴黎。随后由艾伦引路，我们赶紧去找波哈尔狄。他的住宅很不错，生活也优裕，因为除了苏格兰基金提供的养老金，他还有个人的收益。他像对自家人一样招呼卡特里奥娜，显得很礼貌，言语谨慎，但不是特别坦诚。我们打听詹姆斯·莫尔的消息。“可怜的詹姆斯！”他说完之后摇摇头笑了，因此我认为他知道的远比告诉我们的多。然后，我们给他看了帕利泽的信，他看了之后脸拉得很长。
en: We made but a slow journey of it up, for Catriona was not so good at the riding as the running, and had scarce sat in the saddle since the ‘Forty-five.But we made it out at last, reached Paris early of a Sabbath morning, and made all speed, under Alan’s guidance, to find Bohaldie.He was finely lodged, and lived in a good style, having a pension on the Scots Fund, as well as private means; greeted Catriona like one of his own house, and seemed altogether very civil and discreet, but not particularly open.We asked of the news of James More.“Poor James!” said he, and shook his head and smiled, so that I thought he knew further than he meant to tell.Then we showed him Palliser’s letter, and he drew a long face at that.

zh: “可怜的詹姆斯！”他又说道，“唉，当然还有人比詹姆斯·莫尔更坏。但是这个家伙真是坏到家了。啧，啧，他肯定完全忘记自己是谁了！这是一封最令人不快的信。 但是，尽管如此，先生们，我还是看不出我们有什么必要公开这封信。家丑不可外扬，我们都是苏格兰人，也都是高地人。”
en: “Poor James!” said he again.“Well, there are worse folk than James More, too.But this is dreadful bad.Tut, tut, he must have forgot himself entirely!This is a most undesirable letter.But, for all that, gentlemen, I cannot see what we would want to make it public for.It’s an ill bird that fouls his own nest, and we are all Scots folk and all Hieland.”

zh: 对此我们都表示赞同，也许艾伦除外。接着更多谈的是关于我们的婚姻大事了，婚事是由波哈尔狄亲自操办的，就好像根本没有詹姆斯·莫尔这个人一样。他非常合乎礼节地把卡特里奥娜交给了新郎，他用法语说的赞美之词也很恰当得体。仪式还没有完全结束，我们酒兴正浓时，他告诉我们詹姆斯就在这座城市里，比我们早几天到这里，他现在生病了，好像快要死了。我觉得从我妻子的脸上我就看出她想要做什么了。
en: Upon this we all agreed, save perhaps Alan; and still more upon the question of our marriage, which Bohaldie took in his own hands, as though there had been no such person as James More, and gave Catriona away with very pretty manners and agreeable compliments in French.It was not till all was over, and our healths drunk, that he told us James was in that city, whither he had preceded us some days, and where he now lay sick, and like to die.I thought I saw by my wife’s face what way her inclination pointed.

zh: “那我们就去看看他吧。”我说。
en: “And let us go see him, then,” said I.

zh: “如果你愿意的话。”卡特里奥娜说。这已经是早些天的事了。
en: “If it is your pleasure,” said Catriona.These were early days.

zh: 他就在这座城市，和他的族长住在同一个居民区，就在拐角处的一所大房子里。苏格兰风笛声引着我们向上爬到了他睡觉的阁楼。看样子他才从波哈尔狄那里借来这套风笛，以便养病时消遣。虽然他的技艺不如他的兄弟罗布，但是他也很擅长演奏那种音乐。真的很奇怪，居然有很多法国人挤在楼梯口，其中有些人还在笑。他倚靠在草垫床上。第一眼看见他，我就看出他已经时日无多。无疑，他会客死异乡了。但是就算这个时候，我发现我都几乎没有耐心去多想他的结局。无疑，波哈尔狄已经让他提前有了心理准备。他好像知道我们已经结婚了，还为此向我们表示了祝贺，并像家长一样给予我们祝福。
en: He was lodged in the same quarter of the city with his chief, in a great house upon a corner; and we were guided up to the garret where he lay by the sound of Highland piping.It seemed he had just borrowed a set of them from Bohaldie to amuse his sickness; though he was no such hand as was his brother Rob, he made good music of the kind; and it was strange to observe the French folk crowding on the stairs, and some of them laughing.He lay propped in a pallet.The first look of him I saw he was upon his last business; and, doubtless, this was a strange place for him to die in.But even now I find I can scarce dwell upon his end with patience.Doubtless, Bohaldie had prepared him; he seemed to know we were married, complimented us on the event, and gave us a benediction like a patriarch.

zh: “从来就没有人理解我，”他说，“我没有多加思索就原谅你们两个人了。”说完之后他又像原来那样满世界地扯开了。他非常开心地用风笛为我们演奏了一两首曲子，而且在我们离开前还向我借了一小笔钱。
en: “I have been never understood,” said he.“I forgive you both without an afterthought;” after which he spoke for all the world in his old manner, was so obliging as to play us a tune or two upon his pipes, and borrowed a small sum before I left.

zh: 我从他的任何行为举止中都看不出哪怕一丝羞愧。不过他倒挺会原谅别人的，他似乎不断地在原谅别人。我觉得每一次我们见面他都原谅了我。大约过了四天，他带着挚爱圣洁的声誉去世了。我气愤得直扯自己的头发。我安葬了他，但是我真不知道该在他的墓碑上写什么，最终我认为最好只刻上他的生卒日期。
en: I could not trace even a hint of shame in any part of his behaviour; but he was great upon forgiveness; it seemed always fresh to him.I think he forgave me every time we met; and when after some four days he passed away in a kind of odour of affectionate sanctity, I could have torn my hair out for exasperation.I had him buried; but what to put upon his tomb was quite beyond me, till at last I considered the date would look best alone.

zh: 我认为打消去莱登的想法更加明智，我们曾在那里作为兄妹出现过，如果以新的角色回去看起来肯定很奇怪。苏格兰很适合我们。在苏格兰，我找回了曾留在那里的一切，之后我们就乘坐一艘低地的船起航了。
en: I thought it wiser to resign all thoughts of Leyden, where we had appeared once as brother and sister, and it would certainly look strange to return in a new character.Scotland would be doing for us; and thither, after I had recovered that which I had left behind, we sailed in a Low Country ship.

zh: 现在，芭芭拉·鲍尔弗小姐（要设定女士优先），还有肖斯的小艾伦·鲍尔弗先生，故事到这里就要讲完了。你们会发现（只要你们好好想一想），这个故事中出现的很多人物，你们都看见过，而且还和他们说过话呢。莱姆基恩斯的艾莉森·黑斯蒂就是那个给你们摇摇篮的少女，只是你们当时太小不记得了，你们长大一点儿后，她还曾带你们去户外到庭院里散步来着。那位非常优雅的贵妇人就是给芭芭拉小姐命名的教母，她正是那位在检察总长大人家里经常愚弄戴维·鲍尔弗的格兰特小姐。我在想你们是否还记得一位戴着假发、穿着大衣，个子瘦小而活泼的绅士，那个在漆黑的深夜来到肖斯大屋，唤醒你们起床，还带你们下楼到餐厅的那个名叫贾米森先生的调皮鬼？或者艾伦是否忘记了他应贾米森先生的要求所做的事——一桩最不忠诚的行径——为此，按照法律条文，他会被绞死——那绝不亚于隔海为国王的健康祝酒。这些都是发生在一个十足的辉格党人家里的怪事。但是贾米森先生是一位有特权的人，甚至都可以放火烧我的谷仓。如今法国的人们只知道他的名字就是斯图尔特骑士。
en: And now, Miss Barbara Balfour (to set the ladies first), and Mr. Alan Balfour younger of Shaws, here is the story brought fairly to an end.A great many of the folk that took a part in it, you will find (if you think well) that you have seen and spoken with.Alison Hastie in Limekilns was the lass that rocked your cradle when you were too small to know of it, and walked abroad with you in the policy when you were bigger.That very fine great lady that is Miss Barbara’s name-mamma is no other than the same Miss Grant that made so much a fool of David Balfour in the house of the Lord Advocate.And I wonder whether you remember a little, lean, lively gentleman in a scratch-wig and a wraprascal, that came to Shaws very late of a dark night, and whom you were awakened out of your beds and brought down to the dining-hall to be presented to, by the name of Mr. Jamieson?Or has Alan forgotten what he did at Mr. Jamieson’s request—a most disloyal act—for which, by the letter of the law, he might be hanged—no less than drinking the king’s health across the water?These were strange doings in a good Whig house!But Mr. Jamieson is a man privileged, and might set fire to my corn-barn; and the name they know him by now in France is the Chevalier Stewart.

zh: 至于说戴维和卡特里奥娜，在今后的岁月里，我会非常仔细地观察，看看你们是否那么大胆居然嘲笑爸爸和妈妈。我们真的并没有我们想象的那样明智，所以平白生出了很多伤感。但是你们长大后就会发现即使是机灵的芭芭拉小姐，即使是勇猛的艾伦先生，也不会比他们的父母聪明很多。因为在我们这个世界上人们的生活就是一件很好笑的事情。他们谈论着哭泣的天使，但是我觉得他们看待问题时肯定更多地还是站在自己的立场上了。有一件事情是我开始讲这个长长的故事时就决定了要去做的，那就是把发生的所有事情都说出来。
en: As for Davie and Catriona, I shall watch you pretty close in the next days, and see if you are so bold as to be laughing at papa and mamma.It is true we were not so wise as we might have been, and made a great deal of sorrow out of nothing; but you will find as you grow up that even the artful Miss Barbara, and even the valiant Mr. Alan, will be not so very much wiser than their parents.For the life of man upon this world of ours is a funny business.They talk of the angels  weeping; but I think they must more often be holding their sides as  they look on; and there was one thing I determined to do when I began  this long story, and that was to tell out everything as it befell.
